PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will advise the House of the reasons for the power failure that occurred last night at about 6.40 p.m. Part of the building was blacked out and the lighting in the Senate chamber was reduced. The power failure was caused by a fault in ACT Electricity and Water Telopea Park zone substation. It was not caused by anything within the Joint House Department's purview. The power was lost to one of the two primary feeders to Parliament House. The emergency generators did not operate, as they only operate when both feeders fail. The power was restored in the building in about a minute, and power was restored to the building by ACT Electricity and Water within five minutes.

—Honourable members might be interested to know that while power was restored in this building within a minute, it was not restored to other parts of Canberra that were blacked out until two or three minutes later.

—The power in this building was cut for about a minute, and about five minutes later ACT Electricity and Water got the power back on to the building. There are a number of primary feeders into the building and we have a facility which enables them to be switched from one part to the other.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Compass Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the overwhelming support of the Australian people for the resumption of Compass Airlines operation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:-
recognise the overwhelming public support for Compass resuming operations;
agree to work with interested parties to facilitate Compass resuming operations;
provide clear guidelines under aviation deregulation to ensure that fair and adequate facilities are made available to all operators and the public immediately.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles (from 70 citizens), Mr Ronald Edwards (from 14 citizens), Ms McHugh (from 14 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Refugees Held at Port Hedland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble undersigned citizens earnestly pray, that because of the uncertain situation existing in Vietnam and Cambodia it could be cruel and unjust to repatriate those presently held in detention in Port Hedland and other places, who are rejected as being "refugees".

PARA.TAB: That they be given the alternate status of "Domestic Temporary Resident" for a period of two years.
That such a status be granted if sponsored by other Australian individuals or groups, with the guarantee of housing these people for the term of their temporary residency.
That those who are granted such a status be allowed to move freely about the Country, accept work and do skills training.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chaney (from 125 citizens) and Dr Charlesworth (from 599 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws attention of the House to the following issues:

1. The Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (A.O.T.C.) is retreating to "core business" when a majority of its Business Units are profitable and providing cost efficient, timely and competitive services.
2. In the current economic situation with extremely high unemployment A.O.T.C. is actively involved in planning further unnecessary job losses through voluntary and involuntary redundancies.
3. A.O.T.C. assets are being auctioned at a time when the markets are at their lowest point for a decade.
4. No real savings or benefits have yet been provided to justify current action being undertaken by A.O.T.C. Senior Management.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to seek answers to the above points from A.O.T.C. Senior Management/Board of Directors.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ronald Edwards (from 532 citizens) and Mr John Scott (from 601 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Hospital, Heidelberg
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the residents of the Menzies electorate draws to the attention of the House the objection of veterans to the transfer of the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital to the State system.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House:-
recognises the right of veterans;

guarantees that the Government will continue its obligation to fulfil its promise to those veterans who fought for this country and ensure that the veteran community approves of all conditions pertaining to the transfer.

PETITION.TITLE: Queen of Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House moves by certain persons to turn Australia into a Republic by the year 2001.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose any move to remove the Queen of Australia as the Head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Mines in Cambodia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the appalling plight of the Cambodian people maimed by land mines as documented in the Report of the Joint Agency Mission to Cambodia (1989) and Report of Asia Watch: Land Mines in Cambodia (1991).
Your petitioners request the House to:
i) urge the Federal Government to ensure that in any aid package allocated to Cambodia, the clearance of land mines be given high priority;

ii) request the United Nations for a review of the Protocols to the UN Convention on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Certain Conventional Weapons which may be deemed to be excessively injurious or to have indiscriminate effects;
iii) call on member nations of the United Nations for a total ban on the manufacture and use of anti-personnel land mines.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodridge Uniting Church Creche and Kindergarten
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland and electors of the Division of Forde—

draws to the attention of the House the possible sale of the Centre known as "Woodridge Uniting Church Creche & Kindergarten" and the adjoining property located at 25 Ewing Road, Woodridge in the State of Queensland and the resultant significant loss of a much needed service offered to the Community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House—
1. Ensure that the Minister prevents any sale from proceeding;

2. Provides necessary resources to ensure the Centre is able to continue providing the Quality services it currently offers. This may necessitate the provision of necessary funds to purchase the land in question.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest objection to any attempt to alter Australia's existing national flag without seeking prior approval from the Australian people by way of referendum.

The Australian National Flag has been the symbol of the Australian nation and of our national unity for over eighty years. Throughout history men and women have expressed their feelings for their country by showing honour and respect for their country's national flag.
This flag must remain our emblem as a tribute to those who laid down their lives for our freedom.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian national flag as a symbol of our national pride and identity.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Hungarian Language Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Right Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The SBS Board has rescheduled the air time for language programmes on SBS Radio 3EA. As a result, the Hungarian Language Programme has been reduced by 25 percent. In addition, the new time slots are allocated to such extreme hours that they render it impossible for the vast majority of the community to enjoy the broadcasts. We do not wish to gain at anybody's expense, but we must highlight the inequity of the proposed schedule.
We call upon the Parliament to address the grievances of the Hungarian Community.
And Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Consumer Goods
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to proposals to introduce a 15% consumption tax on gas, electricity, wood, transport fares and entertainment which will create hardship for pensioners who have to pay this out of their pension. Many may have to do without heating, hot water and cooking.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will not agree to such a tax.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Second Frequency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of N.S.W. and Vic. draws to the attention of the House that the rescheduling of programmes on radio S.B.S. is a divisive measure damaging to a multicultural nation.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House approve a second frequency for radio S.B.S. in order to adequately meet the needs of newly arrived communities without penalising the ageing and minority migrant groups.

La petizione di certi residenti del N.S.W. e Vic. desidera indurre l'attenzione della camera dei deputati sul fatto che la ristrutturazione dei programmi della radio S.B.S. e' un'azione divisoria che danneggia una nazione multiculturale.

I richiedenti percio' desideranno che la camera approvi una seconda frequenza per la radio S.B.S. per poter adeguatamente rispondere alle necessita' delle nuove comunita' senza penalizzare quelle piu' piccole, o quelle che stanno invecchiando.

PETITION.TITLE: Organochlorine Pesticides
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House:
That we understand that the organochlorine pesticides heptachlor and aldrin have been banned or restricted for health and/or environmental concerns in 34 and 41 nations overseas (respectively).
They are still widely used in Australia for termite control under and around buildings and homes.

As effective non-chemical alternatives are becoming available for the control of termites, we fail to see why Australians and their environment should tolerate these toxic, persistent and bioaccumulative pesticides any longer.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House takes immediate steps to ban all uses of the organochlorine pesticides, particularly for urban termite control.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Services and Facilities: Intellectually Disabled People
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: the Petition of the Residents of South Australia
draws to the attention of the House that severely intellectually disabled people are in dire need of appropriate full-time care and accommodation currently not available in the community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will call on the Minister of Health to remove any discrimination against intellectually disabled people by providing comparable services and facilities which are available to all other South Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Deportation: Foreign-Born Wife of an Australian Citizen
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Forrest draws to the attention of the House the situation which exists where the foreign-born wife of an Australian citizen who has, on a visiting relative's visa, accompanied her husband to Australia yet may not assist her husband in his employment voluntarily and payment-free without facing immediate deportation for doing so.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House to insist that the Minister for Immigration intervene on their behalf.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment—Call for Election
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Bendigo draws to the attention of the House the significant level of unemployment in Australia, and its effect on the well being of the community and the Country.
We particularly draw to your attention the increase in the level of unemployment during the past 12 months, which has jumped from 8.1 per cent to 10.6 per cent, and is expected to rise further.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:
Immediately call on the Governor-General to issue the writs for a general election to provide an opportunity for all Australians to decide upon the economic direction of the Nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal Funding of Abortion House at Moonah
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners draw the attention of the House to the following:-
the running costs of the abortion house at Moonah will be underwritten by the Federal Government's continued funding of abortion procedures and related services through Medicare.

Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives to support Mr Webster's Abortion Funding Abolition Bill which is intended to put an end to the Federal Government's continued under-writing of abortion-on-demand in the Australian States.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am pleased to see so many members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure present in the chamber this morning for this important presentation. On behalf of the Committee, I present the report entitled Warehouse to Wharf: Efficiency of the Interface between Sea Ports and Land Transport, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report deals mainly with the movement of containerised cargo through Australia's major ports. It follows over 10 years of widespread criticism of the performance of the waterfront, criticism that has concentrated on the movement of goods across the waterfront but has not considered what happens when they move between the wharf and the warehouse. The performance of the waterfront had to be improved and action to achieve that improvement is under way. However, almost eight years after the extravagances and inefficiencies of the transport chain between the warehouse and the wharf began to be exposed, little has been done to remove them.

PARA.TAB: Responsibility for this failure to act rests squarely on the shoulders of importers, exporters, transport chain participants and their respective industry organisations. The inquiry has revealed an appalling apathy, ignorance and inertia on the part of users of waterfront services. Participants along the chain have each operated within their own discrete worlds, without regard to the impact of their actions on the overall efficiency of the chain. Much of the evidence presented to the Committee had been heard before by either the Webber Committee on shore based shipping costs in 1984 to 1986 or the Inter-State Commission from 1986 to 1989.

One reason for the apathy could be the unawareness of the individual cost components of the services utilised. This arises from the lack of a direct commercial relationship between importers-exporters and the service providers. Alternatively, it may be that, despite all the rhetoric from some industry organisations, individual firms have not seen waterfront costs as a priority. The Australian Shipping Users Group, in its response to a Committee question relating to the ignorance displayed by the importers-exporters community, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a case of ignorance/disinterest as much as a question of priorities. Individual firms do not see the waterfront as a key issue compared with other more pressing problems (maintaining sales, avoiding industrial disputes) and so do not accord it, or its problems, a high priority.

This may also explain why in many firms, people responsible for transport decisions are well down the totem pole. Whilst improved efficiency, reliability and lower transport costs may not be a priority for individual firms, taken collectively they are major issues in helping Australia become more competitive in domestic and international markets.

PARA.TAB: Improvement in the efficiency of the sea-land transport interface has the potential to give a boost to the Australian economy in its early stages of recovery. This would come from a sharp reduction in indirect costs as well as a reduction in direct costs. Recent studies by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, conducted on behalf of the Committee, show that real shore based shipping costs have declined by almost 20 per cent between 1985 and 1991. Most of this improvement related to on-wharf services.

The report recommends improved communication and flexibility within the interface, which should significantly improve Australia's reputation as a reliable trading partner. With this enhanced reliability, Australia's importers and exporters will have the opportunity to take advantage of modern management techniques which are so important to successful international trade. Reliability is the key to improving our trade performance. How to improve that reliability and its relationship to interface operations is the substance of this report.

The report departs from the ritualistic `bashing of the waterfront' to concentrate on the performance of participants in the chain from the warehouse to the wharf. The Committee focused its attention on those participants and those practices which have escaped close scrutiny in the past. The inquiry found a prevalent attitude among participants of blaming each other for the inefficiencies, expense and failings of interface services. It was a case of `it was always someone else's fault'. It is clear that if participants in the chain from the warehouse to wharf started talking to each other rather than about each other, Australia's trade effort would quickly benefit.

During the inquiry the Committee published a discussion paper From Warehouse to Wharf, which canvassed industry response to issues which the Committee had identified as problems. The excellent response to the discussion paper from both service providers and users is an indication of an improving atmosphere for change within the sea-land transport interface. The discussion paper highlighted the need for urgent improvements in the sea-land transport interface.

Major issues identified during the inquiry were: a lack of information on who pays who for what and why; a lack of coordination and planning within the transport chain; the need for attitudinal change among service providers and the users of the transport chain; the need for industry users to become more involved in industry policy decisions and to monitor the level of service which is provided to them; a cumbersome documentary system which needs to be standardised, simplified and streamlined; the requirement to clarify and simplify international financial documentary requirements; the slow introduction of electronic data interchange throughout the transport chain; problems with infrastructure development; and the need to ensure that improvement in interface efficiency is an ongoing process.

Without doubt, the most important change required is attitudinal adjustment. Unless interface participants adopt a positive outlook, many of the recommendations made by the Committee may prove to be ineffective.

The industry had a history of a cost plus approach which had little regard for the ultimate price of services. Current reforms in the stevedoring industry are changing this attitude on the waterfront. This report will help change the attitude along the entire transport chain, from shipside to landside origin or destination.

Other recommendations are aimed at improving coordination and communication between industry participants. There is a severe lack of coordination within the sea-land transport interface. The most common symptom of this has been truck queues outside container terminals. Another serious coordination problem is the mismatch of working hours between warehouses and the waterfront. Warehouses generally operate Monday to Friday, often less than office hours—in some cases considerably less than office hours—while the waterfront can operate 24 hours a day, 365 days per year. Put simply, it is a case of trying to fit a quart into a pint pot. A better match of working hours would provide a more even flow of freight to and from the wharf and a significant improvement in interface efficiency.

To improve interface coordination, the Committee has recommended that interface efficiency councils be established in Australia's major ports. The task of these councils, comprising top level industry representatives, will be to substantially improve coordination among interface participants. Implementation of the interface efficiency council policy and day-to-day activities within the port would be handled by a port liaison officer. Potential savings to Australian business from the introduction of electronic data interchange are substantial. Tradegate Australia Ltd estimates that potential savings are in the vicinity of $200m to $400m per annum.

Consequently, the Committee has recommended that a working party be established to coordinate the introduction of EDI within the transport chain. This working party will include government departments and peak industry bodies. The working party will address issues such as compatibility between EDI systems, interconnection between networks and message standardisation. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation would have the responsibility for reporting the progress of the working party to Parliament in 12 months.

The Committee also has made recommendations which address documentary and money trail issues. The central problem with these areas is that procedures need to be streamlined and simplified. The Committee's recommendations are aimed at achieving this end.

The efficient operation of the interface between seaports and land transport is of critical importance to Australia's international trade. The Federal Government does not have legislative power to make the changes required to improve the efficiency of the interface. State governments have some power through control of ports and land transport. However, the onus of ensuring that the efficiency of the interface improves falls very much on the users of waterfront related services. Employers and employees alike need to consider carefully their responsibilities in creating a more flexible and cooperative export environment.

Given the major improvements in waterfront performance since the inquiry began, it is important to see that the resulting benefits go to making Australian products more competitive overseas. The same goes for interface improvements. Shippers and importers will need to be vigilant to ensure that benefits do not go into the pockets of the shipping companies and port authorities.

Port pricing will be of considerable importance and there will be a temptation to push up the financial return on port assets, in effect to use port authorities as de facto tax gatherers. Ideally, the primary role of port authorities should be to facilitate trade and commerce.

The inquiry has been broad ranging and well supported by States, port authorities, industry and unions, albeit belatedly in some cases. It has been demanding of the time of Committee members. I thank them for their support, especially members of the Subcommittee. Hopefully, the work of the Committee and the contents of the report will lead to improved efficiency of the interface between seaports and land transport. The results will depend on the attitude adopted by the participants along the transport chain between the warehouse and the wharf.

Later this year, the Committee will conduct a seminar on industry and government responses to the report's recommendations, and then it will make a further report to Parliament during the Budget session.

Finally, I thank officers of the Department of Transport and Communications for their cooperation in responding to the Committee's numerous requests for additional information. I thank Mr John Jenkins and Mr Martin Cotton for their professional assistance throughout the inquiry. I especially thank Committee staff members Mr Christopher Paterson, Mr Les Dunn and Mrs June Murphy for their work in the course of this inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow in the footsteps of the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I join him in expressing appreciation for the way in which the team worked together—I appreciated being part of it—including the other members of the Committee and the staff members who played such a vital role in putting together the report.

PARA.TAB: There can be no doubt about the importance of the matters addressed in the report, keeping in mind the problems that we face as a major trading nation dependent upon trade volumes and the free exchange of trade for our prosperity, our living standards and the future job opportunities for our young people. It is appropriate that we concentrate on the tyranny of distance and our international isolation, and therefore the need for efficient transport as an absolutely vital ingredient for maximising our performance abroad.

It is worthy of note that the Orani model estimates that total savings possible to the nation in the transport sector are of the order of $3.2 billion. That is an indication of just how significant this whole area really is. Yet while progress has been made—I do not think anyone could deny that—in terms of waterfront and shipping in this country, a great deal remains to be done.

Despite all the attention paid to the waterfront and shipping in recent years, they are but two links in a long and complex chain. For example, the chain may well start on an isolated Australian farm and end ultimately in a shop in New York. The processes involved in transporting the original product right through to its end form may be many and varied indeed.

As the Chairman has indicated, those processes often involve an incredible amount of inefficiency and lack of coordination. In fact, whatever reforms have been made, it is probably true to say that two-thirds of the job has not yet been adequately tackled and remains to be undertaken. The Committee came to the view that when trade volumes recover the incomplete nature of the reform task will probably become more evident than ever.

As the product of a joint standing committee comprising members of different parties, the report is a good compromise but, nonetheless, a compromise. I think that ought to be kept in mind. It does highlight some very important and appropriate issues. First amongst those, as the Chairman has indicated, is the need for attitudinal change. Australia's major economic problem is probably attitudinal, as the Chairman pointed out. The attitudes that say, `I'm all right Jack', and `You leave me alone and I will leave you alone' are very prevalent in this industry, regardless of what it means for the rest of the country.

There is no doubt that there is a sort of club environment that reigns in the interfacing area. Port authorities, freight forwarders, ship owners and operators, the stevedoring companies with whom they are often linked, the trucking companies, the Customs agents, to a lesser extent AQIS, are all the sort of group which understands the club rules. But, unfortunately, the club rules are not especially concerned with providing the sort of highly efficient transport that we must have if we are to turn Australia's economic performance around. One exporter—and this is recorded in the report on page 54—put it in these terms:

There is a level of ignorance and disinterest. The disinterest is caused by years of frustration of being ripped-off by the shipping industry which is a `club' of ship owners, port authorities, stevedores and agents, all work to protect their patch helped by customs and unions in a six to one fight. How does the importer or exporter win?

SPEECH.PARA: It is, to a very great degree, a national priority that we listen to and respond to the concerns of our exporters for it is they who have the potential to drag this nation out of its economic mire. It is appropriate too for the report to suggest that the Commonwealth should take a lead in facilitating reform. To that end, there is a recommendation for interface efficiency councils, as outlined by the Chairman. I fully concur with the view that the Commonwealth should not shy away from taking such a leadership role. Of course, there are now many instances available to that end in other areas: the National Road Transport Council, the National Rail Freight Corporation, the talk now of a national electricity grid, and the whole education arena have seen solid examples of an attitudinal change that says the Commonwealth must be prepared to take a leadership role.

PARA.TAB: Another area that I think the Chairman appropriately touched on was the introduction of EDI. It seems that this is an area where there is a great need for leadership by the Commonwealth. I understand, in fact, that compatible systems really must be implemented both domestically and internationally, otherwise we may see that a piecemeal take-up of this technology will prove not to increase efficiency and cost reductions but to serve exactly the opposite purpose. Obviously, nobody has any interest in seeing that outcome.

It seems worthy of note too that competition between ports is a potential catalyst of great worth for change, if that competition can be adequately generated by reforms to our inland transport systems. Competition between far-flung ports is not pie in the sky stuff; it can and should be something that we aim for, which could have a tremendously galvanising effect on the performance of these transport linkages that we are talking about.

In addition, two points flow from this, in my view. The first is that internodal operation—or the taking up of more links in the transport chain than is currently common by companies—might well see them better able to put in a better performance because they then might not be competing so much against one another but competing on a wider scale to offer better economies and performance to importers and exporters.

Secondly, within the constraints of labour market provisions—both those that prevail now and those that might prevail later—more flexible, lower cost and more cooperative workplaces should act as great facilitators for better performance. That sort of flexibility is undoubtedly needed. It is needed to address the sort of situation referred to by Mr Bill Bolitho in a recent article in Australian Ships & Ports in which he said:

The waterfront is structured to work round the clock seven days a week, but in general the consignors and consignees of cargo work their facilities Monday to Friday day shift only. The waterfront is therefore forever trying to put a quart into a pint pot and this is a major cause of waterfront cost and inefficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment that is now largely emerging for there to be the capacity for enterprise agreements ought, in a genuinely cooperative way and in a legitimate way, facilitate better the building up of that greater flexibility.

PARA.TAB: I concur with the Chairman's statement that all participants in this chain need to address the need for attitudinal change. This report drags the whole mess out into the open and exposes the festering sores to the sunlight. It is a most useful start. I pay tribute to the Chairman and to the rest of the Committee for their frankness, their openness and the work they have done. I think it has been a very valuable exercise. I am sure that all of them would agree with me when I say that we must not deceive ourselves, or allow anybody else to deceive themselves, that this is anything more than the beginning of what promises to be a long and arduous road.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED KINGDOM AND AUSTRIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the United Kingdom and Austria in July 1991. The delegation was led by Senator Mal Colston and it was my privilege to be the deputy leader. Senators Michael Beahan from Western Australia, Shirley Walters from Tasmania and Olive Zakharov from Victoria, together with the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), made up the delegation membership and it proved to be a most congenial group.

PARA.TAB: Mr Peter Mason, Director of Bills and Papers in the House of Representatives, acted as our secretary. I pay tribute to Mr Mason for all the work he undertook on our behalf. Mr Brian McNamara from the Office of the President of the Senate acted as an adviser to the leader. We were also accompanied by Mrs Dawn Colston, Mrs Jenny Beahan, Mrs Mavis Braithwaite, Dr David Walters and also members of Senator Zakharov's family. The whole party acted with dignity and decorum throughout—a point which should be made for all such delegations.

I would also like to pay tribute to Their Excellencies, Mr Richard Smith, the Australian High Commissioner to London, and Mr John Wilson, the Australian Ambassador to Austria, and senior members of their staff for their unstinting assistance and support; and to Mrs Smith and Mrs Wilson for the hospitality they offered to us, thereby making our time in their respective homes not only enjoyable but also interesting and informative. I thank both ladies for their kindness.

It would be wrong of me not to also mention our grateful thanks to Mr Colin Shepherd, MP, and Dr John Marek, MP, Chairman and Vice-Chairman respectively of the UK branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, as well as other executive members of the branch. We were guests of the United Kingdom branch of the CPA. One would hope that the Australian branch of the CPA will take a much more active role when reciprocal visits to Australia take place from our British sister and brother members of the CPA.

It is difficult to describe just how much the members of the British branch put themselves out to ensure that we enjoyed every aspect of our visit to England and Scotland. The five minutes at my disposal do not allow me to fully state all the thanks required on such an occasion, but I would be remiss if I did not mention the role of Mr and Mrs Peter Cobb and their colleagues from the British CPA secretariat. Their warmth and friendliness was greatly appreciated by the delegation.

Regarding our visit to Austria, thanks must go to Dr Adolf Klausgraber of the Austrian Nationalrat and Ms Lisa Katschinka for the warmth and friendship they extended to us as school interpreters and guides. I would like to thank Mr Jeff Hart from the Australian Embassy in Vienna for his huge efforts in making sure that our visit went well. He went well beyond the call of duty to be of assistance to us. I would also like to thank the Austrian Ambassador to Australia for his superb efforts in arranging our tour of Austria with such a short time for preparation and which has been brought about by organisational problems caused by the political responsibilities of some of our members. Mr Keiran Schneemann from our Parliament was a tower of strength in getting the visit organised in difficult circumstances. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this morning I tabled the Committee's report entitled ASIO and the Archives Act, which is the first report to be presented to the Parliament by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization. The report addresses the question referred to the Committee of how the activities of ASIO are affected by the operations of the Archives Act 1983.

PARA.TAB: The Archives Act first came into operation in 1983 and provides a right of public access to records of the Commonwealth that are more than 30 years old. It is commonly called the 30-year rule. This is subject to the right of the Government to withhold records on grounds of defence and security and a number of other grounds. Decisions to withhold material are appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Government can reinforce its claim for exemption by applying a `conclusive certificate' to the record. The 30-year rule applies and has applied to ASIO and other agencies of the Commonwealth from the proclamation of the Archives Act in 1983. ASIO is exempted from the general requirement of the Archives Act relating to the transfer of the records to the Archives. It retains full control over its records, only releasing material through the Archives in response to specific requests. In the seven years of the operation of the Act, more than 1,600 ASIO files have been wholly or partially released for public access under the provisions of the Act without any security incident.

ASIO and other agencies in the intelligence communities have consistently opposed the application of the 30-year rule to their records. They were supported in this position by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Hope, who recommended in his 1985 report into the Australian intelligence security agencies that ASIO's operational files be excluded from the cover of the Archives Act and released only at the discretion of the Director-General of Security.

The Government did not accept the royal commission's recommendations and, in tabling the report in 1985, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, stated the view of the Government that the provisions of the Archives Act were already adequate to protect the legitimate concerns of the intelligence community, which should continue to be subject to the 30-year rule.

There has continued to be a difference of opinion between the intelligence community and the Government on this matter of the release of records. In each of its annual reports since 1984, ASIO has continued to seek a review of the decision that it should be bound by the 30-year rule. It was in these circumstances that the Committee was asked to undertake the present review, which has effectively been under way since May 1990.

The question for the Committee was whether ASIO's activities have been adversely affected by the operations of the Archives Act. In considering this, we have been concerned with the operations of the Archives Act only to the extent necessary to answer that question, and the report is not a general review of the operations of the Archives Act. ASIO submitted that the 30-year rule was too short and that its records and those of the other intelligence agencies should be embargoed for 50 years. It submitted that a decision to withhold a record from release on security grounds should not be reviewable on appeal to the AAT.

While the Committee shared the concerns of ASIO about certain classes of records, it does not accept the argument that the entire ASIO archives should be closed for the 50-year period. The Committee's general finding is that ASIO records should continue to be subject to the access provisions of the Archives Act and that the open access period in respect of ASIO records should continue to be 30 years from the creation of the record.

The first of ASIO's specific concerns relates to intelligence information supplied by Australia's defence and intelligence partners. The Committee was told that these allies supply and exchange intelligence information which is of crucial importance to Australia's defence and security and that they might terminate or reduce the level and quality of their cooperation unless completely satisfied with the level of protection provided in Australia. The Committee was told that Australia's comparatively liberal document access was a cause of concern to allies and could result in a reduction or downgrading of cooperation.

To ensure the continued flow of high quality intelligence material, the Committee recommends that it should be embargoed as long as it remains under embargo in the nation supplying it. It reinforces this recommendation by proposing that, once the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security has certified that a record is foreign derived, there should be no further appeal to the AAT from a decision not to release it.

Another specific concern of ASIO is the need to protect agents, sources, targets and methods of operation of the organisation. It is difficult to see how an intelligence agency could function if it were not able to guarantee anonymity to its operatives. The Committee recommends that the identity of sources, agents and operatives be guaranteed in guidelines for a period of 30 years from the person's death.

However, the Committee did not accept, and does not accept, an argument of ASIO that it should be able to claim an exemption on behalf of individuals mentioned in ASIO records on broad grounds of privacy unrelated to security. The Committee was satisfied that the privacy rights of individuals were adequately protected under the general provisions of the Archives Act as administered by the Australian Archives. Nor did the Committee accept the submission of ASIO that the right of appeal to the AAT from a refusal to release ASIO records should be abolished. ASIO has proposed that an appeal to the Inspector-General should be substituted.

The Committee makes three recommendations regarding the appeal process. Firstly, it recommends that the Director-General of Security, not the Director-General of Archives, should determine applications for internal review which involve national security records. We have also concluded that there should be a further right of appeal from the Director-General of Security, through the Inspector-General of Intelligence Security, to the Attorney-General. Finally, an appeal to the AAT should lie from the decision of the Attorney-General.

For their part, the clients of the Archives wishing to access ASIO records have expressed deep frustration, both as to the failure of ASIO to comply with requests for access within the statutory 90-day period and as to a perceived failure of the organisation to be cooperative in dealing with its client group. This evidence was strongly in favour of ASIO remaining subject to the 30-year rule and highly critical of the manner in which ASIO has responded to its legal obligations to provide access to its records.

ASIO has been compared unfavourably with other Commonwealth agencies with whom these scholars deal for access to defence and security records. A problem here is that there is no identifiable person at ASIO with whom scholars can meet to negotiate complicated requests for information. Other Commonwealth agencies, such as the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, employ a designated official qualified to negotiate for the Department and to assist clients to formulate their requests. ASIO does not provide scholars with finding aids and indices, as these departments do, with the result that scholars are forced to trawl by making omnibus requests in the hope of turning up information that they want.

ASIO releases records only after they have undergone a painstaking and labour intensive security by clearers who are senior intelligence officers on a routine posting. The records released, as a result of this process, frequently disappoint the expectations of the clients who complain they have been culled to such an extent that the only material released is documents already in the public domain. The Committee believes there is room for improvement in the way ASIO handles requests. The Government must appropriate sufficient resources to enable ASIO to discharge its statutory obligations. There is also a need for a change in ethos on the part of ASIO to a more cooperative approach. We recommend that an archival unit be established within ASIO to consult and negotiate with researchers, particularly those with large requests. Less complicated requests should be fast tracked. The unit needs to be accessible to the public and this means that it needs to be headed by a person who can be known to the public. This would require a change to the ASIO Act which currently requires anonymity of all ASIO personnel other than the Director-General. The unit should also develop indices and finding aids that can be made available to the public without infringing national security and should also devote some resources to preparing records in advance for release as they fall in the open access period.

There have also been expressions of concern that individuals have no right of access to records to ensure that the information about them on ASIO files is accurate. In certain cases the Freedom of Information Act and the Privacy Act provide such rights in relation to current records but not to ASIO, as that legislation does not apply to the intelligence agencies. Such agencies routinely refuse to confirm or deny whether they have individuals under surveillance or hold records on them. The Committee recommends a means, within the 30-year period, whereby a person may bring a complaint or information to the attention of the Inspector-General of Security Intelligence which he in turn would then bring to the attention of any intelligence agency to whom it might be relevant.

The Committee believes that the adoption of its recommendations would ensure that the security interests of the Commonwealth continue to receive proper protection, at the same time ensuring that important national records are preserved for posterity, while providing a right of public access to those records commensurate with the requirements of the national security. We seek the support of the Parliament for their adoption.

Finally, I place on record my thanks to my colleagues on the Committee and to those who contributed to the inquiry, for the time and effort they put in. I am particularly pleased that we have been able to present a unanimous report. I also wish to thank the staff who supported us during the inquiry, Anne Hazelton, Don Nairn, as secretaries, ably supported by Pat Sherman. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization has just said, that it is a unanimous report. It was not easy for honourable members from both sides of the Parliament to reach that status, especially for the members of the Government, given that all four members on the ASIO Committee from the Government belong to the left wing faction. Similarly, it was difficult for me and my colleague Senator Austin Lewis. There was a great deal of compromise undertaken on that Committee.

PARA.TAB: Whilst it has worked harmoniously, there are a number of matters that are beginning to concern me regarding the behaviour of members of that Committee. I quote from a Sydney Morning Herald report of 7 March 1992 by journalist Bernard Lagan. This report dealt with the appointment of the new ASIO Director-General. It was very much along the lines that the new Director-General was from outside the defence intelligence community club and he was, therefore, something of a breath of fresh air. To quote from the article, which particularly concerns me:

A counter-offensive came from some influential ALP backbenchers who became concerned that the minister responsible for ASIO, the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, would depart even further from ALP traditions and promote a long-serving ASIO officer, its deputy director-general, to the top.
The MPs met Mr Duffy this week and he acknowledged the job had been offered to the career intelligence officer, but he had turned it down.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that is unwarranted and improper behaviour by any member of the Committee or anybody associated with members of the Committee.

PARA.TAB: The committee system of the House of Representatives has responsibility to the agencies and other bodies which it seeks to oversee. The committee system is not a medieval Star Chamber, it is not a court, and, importantly, the committee system is not just another outlet for the political party system. Committees work effectively not only when they act within the terms of their charter but also when they earn the respect and confidence of the bodies they are designated to investigate.

The best committees are those which build a reciprocal bond of trust and confidence with the Public Service or other communities they deal with. That is, the best committees are those which balance basic commonsense with their specific mission statement. This requires a degree of political maturity on the part of members of the respective committees. But once this bond is broken and the committee is running an agenda which is not above board and which will serve to betray confidences, you can wave farewell to the parliamentary committee system. Once the agency or organisation the committee seeks to inquire into senses that members of the committee are pursuing objectives beyond their defined terms of reference, whatever credibility the committee system was thought to possess is lost.

In the case of the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization, it is incumbent upon members to appreciate the sensitivities of the Organisation. ASIO is not just another statutory body delivering a service of sorts, it is the nation's key intelligence arm. The Committee has to appreciate this. It requires a little commonsense. This does not require compromising the Committee's objectives in respect of accountability and oversight. Far from it—in fact, it enhances it.

ASIO would be more inclined to take the Committee into its confidences, to talk more openly and freely, and to illuminate more its concerns and activities if it knew its confidences were not going to be betrayed, and if it knew materials, transcripts and second-hand reconstructions of private conversations were not going to be regurgitated around the Parliament and in the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to have to do this, Mr Deputy Speaker, given that this is a bipartisan report by the Committee, but I am amazed at the comments being made by my—

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Dr Bob Woods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill addresses another of the Government's unforeseen consequences. This is a problem which will disadvantage hundreds of pathology patients, particularly those living in rural areas, those in Western Australia, for example, because of a last minute change to the legislation which was rushed through Federal Parliament earlier on in the sessions of the last year.

PARA.TAB: The 1 February changes, which I refer to, do not allow public sector collection centres to become licensed. Collection centres are places where urine and blood samples are collected. At the same time it restricts Medicare rebates for pathology services to tests on samples collected at those centres.

In essence, what it means is that public hospital practices that retain the right to continue their private practices, which are very important in terms of providing these services to a number of rural towns and rural areas in particular, have missed out all round. This means that those patients in those towns will either bear the loss of having no Medicare rebate or be forced to travel many extra kilometres to have their blood or urine samples taken at licensed centres. In rural areas that might mean many extra kilometres of travelling and, since those isolated areas are already disadvantaged, the Government should have been seeking to improve access—not to make it worse.

Sadly, the mess which the Government has allowed to develop means that there are problems not only for the patients there but also for those practices. They retain the right of private practice and some of their income, which makes the hospitals which they service viable, comes from that private practice of pathology services.

There are a number of problems. For example, patients at Warley Bush Nursing Hospital at Cowes on Phillip Island have to travel for half an hour or so to get their specimens taken. The situation is very similar at places like Inverloch and Mirboo North. It also affects some metropolitan areas. Caulfield Medical Centre has already closed two of its collection centres. Patients have to go elsewhere. It is obviously an error, and our information from the Department is that it actually had no plans to introduce this; it was just something which seemed to sort of happen. That statement, of course, is brought into question when one looks at what Senator Tate said when he was rushing the legislation through the Senate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The intent is to restrict eligibility for collection centre licences to the private sector.
That seems firm enough. He goes on to say:
If the public sector is allowed to establish collection centres Medicare benefits will be payable for specimens—
thank goodness, I might add—
collected in those centres. This will result in the public sector being reimbursed for services for which Commonwealth funding is already provided by hospital funding grants.

That is absolutely and basically wrong. The funding grants go nowhere near paying for the costs of running pathology practices. Without the extra financing available from Medicare rebates in the private sector, many of those public hospital practices would not be viable and funding grants would need to be increased significantly. What the Government has done to the right of private practice in the pathology area is a major blow and, although the number of practices involved is not great, it is significant in terms of the impact upon the community.

PARA.TAB: The Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia is rightly indignant that this amendment was never discussed with it or with its representatives on the Pathology Advisory Committee. It is a sad indictment of the supposed detailed research and consultation and it does not bode at all well for the presumptions on which the rest of the pathology restructuring was based. Indeed, it raises some questions about the anticipated savings from those changes.

The Government should have taken immediate action when this was drawn to its attention. It has not, and therefore we are introducing this private member's Bill, which will fix the particular problem. This will enable public hospital based practices to open or to license collection centres so that patients in those towns will be able to get Medicare rebates on their pathology samples. Quite clearly, that is something which is entirely appropriate. Quite clearly, it is something which this Government does not have any mind to address.

I have to say with some sadness that it is very typical of what is happening in terms of the Health Department at present. I think it is very fair to say that morale in the Health Department is at its lowest ebb for many years; and that runs down from the top. My information is that since the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) had that humiliating defeat over his co-payments problem, since he was rolled over that—and honourable members will remember that he said that it was vital to have co-payments and that Medicare was unsustainable without the co-payments—he has basically become disinterested in the health arena. I think that everybody in this House has heard the rumours that he will either move from Health or be moved from Health.

Why on earth he will not correct a glaring error like this when it would be so easy to fix, as we have demonstrated with this piece of legislation, this private member's Bill, is beyond us. Clearly, this disinterest—uninterest, if you like—that he is showing in the health arena is running down through the Department and there is no motivation to fix these sorts of problems, which are disadvantaging many patients in Australia, in particular patients in various rural areas. I commend the Bill to the House.
Bill read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday, in accordance with sessional order 104A.
Debate resumed from 19 December 1991, on motion by Mr Tuckey:
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)calls upon Members and parliamentary leaders to present appropriate speeches to the Parliament during private Members' business and after Question Time;
(3)agrees to form a committee of 4 Members, including the Members for O'Connor and Stirling, to publicise this day and arrange a display in the Great Hall and a social function in the Members Hall;

(4)calls upon the wool industry, manufacturers, retailers, inventors, researchers, State governments, especially State education departments, and local government to give this day appropriate recognition; and
(5)calls on the Government to consider the issue of an appropriate postage stamp if time permits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks of 19 December.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion that I moved and that was seconded by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on 19 December is, of course, a reality today. But I would like to reiterate that the motion nominated 2 April 1992 as National Wool Day; called upon members and parliamentary leaders to present appropriate speeches to the Parliament during private members' business and after Question Time; and called for agreement to form a committee of four members, including the honourable members for O'Connor and Stirling, to publicise this day and arrange displays in the Great Hall and a social function in the Members Hall.

PARA.TAB: It also called upon the wool industry, manufacturers, retailers, inventors, researchers, State governments—especially State education departments—and local government to give this day appropriate recognition, and called upon the Government to consider the issue of an appropriate postage stamp if time permitted.

Today, every one of those resolutions has been achieved, with the exception of the appropriate stamp. That was not the fault of the Government; it was not the fault of Australia Post—the time scale was just too short. But I might add that Australia Post and the Australian Mint have been extremely cooperative, Australia Post in providing us with displays of the stamps of the past that have recognised the wool industry and the Mint in giving us a number of coins for presentation to important people here today—displays associated with the ram's head and the special 50c piece that was put out.

So here we stand, just weeks after the original resolution, having achieved our objectives. The Australian Parliament, furthermore, has achieved it in a highly bipartisan fashion and at no point in time was there disagreement within the committee. In that regard, I would consequently thank the honourable member for Stirling. I would also thank the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) for their contributions.

Everybody has worked together on this, including the parliamentary staff at every level, and everybody has done something positive. We have just witnessed the opening. I thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) for a very positive contribution, and the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), for his efforts. All the way round, this Parliament is demonstrating today what we can do for the nation when we get together. I am delighted; I think it is excellent.

I might add, Mr Deputy Speaker—this may be not of as much concern to you as it is to the Speaker later in the day—that I have promised that, while honourable members keep talking about wool, I will not take a point of order. So that might calm the day down a little. That is the level of my commitment.

We have at this very moment in the national Parliament a fully fledged commercial wool auction going on, and people are bidding good prices. Let us hope that at the end of the day that auction has lifted the price indicator so that people know how things are going.

I would like to mention a number of people who are doing things outside this Parliament. In my State, the Country Women's Association has taken over Forrest Place and is doing a wonderful display. In Duranillin, Woolshed Industries is doing a display, as are the Doonunder people in Bolgart. In the wheat-belt, places like Koorda, with the help of Merle Henny, are getting on with it. I have got to say, if one can bring a little bit of politics into it, that even the Geraldton branch of the Liberal Party is having a special day for wool.

Leaving my State of Western Australia, I mention that the people involved with the tourist attraction called the Big Woolbales at Hamilton in Victoria are doing their bit. The people who took on one of the great tasks down there of actually manufacturing a product from wool, Ultrafine Merino Gold Jumpers and John O'Sullivan, have put on a special display.

Back in my State, other people who are doing their bit are the Storm Boy people, Noel and May Klopper of Boyup Brook just outside my electorate, and Stonehaven Craft Industries at Arthur River. The Wool Foundation in Tambellup has already created a wool bale which will have value added advantages because when one creates scoured wool, the people who are buying that want it in the pack that will least contaminate it. Of course, wool cannot contaminate itself.

So they are some of the people who have been involved in providing goods to us today to put on display. There are other people who will be mentioned as individuals. I want now to mention particular organisations. The CSIRO has been magnificent in its support. The Australian Wool Corporation is the coordinator and the principal financier of what we see in the Great Hall today. I think the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the other speakers from the Committee will all agree that we could not have possibly done it without the help of the people from the AWC. They have risen to the occasion. I am sure they are reaping the rewards for the wool industry.

The fundamental purpose of what we have done today is to focus the Parliament and the mind of its honourable members on the wool industry. We have seen that happen today because I think the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy included in his speech a commitment to a task force. It happens this way, as we well know. I hope that before the day is out we might even have something from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The important thing is that today the Australian Parliament is thinking about wool. The Australian people are thinking about wool. We hit the Today show with publicity and that is good, because the wool industry deserves publicity. There has been a great reaction from the media to the magnificent display and unique auction in the Great Hall. As I said, I am sure that at the end of the day the price indicator will have risen.

The Parliament has done something positive in a period when the negative seems to apply, when everybody is down in the dumps. We are talking about an industry that over the last 25 years has topped our exports on eight occasions. I think it was second on another seven occasions, and it has never been less than fourth in that 25-year period. It is a great industry, full of great people.

In the display today we can see wonderful examples of cottage industry, with people doing things to value add wool, something which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has expressed as being a target which he intends to achieve. People are doing it, not in a big way, not in huge factories, but all around Australia in smaller factories.

Others who have helped us include Boral Cyclone, a very large Australian company, along with Town and Country Hire services here in Canberra, the farmers and others whom I am sure the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) will also mention. These people were only asked once and they came out with all the things we needed to put this particular display together.

I would like to give a special mention to Simon Dickie who undertook the task of designing and orchestrating the display for the Australian Wool Commission. What is more, I understand that he is working without remuneration. Again, that is evidence of how, when asked, people will give wool a hand. They all say yes.

In closing, I make a plea to the Australian people to do their country and themselves a favour. With winter approaching they should buy some good wool products. They are not expensive any more. I am wearing a tie that was provided by the Wool Corporation, but all the others I wear cost me less than $20. Wool doonas are no more expensive than feather doonas, but they will last a lot longer. They are an Australian product and that is why I am asking people to give by buying, and to help themselves in the process.

If everybody bought two pairs of the red socks that I hope we are all wearing today, we would put a huge dent in their stockpile. All we need is for Australians to buy wool, but as a result of today we will see the wool industry publicised around Australia. I thank the Parliament.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—I take it that the leave granted by the House earlier was for the honourable member for O'Connor to speak again to the motion without closing the debate on the motion which he had previously moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I seek leave to speak again.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney). I am delighted to join the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in his initiative. It was a great idea that he had. As is often the case, it was a very simple idea that turned out to be a great idea. I want to compliment him on that. The first time I heard about it, it made sense to me. As he has just expressed, it is a day that has really resulted in some significant events in terms of this Parliament and, we hope, in terms of the industry.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the honourable member for O'Connor struck upon a very good idea because he could see that we needed to have a National Wool Day which supported a very significant industry. I know that the people in the gallery would understand just how important this industry is to Australia. I would like to particularly thank one of the staff members of the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Norm Haywood; Ruth Webber from my staff, who has been working very hard; and Kylie Croxford and Margaret Fisher, who have done exceptionally good work on this.

I would also like to thank my colleagues on the National Wool Day Committee, the honourable member for O'Connor, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), who have done a great job. I would also like to acknowledge the support for this initiative from the Speaker and the President. I thank them for their support of what is a very significant day.

In joining this motion might I say, as Chairman of the Selection Committee, that this is the largest number of speakers we have ever had on a private member's motion. This is indicative of just how important this industry is as far as this Parliament is concerned.

I also acknowledge our friends in the Australian Workers Union and our friends in front of Parliament House who are unemployed shearers. I would like to point out that today we are talking about supporting Australian wool and the Australian wool industry. I would like to think that the Australian wool industry would support Australian shearers and ensure that they are given a fair go and that they are given an opportunity to get jobs.

The people I have dealt with here today, in front of Parliament House, are exceptionally good, hardworking people; and we will have achieved something if today we can ensure that such people are back in full time work in the industry. I think it is a very important and exceptionally significant issue and we must have that happen.

I also thank the following organisations: the Australian Wool Corporation, which has done an exceptionally good job—it has taken the ball and run with it; and the CSIRO, which brings to this exhibition an example of its high level of research and the high skill of its personnel, for which it deserves every credit. I would also thank Simon Dickie, as the honourable member for O'Connor has mentioned.

I would also like to include the management of CSIRO; the Australian Mint, which is supporting the day with its 50c coins stamped with the ram's head; and Australia Post. I particularly thank the parliamentary departments. I think the Joint House Department has done an exceptionally good job and has really gone out of its way. As Gary Van Egmond said to me last night, he has never dealt with people who are so professional, so cooperative, so genuinely supportive of this initiative.

Also, I would like to thank my colleagues in the Parliament, who have gone about this in the right spirit. This is not a partisan day; this is a bipartisan day. It is a special day. I would like to think that all our colleagues and staff of the Parliament will see it in that way.

June Ey and her team from the Joint House Department have been quite outstanding. I thank also the staff at the Parliamentary Book Shop, who have really gone out of their way to put on sale woollen products. My thanks also go to John Brudenall and the team at the Parliamentary Library, and I suggest that people have a look at the exhibition in the Parliamentary Library. There are some remarkable books there that go back 100 years. As the honourable member for O'Connor well remarked, this is an industry with great stature in Australia, and that exhibition shows the quality of the contribution of the industry.

I also thank the following people: tour guides, Barry Jackson and his team; the security officials, who have been very helpful; Melissa Moore and her helpers in the Parliamentary Catering Service, who provided a farmers breakfast today. I do not think the honourable member for O'Connor and I have had time for breakfast today, but there was a breakfast provided in Parliament House if we needed it. I thank the gardeners, who have also assisted. I thank Peter West from the Government Photographic Service, and I remind all members that he will take photographs in the Great Hall today of this great event. I also thank the Serjeant-at-Arms, Phil Bergin, and his staff; and the Usher of the Black Rod, Rob Alison.

I would also thank ACT Ministers Connolly and Wood for their assistance. We needed their approval to conduct an auction because this Parliament is actually covered by ACT law and, in fact, does not have specific laws to deal with the matter. Mr Connolly and Mr Wood were very positive. They responded in the best possible way and said that we did not need to get an auctioneers licence because they considered this a one-off event and the auctioneers were not going to be here on a full time basis.

It is the sensible and cooperative approach of such people that has been remarkable. I think the honourable member for O'Connor has said it very eloquently. We found that, once we got the idea going, it was a question of saying, `Come and join us', and everyone has been trying to do that. The honourable member for O'Connor's electorate, in particular, has in it a remarkable number of people who have shown an interest in the project.

Bindi Bindi is where these sheep broaches come from. It is a fantastic little product that everyone is asking us about. We should have brought more over, in fact. Everyone is asking us for those. But there are badges being given out today and we are finding that there is a whole lot of support in the community for the industry.

A special mention should go to Jim McPherson and Peter Austin, from the Australian Wool Corporation, who really have gone out of their way to make sure this day works. I thank my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa, who has put in a great effort—I can just seem him there over the wool pile—and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, who has been very active and very supportive locally.

I would like to encourage everyone to visit the displays and the activities because today we have not only the auction in the Great Hall and the Press Club luncheon address by Mr Mac Drysdale, but also a seminar being chaired by the great John Landy—in some senses one of those very quintessential Australian institutions in the way that the wool industry is. I would like to think that people would attend that seminar this afternoon at 4.00. There is also a function on this evening. So I think that this is an opportunity for this Parliament to feel very special about a special industry.

The question we have to ask is: where do we go from next year? I would like to think that we have achieved two goals. First, we have given international recognition to this industry. This is where Paddy McGuinness in today's Australian has got it wrong. Quite honestly, it is the most narrow carping nonsense I have read on the subject of what is happening. He says that the aim of the day is only to promote the domestic market. I would like to inform Mr McGuinness that today in Japan it has been declared Wool Day. In Osaka all the buyers have gathered together and declared it Wool Day. The television feed from the Great Hall is in fact going to Tokyo and to London. If that is not international, I do not know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Embassies and trade commissioners.

—Embassies and trade commissioners will be coming along this evening. They are in there in the hall now. The problem for Paddy McGuinness is that he ought to mix in the real world like we do here, and mix with some real people. He would then understand that this is a business going places, backed by us, backed by the Parliament and backed by the Wool Corporation. I would also like to ask him whether he can find any parliament in the world that would seek out an industry and invite it to have a special event in the parliament. Of course he could not, because he exists in that closeted thinking that holds people back. I think it is absolutely barren thinking, quite frankly.

PARA.TAB: For once we have got everyone working together. People out there say to us that they want parliamentarians to get together and work together. We are doing it. So for goodness sake, Mr McGuinness, try to get in tune with us. We are all working together on this and we would ask you to respond to the tempo and talk to your colleagues in the media, who are equally as enthusiastic as we are. That is very important.

So the two things have been evident: international recognition and domestic recognition. We have all gone out of our way to make it a special day and I thank my colleagues. Quite frankly, they have been terrific. We have worked hard at this. We have tried to make sure that everyone is involved on an absolutely bipartisan basis, and it has worked. It has worked properly and no-one could say that we could have achieved any more.

To our friends and visitors to Australia, this is a very important industry. We want you to understand that it is an important industry. We are behind it and the community of Australia is behind it. I conclude by saying that if out of this we can get greater enthusiasm, better prices, more employment for Australians, shearers and other people in the industry, we will have achieved much. Obviously, I am pleased to support this very good motion of the honourable member for O'Connor and I thank all colleagues in the Parliament for their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a document which is the actual catalogue for the wool selling today.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise today to join this very historic debate. I was very privileged to be included on the organising committee for this great occasion.

PARA.TAB: The celebration of National Wool Day in the Parliament of Australia is an unprecedented event, as it is an unprecedented event anywhere in the world. Credit must be given to all political parties, as they have taken a bipartisan approach to the proceedings of this day.

Further acknowledgment, of course, must be paid to the Australian Wool Corporation for the great role it has played and for the support that we have received from the board of the Corporation and, of course, its recently elected chairman, Mac Drysdale.

It would be remiss of me, at this stage, not to acknowledge the merino ram display which is greeting visitors on the front lawns of Parliament House. I guess last night I went to bed worried whether those sprinklers really had been turned off, but the cooperation I received to ensure that they were turned off was appreciated.

My most sincere thanks go to Wally Merriman, from the Merrivale stud at Yass, who has brought rams here today; Mr and Mrs David Milthorpe, who have come all the way from the Riverina with their sheep; and also to Mrs Winston McDonald, who has come from not far out of Canberra to arrange this exhibition today. Further appreciation is extended to the Australian Association of Stud Merino Breeders for its cooperation in this event. Of course, it is the Australian stud merino breeder who is the first link in the great wool chain. Without the genetic improvement of our Australian flock, we could never see such a great product as we have in Australia today. I also acknowledge the fact that we have the President of the Australian Association here in Parliament today, Mr Stewart Beveridge.

Parliament is further honoured today with the presence of Mr Don Vanrenen, who is the President of the Federation of World Merino Breeders.
