The international wool industry owes Mr Vanrenen a debt of great magnitude for his many years of dedication to the trade. I am very pleased to see Mr Vanrenen here today.

The Australian merino has no peer. The Australian merino stud breeder is not only a custodian of the Australian wool industry, but stud master to the world. Australian merino rams are purchased by wool producing countries throughout the world. For over 150 years Australians have had a free ride on the sheep's back. Today, it is the turn of each and every Australian to salute this great pioneering industry. Today, let us reverse the cliche and put the wool fleece on the back of all Australians, and perhaps reverse some of the burdens that it still has to come to grips with in the next couple of years.

In the limited time available to me this morning, I would like to focus the Parliament's attention on the future prospects for the Australian wool industry. However, before contemplating the future, I would like just to touch on the past. The further that we can look back, the greater capacity we have to look ahead. It was in 1797 that the first flock of Spanish merino sheep landed on Australian shores. These sheep became part of the foundation of the Samuel Marsden and Captain John Macarthur flocks. In fact, the strains of the original Macarthur flocks still exist at Camden Park in New South Wales today.

Throughout wool industry history, Australia has been fortunate in attracting men and women of high calibre, skill and dedication. I would like to pay tribute to some of these people. The names that come to mind are people such as Sir William Vines, Sir William Gun, Mr Alf Mandin and Mr David Asimus. All had a major contribution to make to the future of this great industry and the direction it took.

These men made enormous personal contributions and sacrifices to the Australian wool industry. They were leaders with a global perspective, prepared to take the necessary decisions to ensure that the great Australian wool industry remained the undisputed source with the finest wool in the world—not only the finest wool, but the least contaminated wool in the world.

The Australian wool industry stands as an example to other domestic industries of how efficiency and quality can be produced without tariff protection. It is a pity that the foresight attributed to the wool industry was not inherited by the history of our manufacturing industries. Australia produces the finest wool in the world, in one of the world's harshest environments. Wool produced on the world's driest continent on earth is worn by the fashion conscious across the globe.

It is an interesting statistic that the average merino ram produces 33 kilometres of wool per day. If you work out how much it produces in its entire lifetime, which is approximately seven years, it is enough to have a single yarn going from Sydney to London five times over—such are the productive gains that have been made by the Australian merino since they first arrived on Australian shores.

The very progressive nature of the wool industry demands that representatives aspire to bigger and better things. In the course of history, the wool selling methods have been transformed beyond recognition. The wool auction in the Great Hall today really gives honourable members two examples of how wool was sold. There was the traditional method of selling for single lots, and the sale by description method—the traditional method which is used today. No longer is it necessary for the entire wool clip to be inspected prior to sale. Today wool can be sold to buyers across the world by description—the auction in the Great Hall is testimony to that. Such advances pave the way for the possibility of wool sales direct from the farm gate. In such circumstances, the woolgrower would be able to sell to international buyers from the confines of his or her property.

Most of the qualities of the Australian wool clip, including micron, yield, colour, length and strength can be scientifically measured. However, like any quality, naturally occurring product, there are many subjective characteristics that defy measurement. If this were not the case, wool could be produced synthetically. I believe it will always remain the case that there are some unique characteristics to wool, and that it will never ever be produced scientifically or synthetically.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to an analogy between wine and wool. The producer of a fine wine must consider many variable factors in climate, soil configuration, the year, grape varieties and the expertise of the grower. The final product, however, will be determined by including all these factors. A fine wine will come together only with the right ingredient mix. The same can be said for quality merino wool. An accredited wool classer—or indeed, wine taster—cannot assume responsibility for the quality of the end product. Such quality, in the case of wool, is determined at the early stage, taking into consideration breeding, environmental conditions, the expertise of the sheep classer, and other such variable factors.

In order to progress confidently down the path of sale by total description only, I believe the wool industry must take into consideration the genetic make-up of the merino. We have very clear genetic make-ups in our Australian flock today, and one of the many strengths of the Australian merino flock is that relatively few breeders have influenced the genetic make-up of the Australian parent studs. They fall into four groups—Peppin, South Australian, Saxon and Spanish. Some of those studs have not had any outside genetic influence for more than 100 years.

I believe that is an important characteristic that cannot be measured, but should be identified. In recognition of this factor, the industry should accredit the sheep classer, not only the wool classer in the shearing shed, as is the case today. By accrediting the sheep classer, sale by description should include the genetic type of the flock. Like a fine wine, quality merino wool should be able to be sold by reputation—with the expertise of the sheep classer and the wool classer being taken into consideration. I believe that today is a unique day, and I hope there continues in the future to be a day when the Parliament will recognise this great Australian industry. It is world-class by any standard.

Today I would like to signal to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that in the August Budget he should consider offsetting any increase in the woolgrower tax by an increase in the funds needed by the industry to promote wool in 1992-93. Approximately $27m is required to increase promotion in the coming 12 months, and I believe it would be money well spent. I hope that the Government in its August Budget puts its money where its mouth is, and supports this great Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). I think that the initiative of the honourable member for O'Connor in proposing a national wool day during private members' business should be congratulated. I also know how much effort the honourable member for Stirling has put into it. In the end though, unless we address the underlying problems of the industry, it will avail us little—to make ourselves happy for a day, to think we have achieved something significant.

PARA.TAB: The wool industry is, without a doubt, the greatest decentralised industry in Australia. In a sense it is the most important industry: it employs people over a very wide geographical area of the country and is the only industry that provides any employment in certain areas of the country.

I am happy to be talking on this Bill because it gives me an opportunity to talk about a subject dear to my heart—sectoral support for industry. One of the problems we have in Australia is that no government in Australia has ever asked what sort of industry this country needs. If we ask ourselves the question, the answer becomes self-evident. Clearly, we need the great rural industries and the mining industry. But these industries themselves are not enough. We need to be value adding in what we produce and we need to be adding a manufacturing industry to service them. This is a subject which I shall be taking up in greater length at another time.

If we are going to have a wool industry, it must be an industry that benefits the whole of Australia. I am appalled by the short-sighted attitude adopted by some people in the industry who, for reasons best known to themselves—one can only put it down to greed—have decided to supply employment to fly-by-night tourists from New Zealand who are coming over here and undercutting established awards and breaking down conditions in the industry.

I have spoken to pastoralists who are very concerned about this. Some I spoke to in the Hamilton area said that they had never had a more successful shearing than they had last year and they would not countenance using these people, because they saw it as only a short term expedient. They said that the real danger was that, just when they were making big strides towards revamping the award, getting rid of some of the factors in it which were obviously outdated, and there was very good rapport between shearers—the unions—and them as the employers, the progress would all be thrown out of the window for the short term greed of a few individuals. It is sad to see the agro-political bodies that purport to represent farmers encouraging this influx of New Zealand shearers, who are not paying any tax in Australia.

The most vehement criticism I have had in my electorate is from New Zealand shearers who have come to Australia and made a commitment to this great country. They have said, `We have come over here; we have made a commitment. We pay our taxes. Now we are being forced out of work by these people, who are operating quite unfairly'.

I want to address a couple of other things about the wool industry. It will avail us nothing here today if our good words are just so much hot air. There are real problems in the industry. The most pressing problem of all is the wool tax presently saddled upon the wool producers. Figures I have seen indicate

SPEECH.PARA: that, for a pure wool producer with 12,000 sheep, the imposition of every one per cent of wool tax is equivalent to the imposition of 8 per cent of income tax. This is because the wool tax is paid on the gross revenue of that wool producer. It is very onerous and, in my view, it is not necessary.

PARA.TAB: On the present price of wool, given that the Wool Realisation Commission is forced to sell the assets of the old Wool Corporation—assets which should be sold—there is no need for a tax at all to fund the industry. Suppose, however, that a 2 per cent margin is added to the 3 per cent for research and development and for promotion. That percentage is more than adequate and any attempt by the bureaucracy of the wool industry to raise that should be very strongly resisted. The wool industry can service the stockpile on that 5 per cent wool tax very comfortably. I believe we should be taking steps to reduce the wool tax to as little as possible; certainly 5 per cent is a figure that, in my view, would service.

I want to say something about wool promotion. At a recent meeting of woolgrowers in Perth, the American consulate official that deals here with trade matters was asked why the United States, which is potentially the biggest wool consuming area in the world, was not in fact using much wool. He said, `You really can't sell wool suits in America, because people associate them with those rough, wool serge suits that we had during the Korean War as Army uniforms'.

I thought to myself that, given the enormous amount of money that has been spent on wool promotion, this really is an indictment of our efforts. I find it mind-boggling that, after all the money and all the time that has been spent, this is still the case in the United States. Clearly, the United States, with its large per capita income, and a lot of it with a very cool climate, is an area where wool should be doing well. The fact that it is not is something that needs close investigation. I would suggest that just throwing more money at the problem will not solve it, just as I might add on the side that throwing more money at the Aboriginal problem will not solve that either.

People ask me about the future for wool. There is clearly a future. If one looks at the long term price of wool, one sees that the long term trend line of the Wool Board's 22-micron indicator is around 695c. History shows that in any 10-year period wool will cycle through this line 2 1/2 times. People who have been in the wool industry should understand this; the banks that one would hope would be supporting the wool industry should understand this; the Government that is fearful of being left with a stockpile should understand this; and certainly people in the Wool Corporation should understand it. As the price of wool gets higher than that, people will start to move into other fibres, into substitution, the price will come back and that cycle will be repeated. In this country we ought to be looking to support the wool industry in every way we can. We ought to have in place every facility to assist growers to overcome these disabilities. It is my view that this assistance should be in such market mechanisms as futures, contractual pricing—in fact, any mechanism at all that will help to smooth out that path to give a more predictable income to growers. Certainly the mechanisms are there. All we need is the will to enforce them.

I also want to say something about other uses for wool. I was recently at the Kangaroo 92 exercises. One of the complaints coming from reservists who were on service in those exercises was that their uniforms were very hot. I am pleased to say that the Army is looking at this quickly. I am sure the Army will resolve it and will get for our soldiers the best possible uniform. I doubt whether wool will be considered but a wool-cotton mixture, in my view, could be the very best type uniform for tropical climates. I have lived myself in these areas; my electorate takes in a lot of them. I have found wool one of the more comfortable fibres to wear in that environment. I am hoping that we can look at a wool blend in Army uniforms. Certainly I think it should be considered in Australian Army uniforms. If we produce a uniform that is even marginally better than anything else that exists, we open up potential for sales of that material to other people with a similar demand.

Another problem that concerns me is that I have heard speakers today talk about the unique character of the Australian wool industry, yet we do not take any steps to protect ourselves. There should be imposed an immediate ban on the export of all merino genetic material. The arguments put forward against this by DPIE and by people with vested interests are quite spurious. The reality is that the world can produce merino wool equal to the Australian wool except for two characteristics. One is black fibres—the lack of black fibre in Australian wool makes it a very valuable commodity. The other one is the consistency of fibre diameter within fleece. This can vary very widely and Australia, with its genetic fortune, has wool where that variation is limited; we have a much better consistency within the fibre. The only way a foreign country can do it is to genetically manipulate the sheep for 150 years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on coming up with the idea of the National Wool Day. It is especially important in these difficult times for woolgrowers that Australians do not forget pioneers such as George Russell in the Geelong area and other woolgrowers around Australia who built up this remarkable industry. Geelong today is the home of the National Wool Museum and the adjacent Wool Centre right in the heart of the city. The 50,000 paying visitors attracted to the museum each year include some 7,000 tourists from overseas, and that is a testimony to the esteem in which wool is held.

PARA.TAB: Many of these visitors are able to watch Geelong's 30 to 33 wool sales that are held each year, which consume about 10 per cent of the national wool clip. This combination represents to the people of Geelong what the Stockman's Hall of Fame does to the people of Longreach in western Queensland; it is a national monument. The numbers of visitors to the National Wool Museum has steadily held over the past year. In Victoria only Puffing Billy and the Phillip Island penguins have recorded a greater improved performance as measured by the number of visitors that attend them.

It is critical that Australia uses the National Wool Day as a think-tank or a springboard for some ideas for the future of the wool industry. Australia has benefited greatly from world trade and would benefit more if other nations reduced the usage of tariff and non-tariff barriers. This argument has received much attention recently, both in this Parliament and in the seat of Wills. I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last year on the John Laws program, on 14 March, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia is . . . better off without a TCF industry. . .

There has been a remarkable change in the Prime Minister's attitude to the current rhetoric that he indulges in here in this place. The Prime Minister's statement may be a self-fulfilling prophecy because, under Labor, protection has been selectively reduced but costs in some industries that are fed into the TCF sector have not been reduced. The waterfront is a good example. The National Farmers Federation has recently found that exporters and importers are not seeing any cost reductions flowing from the reduction in waterfront manning levels, and this has a flow-on effect to the wool industry, which is a very important exporter of its primary product. Industrial disputes on the waterfront in December 1991 ran at five times the national average so we can see that the so-called reforms on the waterfront are not helping Australia or the wool industry.

PARA.TAB: The wool industry will be still at a comparative disadvantage by the year 2000 under Labor's plans, with high tariffs for the TCF industry. In that sector Australia needs to move away from the idea that we will be a clever country if we merely have long lines of employees sitting at sewing machines, protected from world competition. Under the Fightback reforms there will be an average benefit to farmers of some $8,100 per enterprise but the TCF industries will not be decimated because those which can move with the times and capitalise on advantages such as shorter lead times that give a greater responsiveness to retailers' requests will survive.

I am confident that many of the forward looking textile companies in my electorate—such as Classweave in North Geelong—which service niche markets in Australia can take advantage of the speed with which they can service customers such as the national retailer Target Australia Pty Ltd. Classweave currently pays 45c extra in the dollar on its base level of wages for oncosts, including training guarantee levy, holiday pay, leave loading, sick leave, Workcare and superannuation. These additional costs need to come down; that will help Classweave continue to prosper in the twenty-first century. Fightback will reduce these oncosts as we outline in the program.

An aggressive policy of cost reduction can be a strategy that will benefit all sectors of Australia. The Australian Manufacturing Council recently found that if the economy functioned at the best international levels and if the Government's admittedly incomplete assistance reduction program were continued, output in agriculture would rise by almost one per cent but output in all manufacturing sectors overall, excluding basic non-ferrous metals, would rise by 6.8 per cent. Even greater gains could be expected if protection of the TCF and car industries were further reduced.

As a result of the disastrous reserve price scheme the Australian Wool Realisation Commission now has a debt of some $2.7 billion and is subject to a seven-year repayment schedule. The stockpile, I am pleased to say, has come down to a little over four million bales. The Government clearly has an obligation to woolgrowers, of which I am one—and I declare my interest—to lower the onerous 12 per cent wool tax.

The Opposition was clear in its view about this wool tax in the lead up to that particular piece of legislation. We advocated that it should be less than 10 per cent. We have been vindicated in our position on the figures and the way in which wool has moved back through the open auction system. I am sure that a wool tax of less than 10 per cent is the way to go. Many woolgrowers regard the diminishing prospect of a cash rebate, as put up in the One Nation package, being introduced as an idea of the Keating Government that would simply eat up about $2m in administrative costs, rather than taking a decision to reduce the level of the wool tax.

I thought it might be appropriate to concentrate on some of the technical breakthroughs in Australian wool that the CSIRO is aiding through its Division of Wool Technology. One of its three laboratories is located in Belmont within the electorate of Corangamite. There are 230 people employed there making CSIRO one of Geelong's larger employers. The Division of Wool Technology costs approximately $26m to run, with 60 per cent of its funding coming from the Wool Research Trust Fund administered by the Wool Research and Development Corporation and 40 per cent from the budget allocations.

I am particularly impressed with the way in which CSIRO has developed a fashion consciousness in the industry. Generally, it has endeavoured to focus on the retail consumer. Its actions have spoken louder than some other sections of the wool industry which have at times mouthed rhetoric but have actually been content to criticise buyers and claim that it was the customers rather than the growers who were at fault for all the difficulties in the industry. I note that the head of the CSIRO's Division of Wool Technology, Dr Ken Whiteley, who I am pleased to say spends much of his time in Geelong and is here today at our National Wool Day, has this to say about wool:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the future, fabrics made from a single fibre type will be the exception. . . a wool rich blend can overcome many of the processing and performance disadvantages of pure wool. . .

In that statement, of course, there is a major debate amongst woolgrowers and processors as to the role of wool. I agree with the suggestion that we need to integrate some of our product with other fibres to make it saleable and useable for the fashion industry. I am pleased that the honourable member opposite agrees with that suggestion.

PARA.TAB: The wool industry has to have a single aim—to meet the demands of the customer. I am pleased to see that the demand in France for Australian wool has risen about 110 per cent over the last year, compared with the French appetite for all wools having increased by 60 per cent. Obviously, whilst there are some special factors in the stockpile, it is encouraging to see Australian wool again being in demand in the fickle European market.

Not only has CSIRO introduced sale by sample—an auction method which has saved the woolgrower millions of dollars—it has over the past few years given attention to the processing. The Siroclear optical sensor contaminant detector has been a specialty of the Belmont laboratory. It has proven particularly useful in reducing the incidence of dark fibres in white wool. All woolgrowers would be aware of the terrible impact of black wool in their woolclip on the processors and on the production of high quality garments at the end of the production chain.

I have previously raised in this Parliament the necessity for wool sales to remain in Geelong. There is no rationale for abandoning sales in an internationally known and respected centre of woolgrowing excellence such as Geelong. The sample boxes could be easily exhibited on the show floors adjacent to the wool storage areas, which is a convenience for brokers and gives satisfaction to the growers who attend the wool sales. It needs to be remembered that Geelong is close to Melbourne and, in this instance, it is easier for wool buyers to travel than to cope with the logistics of transporting literally thousands of sample boxes to Melbourne. Whilst the sale by sample method of wool selling remains, there is absolutely no reason to centralise wool selling in Victoria. However, I concede that if electronic sale by description becomes a standard practice without physical samples being part of the process, the location of wool selling will be irrelevant.

The Australian Wool Stock Exchange now has in place a totally integrated national system of share trading, conducted through terminals in each stockbrokers office across Australia. This system has been running for 18 months. I predict that inevitably wool selling will be conducted in this manner with buyers all around the world having the capacity to make screen bids to an Australian auction clearing house.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in supporting the motion before the House today and I would like to congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), for putting forward this motion and for working together so that we can focus, in Parliament, on our biggest export primary industry—the wool industry. I think that we can be very proud of the cooperation that has taken place, from the Speaker and the President of the Senate to our parliamentary attendants—everybody involved in promoting wool today and, in particular, the Wool Corporation, the CSIRO and all of the other individuals who have already been mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Stirling.

PARA.TAB: This indicates that, while politicians are usually seen to be disagreeing with each other, from time to time we can work together on something as fundamentally important as the promotion of our greatest export industry, our primary industry. That is good; I think it is very important.

I was pleased when the honourable member for Stirling mentioned that Landline is today taking footage of the auction in the Great Hall and of the other events and that that footage is being shown in London, in Tokyo and in Osaka. I think that is very important. Of course, it is promotion for our product, for Australian product. It is pleasing that the price of wool is moving and that, after the last two disastrous years, there is a bit more optimism around. Of course, the weather has also been much more pleasing, and I think we can be optimistic about the future.

It is important at this stage, too, to recognise the pioneers of the wool industry—not only people like Sir William Gunn but also the pioneers who go unnoticed, the men and women who over the last 200 years went to isolated areas, settled and raised sheep. Many of them sacrificed a great deal. Many people had their lives shortened. I think we should pause and pay tribute to our pioneers, particularly the pioneers in the wool industry.

Many speakers today have covered wool marketing and blending, which I fully support. However, one thing which is important but which has not been focused on today is blending wool with other fibres like cotton, if there is a market niche there for our product.

What I would like to focus on is a part of the industry that has not had much recognition in this debate, and certainly in the broader debate out in the Great Hall. The wool industry is not just about sheep; it is about people. It is about those men and women who are pastoralists, those people who work so hard to produce this great fleece, the best in the world. It is also about the transport industry. It is also about the shipping industry. And, importantly, Mr Deputy Speaker—and what I want to focus on—it is about shearers. I have great admiration for shearers. It has been said that, if we all bought two pairs of woollen socks, we would reduce the stockpile. I know that you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I do. I see that honourable members at the table have red socks on today, and it is great to have bipartisanship with such a great colour and great Aussie wool.

It is important that we buy Australian products, and that we buy Australian woollen products. I am very proud to be associated with and to support the wool industry in its drive. But the one thing that disappoints me in this regard is that those same people are not promoting the buying of Australian labour. That is the thing that disappoints me, because this industry is about people; and at the present time our shearers are facing one of the greatest challenges of all times. It has come about because there has been an attempt to destroy award conditions in this industry and because we have a large number of New Zealand shearers coming into Australia. I do not necessarily oppose their right to come over here and to sell their labour; what I do oppose is the fact that many of them are coming over here and breaking down award conditions and health and safety conditions. It is not in the interests of pastoralists and it is not in the interests of the National Farmers Federation to allow that to happen, because we do not have a healthy industry unless we have a fair industry.

In the end, what we need is cooperation; we need unity within our industry. I am disappointed that there is not enough focus on the fact that we need to buy Australian labour if we are going to have a fully united wool industry. I challenge the National Farmers Federation to come out and support Australian labour and award conditions. I am a producer, and we producers want a fair price for sugar, a fair price for tomatoes, and a fair price for wool. The least that we can do is to give a fair price for a man's labour. That can be done only through award conditions.

I want to focus on that. The shearers outside have conducted themselves outstandingly during the time that they have been here. They have not disrupted events. In fact, they have a great recognition of the importance for them—and for their sons, if they wish to go into the industry—of a viable and prosperous industry if they want to have a future in it. They are supportive of the National Wool Day today, too. But I think they deserve a fair go, and they are certainly not getting it. I am pleased to see that the Government is taking up some of the points they have already raised. I know they are having meetings today, as they had yesterday, with some of the Ministers.

This is not an attack on New Zealand. I support CER totally and I believe that we need to be able to travel from one side of the Tasman to the other. But I believe it to be important that, if people come to this country to sell their labour, they sell it under award conditions and they stick to award conditions. I challenge the National Farmers Federation to come out and support `buy Australian' labour. All the shearers buy Australian wool and all the workers in this country buy Australian products. Surely to goodness, all the woolgrowers should buy Australian labour first.

In the short time I have left, I would like to mention again the importance of the wool industry—as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said—in helping to decentralise this nation. It has created towns right across this country which have now become cities. It was the first industry that really opened up the land. Once the early pioneers crossed the Blue Mountains, it certainly opened up this great nation.

I am pleased to see in the House the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), who has one of the largest electorates in Australia—an electorate which has the very heart of the wool industry, Longreach, in it. He is also fortunate that he has in it another great town, Barcaldine. It is ironical that the wool industry is the industry that formed our Party, the Labor Party. It is ironical that 100 years ago, under an old gnarled tree at Barcaldine, it was shearers who wanted a fair go—all that the shearers here today want is a fair go, too—and decided to form their own political movement so that they would get a fair go. It is ironical—and I am very proud of that association—that our Party grew out of the wool industry.
The wool industry has done so much for this country: it has been not only our greatest export earner in primary industries but also the catalyst to the formation of our Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the greatest union.

—Of course, as the honourable member for Kennedy says, it also produced the greatest union of all, the Australian Workers Union, which I am very proud to be a member of. I know that many other people in the House are also very proud to be supporters and members of that union.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, the wool industry is not just about sheep; it is about people. That is why today I wanted to focus on the very people who have helped, in more ways than they are often given recognition for, to make it a great industry—that is, the working men and women of this country and in particular the shearers who are covered under both State and Federal awards of the Australian Workers Union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to join this historic debate and I too would like to congratulate both the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on initiating National Wool Day. I think it is a fantastic effort for the whole of Australia, not just for the wool industry. I think all of us should be very proud to join in this debate—on our first ever National Wool Day, 1992.

PARA.TAB: As a fourth generation woolgrower myself, I am particularly proud of it and particularly proud of the wool industry itself. My forebears settled just north of Clare in South Australia in 1841 and built up a very famous property, known as Bungaree. It is famous not only for its wool but also for its sheep; its rams, which have been sold all over Australia and are noted as big, strong, heavy-cutting South Australian merinos. Today my cousins still run that property. That in itself is quite historic: after 150 years, the property is still in the same family.

I happen to now represent one of the great woolgrowing electorates in Australia, the electorate of Wannon. Wannon produces some of the best wool in Australia and Wannon can boast not only the wool capital of Australia but the wool capital of the world in Hamilton. Hamilton is known world-wide as the wool capital of the world. It is a very justly earned title because of the quality of the wool and the number of sheep that are there.

I will come back to that and give some more reasons as to why Hamilton has earned that title but, first of all, I want to talk briefly about the significance of the wool industry, something that has made Australia the great country it is today. If one looks back through our history, one will find references to the wool industry and its significance from the very beginning. Samuel Sidney wrote in his book the Three Colonies of Australia, first published in 1852, that `wool made Australia a solvent nation, and, in the end, a free one'. In other words, it was the wool industry that took us that big step from being a penal colony to being a free nation. More recently, in his 1966 book, On the Sheep's Back, Ronald Anderson wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: If ever an industry, a single product, built a nation, then wool has built Australia.

Very strong words, words that show very clearly just how significant and how important the wool industry is to Australia. But it is not just the importance of the wool industry to Australia that we want to talk about today, it is the way that woolgrowers themselves have continued to contribute to this nation's wealth and the way that the woolgrowers themselves have continued to improve the quality and indeed the quantity of their product.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1687]

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows the sheep numbers in Australia every year since 1901. It shows that since 1901 our sheep numbers have roughly doubled from 71 million to the current number of about 170 million. But it also shows that not only have we more than doubled our sheep numbers but also the productivity has gone up dramatically. If we look at our sheep numbers as a percentage of the world's—say, back in 1911, the earliest date I have for these figures—we find that Australia had 13.6 per cent of the world's sheep but produced 26.5 per cent of the world's wool. In other words, our production was proportionately double our sheep numbers. We find that in the most recent figures I have here, for 1986, that proportion is still the same. In other words, since 1901 the sheep numbers have more than doubled but the production of wool has gone up more than fourfold. That in itself is a remarkable achievement.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it has not always been plain sailing and we have had some very strong debates in this chamber in recent times about some of the current difficulties facing the wool industry, but that is nothing new. The fact is that the industry has survived and prospered. In the 1840s, for example, there was a drought and a world economic depression which led to the collapse of the wool markets in the 1840s. A sheep that had cost $2.25 in those days could not be sold for 5c. It all has a rather familiar ring about it, does it not?

Australia is still a very major wool producer, in fact, the most important exporter. We produce 29 per cent of the world's wool. We produce 41 per cent of the world's apparel wool—that is, the quality wool—but we produce 70 per cent of the world's traded apparel wool. So we dominate the market, have done so for many years and will continue to do so.

When we are talking about wool, sometimes it is important to get back to the basics and see why this natural fibre, this fibre that comes from agricultural sustainable development, if you like—recycled development in many cases and a product that can be recycled—is such a significant fibre. Why has it been the premier fibre for all these years? I will quickly run through some of its qualities and honourable members will see that it is unique and it is in most cases superior, certainly when one puts these qualities collectively together.

Wool insulates against cold—everyone knows that—but it also insulates against heat. It is water repellent; a lot of other fibres are not. It is flame resistant, which is very significant, particularly for young children. It wears longer than most similar fibres. It can absorb water, which means it is healthy to wear. It keeps its shape, which means that it resists wrinkling. Hence wool is very popular in such things as suits. It also holds its colour, so it dyes beautifully when people want to dye various colours into it. It also resists dirt and has low static qualities—another very important quality. When it comes to comfort, it really has no equal. For all of those reasons, wool has been and will continue to be a dominant fibre.

I said that I would like to come back to a couple of points about Hamilton as the wool capital of the world. Before I do, I would just remind the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) that I certainly believe that the shearing industry and those who work as shearers have made a massive contribution to the industry and will continue to do so. From my experience, shearing is one of the most difficult jobs ever undertaken.

He talks about the problems of New Zealand shearers. I suggest that he ought to have a look at what is happening in Australia: in many cases it is Australians who are breaking down award conditions, by doing things that they want to, such as shearing over the weekends. Sure, not all want to shear over the weekends but, if they happen to want to, why should they not be able to do it? That is probably one of the major reasons why the shearing industry will probably lead the way in the breaking down of the rigid, centralised wage fixing system that has been a blight on this nation's horizon for so many years.

Let us look now, in the brief time I have available to me, at why Hamilton is the wool capital of the world. There are a number of very significant factors. First of all, within a radius of 80 kilometres there are nine million sheep. We have consistently seen some of the highest priced wool sold from the Hamilton region and two of the very well-known studs, Sierra Park and Rockbank, have consistently been obtaining record prices. We can boast the world's speed shearing champion, David Ryan. In 1979 he shore 500 merino sheep in 7 1/2 hours—a record that stands unbeaten today and is written up in the Guinness Book of Records.

To look a bit further, in the Hamilton region we have over 20 different breeds. We have 30 per cent of the national wool clip. We have a world famous sheep show there every year, known as the Sheep Vention, which I am very proud to say was opened last year by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

We have some very innovative industries; there is one on display over there in the Great Hall now. Some very innovative woolgrowers, Mr John and Mrs Joan Lyons, using a wool blend, have developed in their JoRo tracksuit a tracksuit that is machine washable and tumble dryable. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to speak in this House today on National Wool Day. I note that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) has already spoken and has a motion on the Notice Paper, at page 4471, almost word for word in the terms of a private member's motion moved by me in June last year seeking a ban on the export of merino genetic material. Whilst he was not prepared to support my motion last year, and in fact members of the coalition opposed it, I am pleased to see that he now appears to agree with me that we must retain our competitive edge by protecting our unique genetic stock. I congratulate him, I must say, for his efforts today and also the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) for supporting me on this issue.

PARA.TAB: There are many hardworking men and women in the wool industry in my electorate of Kennedy whose livelihoods depend on the Australian wool industry. I am sure that they will all appreciate the efforts of this Parliament in focusing attention on the wool industry through National Wool Day.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) should also be commended for this initiative. Hopefully, by a focusing of national attention on the wool industry there will be direct economic benefits to the industry through increased sales and more concerted efforts to value add in our wool production.

As well as being significant to woolgrowers and shearers in my electorate, the wool industry is also significant to all Australians. Obviously, the industry is of great economic importance, as it contributes about 25 per cent of the value of agricultural production. Until recently, wool was our major export commodity. I also hope there will be social benefits as a result of today's initiative.

Some 18 months ago in this House I opened my maiden speech with the following list of names: Bennett, Blackwell, Brown, Forrester, Fothergill, Griffin, Hamilton, D. Murphy, E. Murphy, Prince, Smith-Barry, Taylor and Stuart. These are the names of the 13 strike leaders who were gaoled in May 1891 for their part in the great shearers strike that changed the course of Australian history.

As we all know, the great shearers strike at Barcaldine in my electorate led to the birth of the Australian Labor Party. In my maiden speech I also described my elation when, in May 1990, as the first Labor member for Kennedy for nearly a quarter of a century, I marched at the head of a Labour Day rally in Barcaldine. I also described my sense of history and how I could almost see the striking shearers camped under the shade of the famous Tree of Knowledge, fighting for the principles of unionism and the right to a decent wage.

It greatly disturbs me that while we celebrate National Wool Day in this Parliament Australian shearers are camping out on the lawns of Parliament House, calling attention to their fight for the same basic principles as the shearers at Barcaldine fought for some 101 years ago.

Everyone involved with the wool industry has been through a traumatic period of change. Last year we saw the abolition of the reserve price scheme, and national attention was regularly focused on the woolgrowers, who were burdened with a massive debt. It was recognised by the industry and the Government that as a nation we could not afford to continue with the reserve price scheme.

The Government and my colleagues on the other side of this House acted together to ensure the survival of the wool industry. The abolition of the reserve price scheme virtually had bipartisan support in this House, and the prognosis for woolgrowers has been improving ever since. The prognosis for Australian shearers has not been so good. It is now time for both sides of this House to act together to ensure the survival of the Australian shearing industry.

The Australian Workers Union estimates that over 42 per cent of the Australian woolclip is shorn by New Zealand shearers. Why? Because the New Zealand shearers are prepared to work at below award conditions. Why are they prepared to breach award conditions? I believe that there are three main reasons, and they are all economic.

Firstly, while things have certainly been tough in Australia, they have been catastrophic across the Tasman. Thousands of economic refugees have fled New Zealand since the conservative Bolger Government came to power. The National Party Government in New Zealand introduced a goods and services tax that has had a detrimental effect on hundreds of thousands of New Zealand families. At the same time, it has introduced Dickensian industrial legislation aimed at breaking the unions and devastating the wages and working conditions of New Zealand men and women.

The minimum wage in New Zealand is equivalent to $A4.60 per hour. Employers constantly negotiate down to this level. With the union movement under attack, desperate workers have to accept minimum wages and disastrous working conditions. As a consequence of these radical right wing economic policies, jobless New Zealanders have escaped across the Tasman, where they are prepared to work in below award conditions because they know they would be far worse off in New Zealand.

Secondly, the exchange rate between Australia and New Zealand makes any dollar earned in Australia worth a lot more in New Zealand, which makes it easier for New Zealanders to live on lower than award Australian wages back home. Finally, the New Zealand shearers have been able to take advantage of the closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand. Under this agreement, any New Zealander working in Australia for less than six months, does not pay any tax in Australia. What tax is paid is paid in New Zealand. If New Zealand shearers do not work for the rest of the year in New Zealand, often they can end up paying no tax at all. Those who are here for more than six months, are taxed at the much lower non-resident rate. It is no wonder that economic refugees from New Zealand are flocking to Australia, and it is no wonder that Australian shearers are fed up with such an unfair scenario.

The hard fought award conditions of Australian shearers are in fact being whittled away. Yesterday I visited the shearers camped out on the lawns of Parliament House. I must say that they are a very well-organised professional group. Just as they know how to shear sheep, they also know how to get their message across.

Yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) agreed to review the double tax agreement with New Zealand. The signing of the CER agreement in July 1990 effectively created a one job market across the Tasman, and it is only fair that the tax treatment of individuals in that market should reflect this. Whilst I commend the Treasurer for his commitment to review the double tax agreement in the course of negotiations with his New Zealand counterparts, the fact of the matter is that negotiations at this level do take time; and one thing that Australian shearers are running out of is time, along with money and patience.

Of course, there is a more sinister side to all this which greatly concerns me. I have been contacted by many shearers in my electorate and across Australia on this issue many times over the past 12 months, and I keep hearing that there are certain groups which are actively encouraging New Zealand shearers to come to Australia. It has been put to me that the National Farmers Federation and certain sections of the United Graziers Association are actively seeking out New Zealand shearers. Evan McFarlane, in an interview with a New Zealand paper last year, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There's a big push by the National Farmers Federation to use these New Zealand shearers. If they get enough over here they'll break down the award and get a seven-day week and if they get a seven-day week there won't be a rise in award rates for many years.

That is taken from the New Zealand Herald of 23 November 1991. McFarlane is no extremist. He is a renowned shearer who has won the highly prized Longreach Diamond shearers competition three times. He is highly respected in and out of woolsheds. His fears are backed up by the fact that it makes economic sense for the New Zealand shearers to want to come here, and there will always be some unscrupulous woolgrowers willing to exploit them.

PARA.TAB: The long term consequences of this mutually beneficial arrangement could be devastating for the Australian union movement. It would be a tragic irony if the industry which spawned the great Australian union movement and the Labor Party were destroyed by the indifference of members of this House.

Senator Cook has agreed to look into the matter, and I sincerely hope that we can come up with a rational and sensible plan of action to protect the hard earned award conditions of Australian shearers. Whilst I certainly congratulate all those who have been involved in National Wool Day today and I certainly hope that this is the start of many national wool days, I do say that we must act together to stop the fleecing of Aussie shearers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with all other speakers in this debate on National Wool Day, I am proud to rise in this House and commend both the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on the initiative they have shown in producing the National Wool Day; and I also pay a tribute to all of those people who have made possible the magnificent display currently in the Great Hall.

PARA.TAB: The Wool Council of Australia, the wool selling brokers, the Australian Wool Corporation, the staff of Parliament House and parliamentarians generally have cooperated in a superb way, and it is characteristic of the energy of the honourable member for O'Connor and the organising capacity of the member for Stirling that all of this has come together in such an effective way.

I do not think it is appropriate today to be particularly political or parochial in the comments one wants to make about a national industry on a national day. It is certainly not the day for cheap political point scoring, when the day has really been characterised by bipartisan cooperation. But I do want to refer to the particular pride that I, as the member for Wakefield, have in the Australian wool industry. While I acknowledge that it is an Australia-wide industry, it is appropriate for me, as the member for Wakefield, to put on record the role that my electorate has played in the development of the wool industry in the State of South Australia. While I want to avoid being parochial, I think one would have to acknowledge that South Australia is dotted with the names of famous people who have made a real contribution to Australia's wool industry and to the genetic improvement in this fibre that we all celebrate today.

If one thinks of the names of those people who historically have been involved in the industry in South Australia, one invariably finds the predecessors to the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan)—people such as the Melroses; the Duttons, who established the famous Anlaby stud that is now part of the Mosey family; A.B. Murray, who first established the Mount Crawford stud and then became involved in the Cappeedee stud that continues to this day; and the Hon. Walter Duffield, with his involvement in Koonoona. One also finds, of course, as the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has appropriately acknowledged, the essential role played by the Hawker family in establishing the Bungaree stud right in the centre of the electorate of Wakefield. Parallel to this and also part of that clear development has been the Angus family at Hill River. We would all be aware of the involvement of the Ashby family in a number of family studs—originally the Ashrose stud—and the prominence of Mr Rob Ashby who today is Chairman of the Stud Merino Breeders Association of Australia.

In my comments, I want to refer briefly to the role of the Collinsville stud because the stud has had some unfortunate financial circumstances in recent times which have meant that its role has been somewhat clouded. We need to recognise that, if we are serious about the continuing role that the wool industry will have in generating exports for Australia and in continuing the proud tradition of the merino line, then we have to recognise the work that was done historically in genetic improvement and is continuing to be done in the Collinsville stud. It is producing sheep that are of the Collinsville build and are appropriate for the station country so characteristic of South Australia—that magnificent country out to the east of Collinsville on which their reputations were so built. This morning we have to acknowledge the role of all of those mid-north studs in improving the genetic line of sheep available to Australian breeders.

I think it is useful today to set the Australian sheep, and particularly the merino, industry in an historic perspective. It is worth remembering that 200 years ago there were very few sheep in Australia at all. Today the figure is difficult to estimate, but it is probably 140 million, 160 million. On the First Fleet, there were ducks and geese, and goats and donkeys, some breeds of which, of course, have continued to make a contribution to Australian agriculture, but no single animal has been identified with the economic success of Australia as has the merino. The merino that first came to Australia landed here in 1797 on 26 June when Colonel Gordon's stock at Cape Town was sold up. It is significant to note that it was sold for #4 a head and, because that figure on those particular rams and ewes was seen as being too high, the purchase was split between a Captain Waterhouse and a Captain Kent. An additional #1.10 per head was incurred in the feed and transportation costs from Cape Town to Sydney Cove.

On arrival in Australia, this particular flock was bought by Macarthur. In July 1803 the first of the specimens of wool were sent to the United Kingdom, and I will quote from the book, Top Paddock, where these comments were made about Australia's first wool shipment:

SPEECH.PARA: Lord Hobart, the English secretary of state, received a memorandum on 26 July 1803, that read:

`The specimens of wool that Captain Macarthur has with him have been inspected by the best judges of wool in this kingdom; and they are of the opinion that it possesses a softness superior to many of the wools of Spain; it is certainly equal to the very best obtained from there. The sheep producing this fine wool are of the Spanish kind, sent originally from Holland to the Cape of Good Hope and taken hence to Port Jackson. . . Captain Macarthur has now about 4000 sheep, all the rams being of the Spanish breed. He calculates that they will double themselves every two and a half years; and that in twenty years they will be so increased as to produce as much fine wool as is now imported from Spain at an annual expense of #1 800 000.'

That was the start of what was to be the most significant rural export ever experienced by Australia and probably by any colony. I think it is appropriate that we recognise the key role that wool production has played in the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that from 1977 to 1990 Australia's wool production, thanks to the genetic improvement of its stud, went from 667 million kilograms to 1,100 million kilograms, an increase of 64 per cent. In the same period, 1977 to 1990, the South African clip fell from 106 million kilograms to 99 million kilograms and, surprisingly, the Argentinean clip also fell. It is a credit to our woolgrowers that, in the face of difficult economic times, the Australian wool clip not only has continued to rise but also has continued to make a key contribution to the success of the Australian economy.

Calculations made show that in 1807 the flocks available to Australian sheep producers cut barely 1 1/4lb per head, an eighth of today's average fleece rate. In fact, the average fleece rate for all Australian sheep is currently 4 1/2 kilograms per head and has been increasing for the last four decades. However, the merino fleece on our top rams is four times the average. These figures highlight the potential that the Australian wool industry has to increase its production and to continue to make a key contribution to the revival and recovery of the Australian economy.

The wool industry makes a very useful benchmark for all other segments of the Australian economy. As the honourable member for O'Connor said in the debate this morning, the wool industry offers key value adding. Much of that value adding can be seen in the display accompanying the wool auction that is occurring in the Great Hall today. I have had little difficulty, Mr Deputy Speaker, in embracing the comments made by previous speakers and in paying tribute to Australian merino sheep, to Australian wool, and to the superiority of the Australian wool clip.

It would be inappropriate for me not to conclude with a comment also recognising the real qualities of the people who make the Australian wool industry work. There are people out there who are making it work in the face of very difficult circumstances. There are people in all our rural electorates who are facing real poverty but who are continuing to hang on to what is a proud tradition. They are exercising innovation, integrity and, in fact, a sense of adventure in developing new markets for Australian wool and in offering value added opportunities for Australian wool. I want to pay a tribute to the Australians who have traditionally been associated with the industry and who in 1992 continue to be associated with the industry. They should take a real pride in what has happened in the Great Hall today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to participate in the debate this morning and I commend our colleagues for putting this motion before the Parliament for consideration. I want to say something on a parochial basis, which is not like me—they laughed at the table; I do not like that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to say something on behalf of the wool industry. The sale that is being conducted in the Great Hall at the moment was scheduled for Newcastle, and we are very proud that the sale is being conducted here within Parliament House. We normally have some nine to 10 sales per year in Newcastle. Sales start on a Monday when brokers, usually exporters, price the wool, and on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday they attend the auction.

PARA.TAB: Last night I had the opportunity in the Great Hall to look at some of the fleeces and the items of apparel as they were being prepared for display. I also had the opportunity to talk to some of the woolgrowers from the region of New England which relates very closely to the Hunter region, to the port of Newcastle and to the sales that are conducted in Newcastle. The wool being auctioned at the moment in the Great Hall is actually still in Newcastle. A special catalogue, Newcastle sale 8/40, has been prepared and printed for this historic sale. I did listen to the sale this morning and I had great difficulty in understanding some of the numbers and the speed at which the calls were made—for a moment I almost thought I was in Question Time.

It is great that the sale is taking place in Parliament House and that that focus is being placed upon the performance of our wool industry and, most importantly, that the sale being conducted here is one that was scheduled for Newcastle. There is an expectation that some 20,000 people will see the display today.

Having said that in respect of the sale and the wool that is being marketed here, I do want to join with my colleagues in making some comment about the position of Australian shearers. We all share in the congratulations about the achievement of our wool industry. We all recognise the enormous importance it is to the Australian economy and to the well-being of most Australians. But we do need, I believe, to ensure that those working in the wool industry, particularly the shearers, do get a fair go, in Australian terms. The problem that is occurring at the moment is not a new problem; it is a problem that has been going on for some years. I am satisfied that there are anomalies in the taxation arrangements that allow New Zealand shearers to get the edge over Australian shearers, but I hope that this matter can be sorted out on an equitable basis as quickly as possible.

Last night I had the opportunity to talk to Mr Darrell Carter of Whyworry Park at Uralla. He produces truly fine, superfine, specialty wool. We spoke about the move to withdraw sales from Newcastle and to centralise them in the three centres of Sydney, Melbourne, and I think Fremantle. The problem is that it takes a full day to turn around a load of bales or a container from Yennora to Botany. Yet, working from Newcastle, a truck can go down from Newcastle at least once and often twice in the course of one day. Newcastle is the natural outlet for the New England. Mr Carter and his family, his dad Ray Carter, his wife Robyn, are an excellent example of what much of Australia's manufacturing industry ought to be doing—taking a product, refining it to a high standard of quality, maximising their care and preparation of that product, and maximising their return on the product as a result of their efforts.

That is the kind of policy that needs to be followed by so many other operators in Australia's manufacturing industry. They need to pick up the model that the Carters are using at Uralla and put it to work in their own Australian business. In the New England, growers prefer road transport because it is more convenient for handling—there is no contamination, there is no puncturing of bales by handling equipment and the bales of wool are not left uncovered, as I am told can happen with rail. I congratulate the Carter family on their contribution to the wool industry.

I want to say in conclusion that we are very proud of the sales being conducted in Newcastle and we want to see a continuation of those sales in Newcastle. We do not support the policy of the Australian Wool Corporation to reduce the number of wool selling centres. We want Newcastle retained in that.

I might say that I am wearing today a superfine wool suit made by Rundles Ltd, the leading manufacturer of suits in Australia. It is a very good firm with a top quality range of products. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I should ask the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) whether he got that suit at a discount. There is no doubt that this concept of having a wool day is great. I commend the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and all the others responsible for it. In fact, I was delighted to hear even the honourable member who preceded me, the honourable member for Shortland, talking about some of my constituents. I can tell him that Mr Darrell Carter from Whyworry and a good many others in New England produce some of the best wool in the world. I am delighted to even have a fleece behind me to admire and handle.

PARA.TAB: People would know that the qualities of wool are more than those that are visually observed, they are a matter of handle and feel and colour. It is something that people perhaps have not comprehended that, for all that the industry has been seen by some—including, regrettably, members of the Government—as being yesterday's industry, it is an industry which I believe has as good a future as it had a past. It is an industry which has enormous flexibility. The product itself breathes and for that reason they have not to date been able to produce any synthetic alternative that is anywhere near as good.

But, as the honourable member who preceded me said, the industry really is a product of the men and women who make it. I have been tremendously impressed over the years in which I have been involved at the way in which they have been able to tighten their belts and they have been able to present their own image of a product that they wish to produce, in spite of the exigencies of government and what it does. If National Wool Day does nothing else, what we should be doing is saying thank you to those family farmers who have really made the industry as great as it is.

What worries me, however, is that there are three things that plague the industry at the moment. Although I have not much time, I would like to say that I am most concerned about the price volatility of the auction system. I blame the Government, as I have done on a number of occasions, for the circumstances that led to the elimination of the minimum reserve price scheme. But that having gone, we have to understand that the pipeline now represented by the stockpile—currently held by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission—is one that is being replaced by a stockpile held along the lines of those who are wool dealers.

I am concerned about the industry's prospects, given the world volatility; the collapse in the Nikkei stock index yesterday; the problems in Japan and its economy; the breaking apart of the former Soviet Union into the new Commonwealth of Independent States; the difficulty in obtaining sufficient foreign exchange in countries of eastern Europe; and the real loss that so many of our major wool buyers suffer because of the way in which the Government led them to believe that the minimum reserve price scheme would be maintained, and then pulled the plug and left them to carry the loss. There is no man more responsible than the man who is now the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin).

It is a bit like the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on tariffs. He says one thing today and then another tomorrow. Unfortunately he, and the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, failed to understand that, when somebody speaks as a Prime Minister or a Minister, their words should be capable of being believed. Unfortunately, the wool buyers of the world believed Mr Kerin's word—and how wrong they were. They suffered enormous losses. The Government has not been prepared—although I understand that there is still one matter before the courts on this question—to pick up any part of those losses; yet they were incurred specifically because John Kerin told them that the reduction in price would not occur.

But now, it is the individual woolgrower who is going to be subjected to that wool price volatility. In that climate of price uncertainty and demand uncertainty, really, it is important that every Australian knows that this concept of a wool day is a way by which we can ensure that some of the elements of that volatility will disappear.

There are problems for the individual growers. The seasons are still not good. There seems to be a mood around this place that the drought has gone. I can tell people that it has not. Also, a lot of my growers say that they would like to know exactly what is happening with the money they have invested in the Wool Realisation Commission and in the Australian Wool Corporation. There is no certainty of just where and to what degree the Wool Realisation Commission is going to see funds returned to growers; yet they have made an enormous investment there, and they would like to have a more open analysis of where their funds have gone. I commend the concept, and commend all those who have made that magnificent display in the Great Hall possible, and, above all, I commend to everybody the qualities and properties of that magnificent fibre—the product of the merinos and other sheep that really constitutes Australia's wool flock. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak fairly close to the end of this debate and pay tribute to all those who have been involved in the organisation of the National Wool Day. It has been an extremely successful day and anyone who has moved through the Great Hall, moved around the demonstration shearing, and had a look at some of the exhibits in the Great Hall and at the front of Parliament House, will appreciate that there has been a great atmosphere. This has particularly resulted from the initiative of four members: the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ron Edwards), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), as well as me.

PARA.TAB: The four of us were able to get it together. I guess, if we had looked for a promotional organisation, there might not have been quite as much moving from crisis to crisis today—which seemed that way to us a bit; although I know many people have said how smoothly it has gone—but it may have cost $20,000 or $30,000 to do the work that the offices of the four members have done.

I pay tribute particularly to Norm Haywood from the office of the honourable member for O'Connor and to Ruth Webber from the office of the honourable member for Stirling for the outstanding extracurricular work that they have done in the organisation of this. Four members from the four parties represented in this House have been able to get together on promoting one of Australia's most important export industries.

We have had a lot of cooperation from other people and groups as well, notably the Australian Wool Corporation. I believe that the effort put in by the Corporation has been of great benefit and, together with the effort put in by the people conducting the auction, it has been a great success.

We have had support from people, such as Gordon Allen of the ACT Lessees Association, who have supplied sheep. In the Australian Capital Territory farmers do not own their properties. They lease them from government. Even after years of operation, they can be put off their farms with only two or three months notice. That is not a particularly good way to operate a business, but that is how they have been doing it. Honourable members should note that this area had sheep a long time before it had parliamentarians.

We also had a lot of support from Tralee, which has a great combination of tourism and wool production. Today, eight coach loads of people are going out to Tralee to have a look at the demonstrations that are put on there, and Tralee has also put in a great effort here. The Australian Workers Union has contributed today with shearing demonstrations. Milton Charnock has brought in his sheep to shear. He gives a very effective demonstration not only of ordinary shearing but also of blade shearing.

One of the great things about today is that we are linking education, tourism and the important wool industry. I have had support in my local area from Neville Gorman and Claire Smith of Bombala and Cuppacumbalong. They have contributed woollen garments and other garments that have been shown. Students have come from all over the place. Thousands of people have come from all over the place. People from all over the world have come here today. They have been able to look at our wool industry as a result of the excellent work that has been done by the wide range of organisations I have met.

The organisation Jumbuck, which produced the mini-jumbuck which is shown here, has also put in quite a bit of money and effort today. Great work has been done by all these organisations. I pay particular tribute to the people who came here to buy wool, the people who came here to see, the people from textile classes, the people from throughout Australia who have made the effort to come here today.

It was not so very long ago that there was some scepticism amongst officials and the wool industry itself about the prospects for wool. It has done a little bit better than we expected, although perhaps not as well as we hoped. There is still quite a way to go. It was said only a few years ago that research and development may offer the chance to obtain an immediate lift in demand in wool. It may not be sufficiently rapid to respond to the short term imbalance in supply and demand, but with effort it can happen. Today we have made a tremendous effort. Today we have done our level best across all parties to make sure that it will happen. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it is a perfect delight to see a mini-jumbuck from my electorate sitting on the dispatch box. I hope it stays there for many a day. All sorts of things can happen in the days leading up to Wool Day. In recent days I have been called a squatter by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in this House and other places. I do not find that a term of derision, but the Treasurer obviously does or he would not have used it. I have to say that he should be careful because his grandfather was a squatter, and one can only conclude that he would sell not only his grandmother for a song, as the saying goes, but his grandfather as well.

PARA.TAB: A number of things need to be said on this day about this great wool industry of ours, an industry that will be successful for many years to come. Firstly, I would like to proffer the observation that there will never be another reserve price scheme in the Australian wool industry. I do not think there is much point in wasting valuable time in discussing it.

Whilst I was very much in favour of the conservative scheme as it was run in the early days, the facts are that in the future no-one will finance it. No bank will finance it, no government will underwrite that bank finance, and the growers will not finance it—and neither should they really, because they are still owed about $2 billion from the last scheme.

We are, of course, to replace that scheme. We are starting to see a rise in the use of the futures market, a market that was started many years ago in London, was taken over by Sydney, and then met its demise as the reserve price scheme started to take the fluctuations out of the market. But we are now starting to see a rise in the use of the futures market again as people realise that large fluctuations in the market are now, again, a fact of life. Those fluctuations will get greater, but they will not necessarily be bad. They will give rise to the greater use not only of futures but also of agreed forward contracts, direct selling, the rise of a market in options and the use in this industry of financial instruments, some of which have not even yet been devised.

It may well be that, when we have sold the wool stockpile in a few years—a lesser number of years than I would suggest that the Government has in mind—there will actually be a cash surplus left over and above the money that was borrowed from outside lenders, contrary to the original belief and the belief of many. If that be the case, then some of that cash surplus could be used to repay the $1.7 billion or perhaps $2 billion that is owed to the growers that I mentioned before. My own view is that the way to do that would be to pay the money out at so much in the dollar, with some minor adjustments made for the interest factor, depending on whether people's contributions came in in 1987, 1989 or later.

Finally, there are, I would like to suggest, some dark moves afoot to pump some millions of dollars of taxpayers' money into various wool processing companies on the basis that the Government will be seen to be helping value add in this country. We have heard that it is, or was, the Government's intention to pump in amounts of as much as $25m to help to provide capital for a German wool combing company to start up in this country. I have heard that it may pump some more money into a company in my electorate. People tell me that in Queensland people are anticipating some more capital; taxpayers' money will go in there. It is an outrageous proposition that some companies, especially foreign companies, should be singled out for capital benefit to the exclusion of small or older players in this matter. It amounts to picking winners within an industry in the worst possible way, to the exclusion of those who compete thereafter and have been competing prior to those days.

More importantly, if this subsidised industry, wool processing, turns out to be less efficient than the processing elsewhere in the world, the eventual result will finally bear down on Australian wool prices. In other words, this false subsidisation could have quite the opposite effect to that originally planned and could have a deleterious result. I hope that is not the case. I hope that the market will be allowed to continue to work and the TCFDA will use the funds it has for innovation and forward looking arrangements. Finally, I would like to say that I wish that this industry will continue in the way that it was going only a few years ago. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am pleased to be able to join with others today in recognising National Wool Day in this place. I first offer my appreciation and congratulations to both the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) for what they have done in recognising this day. I had the opportunity earlier today to visit the displays in the Parliament and it was quite an interesting experience. I think someone mentioned before that listening to the auctioneers is, from time to time, somewhat like Question Time.

PARA.TAB: This particular week has been an important week for our Parliament. Often I think the theatre of Question Time overtakes some of the more important debates in this place.
