I think this week in this place we have had three important debates where there has been very much a bipartisan attitude. I refer particularly to the statement by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) on the Government's response to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Also, yesterday, we heard a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Cambodia, and we heard bipartisan speeches in relation to that. The debate today also reflects very much a bipartisan attitude in this Parliament. I think it is really encouraging to see that when we really want to we can all work together in the greater interest of this great country of ours.

When we talk about the interest in this great country, we cannot talk about Australia as a great country without talking about the wool industry. All who have been associated with the wool industry—for a lot longer than I have been around here—refer to it as probably the most important industry to our country. They know what it has done for us over many years. But I do not think there is an honourable member in this place who does not have some association with the wool industry, whether it be those members who have graziers in their electorates or those of us who have woollen mills and wool scouring plants in our electorates. When it comes down to city electorates, there are probably people with the stores that sell the wool. There are no honourable members in this place who can say that they do not have an association with the industry in some way.

Of course, a lot of people work in that industry and I would like also to associate my comments with those of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), who spoke earlier about the plight of the shearers. I am very pleased to acknowledge here today the great history that the shearers have with my Party, the Australian Labor Party. Last year I took the opportunity during the centenary of the Australian Labor Party to visit parts of the Kennedy electorate, particularly around Barcaldine and Longreach—which is well-known as an historical place for the labour movement. Interestingly enough, my father grew up in that part of the world, and was actually born in a town called Muttaburra. I understand there are a lot of New Zealanders living there now. Of course, my family had a long association in that part of the world, my grandfather having worked on many sheep stations, also my dad until the time of the war. So everyone has some association with the industry.

Also, there has been a lot of mention here today about value adding. I understand that only about 10 per cent of wool is actually value added in Australia. That is something that needs to be addressed in a big way. I mentioned earlier woollen mills in the city of Ipswich, in my electorate of Oxley. Woollen mills formed a very important industry there once, but now there are none left, unfortunately. That is something we really should look at. We did have a wool scouring plant operating there not so long ago, but due to some environmental problems it closed. But it is still there and so are the people who owned it, and there are still attempts being made to get that plant going again. We are talking about employing some 50 or 60 people in those sorts of plants, and that is a very important point in job creation.

With the wool industry, I think we are fortunate in having an industry which, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) referred to before, whilst it has had a great past, also should have a great future. I am sure it has when we see those displays in this place here today. Our friends from the National Party with their displays today are quite something, and I also acknowledge them for bringing to the attention of the House the quality of the products that wool can produce for us. Earlier, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) went right through the great qualities of wool as a product. Those remarks are quite important in showing just how good wool is, and what it can provide for us as one of our most important industries. Once again, I would like to congratulate all those associated with this National Wool Day today, particularly the honourable members for O'Connor and Stirling in the activities here today. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Riverina-Darling, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I stand today in the House to speak on the wool industry. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and his tireless staffer, Norm Haywood, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and his staff, Ruth and Margaret, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), on organising this day today. As I said, it is a great pleasure to speak on the wool industry as the member for Riverina-Darling. We all know the Riverina region of New South Wales is extremely famous for its great wool production, and for the great wool studs that are there. I know it is a bit dangerous to mention some, but Uardry comes to mind, also Wanganella, Pooginook and Goolgumbla. There are many more which I would like to mention but time does not permit.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the wool industry and at my part of the world, Riverina-Darling, we find that the very ethos, the historical essence of Australia, comes from those areas. There were people like Father Hartigan who, under the nom de plume, John O'Brien, wrote Around the Boree Log, Lawson and Banjo Paterson—many poets worked in those areas. Many of their poems which inspire many Australians were initiated in that part of the world.

I could speak a lot about the Riverina, but most people already know a great deal about that region. The Riverina plains are perhaps the best sheep country not only in Australia but in the world. So I pay tribute to that area and to the people in that area who are so important to the wool industry. One of the areas I would like to talk about today is the western division of New South Wales, which also produces a great deal of wool. Of course, the western division is a unique area. It extends down from the dog-proof fence in the north. Those people who have seen the dog-proof fence would know what a tremendous structure it is and what an important job it does in keeping wild dogs and dingoes out of that sheep producing area of the north. Anyone who has seen sheep that have been savaged by dingoes would know just how important that fence is.

The main centres of the western division are Broken Hill and Tibooburra, White Cliffs, Wilcannia, Menindee, Cobar, Tilpa, Hillston, Ivanhoe, Pooncarie, Hay, Balranald, Nymagee, Mount Hope, Lake Cargelligo, Hatfield, Oxley and others. While they may have a romantic air about their names, they all have people who lead fairly difficult and hard lives. In fact, we know that at the moment much of that area is in the grip of drought. For example, in phoning around to find out exactly what the position was, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) found out that in some areas wool carrying capacity is down by over half. In fact, one property has only about 2 per cent of its sheep left on it. That is why I think it is very important that this industry that has done so much for the welfare of the people of Australia be looked after in its time of need. What we really do need to look at in those areas is making sure that when those people can restock when the drought is over those survive—and I hope that all of them do survive—and that the Federal Government provides some low interest loans. They are facing a very difficult period.

The western division contains over 1,500 properties. The average size of the property towards Walgett is about 4,000 hectares. Walgett is in the electorate of Parkes. As we come towards Tibooburra, there may be properties of 40,000 hectares carrying 5,000 sheep. The area is semi-arid: the rainfall is about nine inches per year. I believe that in most of Australia farming involves the management of drought. I would say that nearly 80 per cent of Australia is covered by that semi-arid area, so we must ensure that that area is productive and that we can maintain our people on it to produce wealth for Australia. The value of the western wool clip is about $315m, so we can see how important that is to our overseas earnings.

Most of the people out in that area are great Australian characters. They work hard and they live in harsh conditions. I would like today to pay a tribute to those women who work in those western areas—the wives, the daughters, those who are related to the people there trying to do something to produce wool for Australia. Those women of that western area have always been great stalwarts, great pioneers of Australia and great citizens of Australia. Finally, the wool industry has carried Australia for many years and I believe that it will continue to do so, provided we give it those initiatives and give it that framework to allow it to continue in its very important work. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate those who in their inventive way put together the idea of having this day. I really think that it has been very worthwhile and that it has been good for the House to concentrate on this. Those of us who have urban electorates, of course, are in our way as well aware of the importance of the wool industry as everybody else, particularly those who represent rural electorates. For myself, I have a very fine wool suit on today which was made by Di Fabio Bros of Adelaide, who are the nation's leading tailors. They certainly provide an excellent example of the sort of fine product that can be produced by wool. I think that all of us in this nation have respect for the way that this industry has done so much for the nation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the declining state of our nation. I want to talk about what we should be doing, particularly by way of the use of technology and innovation, to change its unhappy state.

PARA.TAB: I grieve for the years of missed opportunity under this Government. I grieve for the 35 per cent youth unemployment level in my electorate of Aston. I grieve for the 572 per cent increase in unemployment in my electorate under this Government. I grieve for the 70 per cent increase in bankruptcies in businesses in my electorate. I grieve for the State of Victoria, where under Federal and State Labor governments we are now generally acknowledged to be an economic basket case. I grieve for Australia, its massive debt and its true unemployment levels, which are reported today to be probably around the 17 per cent mark. I grieve for the state of this place, where this Government has recently made a mockery of procedures. I grieve, above all, for the fact that we are going to hand to our children and our grandchildren a lower standard of living than that which we inherited.

One of my staff is moving house this weekend. It is interesting that, in clearing out her old house, she dug out an old newspaper, yellow with age, dated 7 March 1983—two days after the election which brought this Government to power. I was actually an unsuccessful candidate on that day. This paper has headlines such as `Hawke Landslide', `Massive Mandate to Revive Economy', `A Guide to Labor Main Electoral Promises' and so on and so forth.

I would like to examine something of the record of this Government since it came to power, nearly nine years ago. We are in the middle of the worst recession in 60 years; we have had crippling interest rates for the last two or three years; we have had divisiveness; and currently the Government is running a whole range of diversions to try to distract our attention from the core economic problems of this country. We have had social engineering in education and we have developed a welfare dependency mentality. I grieve for the lost years and the lost opportunities.
Let us look, very quickly, at the record of what this Government has done. The current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in his former role as Treasurer, said in the 1983 Budget Speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the economic policies of the previous—
that is, Fraser—
Government had failed to come to terms with Australia's deep-seated problems.
Our foreign debt stood at $23 billion. In 1984 he said:
The Government's policies are on track.
The foreign debt stood at $28 billion. In 1985 he said:
. . . a strategy that builds upon our very significant successes . . .
The foreign debt had risen to $51 billion. In 1986 he said:
. . . rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.
The foreign debt had spiralled to $75 billion. In 1987 he said:
. . . our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
The foreign debt had climbed to $82 billion. In 1988—this is the one we are all familiar with—having said of the Budget, `This is the one that brings home the bacon', he stated:
Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
Our foreign debt had actually increased to $92.8 billion. In 1989 he said:
. . . Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession . . .
The foreign debt had passed the $100 billion mark. In 1990 he said:

. . . inflation will fall . . . the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up . . . delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
Foreign debt had risen to $124 billion. After the recent One Nation statement, we now learn that foreign debt has reached the dizzy heights of $145 billion. The record speaks for itself.

PARA.TAB: Today, rather than just look back, I want to try to give one or two constructive thoughts about the future and the sorts of things that I think we need to do to trade our way out of this disastrous situation. Some members of this House would be aware of the faith and commitment that I, personally, consistently apply in terms of looking at the application of innovation and technology to all the areas of business and commerce, and the good that I think it can do our economy.

The Fightback proposals that the coalition launched late last year, of course, spell out the economic and structural environment that a coalition government will bring to this country. I want to emphasise that we can supplement that by working to world's best standards in the way that we run our business and our industry. We have to work smarter; and it is not just a question of inventing one or two clever ideas that will suddenly be the salvation of the country. That is not what is going to do it. What we have to do is to apply working smarter technology and innovation to every aspect of the commercial life of this country.

We have a good history of coming up with some clever ideas: the research people push them out for the business world and nobody wants to invest and pick them up. Then we have that subsequent disappointment because we do not pick up those bright ideas. Business and industry and the management in those areas have to start to say, `When we have a problem, we turn to our research areas, we say what the problem is and we ask them to come up with some solution. We are in an economic war and we have to go to our boffins and our clever people to come up with solutions to our problems. We have to pull those from our research communities'. When that happens, management is much more likely to apply those new ideas and to implement them to help the country.

There are, of course, a number of key elements that we need to achieve this. There are some fundamentals that I just want to talk about briefly. I want to make very quick reference to three. First of all, we should be talking about structures and not products. We should not concentrate on providing mechanisms for supporting, from taxpayers' money, specific products or processes, individual industries or companies; it should not be about supporting bounties, tariffs, grants or tax concessions and so on.

What we should be doing is concentrating on creating a climate for across the board innovation so that anyone can get into the market and compete. Some enterprises will, of course, succeed; some will fail. But the successful ones will be built on a sound commercial basis and will have the incentive to make good ideas work.

It is important, when considering the likely impact of individual policies and legislation, to recognise the desirability of building on our existing strengths. Australia already has some established leading edge science and technology activities, and in these and other areas of development it is appropriate to encourage clusters of excellence and mutual dependence, wherever practicable.

We need to beef up our education and skills. There is a shortage of trained people in the science and technology fields and we have an urgent need to introduce into the education system a bias towards productive studies. We have five arts graduates for every one science or engineering graduate. That is an imbalance that the country should not sustain. We need to turn that around. We are also losing existing skilled people overseas because of poor pay and poor conditions, but above all due to the uncertainty of the funding of projects, which are often on a year to year basis. There is also, of course, an urgent need to establish this country throughout the Asia-Pacific region as a skills haven.

The third point I want to make is that we must adopt much more of an international perspective. We should encourage the development of knowledge partnerships between Australian and overseas institutions and companies. The formation of international relationships and joint ventures for capital, knowledge acquisition and access to overseas marketing and distribution channels is critical to the successful application of technology in commercial environments, and the Government must ensure that regulatory and other obstacles to such relationships are eliminated.

As I come towards the end of my time, I grieve for my children and my grandchildren for what they are about to inherit as a result of this Government's activity and for all the other children in this country. We have a country that has the climate, the resources, the basic political stability, and the trained and skilled people in many areas to be a very successful country in this world. Yet what we have seen from the ALP Government over the last few years are wasted years—years of debt and decline.

Under the coalition's Fightback package we have the taxation and structural reform ideas that we need. But we also need to encourage a sea change in attitude towards the application of innovation and technology. With lower business costs, freer markets, revolutionised industrial agreements and the take-up of innovation, we can achieve world best standards, we can compete and we can reverse the present trend. We need not hand a lower standard of living to our children and grandchildren after all. But time is short; we need to change. Innovation and technology can be harnessed to the other Fightback measures to offer all Australians hope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout its long history, Turkey has been a home and refuge to many different racial groups who have prospered and created great civilisations on this ancient land. Modern Turkey is a free and democratic nation. Turkey is a member of NATO and an important ally. Above all, Turkey is a constitutional democracy which protects the rights of its citizens, irrespective of race, religion and sex. Turkey is a nation which has earned and enjoys the respect of the world community.

PARA.TAB: There are vast numbers of Turkish citizens of Kurdish ethnic background living in Turkey. Many of these people of Kurdish descent reside in the big cities of Turkey and they make a substantial and worthwhile contribution to the economic, social and political life of the nation.

Two weeks ago violence erupted in various parts of Turkey, particularly in the border district of Sirnak where heavily armed terrorists launched a violent attack involving innocent people who were celebrating the religious festival of Nevrouz. These terrorists belong to the Kurdish Workers Party, otherwise known as the PKK. About 1,500 PKK terrorists infiltrated the populace of the town and on the day of the festivities forced hundreds of people, and in particular women and children, at gunpoint into demonstrations and attempted to use them as a human shield. The terrorists even tried to occupy the Governor's office, hang the Governor and hold the building. During the ensuing fight against the police and security forces, the PKK terrorists used rockets, mortars and machine-guns. At least 45 people, particularly from the security forces, lost their lives during these clashes that occurred in Turkey at this time. It was a calculated and premeditated attack on the state of Turkey.

It is important to make the distinction between the tragedy of the Kurds in northern Iraq and the events which occurred in Turkey just two weeks ago. The Kurds in northern Iraq have been the victims of a genocidal onslaught by the forces of the Butcher of Baghdad, Saddam Hussein. Indeed, over the last few days, three heavily armed Iraqi divisions are reported to have resumed their assault on the Kurds.

As a consequence of the Iraqi attacks against its Kurdish citizens, the world has extended its sympathy to them on their terrible plight. In the Wall Street Journal of 24 March 1992, the Director of the Centre for Security Policy in Washington, Frank J. Gaffney Jr, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Kurdish Workers Party, known as the PKK, has attempted to exploit the sympathy legitimately extended by the international community to the Kurds of Iraq. But it is wholly undeserving of such support. The PKK is an avowedly Marxist organisation, bent on imposing through terrorism its demands for an independent Kurdistan on the democratic government of Turkey. Premier Suleyman Demirel called the weekend's clashes `a declaration of war by the PKK'.

PARA.TAB: The principal sponsor of the PKK is Syria's Hafez Assad, who permits the party's leadership to be openly headquartered in Damascus and its terrorists to train in the Bekaa Valley. Like its Syrian patrons, the PKK relies heavily on illicit international drug traffic to finance its operations.

The main victims of the PKK's attacks are fellow Kurds in south-eastern Turkey, who have been assimilated into the Turkish population, have the democratic rights of all Turkish citizens and are represented in Turkey's parliament and government (the current Foreign Minister, Hikmet Cetin, is an ethnic Kurd). As with terrorist organisations elsewhere—which attempt to justify violence against civilians by dressing it up as national liberation heroism—the PKK is primarily engaged in terrorising its ethnic fellows to exacerbate relations between the minority and majority populations.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been reliably ascertained that over the past eight years, members of the PKK have murdered more than 1,000 civilians, men and women, young and old. Most of these casualties were of Kurdish origin. In addition, the PKK has murdered 821 Turkish officials.

PARA.TAB: Some of the more heinous acts of barbarism committed by the PKK include these examples: in December 1989, PKK attacked a Kurdish village and murdered 28 people, mainly women and children; on 12 June 1991, PKK terrorists raided a village in Siirt and murdered 27 villagers, including 12 children, seven women and four village guards; on 6 June 1991, PKK terrorists murdered seven villagers in Kahramanmaras, including three women and one child; and, again, on 25 December 1991, Kurdish terrorists bombed a seven-storey shopping mall in Istanbul and 11 innocent people died. The PKK is now receiving logistical and materiel support from Iraq. In return, the PKK is being encouraged by Sadaam Hussein to attack Kurds living in northern Iraq. For example, a few weeks ago, the Kurdish headquarters in northern Iraq was bombed, apparently in an attempt to kill the Iraqi Kurdish leadership. Fortunately, for the Kurds, the leadership escaped unscathed. The acts of barbarism and terrorism by the PKK, that I have described, have shocked the people of Turkey and the Turkish Government. As the Turkish Prime Minister, Suleyman Demirel, said just three days ago:

SPEECH.PARA: Use of arms against security forces in a democratic State based on supremacy of law cannot be tolerated. It is the ultimate duty of a State to provide safety for all its citizens and to protect first of all their right to live, the very basis of human rights. In performing this duty, the State has responsibility to isolate those who take up arms against the democratic order and to hand them over to justice.

In a democratic system, there are legitimate channels through which people can raise their demands, and structures which duly process them. In Turkey, freely elected representatives of the people are carrying out this function within the legitimate grounds of pluralistic democracy.

The Turkish Government has a responsibility, both at law and in the name of humanity, to protect the lives and property of its citizens. It is extraordinary, therefore, to find voices raised in defence of the terrorist activities of the PKK. Terrorism is a scourge of our age. There have been countless denunciations and declarations by the United Nations, and other international bodies, condemning terrorism.

PARA.TAB: Shortly after it was elected, the Government of Turkey instituted a number of steps to assist its citizens of Kurdish descent. In a number of areas, there is a strong policy of affirmative action for Kurds. The Government has acknowledged a Kurdish identity and recognised the rights of citizens of Kurdish descent to cultivate their Kurdish identity. However, the PKK is attempting to thwart these reforms. As Frank Gaffney said in the article that I referred to earlier:

SPEECH.PARA: The challenge to the U.S.—
and Australia—

and other Western democracies sympathetic to the plight of the Kurds will be to differentiate their responses to the incipient Kurd-related crises in Iraq and Turkey. On one hand, the West should oppose with force any renewed assault by Sadaam against the Kurdish population in Northern Iraq. Only by threatening such a response and, if necessary, carrying through on that threat, can civilian lives be protected from Sadaam's renewed predations.
As for the PKK's activities in Turkey, Washington and other Western capitals—
including Canberra—

must recognise that they represent a serious terrorist threat to the security of an ally and fellow democracy. The fact that this organisation is made up of people with ethnic ties to the long-suffering Kurds of Iraq would no more legitimise the PKK's destructive activities than the shared nationality of the Khmer Rouge with the people of Cambodia, makes their abhorrent behaviour acceptable. Far from criticising Turkey for dealing forcefully with a renewed campaign of terror on the part of the PKK, the West—especially the U.S.—
and Australia—
should encourage Ankara to deal firmly though discriminately with this terrorist Marxist gang.

The Government of Turkey is continuing to combat terrorism to the best of its capacity. People should never forget the humanitarian aid extended by the people of Turkey to the Kurds of Iraq, who escaped Sadaam Hussein after the gassing of thousands of them, and more latterly at the end of the Gulf war. The people of Australia have great empathy with the principles of democracy and freedom. I hope that the governments of the United States and Australia recognise the magnificent efforts of the Government of Turkey to try to restore law and order to that wonderful country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issues which the previous coalition speaker, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), was grieving about today related to Australia's standing in the world community. On a different aspect, I want to continue that theme. My theme is to look at education in Australia because I believe that that is at the heart of many of the difficulties with which we are faced.

PARA.TAB: Back in 1900 Australia was the No. 1 nation in the world. In 1990 we have slipped to being fifteenth and yet countries in our own region during this period of time have actually increased their standard of living. If we look at economies in the Asian region, we find that, in the last decade, they have grown 2 1/2 times, whereas our economy has not even grown by half. I think that shows to us that somewhere Australia is failing to meet the standards which are being set right around the world.

As far as trading goes, Australia was a great trading nation, being thirteenth in 1961. It is now slipping down that scale and in 1989 was nineteenth in the world. But if we have a look at a country such as South Korea, we find that it was ninety-ninth in the world back in 1960 and is now thirteenth in the world, while Australia was thirteenth and is now nineteenth.

So changes are occurring around the world, the consequence of which is that Australia is simply not making the grade. Of course, the honourable member for Aston was pointing to the fact that technology is one of those areas where Australia was not making the grade, and the structures put in place by the present Federal Government in Australia were one of the reasons why it was not.

Evidence is clearly now coming to the fore that we have to up our standards in Australia. If there is any objectivity about it, we can say that within Australia we have maintained education standards. But the rest of the world is going past us. It is bypassing us because the level of skills and knowledge which we are getting through to our young people in our schools and our colleges is not as good, is not as competitive, is not of the same high quality and standard as that which is being achieved around the rest of the world. Otherwise, why is Australia slipping behind?

Governments do not have any other mechanism really to lift a nation's quality of competitiveness in the world except through education. It is the only avenue whereby we can encourage Australians to do better. The question is: how do we change this downward spiral?

The first thing which we have to do is recognise the fact that Australia has problems in this area. One of the fundamental problems that have occurred is the centralised industrial relations of the Australian Teachers Federation in Australia. It is a critical factor as to why education has not gone ahead. I am not referring to the quality of teachers but to the industrialised structure which we have in the teaching system.

Secondly, we have to educate our people more effectively to be competitive. To achieve this, there is a much broader role, of course, than just what governments can do, but governments have an important role to play in ensuring that knowledge and skills are transmitted to our young people for future generations. If we do not do that to the best of our capacity, then we are handicapping our children and future generations of Australians.

I want to turn now, in particular, to some of the processes and systems changes which are occurring in Australia, some of which are good and positive, but there are aspects of the education systems in our schools which are not satisfactory and which need improving.

I draw the attention of honourable members to a news item of March 23 this year. It refers to a test of mathematical skills done by university entrants at Melbourne University. What we find is that 44 per cent of 654 first-year students passed the mathematical skills test at the University of Melbourne. In other words, there was a 56 per cent failure rate among year 12 students going into university at what the university regarded as a satisfactory level. What is really disturbing about it is that, under the changed Victorian Certificate of Education, these results are 14 per cent lower than those students were achieving under the old Higher School Certificate. This is disturbing because we are being told that as we put these new systems into place we are going to get a better quality. People argue about whether such a test is objective or subjective, but this measurement is as objective as we can get and standards are obviously dropping.

In Tasmania also we have moved to a Tasmanian certificate of education and I want to raise a few queries about that move. There is a good basis for moving towards encouraging skill development, but there are problems in authenticating the work of students. There has been a change away from having objectivity in our assessments. How do we authenticate project work which is done at home? How do we know it is entirely the student's work? How do we have teachers who can verify these things? These concerns are raised about the processes which are now developing within our schools. Yet at the end of the day students are going to be given As or Bs or Cs, but we will not really know whether the work was theirs.

With regard to verification, how do we know that the standards being required within our schools or between our schools are the same? This is the case with the new system in Tasmania. By way of illustration, within the Tasmanian system there are courses, which are called B courses, for year 9 and year 10 students. These courses are meant to have a timetable of approximately 100 hours within the schools, and the school board is quite happy to accept plus or minus 10 per cent. But in schools within my own electorate I have found that the variation is from 80 to 120 hours for the same courses. I wonder whether parents really understand, or whether employers understand, that there is this great variation. Can we really say that children who are getting 80 hours in one subject in one school as against children getting 120 hours in the same subject in another school are getting a fair deal? Will this maintain credibility in the eyes of the public?

Over the period of time when we have seen changes in Australian education, I believe that we have seen a decrease in objectivity of the instruments of assessment testing used in schools and an increase in the subjectivity. With criterion based assessment, or common assessment tasks as in Victoria, I do not know how we assess and maintain reliability between schools as to whether a child participates well in group dynamics or works independently, and I do not think the parents or the public generally understand.

There is a great need for public credibility in our education. If the public loses confidence, I do not believe that that education system can be maintained. It behoves all of us in parliament to ensure that education does maintain its public credibility.
In closing, I mention what a lecturer at the University of Tasmania has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Students and parents are being sold short because of the drift away from challenging academic courses.
I believe this is occurring throughout Australia, and we have a responsibility to make sure that our students are equipped and have a rigorous education. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —A popular saying is that there are three types of lies—lies, damn lies and statistics. This may well be so, but much can be gleaned from the Bureau of Statistics figures. For a start, they tell us much more than just the official population. They can also show us where growth areas are and help us with future planning of everything from schools to hospitals to shopping centres, nursing homes, child-care centres and bus routes. Just as importantly, they help us decide where the allocation of some $14m of Commonwealth funds each year to the States, Territories and local government actually should go.

PARA.TAB: For some time, Queensland has been Australia's high growth State. Whether this is due to the climate or the sound economic management and popularity of the Goss Labor Government, people have been flocking to Queensland in droves. Some people may scoff at these claims, but they certainly cannot argue with the figures. The growth rate has been shown once again in the population figures released this week by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The figures are the first Queensland count from last year's census and they show that there were almost three million people in the State on census night on 6 August last year. This is an increase of some 391,000 on the figure in 1986 and represents an increase of 15 per cent over that period. Of this growth, some 260,000 is attributed to interstate and overseas migration, with the remainder the result of natural growth.

There are several noticeable factors in these figures. Firstly, like the rest of Australia, Queensland's population continues to age. In fact, the median age now of a Queenslander is 32, up from 30 in 1986. Secondly, although there was an increase in the number of children up to the age of 14, their actual proportion of the Queensland population declined from 24 per cent to 22 1/2 per cent.

Much of Queensland's population growth has occurred in the State's south-eastern corner. Naturally, I was interested to see what population changes had occurred within my own electorate during the period. This shows that the population of my home shire, the Pine River Shire, has grown by almost 14,000, to 88,000. This represents a massive increase of almost 20 per cent. In the neighbouring Caboolture Shire, the population grew by 22,500 to 70,000. This is a staggering increase of almost 50 per cent in just five years.

No-one could dispute that such figures hammer home once again the importance of proper forward planning and the need for closer cooperation between all levels of government. These figures come hot on the heels of recent debates in this House about urban planning, sustainable development and the appropriate level of immigration. Nowhere is there more pressing evidence of the need to control the urban sprawl than in Queensland.

In February of this year, the Queensland property consultants Rider and Hunt issued a report which suggested that the Brisbane-Sunshine Coast-Gold Coast triangle could have a population of some four million within 30 years. Brisbane and the Gold Coast are predicted to merge within four years and by the year 2022 the region is expected to overtake Melbourne as Australia's second largest population centre. The State's population is, in fact, a time bomb and it is ready to explode unless we all act now to defuse it.

I raised similar issues to these in this House some 18 months ago, when I pointed out the need to get a much greater level of cooperation between local, State and Commonwealth governments on the issue of urban planning. At that time, we were embarking on the concept of new federalism and I was a bit sceptical as to whether new federalism, in fact, had come too late to overcome many of the population problems which were going to confront the greater Brisbane area. However, there have been some glimmers of hope in the preceding 18 months. The series of Premiers Conferences, although they are stalled somewhat now, has contributed greatly to overcoming issues of service duplication and establishing a degree of uniformity in a range of government services; and these are indeed positive achievements.

The $800m better cities program announced in the last Budget is up and running and successful in several States. In Brisbane, not too far from my own electorate, there will be some $31m spent over the next four years in revitalising the inner suburbs of Bowen Hills, New Farm, Fortitude Valley, Newstead and Teneriffe. Although honourable members opposite might scoff at this program, it is the first serious attempt to deal with the idea of revitalising inner city areas of the Australian capitals, and that is an extremely worthwhile objective. I was pleased to see that the Government's commitment to the better cities program was reaffirmed in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. As a result, the long awaited Brisbane-Gold Coast rail link will become a reality, thus taking pressure off the Pacific Highway and enabling more considered planning of urban development along the Brisbane-Gold Coast corridor.

My colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) is in the House and I know that he would join with me in hoping that the Commonwealth funding of the Gold Coast railway may leave some scope in the hands of the State Government to proceed with the long awaited rail to Redcliffe. That services parts of both my electorate and my colleague's electorate. It has been promised now for about 100 hundred years; it has been trotted out at every State election for the last hundred years. With Commonwealth funding of the Gold Coast rail link, there may be some hope that the work necessary to bring forward the Redcliffe rail link can be put firmly on the State Government's agenda.

There have been, indeed, some positive changes in terms of forward planning in my own electorate in recent times. For instance, after much lobbying by local residents and me, the Department of Social Security has agreed that the Pine Rivers Shire needs its own Social Security office. This office will be opening a bit later this year and will overcome the intolerable situation that has existed for many years of residents from the Pine Rivers Shire having to travel quite a considerable distance into Brisbane in order to lodge forms or seek advice.

In the area of child-care, the region is beginning to receive recognition of its high needs. In fact, it will be my pleasure next week to host a visit to my electorate, to the Pine Rivers area, by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and he will be meeting with the Pine Rivers Shire Council to discuss this very issue.

There have also been some encouraging examples of closer cooperation between administrations. The Brisbane City Council and the Pine Rivers Shire Council, for example, have conducted a trial bus program designed to provide better transport links between the two local authority areas, recognising that Brisbane simply does not end at the boundary of the Brisbane City Council and that Brisbane is a broader concept taking in the neighbouring local government areas.

In the area of housing, there has been some encouraging acceptance of the idea of the green street concept in the suburb of Strathpine in my electorate. Some 400 townhouses have recently been constructed according to these principles. These townhouses are close to shops, schools, transport and entertainment. They are ideal for retirees, young couples and sole parents. The estate's design cuts down on noise and traffic. There are no through roads and there are pockets of green areas throughout. So far, more than 250 townhouses have been sold at an average price of $89,000, which is a very significant step in making housing more affordable in this part of Australia. This is a challenging style of development and, if we are serious about tackling the problems of urban sprawl, we will have to have similar examples becoming far more common on the outskirts of our major cities.

There are a number of other Federal Government programs which are tackling urban sprawl issues. For instance, the community cultural and recreational sporting facilities program and the black spots program are both initiatives that have helped overcome particular problems. Both these programs have contributed to very worthwhile projects in my electorate being funded. We have seen sporting organisations receive funding, particularly the Police Citizens Youth Club in the most recent round. Given the high youth population of the area, that is extremely worth while and to be commended.

At the end of the day the real issue turns on the acceptance that issues of this nature are too important simply to be left to a local government authority to judge a town planning application on the basis of its merits alone, without taking regard of the wider impact of greater and greater population increase. There has to be overall State planning coordination of local authorities in the south-east corner of Queensland. We also have to see, and I am encouraged to see, that the Commonwealth has a role to play in these areas. Really, not since the days of the Whitlam Government has there been an acceptance that the Commonwealth Government has a role in overcoming these very important urban environment issues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak today about the problems of urban sprawl and I hope that the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) may take some interest. I think there is common agreement that Australian urban areas, where some 80 per cent of Australians live, are in a state of social, environmental and economic stress. Over the last 30 years there has been an ever increasing number of seminars, reports and conferences on the subject.

PARA.TAB: The main solution to these problems has been seen as stopping the sprawl of cities by increasing residential densities. This policy of urban consolidation has received the enthusiastic support of academics, bureaucrats, architects, planners, the development industry and, inevitably, State and now Federal Government. Yet in the same period cities have sprawled at a greater rate than ever before, residential densities have fallen and public resistance to higher densities has increased.

The social and economic conditions of our major urban areas are deteriorating and it appears we are headed inexorably down the nightmarish urban track of American cities. We were supposed to know the problems and solutions, so what went wrong? Perhaps we should have taken notice of Jane Jacobs, who in her book Life and Death of Great American Cities wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The pseudo science of city planning and its companion the art of city design have not yet broken with the specious comfort of wishes, familiar superstition, oversimplifications, symbols, and have not yet embarked on the adventure of probing the real world.
Years of learning and a plethora of complicated dogma have arisen on a foundation of nonsense.

Naturally in time, forceful and able men, admired administrators, having swallowed the initial fallacies. . . go on to the greatest destructive excesses which prudence or mercy might previously have forbade.

Hence, today we have the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with his visiting professor irrelevancies about `elegant, medium density human-scale architecture on consolidated multiple blocks'. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) chants an endless mantra about the evils of single dwelling houses. In New South Wales, Greiner has his `vision of a high-density city'.

PARA.TAB: It is not much good blaming public opposition or local government, which has largely turned feral on urban consolidation in the last decade. There are no great gains to be made in abuse of nimbys or calling for administrators for councils or fantasies that some bold, new urban development resource security Bill could be rammed through State or Federal Parliament to solve the problems. That has been tried many times before, without much effect.

While our political systems are in about the same shape as our cities, there is still some democracy every two or three years; and elitism and authoritarianism have not and do not work. Elections can be and have been won or lost on urban policy. We have to re-examine the conventional wisdom of urban consolidation and its associated mythology and address the real causes of sprawl and deterioration of cities. Ridicule and exaggeration of the great Australian dream and its quarter-acre blocks is, quite frankly, asinine. Single dwelling house lots in the major Australian cities range from one-thirtieth of an acre to an average of one-eighth of an acre.

The great Australian dream is not peculiarly Australian; it is inherent in human beings. Since the world began, irrespective of race, religion or status, given a free choice, everyone has wanted more space. While it is true that a substantial number of people will accept higher density living and smaller space needs at various times, they know that low rise separate dwellings mean more freedom, greater self-expression, more privacy and a better and more flexible living environment. They fear that increased densities will add to the worst problem of cities—traffic, more congestion, pollution, accidents, pedestrian danger, environmental breakdown and parking difficulties. They fear a threat to their major investment—their home—and many of these fears are justified.

Australians are constantly told how far we have slipped down the per capita GDP list but, with all the faults, we still have the world's best urban living conditions. While the public may put up with the short term asset stripping, divisive, survival of the fittest approach characterising State and Federal governments in recent years, they will not put up with governments which attack them in their own homes.

The myth that high densities produce cheaper, affordable housing, and that Australia has too much investment in housing, is a constant refrain. The facts are that single dwellings are the cheapest form of dwelling. Building costs per square metre rise almost directly with density. Space required per person also rises as density of housing forms increases. So if you want to virtually double the cost of housing per person, and the nation's total investment in housing, moving the population into flats is the way to go. Another example of the failure of the urban consolidation theory is what I call the `reverse cargo cult' myth—the idea that our predecessors built all this infrastructure in the inner cities with unused capacity, which lasts forever, just waiting for us to use. Not only is the spare capacity theory dubious, there is no sound evidence that creating new infrastructure is more expensive than renewing antiquated existing infrastructure.

In addition, urban renewal alters social structure and infrastructure requirements. For example, child population falls, schools close and are replaced in much more expensive form, consuming greater land areas, elsewhere in the city. The notion that housing density alone has anything to do with urban sprawl is at the heart of the urban consolidation failure. Housing occupies only about 30 per cent of total urban areas. Even a theoretical doubling of density on that 30 per cent would save only 15 per cent of the area of the city as a whole. However, if this were achieved, land use needs are created for many other needs such as roads, open space, car parks, businesses and child-care. The expansion of these other uses means that not only is the 15 per cent theoretical saving used up but the remaining residential component is reduced and the population falls. That is the story of Australian cities since the 1950s.

Net residential densities have increased dramatically as many thousands of flats have been built but gross residential densities have fallen. What has been happening is that we have been building more and more on less and less, reducing population, increasing housing costs and total housing investment, and not worrying about the constantly expanding 70 per cent of other land uses, and the inevitable corollary of change and redevelopment—wasted idle land. It is this 70 per cent of the total city consisting of the non-residential land uses where the god of urban sprawl really resides.

The failure of urban consolidation over the last 30 years is a result of these myths: that urban consolidation can be achieved by elitist and bureaucratic values imposed without public support, that higher densities can produce cheap and affordable housing, that there is a great economic advantage in utilising existing infrastructure rather than building new and that housing density has anything to do with the size of cities. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) that there is an agreement that honourable members do not call quorums during private members' business. If he has a quarrel with the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), he can take it up with the honourable member for North Sydney but he should not try to deliberately count him out, using up the time of honourable members who want to use this time to place grievances.

PARA.TAB: Now that I have made that clear, let me put forward my grievance. It has to do with the Leader of Opposition (Dr Hewson) deliberately misrepresenting a food shopping basket of goods that he, and he alone, has said represents the normal purchases that Australians would make week in, week out. Of course, it does not, but this is what he said in his press release of 9 December 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: A price survey by the independent Queensland supermarket group Foodlink shows on their estimate that the impact of the Goods and Services Tax on a representative shopping basket of groceries is 4.8 per cent.
What does `representative' mean? Foodlink responded to claims by the Government yesterday by saying;
At no time was it stated by Foodlink that this was a total of food purchased for a family for two weeks.

Foodlink is not to be criticised here; the Leader of the Opposition is, and I will tell honourable members why. Foodlink measures the sorts of goods that are bought at supermarkets, but I and most Australians do not buy a lot of our goods from supermarkets. We go to the hot bread shop to get our bread; we get our milk delivered or we go to the milk bar; we go to the greengrocers in order to get our vegetables and fruit, and all the rest of it. In other words, this is misleading. Foodlink simply measures a small proportion of a certain sort of purchase.

PARA.TAB: Foodlink Ltd is correct—it does not even claim to represent all the purchases that Australians would normally make to keep themselves well fed in a healthy manner. All that Foodlink has measured are the sorts of products that go through the checkouts of supermarkets. We know that, by and large, Australians will buy things such as cleaners at a supermarket because they are a great deal cheaper there, but the normal convenience foods—the perishables such as milk, bread, vegetables and fruit—are purchased at local stores.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not, because the Leader of Opposition has measured only a small number of items that we Australians would buy from time to time. We do not buy food exclusively through supermarkets. If we take out the sorts of products that are of absolutely no importance to the broad range of goods that we would seek to purchase, such as fresh fruit and vegetables, milk, bread and meat—if we take out Pine-o-Cleen, Preen, Fabulon, Ajax, Harpic, Snow White, Pal dog food and all the rest of it—
—The Leader of the Opposition got pinched this morning.
—Did he? That does not surprise me in the least. If we take out of the Foodlink so-called representative parcel of goods—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Bob Woods

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the Minister should be required to withdraw that interjection.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—The Minister has left the chamber. I call the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. If we subtract all of those goods, which are purchased mainly through supermarkets, we find that the impact of the GST on prices is not 4.8 per cent but over 10 per cent. We cannot concentrate just on the sorts of items that are not exclusively purchased from supermarkets, such as the fresh items, the butter, the bread, the milk—the sorts of things which we need to sustain ourselves but which my friends the Rumphs up in the gallery there do not purchase exclusively in supermarkets. They might go down to Wavell Heights or Banyo and shop around: like me, they probably do not do all their shopping through the supermarket.

PARA.TAB: It was wrong and deliberately misleading of the Leader of the Opposition to suggest that a Foodlink survey of supermarket purchases somehow represents the purchases of all Australians on a week to week basis. It does not. I go to the local milk bar to get milk or I have it delivered. I go to the hot bread shop to get my bread. I go to the greengrocer to get the best and the freshest vegetables and fruit. I do not purchase those things through the supermarket. The sorts of things that I purchase through the supermarket are the cleaners, the Vim and the Ajax, and the toothpaste and toothbrushes and all those sorts of things. We need to add up.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got sales tax on them.

—Stick to the question. These blokes opposite need to add up all of the goods which Australians purchase. The Foodlink survey does not represent the sort of purchase that the Leader of the Opposition purported to say that it did. He is wrong. He deliberately sought to mislead this House and the Australian people over what was a representative sample of food. When we extract from those, misleading is not a problem.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Parliamentary Secretary's exact words were that the Leader of the Opposition sought to mislead the members of this House and the Australian public. That is a direct reflection on the integrity of the Leader of the Opposition, and I would ask that it be withdrawn.
—I have taken advice. If the Parliamentary Secretary did say that the Leader of the Opposition deliberately misled the House, then it would assist if that was withdrawn.

—I will assist and I will withdraw that absolutely. I do say—and I repeat—that he deliberately said in his press release of December that there was a representative shopping basket as measured by the Foodlink Ltd survey.
—You have just confirmed it.

—I have not. The point is that Foodlink measures only the materials that go through the turnstiles at supermarkets. What the Leader of the Opposition clearly wanted people to believe was that that somehow represented all of the goods that Australians purchase normally to keep themselves healthy. It is not. It is a lie to suggest that those goods represent the purchases that honourable members and I and my constituents would make week in, week out. The essential foods are not necessarily, and certainly not exclusively, purchased from supermarkets. They are purchased from other outlets. We need, of course, to measure all of those matters, because at the end of the day if we subtract—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member has used the word `lie'. He cannot use such words in terms of the Leader of the Opposition. I ask that you direct him to withdraw those comments.
—He said it was a lie; he did not say anyone lied.
—On another point of order—
—There is no point of order on that. I call the Parliament Secretary.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. At the end of the day, what we have is an attempt to make representative an unrepresentative set of purchases. We cannot even claim that that basket of goods represents the sorts of goods that I and other members of this House or anybody else would buy for our weekly or fortnightly uses.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition hoped that we would not pick this up. The distortion is that the Leader of the Opposition has suggested that we would purchase normally things such as Preen, Fabulon, Ajax, Harpic, Snow White, Pal dog food, Whiskers, Pal Meatybites, Whiskettes, Uncle Toby's and all the rest of them—that those are the things that we buy and that we buy them in the proportions suggested by the Foodlink survey.

We do not. We simply do not do it. As the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has said, if people were to survive on the sort of shopping basket that Foodlink represents as going through its turnstiles—and this is not a criticism of Foodlink; Foodlink was simply asked to do the measurement—it does not represent the sorts of things that we need to keep us healthy. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services said, quoting from a National Food Authority:

SPEECH.PARA: In order for a family to meet the recommended daily intake of nutrients—
and surely that is a decent thing that we should have—

the National Food Authority analysis indicated that the Opposition's fortnightly grocery list would have to be supplemented with the following: an extra 13 loaves of bread, an extra two kilograms of apples, an extra three kilograms of potatoes, 21 litres of milk, a packet of Wheaties, pasta, tuna, bananas, the rest.

The Leader of the Opposition deliberately left out those sorts of goods, which Australians purchase every day, in order to suggest that the GST is not going to be absolutely terrible for the Australian consumer. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the problem with Government members when they seek to trip up the Opposition on the Fightback package is that their own words of the past, whether they be the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the words of their own Government estimates, come back to undermine their attacks and destroy their credibility. It absolutely haunts them that they are unable in any way viably to challenge the calculations and conclusions of the Fightback package. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) has spent some time attacking the Foodlink survey of supposedly everyday items, but the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has, of course, stated that it was never relied on as anything other than a collection of some items from a supermarket.

PARA.TAB: But let us rely on the Government's own calculations. The Treasury document itself has estimated the price effects of the Opposition package on everyday items of everyday families, whether they be cereals, dairy products, meat and seafood, fresh fruit and vegetables, soft drinks, ice-creams, takeaway foods and meals. So the Treasury itself has measured the impact of the goods and services tax, and do honourable members know what it concludes? Does it conclude that there will be a 15 per cent increase for all Australians? Oh no, it says 4.77 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not claiming that.

—The Parliamentary Secretary says that the Government is not claiming that it will cost ordinary Australians 15 per cent more to live. That is absolutely wrong. Look at the brochures it is putting out: 15 per cent rise in the cost of living; basic necessities go up 15 per cent. How can any respectable member of Parliament propagate these falsehoods when the Treasury documents—the Government's own Treasury documents—estimate the cost of living at 4.77 per cent on everyday items? When you take out the fuel excise, the payroll tax, the tobacco excise, it comes down to 3.6 per cent. That is a one-off 3.6 per cent on the consumer price index. To be conservative, we say 4.4 per cent, and on food and other items Treasury says 4.77 per cent. So where is the 15 per cent increase in the cost of living? That is absolutely wrong. It is absolutely wrong for any member of the Government, particularly a Parliamentary Secretary who aspires to ministerial office, to continue these falsehoods. It does the Government no good.

PARA.TAB: The people of Australia are not stupid. They know very well that the Treasury itself has said that the cost of living goes up 4.77 per cent and, overall, when the other reforms are taken into account, it goes up 3.6 per cent. So look at the compensation that is provided to Australians to overcome the overall 3.6 per cent increase in the cost of living, or on daily living expenses of 4.77 per cent. Pensions will go up 8 per cent. We were conservative as we did not want to leave any margin for error. With tax cuts for PAYE taxpayers, one-third is lopped off.

Under One Nation, Australians earning less than $20,700—and that amounts to four million Australians, or almost half the adult population—get no tax cuts. Under Fightback we will bring down the tax rate for more than 50 per cent of Australians from 20 per cent to 16.2 per cent. Here is a chance for honourable members opposite to deny that One Nation gives no tax cuts of any kind to people on an income below $20,700.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are increasing the family allowance.
—That is marvellous—the family allowance is the solution!

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Fightback doubles the family allowance and, moreover, it brings down the tax rate from 20.7 per cent to 16.2 per cent. What upsets members of the Government—
—Order! If the honourable member would like to address his remarks through the Chair he would get a better hearing, I am sure.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am facing a barrage from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) whom you have not called to order at any stage in the last five minutes.
—Order! I have called honourable members on both sides to order, if you would only listen.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am reassured by your intervention. I just wish you would call the Parliamentary Secretary by name. What upsets honourable members opposite is that their mantle as the party for the low to middle income earners has been dismantled. It has been blown apart. They do not represent low income earners. Why do they not give low income earners a tax cut? Why are they giving middle and upper income earners tax cuts and not the 50 per cent of Australians who earn less than $20,000 a year? Why have they abandoned the low income earners?
—It is a useless form of redistribution.
—Order!

—The Parliamentary Secretary says that it is a useless form of redistribution to give 50 per cent of Australians an income tax cut. It is an income tax cut which will benefit 50 per cent of Australians, so let us put to rest once and for all the fallacies that have been aired in this place today. Let us put to rest the cheap, dishonest, misleading, outright lies which are contained in the brochures being sent by members of the government and by unions affiliated with the ALP that the cost of living will go up by 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury's own figures estimate that the cost of living for Australians on everyday items will go up 4.77 per cent, and 3.6 per cent overall. I seek leave of the House to table that document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are too sensible to fall for the falsehood being put out by the Government. The Government will go to any length to conduct this scare campaign. They will stretch the truth or, in many circumstances, abandon the truth. The reason is that it is getting across to Australians that what is needed more than anything else is incentives: incentives to individuals, to working men and women; and incentives to business.

PARA.TAB: We can have some confidence in and optimism for the future of Australia as long as we realise that old axiom that it is not governments that create wealth, it is the private sector, it is business. We will lift $20 billion in taxation off the private sector. People talk about the assistance and subsidies and handouts that this Government will give to the loudest and noisiest lobby group or the most skilled lobbyist representing any industry. We will give a massive across the economy boost to business.

Honourable members opposite talk about assistance by way of dodgy one-off intervention schemes for export industries: we will abolish $1.7 billion of wholesale sales tax for export industries. They want assistance for export industries: how about $1.7 billion in one hit by abolishing wholesale sales tax? They want to help farmers, but the farmers paid $170m in wholesale sales tax last year: we will abolish it. They talk about assistance to farmers and small business: we will abolish fuel excise.

We do not believe in favouring one group over another. We want to give a massive, fantastic, across the economy boost to the private sector so that there is incentive to reinvest and there is incentive to grow and incentive to employ people. It will reward people individually because it will allow people to do what they cannot do in the present circumstances, that is, work overtime or work a second job. How many times have we heard Australians complain over the years that there is no point pushing yourself to the limit because there is no reward for it, it all goes in taxes?

The people have to make a decision at the next election. We on this side are offering change the like of which has never been seen before. We are going to turn back once and for all the legacy of Whitlam which made government the first port of call for lobby groups, for industry groups. People turned to government always for assistance. We will give that assistance by reducing the tax take of government. What could be fairer than that? It will assist farmers, small business, business and working men and women.

The Fightback package offers hope for the future. It outlines a vision. It is a very different view of government from that of the Labor Party, and I do have confidence that the people of Australia will make the right decision and vote for the coalition. It is a fundamental change. There has probably been no other election since Chifley and Menzies in 1949 that so starkly separates the future proposals of the two sides of Parliament, and I welcome that debate. We have waited a long time on this side to once and for all reveal to the Australian people the Government's shortcomings, its failures, its pathetic record of government. It has demonstrated again here in the grievance debate, and on adjournments night after night, the falsehoods it will spread about the goods and services tax. They are demonstrably false on its own figures. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to deliver a speech today about a great old friend mine, a chap called Jack Devereux, a former president of the Metalworkers Union. Jack was a social justice expert long before social justice become the buzzword of this era. I would not be able to give Jack the credit he deserves in the time I have left here this afternoon, mainly because someone called a quorum—which was a disgrace. I am sure Jack would expect me to respond to the rubbish that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has been dishing out here this morning.

PARA.TAB: Jack Devereux certainly believed in social justice and so do we on this side of the House. The Opposition's package shows that it obviously does not. The honourable member for Gippsland is trying to tell us that 15 per cent on all essentials in life, on bread and butter and all those sorts of things, will not make them cost 15 per cent more. Honourable members opposite have the audacity to claim that the new tax is not going to affect farmers, is not going to affect business. What about all the small business people? Small business will be devastated under the Opposition's package because they are the guys who are going to have to work on Sundays—most of them already work Saturdays. On Sundays, when they might have had a little bit of time with their families, they are going to be sitting down doing tax returns to comply with the requirements on these ridiculous GST proposals. It is the craziest thing that this country has ever seen.

The honourable member for Gippsland is absolutely right when he says that there is quite a clear division between us and those opposite. The Australian people can see that what the Opposition is trying to do is take us back to the bad old days—the really bad old days. One of my constituents actually suggested to me one day that the coalition would take us back to the sixteenth century. The Opposition's proposal would mean running around collecting taxes from everybody and taxing people out of getting the real necessities. What a disgrace it is. What about the farmers, the people honourable members opposite pretend to represent? They are going to tax everything that farmers are doing, including a lot of things that are not taxed now.

The whole Fightback package is a shoddy proposal. It is a bigger failure than the `Futile Diversions' package of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) a while ago. Opposition members accuse us of making diversions in this place, but this thing is the greatest diversion ever. The two honourable members who have been trying to interject have obviously learnt a lot from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) because they swing around now and put their backs to those speaking. They do it all the time to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this place. They are learning well from the Leader of the Opposition. Of course, they do hot have the guts to face up to us in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You strike fear into us.

—Yes, I am sure I do. I cannot understand how the people of Gippsland could possibly tolerate the rubbish that the honourable member is going to dish out to them by taxing every one of them at 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Dubois)—Order! It being 1.45 p.m, in accordance with sessional order 106, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:
That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the grievance debate, when I was speaking on urban planning, a quorum was called on me by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay). Not only did that break the conventions of the House but, when I approached the honourable member for Fairfax and inquired why, I was told that, if I wished to vote with the Government on divisions, that was the way it was.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that I am sitting in a blue-ribbon Liberal seat and I am also aware that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has been down in Wills rubbishing me because he does not want independents to get up. But really I think this is a breach of privilege. If there is an attempt to intimidate me in my voting, that is, frankly, a breach of privilege. It is also an act of stupidity. I think anyone who knows anything about the North Sydney area, and me in particular, knows that intimidation will get him nowhere. It is an affront; I think there would be very few members of the Opposition who would support such an action.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when the Federal Government is consolidating defence strength in northern Australia, it is of very real concern that the Liberal Party's proposal to save $1,150m in Defence Force expenditure over the next three years would have devastating consequences for Townsville. Townsville has the largest Defence Force establishment in northern Australia. Townsville and members of the Defence Force stationed there would be the big losers under the Liberal Party's Fightback package. A person does not need to be a clairvoyant or a fortune-teller to predict the consequences for Townsville's economy of tampering with defence force funding.

PARA.TAB: The tables and explanatory notes in the Fightback! document clearly contradict Opposition claims to reallocate $300m to combat forces. In particular, table 16.2, at pages 231 to 233, directly indicates that the Opposition plans to save $1.15 billion over three years. Even if the Liberal Party's savage spending cuts were focused mainly on the civilian component of the Defence Force, there would be inevitable flow through into combat capability.

Members of the Defence Force, like everyone else in the community, would also be burdened with the consumption tax of 15 per cent. It has been estimated by the Federal Department of Defence that it would cost Defence $744m in purchases because of the application of the GST. I challenge the Liberal Party to show me where in Fightback! the Defence Department is exempted. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with others today to congratulate those responsible for the National Wool Day and to pay my respects particularly to the animal and to those who have bred sheep and wool over the years.

PARA.TAB: I wish, however, to appeal to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to finalise the legislation concerning the dairy industry. I refer to the underwriting for the dairy farmers on the export of the products. About 27 per cent of our dairy industry today goes overseas and there are approximately 100,000 people employed within the industry. It is a stable industry and the farmers are calling upon the Government to let them know what their future will be. The underwriting costs the taxpayers nothing at all, because the dairy farmers pay a voluntary levy of 2c a litre for milk. They therefore pay themselves for the underwriting of the export.

It is an industry which is very important to Australia. Many people are employed there and the farmers today are most anxious indeed to know that the stability of the industry will be supported. Fortunately, today the industry speaks as one voice. All the States basically agree with the plans of the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House misleading advertising which appeared in my local paper, the Comment News, this week. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Meet the next Treasurer of Australia, Peter Reith, in Karragullen.

It is outrageous that it is possible to put this in the newspapers, because obviously it is misleading and it is wrong. Karragullen is very near to my electorate; it is actually in Pearce, just next door. I wonder whether the Opposition Treasury spokesman will be telling the crowd that turns up—most probably Liberal Party faithful—about the sorts of things that the Opposition has been doing here with the shopping trolley, the deceptive basket of goods, that it is trying to peddle around Australia, saying that really food prices are going to go up by less than 5 per cent, when in actual fact it is double that amount.

PARA.TAB: That sort of duplicity, I would imagine, would be told to the people of Karragullen. If not, it is a double deception, because those opposite will also be misleading the people of Karragullen by saying that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) will be the next Treasurer, whereas he obviously will not be if he is going to try to ram a 15 per cent goods and services tax down the throats of the good people of Karragullen. The people of Karragullen whom I know and the people of the city of Armadale will not have a bar of it. They will not have a bar of those opposite taxing food; they will not have a bar of them taxing clothing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw attention to the Easter 92 Project to take place this Easter.
