Under the patronage of the heads of all the Christian churches, from all the denominations in the several States—Anglican, Catholic, Greek Orthodox, Presbyterian, Uniting, Lutheran, Salvation Army—and right across the country from Darwin to Hobart, Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and 85 other cities and towns, thousands of Christians are joining together, notably on Easter Sunday, 19 April next, to proclaim that Easter is about the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, a new life in him, and not about the Easter bunny and the other paraphernalia of the secular Easter holiday period.

PARA.TAB: In Sydney, the central and climactic event of the program will be the coming together around 3 p.m. on Easter Sunday of a vast gathering of Christians, having marched from four assembly points, in front of the Town Hall in the city, declaring the Christian message, Christ is risen, to the nation and, with the Archbishop of Sydney, offering a prayer for the city and Australia. I take this opportunity of the broadcast to urge the churches of Australia and their people to `be in it' on Easter Sunday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Life membership of the Australian Labor Party does not come easily. People have to be members of the ALP continuously for 40 years before they can be considered for that high honour. It is a proud day for any city when one of its members is awarded life membership of Australia's greatest political party. It is a fantastically proud day for a city when four citizens have life memberships conferred on the same day.

PARA.TAB: The city of Cessnock has struck the quadrella. On Friday, 8 May, four wonderful citizens of the city of Cessnock will be honoured by having conferred upon them life membership of the Australian Labor Party—that is, after 40 years service. Mrs Alma Bedford joined the ALP in Cessnock and has been a member of the branch for 50 years. Mrs Lola Neilly has been a member of the ALP since 1950, that is, 42 years membership. Noel Mitchell, a very worthy citizen of the town, has been a member of the branch for 42 years. And Ambrose Murray, a distinguished raconteur, has been a member of the Abermain branch for 42 years. They are four wonderful citizens, Mr Speaker, and I know that there will be a large turnout of party members to honour those four citizens on 8 May. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with a great event which is being held in the Parliament of Australia today, that is, the National Wool Day. I am proud to be associated with it, and I note the 1974 Australian Wool Board tie—massive tie, wonderful promotion.

PARA.TAB: The wool industry, of course, is one of the most important industries for Australia and has been for over 200 years. I commend the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) for their bipartisan approach to the Wool Day which was held today. I commend everyone in the gallery not to miss seeing the display in the Great Hall before they leave this building today. I want to encourage them to buy Australian. I want them to buy Australian products. I want them to buy woollen products.

We have had a couple of products given to us. Most of the members in this House will be wearing these magnificent red socks, and I want to commend the industry for providing them so that they can be promoted as a worthwhile product for everyone to buy. Wool is our major export commodity and I represent a very large area of woolgrowers and representatives in the north central Victorian area where I know that they are proud of the progress that the industry has made. They all subscribe to the theory that we should buy woollen garments, that we should buy Australian products and that we should promote our wool overseas. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Courier-Mail front-page story today shows that one-third of employers in Queensland have underpaid the youths of Queensland. That is without voluntary agreements, the very mechanism that those on the other side wish to use to destroy award conditions. I would like to join with speakers on the other side of the House again to promote Australian products and buy Australian wool but I challenge each and every one of them to have the courage to stand up and say, `Employ Australian labour in the wool industry', because the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) is very keen to employ New Zealand labour on his own property. So I would like to challenge all honourable members to put their loyalty to this country first and support Australian labour in this industry.

—I am surprised at the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). The Labor Party is in government in Queensland and is the Australian Government and yet he is attacking our side of the Parliament. I just cannot work that one out.

PARA.TAB: But what I want to speak about is the family allowance gift that has gone out today to all those families—and most Australian families are in great need today—from the Australian Government. It was interesting listening to the ABC today to hear the women interviewed. Two out of three, I think, or three out of the four, said they were not going to be bought off by this short term bribe even though they really needed the money. I would ask the lady who did accept it and who said that it was a wonderful gift, to ask the Government what would happen if the Government stuck to its tariff policy. I ask her to consider how much more clothing and shoes she would be able to buy for her children if the tariff regime that the Government originally proposed were kept in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a very serious matter and it is not the Opposition's GST. I do not think that too many members of this place would be opposed to what I want to say. I believe that His Excellency the Governor-General, Bill Hayden, has brought a lot of dignity to his high office. I was particularly concerned to read on the front page of today's Courier-Mail and also in my own local paper that a member of the Ipswich RSL has made moves to stop not only members of Parliament from going to Anzac Day services—which I take offence to—but also His Excellency. This particular person does not speak on behalf of the Ipswich RSL. I spoke to the President of the RSL yesterday and the Ipswich member certainly does not represent the wide-ranging views of people in the RSL.

PARA.TAB: To me Anzac Day is something that is above politics. It should be treated as very much a bipartisan thing. This gentlemen, Mr Reg Bishop, who is carrying on like this, does nothing for the memory of those people who have made the supreme sacrifice and whom we remember on Anzac Day. When he calls for the sacking of different people, particularly the Governor-General, he does nothing—
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) is absolutely right. He should resign from the RSL or certainly be dismissed by it within the terms of their own rules. It is absolutely disgraceful and I would ask Mr Bishop to curtail what he is doing. I would ask the RSL to ban him from any more operations. (Time expired)

—I would like to draw the attention of the House to the magnificent wool rugs that have been manufactured by the Bowron family. The Bowron family has grown its industry into the most innovative wool skin industry in the world. Because it has processed 1.75 million lamb skins per year, this company has enormous resources to produce the highest quality product consistently, and the capacity to ensure reliable delivery every time anywhere in the world. Today they are an international market leader. They are dedicated to servicing and expansion of overseas markets and have earned significant recognition in the world tanning industry.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As the Prime Minister will be aware, in his One Nation statement he indicated that any surplus from the sale of wool from the stockpile by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission would be refunded to those who had paid the 12 per cent wool tax this season. This was confirmed by the Treasurer in answer to a question last Thursday. However, it has been reported that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is now favouring the position of the coalition and the wool industry at large: to reduce the tax to 10 per cent or below this coming season and not proceed with the cash rebate refund arrangement that he had announced previously. What exactly is the Government's position? When will it make this position clear in the interests of the industry on this great first-ever National Wool Day?

—I thank the honourable Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question. I congratulate in this House those who have been responsible for organising National Wool Day. It has been a great show and I think all of those who have gone into the Great Hall and seen the display on exhibition would be justly proud. I am also pleased to say that the sale in the Great Hall has made a significant improvement to the wool price. I think it had something to do with the new auctioneers. I think it was the shortest training scheme that the Leader of the Opposition and I had been through; but we have been part of it.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the honourable gentleman's question. It is true that in the economic statement the Government announced two important initiatives as far as the wool industry is concerned. One was to introduce flexibility into the debt reduction schedule; and the other was to ensure that because there was a surplus this year, it should be returned to wool growers.

I will go to the first point because I still think it is very important. The coalition is still calling for a cut in the tax. But the reality, based on one year's performance in a seven-year cycle, is that I think one would have to be a very brave person to be putting at jeopardy the future discharge of the debt that is owed by the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Council has put its position on this. What about that?

—I will come to the Wool Council in a moment. I have had some very good discussions with it, rather than just berating or parroting it as you do from your side. I am actually prepared to sit down and talk with it, rather than assuming that I know what it is doing.

PARA.TAB: So far as flexibility is concerned, it is very important to understand why we introduced the cumulative schedule. It does not mean that the timetable and rate of payments themselves will be reduced; what the cumulative schedule does is remove the need for the Wool Realisation Commission to sell into poor markets in order to meet fixed annual payments. That was an approach which the industry made to us and to which we responded positively. I might add that the other advantage of that is that it will protect wool growers in falling markets from forced AWRC selling activities. In this regard, legislation will be introduced into the House.

So far as the surplus funds are concerned, the One Nation statement did indicate that any surplus funds not prudently required by the Realisation Commission may be used as a rebate to wool growers in the form of a cash payment. The commitment was also given by the Government that I would consult with the wool industry on the distribution of such funds to growers. The Government's intention was to establish a process which would allow growers to benefit directly from the improved performance of the Realisation Commission.

The immediate response from the Wool Council, as it was from the Opposition, was to criticise this proposal without looking at what the words really said and to call for a reduction in the wool tax rate. As I have indicated before, the Government is not prepared to reduce the wool tax at this stage. We cannot make the judgment based on one year's performance in the course of a seven-year debt reduction schedule. It simply is not enough time to justify at this stage a reduction in the prescribed rate of tax.

Nevertheless, I can advise the House today that following consultations with the Wool Council I have obtained Cabinet endorsement to provide for further flexibility in the distribution of surplus funds from the Realisation Commission. Therefore, I propose to use any surplus funds this year as a rebate against the wool tax. This will enable an effective reduction in the rate of tax whilst maintaining the prescribed rate of tax at the existing 12 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—You would not have had the imagination to think that through.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lloyd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party!
—I might add that the Wool Council of Australia has agreed that it will not pursue a reduction in the prescribed level of tax in the light of the effective reduction through rebate.
—In the tax.

—It is not in the tax; the prescribed rate of tax will remain the same. We will simply vary the mechanism by which the surplus is repaid. You do not understand that if you take down the tax, you do not provide a basis for collection to the Realisation Commission in future years. This mechanism rewards on the basis of performance, not guess, and makes sound judgments to secure the base for this industry.

PARA.TAB: The size of the surplus will determine the level of the rebate, which we will not know until closer to the end of the selling season. I will have to consider further the proportions of the overall 12 per cent remaining tax in the light of the recommendations from industry bodies. We will introduce legislation in the current Parliament to provide for the distribution of surplus funds by way of a rebate against tax or as a cash rebate, whatever might be the appropriate approach in any given year.

I conclude on this point: this outcome yet again reflects the capacity of government to work constructively with the industry to achieve sound public policy. For the reasons I outlined today at the opening of Wool Day in this Parliament, I believe that this industry has a very strong future. The decision that we announce today will help secure it.
Mr Bruce Scott—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of parliamentary privilege. This morning I brought into this House a fleece of wool from my electorate of Maranoa and placed it on my desk.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Moreton.

INTERJECT.PARA: Dr Bob Woods—Come on, answer it!

PARA.TAB: Mr MacKellar—Do your job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members might consider that there is some very important reason to support the concept of Wool Day, and I am sure everyone supports that. The honourable member for Maranoa suggests in some absurd way that there was a matter of parliamentary privilege involved in his not being able to put a fleece of wool in front of him; that might be an improvement—I do not know—but I want to be able to see the honourable member for Maranoa if he rises. I suggest to all honourable members that, while it might be laudable to support the concept of Wool Day, to attempt to take sham proposals like the honourable member for Maranoa has just done is absolutely ridiculous.
—I ask the Treasurer: is the Treasurer satisfied with the balance of payments results published yesterday and do the figures indicate whether the economy is in recession or not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Of course, the balance of payments figures do contain a great deal of encouragement for the Australian economy and, therefore, for the Australian people as a whole. We have witnessed a dramatic turnaround in Australia's current account performance in recent times, the current account deficit having almost halved as a proportion of GDP since the late 1980s. In the eight months to February we have seen the current account deficit down some 34 per cent on the situation at the same time last year, and that itself was down 29 per cent on that recorded in 1989-90.

PARA.TAB: There have been some claims or some suggestions made about the fact that these are not real gains being made by the Australian economy. In fact, we have the Leader of the Opposition producing press statements about how we should take heed of his warnings about the dire consequences confronting the Australian economy. He has now taken to producing documents entitled `Documenting The Risks I', `Documenting The Risks II'—and we are now up to `Documenting The Risks III'. It is kind of gloom by instalments as the Leader of the Opposition continues his campaign of talking down the Australian economy and, more importantly, disparaging the achievements of Australian working men and women and, of course, disparaging the achievements of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even you can take yourself seriously.
—Well, what I—
—Order! The Treasurer will not respond to the interjections.
—What I will take seriously are the very real achievements of Australian businesses, of Australian men and women, as they have each made their contribution—
—You must be walking around with your head in the clouds.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Well, they are not walking around with their heads in the clouds—
—You. I said `You'.
—Order!
—And neither am I.
—You are.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I am observing their real achievements, and all you can do, day after day and week after week, is disparage the efforts of Australian businesses and Australian working men and women as they make their contribution to improving the performance of this economy. It is not something which is mythical, the fact that we are now producing more manufactured exports and that we have had this dramatic improvement in our exports. This is not a current account improvement induced by the recession in the way in which the Leader of the Opposition likes to maintain that it is. It is a current account improvement which has been produced by the hard work of reform, by the hard work of workers, their unions and the firms which employ them.

PARA.TAB: That is the way in which we have had this improvement which has seen exports growing by some 7 per cent a year, growing year by year, as we put in a much better performance as far as Australia's trade effort is concerned. Of course, this is something which has not been lost on some of the economic commentators who wrote in the newspapers today. In the Australian Laura Tingle said:

ANSWER.PARA: The improving trade performance of recent months bodes well for Australia's growth prospects . . .
Ian Davis in the Canberra Times said:
. . . our current account is getting better. And it's getting better for the right reasons. And, there is very little room for doubt.
But of course you cannot do anything about Dr Gloom over here who continues to talk down the Australian economy because he has-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: could you ask the Treasurer to withdraw that remark and to refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his title?
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—The Leader of the Opposition—I do beg his pardon. The Leader of the Opposition is engaged on this campaign. I am surprised that he takes offence because I thought he had made gloom a bit of a trademark. I thought he would welcome the fact that this appellation had actually stuck at last, as he has gone around Australia telling everyone how woeful our prospects are and how appallingly we are doing.
—Come on, Paul. Do you fellows really put all this effort into such things? What a waste.
—The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—I thought he would wear it as a badge of honour, rather than as something that the honourable member for Hume would complain about. If we go back to January of this year to a little-reported speech that the Leader of the Opposition made in Perth, we can find the real idea, the real feeling that this man, the Leader of the Opposition, has for the Australian economy. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are a lot of pressures, there are a lot of uncertainties and there is now a lot of volatility and instability in the world economy, and that severely constrains what a small trading nation like Australia can hope to do in the course of this decade.
He went on to say:
So it will mean a much longer period of recessed activity in Australia, much more economic hardship, much more adjustments to be made.
In other words, what this man foresees for Australia is a decade of recession, a recessed economy for a decade, in spite of the fact that we are now seeing improvements—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your recession. You are to blame.
—I warn the honourable member for Mayo.
—You are responsible for it.
—The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—These improvements are not just heralded by the Government but are being observed and commented upon by others who are in an independent position to make those observations. Australia is doing better; the manufacturing industry in Australia is doing better; and it is about time the Opposition, and particularly its Leader, began to congratulate those hard working men and women out there, those hard working employers, who are making the changes and making the improvements on behalf of us all.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Is it a fact that her colleague Senator Richardson has received an invitation from the Australian Olympic Committee to be its guest in a private capacity at the Barcelona Olympics later this year? Does the invitation also extend to air fares and accommodation for Senator Richardson? Does the Minister think it grossly improper for a Minister of the Crown to accept such an offer from a group which has received millions of dollars in taxpayers' funds, corporate donations and donations from private individuals, given on the understanding that they were assisting Australian athletes in their quest to go to the Olympics? Alternatively, was it really part of a deal, about which Senator Richardson has been bragging, involving additional funding that he himself claims he got last year for the AOC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Richardson, as the previous sports Minister, has received an invitation from the Olympic Federation to attend Barcelona.
—Are you going to stop him?
—Order!

—As I understand it, the Opposition has too; as I understand it, so have the Premier of New South Wales and the sports Minister in New South Wales. —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House of the current level of inflation and the prospects for inflation? What are the implications for the cost of living for Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has succeeded in breaking the back of inflation after two decades from the double-digit inflation bequeathed to us by the Opposition to a statistical rate now of 1 1/2 per cent and an underlying rate of about 3 per cent. Of course, honourable members opposite are always terribly embarrassed that they found they were incapable of dealing with inflation, and terribly embarrassed about the fact that this Government has been able not only to deal with it but to deal with it decisively.

PARA.TAB: The aim must be to maintain that inflation gain in the 1990s by keeping inflation structurally low. This, of course, would be put at risk by taxes upon consumption that drifted back into the wages system. We have had some debate in the House over the last week about the impact of a goods and services tax at 15 per cent upon the cost of living of Australian men and women, taxpayers, families, et cetera.

We have found that the Opposition has been relying on a so-called Foodlink consumption tax survey. I will just make a couple of simple points about it. The first survey was produced by Foodlink on 10 June 1991; on 11 July 1991 the GST campaign group, headed by Senator Baume, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Downer and others, produced a press statement, `Labor's hidden consumption tax exposed', in which they said:

ANSWER.PARA: The basket of groceries annihilated this week by revelations from a Queensland supermarket group that Labor's scare campaign over how much the basket of groceries would cost with the GST has been annihilated by the revelations of this group.

That came out a few weeks later. Then on 20 November 1991 the second survey from Foodlink came out—surprise, surprise!—one day before the presentation of the GST package on 21 November. In that survey we found that there had been a change in the basis of the survey. Added into the second basket were all goods with a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax penalty: Ajax Spray and Wipe, 20 per cent; Harpic toilet cleanser, 20 per cent; Snow White bleach; three extra cans of Pal; three extra cans of Whiskers; two extra rolls of toilet paper; four extra soap bars.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you tax those things?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo. If he interjects again, I will name him.

—All of these things with a 20 per cent WST were added in and then goods not attracting the WST were deleted, such as Nestle's condensed milk, Pauls thickened cream, cornflakes, pineapples, onions, et cetera. In other words, we saw a vast change between the goods in the first and second surveys. The composition of the sample was dramatically changed between the first and the second surveys and it was produced one day before the GST package was presented.

PARA.TAB: Then on 9 December 1991 the Leader of the Opposition put out a press statement—again in his usual extravagant language: `Another Labor lie exposed'—and said:

ANSWER.PARA: A price survey by the independent Queensland supermarket group, Foodlink, shows on their estimate that the impact of the goods and services tax on a representative shopping basket of groceries is 4.8 per cent.

Of course, the questions are: who made it representative? Who decided what would be in the basket? Was the public not entitled to believe that a representative basket of groceries included food? Of course it was.

PARA.TAB: Last night the Leader of the Opposition, stung by criticism in the House, put out another statement, again verbose, with language such as `breathtaking fraud', `based on a lie', `shamelessly misrepresented'—the usual stuff. After we get past all the defamatory material, it says:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Foodlink basket was never distorted or represented by me to be anything other than what it was;
But he said that it was a representative basket of groceries. Therefore, most Australians took that to mean that it included food. Then we found that yesterday Foodlink Ltd said:
At no time was it stated by Foodlink that this was a total of food purchased for a family for two weeks. . . . At no stage did we say this was representative of a `food basket'. . .

I will leave it to the public to judge. This survey came out. Then the Opposition came out with its campaign group press release a couple of weeks later. Then, on the day before the GST package came out, there was a new tax link survey with the composition of it changed. Then the next day the GST arrived. Then we found that the items that were taken out of the survey were those which materially affected it. Then we found that the wholesale sales tax calculation had been levied at the retail level whereas, if it were levied at the wholesale level, the base would shrink; therefore, the size of the price impact would be greater. So the 4.8 per cent is actually 7 per cent. Even on your own figures—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The wholesale sales tax is levied before mark-up. You have tried to maximise the wholesale sales tax base by levying it after mark-up, as though it were a final tax when, in fact, it is an intermediate wholesale sales tax.
—That is rubbish.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—The 4.8 per cent was actually 7 per cent. So not only is there a fabrication in the change in the composition which the Opposition relies upon, but it is actually calculated applying the wholesale sales tax at the retail, rather than the wholesale, level. The questions are: how did the Opposition arrive at this representative basket that the Leader of the Opposition refers to? How come just one loaf of bread is to obtain for a family for a fortnight? How come there was no meat and so few vegetables and fruit?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—How come the staple foods were in short supply and those staples—meat, fish, vegetables and bread—were called top-ups? Obviously, the Opposition's policy is, `Let them eat Pal'. The Leader of the Opposition would not say `cake' because that would push the calculation in the survey up again. He would not say,`Let them eat cake', because we would find that, if cake is anything like biscuits, it would be up to 18c a half kilogram and therefore an addition to the impact of the tax.

PARA.TAB: I will let the public make its judgment about Foodlink, the veracity of its survey, the coincidence of its statements and publications and the GST, the shonky calculation of the 4.8 per cent figure, which has the wholesale sales tax at a retail taxing point and not the wholesale taxing point without mark-up, and more particularly the fact that it is totally unrepresentative of a family shopping basket. As the Treasury shows, the impact on food is about 10 per cent.

I remind the House of what I said yesterday. I do not know of any political leader who would rely upon such a device to sell the Australian public on a major piece of policy, who would rely on such a dodgy basis and who would be so fleet of foot in regard to the veracity of the claims, the calculations and its representation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and it relates to the Labor scare campaign on inflation and our Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members of my right will cease interjecting.

—I ask the Prime Minister: is it a fact that the Treasury analysis of the Fightback package forecasts that the inflation impact of our package is less than 4 per cent on a CPI basis, and only 1.3 per cent on a GDP deflator basis? I also ask the Prime Minister why his Wills by-election brochure says:

QUESTION.PARA: Basic necessities all go up 15 per cent.

Yet on the reverse side the illustration shows that the price of milk, for example, rises by less than 15 per cent. On taking office he undertook to tell the truth to the people of Australia. Why has the Prime Minister told a blatant untruth to the electors of Wills that all basic necessities go up 15 per cent under the Fightback package?

TALK.START.PARA: —For the simple reason that something untaxed and to be taxed by the GST will rise by 15 per cent. It is as simple as that. It is not a terribly staggering intellectual conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—That is a lie, and you know it.
—The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—As far as the Treasury is concerned, is it not interesting that the Leader of the Opposition relies upon the Treasury, but two weeks ago blackguarded the Department as being politicised for even daring to produce an analysis of the GST? Two weeks ago the Treasury was beneath contempt, not to be relied upon, a politicised Department, involved in the political chicanery in an analysis of the GST; now it is to be regarded as a reliable authority, as it was for the Leader's purposes—

PARA.TAB: Mr Bradford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—in a debate a day or so ago when he asked me about whether the Treasury was involved in the growth forecast for the Government. That is the very same Department as that which in the previous sitting he blackguarded as being a politicised joke of a department. The lack of consistency by the Leader of the Opposition is profound. The fact is that the CPI effects, as measured by the Treasury in the Opposition's GST policy, excluding the increase in tobacco prices, was 3.6 per cent—
—Say again.

—It was 3.6 per cent. But the increase in tobacco excise was included at 3.9 per cent, plus the Treasury's estimate of the impact on the Opposition's health costs in the proposal of 4.6 per cent, plus the introduction of the Medicare co-payment—the Medicare co-payment has since been abolished, but you have a co-payment proposal—and the reduction in GST oncost of 4.9 per cent, plus the impact of road user charges of 5.6 per cent. So by the time you adjust your whole package, you are at 5.6 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—They are the Treasury numbers as well. So, do not go quoting the 3.6 per cent, relying on a simple analysis of the overall impact of the GST on prices. The Leader of the Opposition is blowing his bags about doubling the inflation rate—
—You cannot add up. Here he is again. Here's the conspirator from Kirribilli again.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.
—from an underlying rate to 3 per cent, to an underlying rate of 6.6 per cent, which is in fact an underlying rate of nearly 9 per cent when we add in the other things. He is now skiting about that.

PARA.TAB: I do not know of any other person in any other modern economy who would be standing up in a parliament, in a chamber like this, beating his chest about his capacity to double the inflation rate. What a terrific policy that is. Suppose he had said, `We propose to double the inflation rate but we will remove the impact from ongoing inflation with a wages policy'. But he wants no truck with the unions, no conversation with the unions, no accord and no discussion about compensation. He wants to partially compensate people and then expects them to line up for less than full CPI.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell the truth?

—Why do I not tell the truth? I am exposing your duplicity—the high inflation specialist. He left us with double digit inflation when he waddled off to the private sector in 1983 and he is back to give us double digit inflation after we have got it down into low single digits.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Why did the Government decide to increase public outlays in the One Nation statement? What would have been the implications of reducing public expenditure when the Australian economy is just starting to emerge from recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Fraser, the increase in expenditure in the One Nation package, which was principally in the area of infrastructure and assistance to families, was designed to try to ensure that the recovery which is gradually taking place was made stronger and more vigorous, and that we move more quickly back into the kind of growth which will give us substantial increases in employment and reductions in unemployment. But in doing that the Government is not abandoning its approach to the public sector.

PARA.TAB: During our period in office we have been seeking to ensure that the public sector was made much more efficient and that the overall size of the public sector was reduced. We have been quite successful in that respect. When we came into office, public sector outlays as a percentage of GDP were about 29 per cent. These outlays were reduced to 23 1/2 per cent by 1989-90 by a whole series of measures that we took, including targeting programs to make sure that they were more effectively targeted to those in need. Some of these programs were opposed by the Opposition, such as the assets test on pensions. With the recession, outlays as a percentage of GDP have gone back up to over 26 per cent. Structurally we have a public sector which is much less than that which was inherited from the Fraser Government.

The Opposition in the Fightback statement, instead of boosting the public sector in the way I have described, would have taken the opposite approach. As we know from the Opposition's Fightback package, if it had been introducing its package it would have been cutting the public sector. The Opposition claims that its gross expenditure cuts would be $10.1 billion over three years with net expenditure cuts of $4 1/2 billion. When properly costed by my Department, that comes to gross cuts of $7.6 billion and a net cut of $1.9 billion. The figures are different but still in the same direction; there are still substantial cuts in the public sector.

The Government does not support that kind of approach because it would have been quite the opposite of what the economy needs at present; it would have pushed us further into contraction rather than recovery; and it would have a devastating effect on people currently being assisted by the programs involved. If we look at the proposals to cut expenditure, we see that they are, indeed, crude and callous. The nature of that is perhaps reflected in comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition recently in a speech in Brisbane. When talking about the public sector and the need to reduce it, he said, `The trouble with bureaucrats is they don't eat their young'. In relation to government programs, he said that the Government should be prepared to just chop them off at the knees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—This is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition describing, in a sophisticated way, the Opposition's approach to the public sector. Having made those sorts of comments, which describes the fine approach that the Opposition takes to this area, he immediately went on to talk about the Opposition's proposals for a $10 billion cut in government expenditure as evidence of that approach. This macho language is very revealing of the Opposition's utterly insensitive approach to the public sector. That insensitivity is something which is realised by people on the Opposition side and, in fact, by people in the office of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I have here a fax of yesterday's date which came to us—it obviously was not meant for us—from the office of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Reith. It is sent by a Mr David Turnbull to someone called Chris. It contains a transcript of the comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in that speech in Brisbane and an article from the Canberra Times reporting that speech. There are some remarks on the front page, presumably from David Turnbull. I quote:

ANSWER.PARA: Here's that article plus the transcript. I'm a bit worried they might just highlight the knees stuff if we give them the transcript!

I do not know who `them' was, but I can understand the sensitivity, because it is indeed incredibly crude stuff. The Opposition is, of course, about chopping off at the knees hundreds of thousands of people who would be affected by the programs that it would take the axe to.

PARA.TAB: Who are the people that the Opposition is going to chop off at the knees? They are the unemployed, certainly. The Opposition will end Job Search allowance after nine months. Yes, one can get special benefit if one is destitute, but one has to be destitute first. It will wipe out all of the job subsidy programs and bring in Austrain or `Aus-slave', in which people work for 20 per cent less than the award rate. So those involved in our job subsidy programs will certainly be cut off at the knees. The Opposition will increase the waiting period for Job Search allowance and sickness allowance from one week to three weeks effectively, making it a five week wait.

Obviously, the unemployed are among the people who will get chopped off at the knees. They will also lose the CES as a job placement centre. That will all cease and go off to the private sector or will not occur at all, so their chances of getting a job will be greatly reduced. Sole parents with children 12 and over will lose their benefits, so 16 per cent of them, or 42,000, will be affected. Sole parents will get chopped off at the knees. Disability pensioners, people with up to 70 per cent impairment, which includes paraplegics, will be made to undertake annual medical reviews to save $70m. So they will get chopped off at the knees. The people who rely on bulkbilling—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—Mr Speaker, standing order 145 clearly requires that an answer shall be relevant to the question. The Minister has in his answer strayed way beyond the original question. I remind you, Mr Speaker, that Speaker Snedden asked Ministers to remain relevant on 14 occasions and you have asked on only two.
—Order! The honourable member has made his point of order. He will resume his seat.

—I was saying that the non-cardholders who rely on bulkbilling would lose that under this program and the Medicare rebate would be cut from 85 per cent to 75 per cent. So people using Medicare, which is just about everybody apart from the cardholders, would be worse off. Migrants would get no benefits at all in the first two years after arrival. They would obviously be chopped off at the knees. Importantly, perhaps, in the current context, Aboriginal programs would be cut by $90m. At a time when this Government is responding to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Atkinson

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It relates to standing order 145 and relevance. I draw your attention to standing order 142 in expressing that. I point out that that standing order says:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.
I would suggest that the information being conveyed, if you would like to term it that way, by the Minister for Finance is totally inappropriate and therefore out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has made his point. The Minister for Finance was asked a question about public outlays. The Minister will answer the question.
—As I was saying, in the area of Aboriginal affairs the Opposition program involves a cut of $90m when this Government—
—A point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Here is the expert.
—No, I just like the Standing Orders.
—Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister has now strayed into the area of Aboriginal affairs. That is clearly not an area of his responsibility.
—Order! The Minister for Finance was asked a question about public outlays; the Minister is answering about public outlays. The Minister for Finance is in order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have finished this answer long ago had it not been for all these points of order.

—Opposition members obviously do not want to hear about their candidate for Wills, because his comment in a letter to the Prime Minister that he wants to cut social welfare payments by 30 per cent is a horrendous position to hold. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—There is a fundamental point that needs to be understood about the GST debate. PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If business hangs on to $20 billion, the CPI effects would be double digit. The Opposition wants to have its cake and eat it. It wants to say that there is a $20 billion benefit to business and then presume, as the Treasury has presumed—relying on the Treasury presumption—that it is all passed through to lower prices to produce 3.6 per cent. But, if it is not all passed through to lower prices—if business hangs on to the $20 billion—we would be back to double digit inflation. Again, duplicity and dishonesty in the claims by the Opposition! It is either a $20 billion bonus for business and double digit inflation or a pass through of the $20 billion to consumers, as the Treasury has said. Treasury has presumed that every cent of it is passed through to lower prices. It has presumed—

—Order! The House will come to order!
—You don't like that.
—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will cease interjecting.

—If such things as lower petrol prices and payroll taxes are not passed on to consumers but hung on to by business, the CPI effects must be in double digits. Treasury has done the decent thing and presumed every cent of it is passed on to produce the 3.6 per cent. We know that even under ideal conditions not every cent would be passed on; that the 3.6 per cent is a myth. The Opposition is now claiming that there is a $20 billion bonus for business—but the GST raises only $27 billion. So, if it is a 15 per cent tax on all goods as a final tax to raise $27 billion, but $20 billion of the $27 billion is transferred to business, I leave it to you to make the CPI estimates—but they must be double digit.
—You are ignorant.
—I am ignorant, he says.
—You are.
—Instead of exhorting me to tell the truth, start telling the truth yourself.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chaney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Pearce will cease interjecting.

—Will the Treasurer inform the House of the implications for small business of the Government's recent decisions relating to wholesale sales tax? How will this compare with those in other countries?

—I did announce today that the Government has completed the simplification review of the wholesale sales tax, foreshadowed by the Prime Minister when Treasurer in the 1990-91 Budget. The review has involved the most comprehensive examination of the sales tax ever undertaken. The Government has decided to introduce major new measures to simplify and improve the wholesale sales tax system. As I announced earlier today, the main features of the new measures are a significant reduction—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Can I presume you will allow policy announcements to be made in Question Time in this way?
—Order! The Minister has said that he has already made the announcement. He is now elucidating—
—He is making it in the House for the first time.
—Order! The Minister is commenting on an announcement that he has made.

—The measures include a significant reduction in the number of persons required to pay sales tax. The Government has decided to provide a new concession for small business which will give taxpayers with an annual sales tax liability of less than $10,000 the option to be outside the sales tax law. There has also been a complete restructure and a rewrite of the legislation, which will reduce the number of Acts from 27 to six.

PARA.TAB: There will be a streamlining of the system for requiring business inputs and other conditionally exempt goods free of tax, and there will be a significant strengthening of the anti-avoidance provisions of the law. The new measures will reduce the cost of administering and complying with the wholesale sales tax. The small business tax concession is a major initiative designed to assist small business and will lead to more efficient and effective—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you will recall that during his term in this House the former member for Reid, repeatedly during the days of the coalition Government, suggested that comments made on matters of this ilk where there has been a press statement relating to a major policy issue were not matters to be raised in Question Time.
—What is the point of order?

—I suggest to you that this type of policy statement is quite contrary to the concepts of this place. It should be made by way of a ministerial statement, and past Speakers have always required that it be so.
—Order! The Minister has said that he made an announcement this morning. He has been asked for comment on that, and the Minister is commenting on it.
—He has made no statement here.
—Not in this place.
—Order!
—Mr Speaker, I am not reading a ministerial statement. A press statement was released earlier today. I have a copy of it here, and I am perfectly happy to table it. I table it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Now sit down!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Now I will answer the question, which asked for some comments on the statement. I will be more than delighted to respond, particularly to the last bit of the question of the honourable member for Hunter, which asked me to observe the benefits for small business which might be included in these initiatives compared with those proposed elsewhere, particularly from those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The point is this: there are about 800,000 small businesses in Australia, and at the moment there are about 70,000 wholesale sales tax payers, so already very few small businesses are included amongst those who are wholesale sales tax payers. Of the 70,000, we have now provided an opportunity for the exemption of 54,000, or 77 per cent. In other words, there will now be fewer than 20,000 wholesale sales tax payers out of 800,000 small businesses and, of course, more than that in terms of businesses as a whole. This means a dramatic reduction in the administrative load that the wholesale sales tax imposes upon business, and particularly small business. This is to be compared with what is proposed on the other side where, of course—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were asked about other countries.
—Well, what happens, Professor, is that—
—Answer the question.
—I am, Professor, and I make the point in this way—
—Order! The Minister will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—The honourable member for Goldstein says that I should relate the answer to other countries. Of course, the whole point about the Opposition proposals is that they are not unique or original. They have been picked up and cobbled together from the experiences of various other countries.

PARA.TAB: Since the honourable member for Goldstein invites me to do so, I might just make a comment on the British system, the value added tax, and the cost of compliance to small business as a result of that tax. A study by Professor Sandford says that the cost in Britain for small business—the cost of compliance, not paying the VAT—is #7.80 for each 1,000 pounds of goods sold, whereas for large business it is only 3p per #1,000.

So there is an enormous imposition in administration costs, the compliance cost for small business. This is a compliance task, an objective which the Opposition now has for every business in Australia large and small, but it will impact differentially and more excessively on smaller business in the same way as it does in Britain, as evidenced by the study by Professor Sandford.

We have seen exactly the same evidence coming out of Canada, another country which members of the Opposition have decided to exemplify. They boasted that a tax official from Canada came out here to tell them how to do it, and there are studies showing what an enormous impact it is having on business in Canada. Similarly in New Zealand, another country which they are trying to exemplify in more ways than one, accountants are advising businesses in Australia that they should pick up the idea of a consumption tax in Australia only if they want to abolish their Sunday leisure time, because it will take all their Sundays and not a few dollars in order to comply with the provisions of the Opposition's proposed consumption tax.

The Opposition has become fond of quoting Senator Peter Walsh recently. I will refer to one observation that he made on 11 February this year. When talking about small business, he said, `For them'—that is, for small business—`voting for VAT'—as Senator Walsh calls the GST—`is akin to turkeys voting for Christmas'.
