DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith—That the Speaker no longer possesses the confidence of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, and reserve my right to speak.
—Mr Speaker, we will take the want of confidence motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Speaker no longer possesses the confidence of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not take this step lightly, because this is a very special motion about one of the very special, most important positions in our Parliament, namely, the role of the Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—It is absolutely essential that the Speaker performs the role of an independent umpire in the course of the conduct of the Parliament.
—Order! The member for Calwell will cease interjecting.
—So far this year, since this man took over as Prime Minister, this House has just become an absolute shambles.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, without any exaggeration, you are a national disgrace.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never seen in living memory the extent of the blatant bias and manipulation of parliament to the advantage of this Government.
—Hypocrite!

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I have never seen in living memory the extent to which you favour that side, the Government side of the Parliament—
—Liar!
—at the expense of the Opposition.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The member for the Northern Territory will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Let me give you a couple of examples of what has happened in the course of this two-week parliamentary sitting. We have seen Question Time simply used as a device for the Government to bucket the Opposition rather than debate policy issues or to answer detailed policy questions.
—You have set this up.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—If Question Time is to have any meaning in this Parliament—I suggest it should have some very real meaning in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years—it should provide the Opposition with an opportunity to cross-examine the Government and a reasonable expectation should be that the Government will answer the questions in the best interests of the people of Australia because, after all, we are asking these questions on behalf of the people of Australia. Yet in the last two-week parliamentary sitting, not counting today, of 68 questions 55 were nothing less than a total bucket job on the Opposition with no serious attempt to answer any of the questions that were made.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—In fact, if we look at the last six parliamentary sitting days before today, we see that the Speaker has warned or threatened to name 52 members of this Parliament: all of them on this side of the Parliament; none of them on that side of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, if we go back over the time between when you became Speaker in August 1989 to the beginning of the current sitting of the Parliament, we find that the honourable member for Grayndler, as Speaker, has warned honourable members of this House on 218 occasions. Of those warnings, 98 per cent were to members on this side of the House and less than 2 per cent affected those on the other side of the House. The Opposition has very limited—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a disgrace.
—The Opposition has very limited scope—
—You are a disgrace.
—Order!
—Don't call me a disgrace, son; you're the disgrace.
—Name him!
—Order!
—Why don't you name him?
—Order!
—Warn him!
—Order! The House will come to order!
—Why don't you name him?
—You are a disgrace.
—Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my left are just taking up their allocated time.

—Mr Speaker, prove to us once and for all that you can be objective. Name the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for what he just said. Just prove that for once in your life you can be objective. Prove that you can be objective.

PARA.TAB: In Question Time yesterday we had a situation which was an absolute farce, a total farce, where you called on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to withdraw a remark. He did not withdraw that remark. In fact, he gave you the nod that you were not to question or cross-examine him at all. So you went through this unbelievable farce of changing your version of events in a series of explanations in the course of a series of points of order to try to let that Prime Minister off the hook.

You started out, as soon as the statement was made that I was a fraud and a cheat, by asking the Prime Minister to withdraw those remarks. By the end of the period of time I am describing, you had moved to a position where you had not heard them. That was the next stage. You said that, if the Prime Minister had said something that was unparliamentary, he should withdraw it. You then went on to claim that you had asked the Prime Minister whether that was the case. He said no, so that he did not have to withdraw it. What an amazing farce! You are a national disgrace in the most important institution in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who voted for him on your side?
—Order! The honourable member for Banks will cease interjecting.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Name him, name him!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Speaker, here is your second test: name that honourable member, too.

—Order! I remind honourable members on both sides that they should cease interjecting and, to honourable members on my left who seem to think that an honourable member should be named, I say that on all occasions I have issued a warning before I have named a person. I warned the honourable member for Mayo twice today.
—Not today.
—Twice.
—Not today.
—Twice today. Indeed, if honourable members on my left had not been interjecting so much, the honourable member for Mayo might have heard it. It was certainly heard by everybody else.

—That was yesterday. We have seen evidence in recent days that you have trouble with your hearing. But I am trying to make the point that you are one-eyed when it comes to the conduct of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has very limited power in this Parliament to encourage you to take a sense of balance in the proceedings of this House. The only standing order that relates to answers is standing order 145 on the issue of relevance. That is the only way in which we can urge you to try to exert some balance in this Parliament and to pull a Government Minister into line when that person is absolutely flouting the procedures of this House.

Yet consistently, almost without exception, you have allowed Ministers to ramble on for whatever length of time they have wanted to take and to make policy announcements when they should be doing so by way of ministerial statement. Yet, on every occasion when we on this side of the House try to stand up to take a point of order under standing order 145 on relevance, you have not even let us finish the point of order. I do not know how you can do it. I have no idea how you can conclude what our point of order will be before you have heard it.

That has been a characteristic of your performance in recent days. That is a part of the disgrace that we are debating today: the fact that you draw conclusions about what we are trying to do in terms of raising a point of order before you have even bothered to listen. You snarl and yell; you break up the debate; you single us out, if you like, for disrupting Parliament. In the same week as you did that, for example, you allowed the Prime Minister to stand up and do bird calls in this House. If that is not disrupting Parliament, I do not know what is. The fact is, Mr Speaker, that you have consistently failed in your duty to provide a fair go for both sides of this Parliament in the conduct of the daily proceedings of this House.

We need to step back and ask ourselves why this Speaker behaves the way he does. We work on the principle that the Speaker takes on a responsibility to be independent and objective. When we look into the reasons why, we find that they have nothing to do with the interests of Australia but have to do with the interests of a couple of mates, the mateship between you and the Prime Minister.
Mr Speaker, you can probably remember back to 1986 when there was an incident in this House and the Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, had you down to his office and—I forget the press description—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bounced him around the walls.

—Bounced you around the walls—I think that is probably the way it was described—because you had not offered him sufficient protection in this Parliament. I have never seen anybody offered the extent of protection you offer this Prime Minister. He stands up here on a daily basis and flouts every conceivable sense of propriety in this Parliament, and you allow him to get away with it. Indeed, he dictates to you how you should conduct this House. You see the nod, you see the wink, you see the twitch, you see the direct instructions—things like, `It is a frivolous point of order; name him', and all this sort of thing, coming from the Prime Minister to you on a regular basis.

PARA.TAB: We have sat here and noticed how on many occasions you have sat there and waited until you received that instruction before you moved in relation to this side of the Parliament. This has been a consistent feature of your performance, and it has heightened in the last few weeks as the pressure in Wills has built up and the uncertainty of your personal preselection has come to a head.

The Prime Minister has become—what were the words used yesterday?—subject to violent mood swings, of course under the pressure of what is happening in Wills, and you, Mr Speaker, have started to feel the real pressure concerning your preselection and the fact that the Left has control of the seat of Grayndler and you are about to be a lame duck Speaker. Today I am giving the Left a very real opportunity not to wait for preselection. The members of the Left can express their point today in support of getting rid of this man by voting with us on this motion of no confidence in the Speaker. I ask them to think seriously about that. It is a unique opportunity that they can take to express a view. I know that there are some very sensible, measured and honest people on the other side of this Parliament, and I know that they too have been totally offended by the behaviour of this man in the course of the last few months as Speaker.

I return, though, to the mateship. It is the mateship with the New South Wales Right that has taken control of this Parliament. That mateship has never been in the interests of the people of Australia. I do not think you have ever focused on what is in the best interests of the people of Australia. As we have gone out of our way in recent days to establish, you will say or do anything, you will distort or misrepresent anything, you will bend any principle—it does not matter what it takes—in order to save your own political hide.

Right now, when your own political hide is at risk and you desperately need the support of the Prime Minister and the other members of the New South Wales Right, you have blatantly and overtly bowed in favour of the Government in all your rulings in the course of the conduct of this Parliament, to the point where the Parliament is no more than a total shambles and an embarrassment to the people of Australia, who sit back and watch the televised proceedings of the Parliament every night and cannot understand how, in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years, with one million people unemployed, you have no interest in those issues. The Government has no interest in those issues; you have no interest in ensuring that Ministers answer questions about those issues.

It is little wonder that the standing of both sides of this Parliament has been called into disrespect in the eyes of the Australian people—and a substantial part of the responsibility for that goes right to you. You are the one who has the unique position, despite the extent to which you try from time to time to hide behind Standing Orders, and the power to actually make the rulings you want to make in the interpretation of Standing Orders to maintain control of this Parliament. There is nothing to stop you actually exercising the power that is necessary to maintain a sense of order and a sense of balance in this Parliament. I have no better authority for that than the ex-Clerk of the House, Mr Browning, who has gone out of his way on several occasions to make that particular point.

You duck and weave and hide behind particular interpretations of the Standing Orders which favour the Government side of the House. You do not try to strike a balance or to maintain any sense of decorum and decency in this Parliament. You allow conduct which is totally unbecoming in this Parliament and which has brought us all into total disrepute. This mateship is the central element of what dominates this Parliament today. We should not forget that the New South Wales Right is the nearest thing this country has had to the Mafia in decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the blokes in Boggo Road gaol.
—The New South Wales Right stretches from our gaols, in certain parts of Australia, right through to the top office in this land—the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Ask Peter Baldwin!

PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER—Order!
Honourable members—Name him!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to name the honourable member for Higgins.
—You do every other day.
—I will now, if he wants me to.

—To members of the New South Wales Right, their particular end justifies the means. They see everything as a political game, a political power play. The characteristics of the behaviour of the New South Wales Right are now manifested in the Speaker of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The basic attitudes and values that you people have pursued in the course of your own political efforts over the years go all the way from when you used to sit in Paul Keating's front yard and discuss political tactics through to today. Those same basic values, those same basic attitudes and that same basic focus on your own particular interests at the expense of everybody else is what dominates your behaviour in this House, and it is what dominates the conduct of the daily business in this Parliament. That is another element of why you, sir, are a national disgrace.

I have heard you on many occasions stand up and say how proud you are that a Telecom linesman could rise to the position of Speaker of this Parliament. I think you should just stop and think what the responsibilities really are in relation to the position of Speaker of this Parliament. It is not just a personal grab for power; it is just not an opportunity to wallow in the trappings of the office; it is a very special position in this Parliament. You will go down in history as probably one of the worst Speakers of all time.

Since 1901 only about 10 speakers have been censured by this Parliament, and you have got up there three times. Three of the 10 have been you and today is the fourth: four out of 11. That is a clear-cut statement that you do not perform the duties that have been entrusted in you as the central element of the conduct of our system of parliamentary democracy. As I make these points to you, Mr Speaker, I ask you to think about your own personal position. You are so very conscious and so very proud of what you have achieved. You just think of how history will record your time as Speaker. History will record you as one of the worst Speakers that this Parliament has seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —The worst.

—If, indeed, not the worst Speaker that this Parliament has seen. We come here today on a very important issue when we censure the Speaker. We are very concerned about the fact that the reputation of this institution, which is the centrepiece of our whole system, has been dragged so far down into disrepute.

PARA.TAB: I have seen recent examples of where we as politicians are ranked in the eyes of the electorate. We are ranked below the press gallery, to give you some idea of how low we have been dragged. But I should be fair: the television media are ranked above us and the print media are ranked below us in the last survey that I saw, but we are down near the bottom.

People in the community, in Wills, for example, or in other parts of Australia, who are queuing up to get their unemployment benefits, who are going into various welfare agencies to get assistance or who are facing the cold, hard reality of financial crisis as a result of the worst recession in 60 years—one inflicted on them by a government and by one particular individual who pursued his own political ends, in the same way as you have, at the expense of everyone else—cannot understand why this Parliament has been dragged down as far as it has been.

I believe that we all now have a very serious responsibility, and I hope that today is a turning point in this respect. We face the need to significantly upgrade the standards and performance in this Parliament. I make the very simple point that there are three people that can actually make the change in the Parliament that has to be made and who are essential to making that change. They are the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and the Speaker. We are quite happy to do our part, and we have been doing our part in the course of the last two years. We have pursued many opportunities to raise parliamentary standards, only to see them dragged down in the pursuit of particular personal political ends by the Speaker and the Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —You?
—You have got to be joking.
—Order! There is far too much noise. The honourable member for Moreton will cease interjecting.

—to the point now where the people of Australia justifiably hold us in total disrespect. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that your behaviour in the course of the last few months in particular has pulled this Parliament down to those depths. This is at a time when the electorate is crying out for leadership and crying out for us to deal with the problems that beset this economy. It is fundamentally important that we face the reality of where we have arrived in terms of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I challenge you, Mr Speaker, to significantly lift your game and I challenge the Government to think about the ridiculous extent to which it has gone in recent days to grossly distort and misrepresent what should be a very genuine and very important policy debate. We have led the way; we have put detailed policy proposals on the record; we have been prepared to debate those as genuine issues. All we have seen has been a policy, facilitated by the Speaker, of gross misrepresentation and distortion, and we have seen a couple of examples by the Prime Minister in the course of this particular Question Time. It is a ridiculous situation where the issues are not being addressed and where the people of Australia simply cannot understand it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Our case rests on your conduct, Mr Speaker, at the very opening of this particular debate when, once again, you allowed Government Ministers and Government members to interrupt continually, and you allowed a disgraceful conduct of this debate to develop from the start.

PARA.TAB: Our case rests on several counts, Mr Speaker: firstly, your total failure in the handling of Question Time; secondly, your total failure with regard to the conduct and consideration of points of order; thirdly, your failure to properly administer the provisions of Standing Orders regarding suspensions; fourthly, your entering into the debate from the chair on repeated occasions; fifthly, your repeated failure to stand up to Ministers and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when fairness demanded that you should do so; sixthly, your failure to deal properly with the question of relevance; and seventhly, your failure to listen to the points being put by honourable members on both sides of the House when they rise, quite properly, under Standing Orders. It is clear from the events of this and most recent sitting weeks that all sense of fairness and justice has evaporated, as has been pointed out very capably by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). This is the citadel of parliamentary democracy. It is not the cauldron of the New South Wales Right.

The House is considering today one of the most serious motions ever to arise; namely, the want of confidence in the Speaker of the House. It is not moved lightly; it is moved only after the most severe provocations over weeks and months, and a deterioration which has occurred since you, Mr Speaker, have become the Speaker of this House. In this regard, let me say, firstly, that you are the custodian of the rights and privileges of all honourable members of the House, not just the Ministers and Prime Ministers who form the Executive Government before this House. It is necessary to ensure that this balance is maintained in your dealing to handle the proper workings of the Parliament.

It is in this context that I want to examine specifically those areas of specific charge that we make against you. Firstly, I deal with the conduct of Question Time. Is it fair and just that we can have Minister after Minister giving extended answer after extended answer without even an attempt by you to bring their answer to a close with a proper sense of fairness and justice?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we cannot expect him.

—We cannot expect it. Indeed, Derek Parker in an article written in February 1989, when you were just Chairman of Committees, focused on the deterioration of Question Time, which has gone downhill steadily since that time.

PARA.TAB: Let me remind the House that even Speaker Joan Child on 12 February 1986 had the courage to say to the then Prime Minister during an extensive answer, `The Prime Minister is now curtailing his answer'. Then she went on and said, `The Prime Minister will now finish his answer'. That is what Speaker Child had the courage to do in her lonely work as the first female Speaker of this Parliament. That is something you have never had the courage to do, Mr Speaker, and on which you stand found guilty for your conduct in conducting Question Time.

There has been a steady decline in the number of questions, until even the Government's sensitivities were offended. You might remember that under Prime Minister Hawke we suddenly had the necessity to adopt an arrangement where Question Time went longer than 45 minutes and we on this side of the House would be given seven questions, no matter how long it took. But even that operation, even that convention, even that understanding, has now gone by the board as a direct consequence of Prime Minister Keating. It is down to two, three or four questions for every three-quarters of an hour. It is not our fault. We get just 30 seconds, at best 60 seconds, to put the question. We then get irrelevant replies that go for five or 10 minutes and that you, Mr Speaker, allow to continue in a way which is totally unacceptable.

I turn to points of order, our one opportunity to raise matters properly and fairly in terms of your conduct of the House and to assist you to make rulings and take a stand in the interests of parliamentary democracy and fairness of play. What do we have in respect of points of order? You do not hear out the presentation of the point of order. We saw an example of that today when you chopped off members in presenting points of order, including the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). Quite often you do not even bother to rule on them, but just call the Minister back to the dispatch box. Worse still, when you do rule and say the point of order is not sustained, you rarely give a reason.

Over 22 years I have served under a number of Speakers, both in the ultimate bear pit—the New South Wales Legislative Assembly—and in the Federal Parliament since 1984. Never have I seen a Speaker as bad as this Speaker. Never have I seen a Speaker so rarely get to his feet when the situation requires that he get to his feet and command respect for the office of Speaker, which has to be granted. Why? Because he likes to let it flow, as he admitted in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. He lets it flow one way, unfairly, unjustifiably, totally towards the Government and stacked against the Opposition.

I point out to the House that this is not the centre of the MCG, the SCG, the WACA or the Gabba; it is the centre of parliamentary democracy in Australia. But time after time you give biased rulings on points of order without even listening to the whole structure and presentation that honourable members seek to make on their points of order. You have failed in these custodial duties and in the maintenance of these conventions, written and unwritten, which are the cement, if you like, or the glue, which provides cohesion to the working of parliamentary democracy and which you, Mr Speaker, have wrecked in terms of the conduct of this Parliament. Let me turn to the suspension of members. I sought information, quite properly, from the Acting Clerk, and I received a letter dated 27 November 1991. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Fischer,
Our records reveal that since becoming Speaker—
and up till that point in time—
Mr McLeay has named eight members who have been suspended.

Let me ask those present in the gallery how fair they might think this is: seven of them were in fact from the coalition and just one was from the Government. That is not a bad ratio. This year we have had another two from our side of the House, so the ratio is nine on this side sent to the sin bin and further and just one on the Government side.

PARA.TAB: I think there would be an absolute riot at the SCG or the Sydney football ground if there were rulings from a referee in that ratio. It is not acceptable for the Leader of the Government to mutter under his breath about this and to argue that the reason it is so lopsided is that we are misbehaving more. That is absolute garbage. It is a tilt given by the Speaker with regard to these rulings which causes a very unfair ratio to unfold in terms of the suspension of members.

We then had interventions by you from the chair in debates in the Parliament. I want to give two examples. The first is when you were the Chairman of Committees. You said on 20 May 1986 when sitting in the chair of this Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to add my warm regards to the Minister on the passage of this legislation which builds on the landmark work he did in this area in a previous Labor Government.

Okay; we might tolerate such a one-off, as it gets very boring sitting there in the chair. But let me come to the statement you made on 18 September 1990 as Speaker of this House, sitting in the chair, dealing with legislation. You lent forward and said—and it is recorded in Hansard:
Members might be attracted to the view of the member for Barton and myself in relation to the third runway, namely, opposition to the third runway at Mascot.
Mr Speaker, that is what you said from the chair. You had a right to take off your wig—if you wore it—step out of the chair, come to the despatch box and make a speech from there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was said in jest and you know it.
—Order!

—The honourable member for Barton is a bit sensitive about the third runway. Let me remind the honourable member for Barton that it is going to cost him his seat for all the reasons he does not think it will.
—Do you want to bet?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party might get back to the matter. I do not think he is after the honourable member for Barton today.
—In the same period the Kuwaiti international airport was closed, destroyed, rebuilt and reopened, the Government is yet to shift one tonne of dirt to build the third runway at Mascot.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party is talking about a censure motion involving the Speaker, not about the third runway.
—And I am talking about you intervening from the chair, Mr Speaker.
—I am intervening from the chair to bring you back to the matter before the House.

—And let us come right back to the matter before the House. Let us say that you no longer have the confidence of this House to carry out the duties of the Speaker of this House. It is tragic that you have allowed the situation to reach the stage that it has this day, culminating, quite properly, in a legitimate motion of no confidence in you as Speaker.

PARA.TAB: The absolute crime that we on this side of the House charge you with today in respect of this no confidence motion is your repeated failure to stand up to Ministers, to clearly object to and reject the pressure, direct and indirect, which Ministers place on you. I understand that there has been a bevy of notes flowing between the Chair and the Minister even in the course of this particular debate. Let me simply say, Mr Speaker, that you not only have to be fair but have to be seen to be fair with regard to the conduct of the Chair, and you have repeatedly failed to be seen to be fair in terms of the body language directions which have flowed from the front bench, in terms of the other directions which have been meted out to you in your own office, as we have read and as has been referred to by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in relation to your whole conduct as Speaker of this House.

I simply say to the House and say to you that you have failed in your duties as custodian of the rights and privileges of all members of the Parliament. You have failed in preserving the duties of the office of the Speaker developed over centuries, especially to act on balance and with balance, especially against the excesses of the Executive.

We look to you, Mr Speaker, to take a reasonable stand on behalf of all honourable members, all backbenchers on both sides of the House, particularly in regard to the dominant role of Ministers and Prime Ministers, yet you have failed to uphold the Standing Orders and to uphold the conventions which might bring that about.

I have to say that I accept that, under the Australian application of the Westminster system, you must maintain a party connection. I understand that this is occupying your mind a great deal at this time as the matter of pre-selection is dealt with, but I have to say to you also that that does not extend to your actions and to your conduct in the chair of this House. That, sir, charges you with responsibilities which have been developed over centuries, which have been developed in Australia since 1901 and which require of you absolute fairness, not only in terms of your direct deliberations, your direct determinations on the floor of the House, but also in terms of the upholding of all the conventions which apply to the conduct of the Speaker.

I have to say further, Mr Speaker, that I acknowledge the fact that you have put a great deal of effort into aspects of the Speaker's office. I acknowledge the work you have done with regard to inter-parliamentary relations—the CPA, the IPU and the like—but all of that pales into insignificance when we come to the fundamental question of what happens in the House at the most critical time in the deliberations of the House. The question is: how do you handle the conduct of the House and maintain the freedom, rights and privileges of honourable members on both sides of the House? That is where you have failed. You have failed to stand up to the Ministers; you have failed in the conduct of Question Time; you have failed in the handling of points of orders; and you have failed in the handling of suspensions. You have entered debate from the chair in a disgraceful way and you have failed to stand up and listen to members and consider what they have put before the House.

I understand that the Leader of the House ( Mr Beazley) is going to reply in this critical debate. I have to say it is curious in the extreme that the Prime Minister has not chosen to enter into your defence in relation to this particular motion. I think it perhaps reflects the time. Perhaps it also reflects comments which go back to an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on 25 October 1988. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, Mr Keating, was reported in 1986 to have verbally "bounced" the Deputy Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay, "around the walls" for not affording Mr Keating enough protection during a debate in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating's actions would have been justified had they not been for his own benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The performance of Mr McLeay . . . is not good enough for Australia's Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Amen to that. Mr Speaker, your performance is not good enough for the Australian Parliament. It is not good enough for the House of Representatives at the height of a recession when we quite properly and legitimately want to raise the fact that yet another factory closed yesterday in Albury, costing some 90 jobs. It is not good enough when you are supposed to be paving the way for the proper process of parliamentary democracy. It is for all of those reasons that you lack the confidence of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just point out for the benefit of honourable members that the Speaker is not able to participate in this debate and, according to tradition, the Leader of the House will enter the debate on the Speaker's behalf.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the defence of you is a very easy task to undertake in this place. This motion—the proponents of which are now leaving the chamber as I speak, so seriously do they take it—was conceived in hypocrisy and ignorance.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House will resume his seat for a moment. I must say that, bearing in mind that the Speaker himself cannot participate in the debate, we should at least hear the Leader of the House in silence or I will name anyone from either side who interjects.

—As I said, this motion was conceived in hypocrisy and ignorance. Where did this hypocrisy stem from? I think, in his soul, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) knows where it stems from because when he talked about those who were responsible for the conduct of this Parliament and named three officials whom he regarded as being responsible, he named himself as one of them and suggested that he might be obliged to lift his game in that regard. In fact, he is wrong when he says that three people are responsible for the conduct of this House. Some 147 people are responsible for the conduct of this House, and some 146 owe respect to the Chair. At least 50-odd on the other side of this House have displayed none of that since the day this Government came to office. I will go through that in some detail later.

PARA.TAB: When the Leader of the Opposition became the Leader of the Opposition he made a song and dance about how he was going to lift the parliamentary standards of this place. I welcome his confession that he has not; nevertheless, because he is prepared to confess that he has failed in that regard on his part, it does not absolve him from some discussion of it in the course of this debate.

Everybody who sits in this chamber at Question Time knows that throughout Question Time the Leader of the Opposition sits there and persistently heckles speakers at the despatch box. He is not brought to book because the Speaker, following past traditions, gives a very wide berth to the Leader of the Opposition and his own personal conduct in this place. Every now and then he goes over the top and is dealt with. I sat behind Bill Hayden when he was Leader of the Opposition in times that were as troubled as these, and I never saw conduct from Bill Hayden—now the Governor-General—that in any way, shape or form matched the performance that we have had from the Leader of the Opposition in Question Time in this place. He, personally, is utterly disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's your biased opinion.
—Order!
—Then there comes the question of ignorance, but I will get to that a little later because I want to say something more on the question of hypocrisy, and that goes to the development of his motion.
—That's a memory lapse.
—If the honourable member for Hume walks around the chamber interjecting, I will deal with him. Resume your seat or leave the chamber.

—The member who moved this motion and every other honourable member in this House will have noted one thing about it. The speech of the Leader of the Opposition—who is not in this chamber to listen to it being opposed—is replete with a description of the conduct of this Question Time as part of the basis on which the want of confidence motion was moved.

PARA.TAB: It is of passing interest that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), in seconding the motion, managed to read the bulk of his speech from a typed script. Either this was a thought-out, got-up motion for this particular occasion, or there is a miraculous typist sitting in the office of the Leader of the National Party. If that person lets us know who he or she is, he or she will receive a heck of a lot better offers than he or she currently has in working for the Leader of the National Party.

The Opposition has been letting it be known around the gallery—in utter contempt of this chamber—that it intended to move a want of confidence motion against the Speaker here today. So the maintenance of the view that the censure of the Speaker has somehow been thrust forth from a welling of sympathy or an outbreak of sheer misery as part of the Opposition's concern at the conduct of this Question Time is of course an act of total hypocrisy.

A couple of things might be said about one or two people who have been suspended from this place. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is no longer with us, but the situation of the honourable member for Mayo has been cited as an example of the unfairness of the Speaker. It is said that the Speaker failed to warn the honourable member for Mayo before sending him out of the House for 24 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is warned every day.
—Order!
—The record will show that the honourable member for Mayo was warned twice during Question Time. So that piece of dissembling—that lie—
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. That piece of dissembling will be seen for what it is by all of those who read the parliamentary record today. Mr Speaker, people ought to recognise that the honourable member for Mayo has been warned 15 times by you since this part of the session began and 11 times by your deputies since this part of the session began. Perhaps there are one or two people around this chamber—apart from your good self, sir—who have had occasion to take umbrage at the attitude of the honourable member for Mayo in this place.

PARA.TAB: Why is somebody warned? Is he warned for sitting there listening to the discussion of the serious national issues that the Leader of the Opposition referred to? Is he warned for that? He is not; he is warned for being disruptive in this place. He is warned because his conduct in this place means that the business of this place cannot be conducted. That is why he is punted and that is why anybody who is suspended from this place is so suspended.

The Opposition tries to make the point that only one Government member has been suspended by the Speaker, but numerous Opposition members have been suspended. I have news for you: there is a pretty ample precedent for that. Only one Government member—those opposite were in government at the time—was suspended by Speaker Snedden, and a very substantial number of Opposition members, namely us, were suspended during his period of tenure. So that particular figure proves nothing, but I will tell honourable members a figure which does mean something. As was said by the Leader of the National Party when he commented on the Speaker's intention to allow a free flow of discussion in this place, part of that free flow extends to the unprecedented way in which the Opposition has been given liberal treatment as to what may be included in the questions that are asked in this House.

If I might take basic statistics to suggest that, I will go through a few. The `unfair' Speaker whom we have with us here today, according to this motion, has as of 2 April 1992 ruled out of order five Opposition questions and four from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what!

—I will get to the `So what!', my friend. Speaker Child ruled out 12 Opposition questions and eight from the Government. Speaker Jenkins ruled out one from the Opposition and nine from the Government.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Speaker Snedden ruled out 90 from the Opposition and 17 from the Government.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I well remember those occasions. These paragons of fairness, these hypocrites, who come into this place to cite their statistics to blackguard the reputation of the Speaker have that statistic to look at. I happen to be a personal victim of that statistic. I recollect on the odd occasion asking a question in the old Parliament House when Speaker Snedden was in the chair and being ruled out of order. I rose on those occasions to ask for an explanation of Speaker Snedden as to why I was out of order. There was not some sort of debate that took place as to why I was ruled out of order on that point of order; his response was, `The member knows why', and he proceeded to the next question.

PARA.TAB: When I asked my Whip, a robust person—who happens to have been a member of the New South Wales Right, now that it has been mentioned—Les Johnson, he said, `Don't be stupid. When the Speaker rules you out of order, you are simply out of order. He is not required to give you an explanation. That is it. You got up and made your point and he ruled you out of order. There is no requirement upon the Speaker to make an explanation of that. You as a member of parliament, young fellow, are supposed to know the Standing Orders and develop an understanding of them so that you will know whether you are right or wrong. It is not for the Speaker to explain it. The Speaker is there, elevated above the debate, to conduct the debate'.

The Opposition has developed a habit of debating points of order. That did not happen when I was in Opposition. Honourable members would never take a point of order that was accompanied by a raft of precedent. It is obviously sensible for the House to regard that sort of behaviour as disorderly. If that stands, it is obviously sensible for us not to proceed with any business of the Parliament, but to spend the whole day endlessly debating points of order. That, of course, disrupts the business of the House. And that, of course, is why the Opposition does it.

Many of those opposite have short memories, and very few of them were involved when the coalition was in office and were able to witness a situation in which an Opposition fairly dealt with by a Speaker has been drawn from this Government's ranks. An Opposition asks a whole series of questions that unquestionably contain argument, inferences, imputations, epithets, ironical expressions and hypothetical matter, and they are allowed. To have an even balance of questions ruled out of order between the Government and the Opposition would be unprecedented in the history of this Parliament, and certainly when we look at the record of Speaker Snedden, who ruled 90 Opposition members' questions out of order and 17 Government members' questions out of order.

The Opposition knows what its tactics have been since it came into this place. We have seen occasions here when the Opposition Leader has thought himself to be in trouble, gone to the Whip and had a whip-round on the back benches to get a bit of noise going in Question Time. More recently—and I suspect this is where this motion stems from—the Opposition front bench has been a little reluctant to engage in those sorts of tactics, and the tactics have been engaged in by members of the back bench who have been frustrated by the inability of their leaders to get a point across in Question Time, or any other time, and been worried increasingly by the implications of where their policies are taking them. They have started to be utterly disorderly.

The Leader of the National Party in this place said, `Mr Speaker, you do not rise to your feet often enough'. If that is a criticism of the Speaker, he might like to take it on board. But the Leader of the National Party has a very short memory. Yesterday the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) was allowed a holiday from this chamber for 24 hours. Why was he allowed that holiday? Because he persisted in standing while the Speaker was standing. Having been warned by the Speaker to take his seat, he failed to uphold the Speaker's position on that occasion when he was conducting a practice which the Leader of the National Party demanded he undertake. The Leader of the National Party voted against the Speaker on that matter. That is another manifestation of the hypocrisy of the Opposition when it comes to debating this matter in this chamber.

Fundamentally, the problem of the Opposition is ignorance. Those opposite do not understand that in the parliamentary process we do not go through endless debates and discussions on points of order in Question Time. That is simply not done. Furthermore, the Opposition does not understand the withdrawal process itself. Any member may take offence at any matter that is directed at himself but, if a third person takes offence from that interchange, the words used must be unparliamentary to allow that third person to intervene.

Yesterday, great umbrage was taken at the Speaker because he allegedly failed to call upon the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to withdraw the expression `cheat'. Where has `cheat' been used recently? The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said:

SPEECH.PARA: What absolute nonsense! Government members lie and cheat.
Was he asked to withdraw `cheat'? No, he was not. The Leader of the Opposition said this about the Prime Minister:
. . . he will lie, he will cheat, he will misrepresent. . .

What was he required to withdraw? `He will lie'. Opposition members are utterly in ignorance of parliamentary procedure in this place. In their ignorance lies their multiplicity of acts of disturbance of the good conduct of the business of this House.

PARA.TAB: This motion, conceived in hypocrisy, manufactured in ignorance, is a disgusting piece of work by the Leader of the Opposition in this place, who has been disgustingly hypocritical when it comes to dealing with decent Standing Orders in this place. Opposition members are contemptible people, and the House will now reject their contemptible motion. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following reports: report No. 314 entitled Eighth Performance Audits and report No. 315 entitled Social responsibilities of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make some brief comments in relation to the two reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts as outlined. I will deal, firstly, with report No. 314 entitled Eighth Performance Audits. Under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, the Committee is required to examine all reports of the Auditor-General, including reports of efficiency audits. In report No. 314 the Committee examines eight reports of the Auditor-General covering the period from May to November 1990. These Auditor-General's reports cover a variety of programs and departments, including the Department of Veterans' Affairs; the Department of Employment, Education and Training; the Department of Community Services and Health; and the Department of Social Security.

PARA.TAB: The departmental responses to the Auditor-General's recommendations are as follows. The responses by departments to the audit reports and recommendations were encouraging, with most of the recommendations being accepted by the auditees. Only two matters are highlighted in the Committee's report as needing further attention, and both relate to the use of internal audit by government agencies.

The Committee notes that a major activity currently being undertaken by the Australian National Audit Office is the survey of internal audit in the Commonwealth public sector. The Auditor-General has reported on stage 1 of the survey, with the second and final report expected in June this year. The survey found that 70 per cent of Commonwealth departments and agencies had internal audit units and that, overall, internal audit activity resulted in improved efficiency within departments.

The Committee considers that internal audit activity is critical to the efficiency of a department and its accountability to parliament and has recommended in this report that new financial administration legislation requires that all Commonwealth organisations establish an effective internal audit function. Another recommendation relates to the need for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to strengthen its internal audit activity.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts plays an important role in stimulating efficient and effective use of public moneys through its scrutiny of Auditor-General's reports and departmental responses to his recommendations. The Committee believes that systematic follow-up of performance audits by the Audit Office is an essential adjunct to the Committee's scrutiny of performance audit reports. The Committee, in its report No. 296, made it clear that the Auditor-General should accept responsibility for the follow-up of his recommendations. The Audit Office has accepted that recommendation, as has the Government, by providing additional funds to the Audit Office for efficiency audits. The Committee notes, with approval, that the Audit Office has embarked on a program of follow-up audits, conducting four in 1991 and planning a further six in 1991-92.

I now wish to comment on the Committee's 315th report, entitled Social Responsibilities of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. This report is the result of the Committee's investigation of how statutory authorities and government business enterprises, known as GBEs, measure and report to the public and the Parliament on the performance of their social responsibilities. The report also records the Committee's conclusion that most government agencies still have some way to go before they perfect the use of performance measures and recommends ways in which this might be done.

Social responsibilities are defined in terms of the responsibilities of statutory authorities and GBEs towards their clients, their employees and the environment. Their responsibilities towards their clients include making their services as accessible as possible, having means available by which clients can provide input to the operations of statutory authorities and freedom of information. The social responsibilities of statutory authorities and GBEs towards their employees include: equal employment opportunity; occupational health and safety; training; and industrial democracy.

Some of these responsibilities are imposed on statutory authorities, while others are undertaken by them on a voluntary basis. Whether they are legally required or voluntarily assumed, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts believes that the nation's statutory authorities and GBEs should act in accordance with the highest possible standards. The Committee recognises that there may be pressures on commercially oriented agencies to concentrate on their commercial performance at the expense of their social responsibilities. It is essential, however, that this not happen.

To ensure that the government organisations act in a socially responsible manner and can demonstrate this to the public and the Parliament, the Committee is, firstly, recommending that social objectives be included amongst the corporate objectives of these organisations and, secondly, that progress in meeting all these objectives be reported in annual reports.

The Committee recommends that, in making their reports, whether annual reports to the Parliament or reports for other purposes, statutory authorities and GBEs should: compare performance with a standard or target; focus on outcomes; use several indicators for each program, retaining the same indicators over a number of years so that changes over time can be monitored; choose information to suit the needs of the user; and use both qualitative and quantitative information.

While recognising that there are limitations on the use of performance information, the Committee believes that agencies should strive for the best possible performance information and develop expertise amongst their staff in the development and use of the performance information.

The Committee's report provides detailed recommendations about the nature of the information that should be reported in relation to EEO, training, access to services, activities that impact on the environment, and the activities of consultative groups, including those of statutory marketing authorities. A social responsibility summary is advocated by the Committee as a means by which each organisation can outline its progress and achievements in the performance of its social responsibilities.

Requiring an organisation to define its social objectives and measure and report on its performance focuses the organisation's attention on its social responsibilities. If its reports are scrutinised and regular response provided, the pressure on the organisation to observe its social responsibilities will be enhanced. Scrutiny of and providing response to its reports are therefore of the utmost importance, whether they are provided by Ministers, the Parliament—especially the committees of this House—review bodies or the public.

The Committee also considered the means by which values could be attached to social responsibilities. Needless to say, this was a difficult task. The value of social responsibilities may be financial or non-financial; they are of value to individuals, the organisation providing them and the wider community, but their impact cannot always be fully assessed.

Most of the information received by the Committee about the value of social responsibilities concerned the cost of providing them, particularly the cost of providing community service obligations, such as telephone and mail services to remote and isolated areas of the country. How the costing should be carried out has been determined by the Government in relation to Telecom's provision of telephone services. The method of least avoidable cost is to be used and it is expected that other GBEs will use the same method. The Committee noted the criticism that has been expressed about the validity of estimates of community service obligation costs; and, accordingly, we recommend that the way in which estimates are made should be monitored and improvements sought.

On the more general level of dealing with the values and costs of socially responsible behaviour, the Committee endorses the use of cost-benefit analyses. Such analyses should consider both the quantifiable and qualitative aspects of any proposal and take as wide a view as possible of the impact of the proposal on the community and the environment.

In conclusion, the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the social responsibilities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and GBEs is important and I suspect in time will prove to be one of great significance. Both this report and report 314, which reviews eight of the Auditor-General's performance audits, focus on increasing the accountability of government agencies to the Parliament. I commend both reports to the House. In closing, I would like to thank all members of the Committee and the staff, who have always worked tirelessly, and on this occasion, of course, particularly Dr Sarah Hnatiuk for her work on the social responsibilities report.
