Debate resumed from 31 March, on the following paper presented by Mr Tickner:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody—Ministerial Statement, 31 March 1992

PROCTEXT.PARA: and on motion by Mr Beazley:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody will stand as the monumental work to date in examining the position of Aboriginal Australians within the broader Australian society. I have no doubt that in years to come it will be looked upon as a watershed, although exactly why remains to be seen. I hope it will be looked upon as the time that Australia took the opportunity to form a partnership for the advancement of Aboriginal people. It is quite possible that it will be looked upon as a lost opportunity and show us as a nation too immature to put aside petty differences in order to achieve something of real benefit to the whole country. I hope my speech today goes some way towards creating a situation in which this report proves to be the catalyst for re-examining where we are today in Aboriginal affairs.

PARA.TAB: When one reads the report, one cannot help being hit with a whole variety of emotions—anger, sadness, joy—and no doubt these are the emotions that the commissioners themselves experienced in writing the report. It is a frank and honest assessment of the attitudes of Aboriginal Australia, the position that Aboriginals occupy in our society and the attitudes of the broader Australian community. It is also a fairly frank examination of our past and why we are where we are today. It does not seek to instil guilt or apportion blame, but merely, in some cases coldly and clinically, dissects the facts and lays them bare.

In understanding some of the difficulties we face today, the words of Commissioner Johnston, better than anybody else, explain his reaction after having spent several years of his life listening and talking to Aboriginal people. He states in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: I say very frankly that when I started upon my work in this commission, I had some knowledge of the way broad policy had evolved to the detriment of Aboriginal people and some idea of the consequences. But until I examined the files of the people who died and the other material which has come before the Commission and listened to Aboriginal people speaking, I had no conception of the degree of pin-pricking domination, abuse of personal power, utter paternalism, open contempt and total indifference with which so many Aboriginal people were visited on a day to day basis. It's hard to convey the understanding, because each particular story takes time and space to tell.

He goes on to talk of two such cases. The first was a letter that came from a protector of Aborigines in Queensland who was shocked to receive a request from a newly married Aboriginal woman to have from her bank account, which he controlled, four-fifths of her week's earnings. This was despite the fact that he acknowledged that her employer, who was going to do the shopping, would be very careful with the disbursement of her money. He refused the request but, as it was Christmas, allowed her a bit of her own money to buy lollies with, for which she had not asked.

PARA.TAB: Another case into which Commissioner Johnston inquired was that of a young boy who had been put into an institution because he kept running away from home, where there had been a lot of domestic strife. He wanted to go to the home of his sister, a married woman who lived on a reserve. The sister and her husband are to this day leading members of the community. The superintendent refused the lad permission to come onto the reserve to join his sister. His reasons included that the couple were thought to keep some beer in the refrigerator at a time when it was lawful to do so, and they had some household items on hire purchase, including a TV. Commissioner Johnston goes on in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: This petty tyranny, escalating to interference with the most fundamental of rights to practise one's own culture, one's own religion with one's own children is deeply resented.

Some years ago there was significant violence in the Kempsey area of New South Wales. The local council commissioned a report from a clinical psychologist into the basis of the violence and the racial tensions in the area. This report is illuminating reading. It states that the single most important factor in the poor race relations in the Kempsey area was the bitterness that Aboriginal people felt. It was not bitterness for what happened 150 years ago or 100 years ago; it was bitterness for what has happened in recent living memory.

PARA.TAB: Before I became the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, I had no conception of what had happened in recent memory. I started to look. I found that in New South Wales until 1964 an Aboriginal child could be actively excluded from school on the basis of race; in the Northern Territory until 1965 Aboriginal people needed permission to marry; in Western Australia until 1968 Aboriginal children were still being forcibly removed from their parents against the will of the parents; and in Queensland until the mid-1960s Aborigines had to carry what was in effect a passport if they wanted to leave a reserve. If they were caught without such a document exempting them from the Aborigines Protection Act, they were arrested and returned to the reservation.

Not long ago when I was visiting a children's service in Brisbane I met a man in his mid-forties—the average age of members of this House. To this day, he carries a small green booklet in his pocket, which was his passport. Without this, he was imprisoned on a reserve. All these things happened in my lifetime, and I am one of the youngest members in this place. It meant that, if any of us had been born a half-caste Aborigine, the chances are that we would have been forcibly removed from our mothers and raised in an institution, and the chances are that we would not have gone very far beyond primary school education.

I have talked of these matters to groups within the community, and on a number of occasions I have had the same thing happen. There has been someone from South Africa in the audience who has come up to me afterwards and said, `We never went that far in South Africa'. The legacy of this is a population marginalised, dispersed, dispossessed and with very poor education.

The first Aboriginal man in Australia to graduate from university, Charles Perkins, did so in 1966. The first New Zealand Maori to do the same was in 1901, fully two generations earlier. This is where we come to today. Like it or not, the scrutiny of Aboriginal affairs is not going to go away; it is going to intensify. It is incumbent on us in this place to see that this petty tyranny, this pinpricking domination and utter paternalism—of which Commissioner Johnston speaks—is finally put behind us.

We simply have no other choice, because today the debate on Aboriginal affairs is an international one. This year is the five-hundredth anniversary of Columbus landing on the east coast of the Americas. That is forcing Europe and the United States to examine the whole colonisation process, as our bicentenary forced us to examine our past.

Next year is the International Year of Indigenous People, and the two countries with which we most closely identify in indigenous matters, New Zealand and Canada, have both decided that it is in their national interest to bury the differences with their native people. They have found that acknowledging problems and attempting to fix them promotes national unity and that the real threat to a secure, stable country is pretending that the problems do not exist.

Further, like it or not, fairly or unfairly, in the international arena we are judged as not having a good record in our relations with our indigenous people. In fact, of the 10 OECD countries that have indigenous people, we are generally rated last. We may all think this to be grossly unfair and overstated, but in politics we know that it is not the facts that count; it is the perception. The perception overseas is just as I have stated it. On that background we have this report and, as a country, we have to make a response to it.

It is worth remembering the environment in which this royal commission was originally set up: 1987 was a year of an unusually high number of black deaths in custody. Twenty people died that year, which was over double the average number of deaths for the previous seven years. Each successive death drew greater and greater media coverage and fuelled growing anger in the Aboriginal community.

Just as today, where every isolated instance of racism, even one that is three years old, is a leading story on the ABC News, five years ago each death was catapulted to national prominence. When the royal commission finally came, it was also partly in response to a campaign which had been waged since 1984 by the Committee to Defend Black Rights. This Committee had been founded after widespread dissatisfaction with the verdict on the John Pat case in Western Australia. John Pat had died in police custody in Roebourne in 1983. The ABC focused national attention on the John Pat case and other deaths in custody in a Four Corners program in September 1985; a program that drew angry responses from the Western Australian Police Union, with accusations of bias and inaccuracy. We were also subject to growing international pressure. In the middle of 1987, the London-based anti-slavery movement concluded a two-month study of Australia's Aboriginal population and reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Widespread allegations of physical and psychological abuse of Aborigines in custody . . . including young women and children.

This report was tabled at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver. The royal commission was the last of a series of responses made by the Government to quell growing public anger. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs had been given a brief to inquire into Aboriginal involvement within the criminal justice system, but this had lapsed on the calling of the 1987 election. Thus, with a growing number of deaths, in the end there was no choice and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was set up in October 1987.

PARA.TAB: The royal commission, however, was not without its critics, and throughout its three-year history attracted its fair share of publicity. It was expensive. In the end it cost over $30m, but in hindsight some of that criticism was perhaps a bit unfair. In many ways, it was really 99 individual royal commissions, as the commissioners were required to report individually on every one of the 99 deaths in custody.

At the same time, the commission allowed us as a country to have some breathing space. It was a circuit breaker which allowed us to really look at why so many Aborigines were in custody and why they appeared to be dying so frequently. The research that came out of the commission was generally first-rate and very valuable. Most importantly, it showed early on that Aborigines were 29 times more likely to be in gaol than non-Aborigines. But, for any given instance of imprisonment, the chance of an Aborigine dying in custody was actually slightly less than that of a European person.

The debate shifted when we realised that it was not so much a problem of what happens after someone goes to gaol, but rather the high numbers of Aboriginal people that are in gaol in the first place. This fact that Aborigines are 29 times more likely to be in prison than non-Aborigines—as was the case in 1987 and still is the case in many parts of Australia—makes Aboriginal people one of the most imprisoned races in the world. Except for South African blacks, no group in the world has such a heavy over-representation in prison.

However, this figure is somewhat misleading, and it is a great pity that the research did not go one step further. The age profile of Aboriginal people is significantly different from that of the general Australian population. The birth rate is higher; life expectancy is less. No doubt this skewed age profile would contribute to high imprisonment.

The whole of the difference is consistently ascribed to race; that is, because someone is an Aborigine he has a 29 times higher likelihood of being in gaol. This is clearly not the case.The report shows us something of the poverty in Aboriginal society, and no doubt a good proportion of that increase is, in fact, due to poverty rather than aboriginality; how much so, we do not know. It would have been interesting to look at imprisonment rates in Melbourne Housing Commission flats or Sydney's outer west. If this had been done, I suspect we would have found that a good part of this increase could be explained by poverty. That is a pity because so much of the debate today is on technical methods to keep Aborigines out of gaol, whereas it might have been on ways of addressing Aboriginal poverty as a preventative measure.

What does the royal commission tell us of those 99 people who died in custody? It is, in fact, a rather chilling profile. Of the 99 people, 88 were males and 11 were female. The mean age at the time of death was 32. Of the 99, only two had completed secondary education and only one had completed vocational training at TAFE; 83 were unemployed at the time of their last detention; and 43 had been separated as children from their natural families by the action of government. In Western Australia and Queensland, over half had been separated from their natural families; in New South Wales, just on half. Of the 99, 37 had died of natural causes while in gaol. The average age of those dying of natural causes was 30. The health of this group of people ranged from poor to very poor.

I now turn to the 339 recommendations themselves. These recommendations cover an enormous variety of areas. Many are purely custodial in nature and cover areas as diverse as relations with the police, youth and justice, diversion of arrest, bail issues, courts, custody and Aboriginal legal services. These generally receive unanimous support by the Commonwealth and Territory governments. Other recommendations relate to all areas of endeavour in Aboriginal affairs, housing and infrastructure through health, jobs and schooling.

Obviously it has been impossible for me in 48 hours to discuss with all of my colleagues the 1,400 pages and 339 individual recommendations. However, the most important areas of overlap are those with the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods). In commenting on these recommendations, I must say that they are at this stage only our personal views. With the time span involved it would not have been possible any other way.

I have discussed the issues relating to law and justice with the shadow Attorney-General and, with only minor exceptions, we find the recommendations unexceptionable and sensible. Many of the recommendations relating to diversion from arrest, bail and representation before the courts are ones which really should apply to the whole community, not just one segment of it. This applies particularly to bail issues, breath testing of people taken into custody, and families of deceased being entitled to legal representation at coronial inquiries. That these recommendations should have wider application does not mean that we do not support their introduction for Aboriginal people; it simply means that we hope that governments at all levels might look at their broader application. In the area of health, I have discussed the recommendations with the shadow Minister for health and, again, we view them as sensible and desirable.

Some of the recommendations are long overdue. Recommendation 45, proposing a special national survey of the social, demographic, health and economic characteristics of Australia's Aboriginal population, is welcomed. My view is that such a survey should be carried out in conjunction with the census. In that way it would provide the most meaningful data. In so much of Aboriginal affairs, our endeavour has been merely based on guesswork or anecdotal evidence. We have to be honest with ourselves as to whether or not our policies are achieving what we wish them to, and this special survey will give us a basis on which we can determine our benchmarks and look at our success or otherwise of the programs in the future.

Some of the recommendations have been overtaken by events. Recommendation 339 states that all governments support the process of reconciliation. This has now happened. After the areas of the Attorney-General and health, the majority of recommendations relate to ATSIC and those Aboriginal education programs within DEET. The majority again appear relevant and sensible, and the agreement by the Commonwealth and States on the majority of them reflects the fact that there is a growing agreement as to what is successful and what is not.

There is one part of the report, however, that has the potential to cause major conflict. This conflict may be more perceived than real and it may not be insurmountable. It relates to recommendation 188 which talks about ensuring that the self-determination principle is applied in the design and implementation of any policy. I do not wish to open up old wounds, for it was on this very word—and only this word—of self-determination that the first motion in this new Parliament House on Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders failed to attract the full support of the House. As I said, I do not want to open up old wounds; rather, I would like to use this opportunity, hopefully, to lead to a better understanding of and some dialogue on this issue.

The report talks a great deal about self-determination. Indeed, self-determination comes through every single volume of the report. In the overview, Commissioner Johnston states, when talking of the requirement to adhere to the principles of self-determination:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a concept which—I think—does not have a precise definition.

The difficulty with this is that Commissioner Johnston is, in fact, wrong. The principle of self-determination has a specific and precise meaning in international law. It is contained in the first article of the United Nations Charter of 1945 and it is also contained in the first article of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Let me read them both. In the Charter of the United Nations, a second purpose of the UN is stated as:
. . . to develop friendly relations amongst nations, based on respect for the principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples. . .
In the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, it is stated:
All peoples have the right of self-determination. By virtue of that right, they freely determine their political status. . .

In both these texts, the word `peoples' was chosen over contending terms of minorities or nations. In international law, indigenous people are not a people, for the meaning of these two texts. There are people of Kuwait who have a right to self-determination but that applies to the nation as a whole, not a minority within it—even an indigenous minority. This is not just of historical interest. In the draft declaration of the Working Group on Indigenous Peoples, the usage of the word `peoples' is specifically precluded by the United Nations from conferring the rights associated with the word in international law.

PARA.TAB: The demand for self-determination is thus inextricably tied up in international law with the idea of an independent sovereign state. It is not adapted to degrees of autonomy less than full autonomous self-government. We can talk of degrees of autonomy and devolution, but there are no degrees of sovereign statehood. Thus the idea of self-determination within the wider state, or self-determination under a wider law, is in itself contradictory.

I wish it were not so. I would like to find a way around it. It would be much easier for me to pretend that self-determination or the principle of self-determination meant whatever one wished it to mean and that there was room for argument. But I do not see this as the case for, in international law, self-determination applies to sovereign states, and neither the Labor Party nor the coalition has ever suggested that we should be talking about dividing Australian's sovereignty.

In stating this, I do not want to get caught in a tyranny of words, because I suspect that the concept that we talk of in self-management and the concept the Government talks of in self-determination are similar concepts using different words. When the royal commission talks of policies of self-determination over the last 20 years, it fails to recognise that these have been policies of one political party. It has not been a continuous policy of successive governments nor a continuing policy of successive State governments; it has been a policy of Labor State and Federal governments.

That is not to say that the coalition does not believe that it is desirable for Aboriginal people, in matters relating to their own internal and local affairs, to have the greatest possible degree of autonomy consistent with obligations to the broader community. Our support for ATSIC and our long held policy position that Aboriginal people have the right, as a right, to choose to live a traditional lifestyle and to preserve their culture, support our view that, when Aboriginal people have control over those matters that affect their day to day lives, they have by far the greatest chance of developing self-reliance, independence, dignity and choice.

There is, in international law, an emerging concept of internal self-determination. Perhaps, in the future, this will offer us a way out. However, it is just, as I said, an emerging concept. It does not have a body of legal precedent behind it and there is not general acceptance as to what it means.

I would like to talk of areas of concern that I have within the royal commission report itself and the Government response to it. I raise these as concerns, not as criticisms, in the hope that they can provide a constructive point of view as to the limitations the coalition sees with the approach being taken at the moment. These concerns relate to three areas: the first is the limitation of government itself; the second is the challenge of helping Aboriginal people move from a welfare dependent state; the third is the administration of Aboriginal affairs and Aboriginal organisations.

My first concern is that government alone will never solve the challenge facing Aboriginal Australians. This is clearly recognised in the royal commission when, in the overview, Commissioner Johnston talks of three essential prerequisites to Aboriginal people having control over their lives and their communities. His first essential pre-requisite, and the most crucial, is the desire and capacity of Aboriginal people to put an end to their disadvantaged situation and to take control of their lives. In his words, `There can be no other way'. Only the Aboriginal people can, in the final analysis, ensure their own future.

The second pre-requisite is assistance from the broad society and this, basically, means assistance from government, with the support of the electorate or, at least, without its opposition. According to the Commissioner, the third pre-requisite is having in place an established method and procedure whereby the broader society can supply the assistance, and the Aboriginal society can receive it, without a welfare dependent position being established between the two groups. I agree with this totally. What Commissioner Johnston is talking about, in effect, is a partnership between the Australian Government, Aboriginal people and the broader community, and there is simply no other way.

`Partnership' is a word that is hardly ever used in this country, yet it is not a meaningless concept. It should underpin everything we do and seek to achieve in Aboriginal affairs. Partnership is the underpinning of the entire policy that Canada and New Zealand have towards their indigenous people. Yet partnership seems to be almost forgotten in Australia. In the royal commission, after having clearly identified the need for partnership, not just between governments but right across the community, the report then seems to forget it. The rest of the report relates, by and large, to what government can or should do.

That is a pity because no amount of government assistance in Aboriginal education, for example, is going to be successful if Aboriginal parents still do not want to send their kids to school. No amount of money spent on programs to combat petrol sniffing or substance abuse is going to work unless the community wishes to take responsibility for what is going on in its midst.

I would like to share with the House my experience of the most successful anti-petrol sniffing program being run in the country. It runs at Daly River. There are no petrol sniffing problems whatsoever, in spite of it being endemic right across the Top End. When I met with the chairperson of the local community, a woman who is also principal of the school, we were in the community store. I asked her about petrol sniffing. The conversation went something like this. I asked, `Do you have a petrol sniffing problem here in Daly?'. She said, `No, no problem at all'. I asked, `What, you don't have any petrol sniffing at all?'. She said, `Oh, we occasionally catch kids sniffing petrol, but they don't do it again'. I asked, `What do you do?'. She said, `Oh, well, we send them out with the old men for a couple of days'. I asked, `What do the old men do?'. At this point she looked up on the wall of the canteen where there were a whole lot of fairly ferocious looking spears and, looking at the spears, she said, `I am a woman and I wouldn't know anything about that. I don't know what they do, but they certainly never do it again'. What is the total cost of the program? In dollars, zero; in effectiveness, 100 per cent.

In the end I do not believe we yet have a partnership in this country. It is what we desperately need and what we should desperately work towards. If we have a belief, as I seem to read in the royal commission report or seem to read in the Government's response to this stage, that Government alone has the capacity to turn this around, then we are wrong and we will fail, as we have failed previously. The corollary of this relates to money. When we say that money alone will not fix the problem, we do not mean that money is totally unimportant. It is important, but it is not important for its own sake. It is important for what it can achieve in real, tangible, positive benefits on the ground for Aboriginal people. In all the discussion of the report and in the Government's response to the report, accountability relates to the way we spend the money, but not so much to what the money achieves. In the majority of instances where ATSIC or DEET have performance indicators, those performance indicators relate to the timely disbursement of the money, not what the money achieves.

This is where we have to have a total turnaround in thinking in this country, because while we are prepared to see as sufficient, and prepared to be content with, merely spending the money, or see accountability only in terms of getting the money out, or having enough money to spend, then we are going to miss the point on real accountability. The question is: are we being effective in what we are doing? In this way the issues do not become: whether it is State or Federal jurisdiction or whether it is Aboriginal controlled or non-Aboriginal controlled. They do not become issues of ideology or party politics. The only issue is: does it work? We have some way to go on this score.

My second concern is this: to me, a fundamental issue in Aboriginal affairs today is: how do we help Aboriginal people move from a position where they are dependent on government to a position where they are self-reliant? Until we face up to this, all other issues are secondary.

I am pleased to note in the Minister's speech that in three months time, after discussions with the States, there will be a further report when this issue will be addressed. I am pleased to note that the royal commission mentions this in its introduction, but, unfortunately, the concept seems to get lost after that introduction. I have to say that fundamentally this is not an issue of money. No-one in his right mind is going to say that another $50m a year is going to make the difference either way between welfare dependency and self-reliance. The problem here fundamentally is one of attitude—attitude on both sides; the attitude in the broader Australia community to supply the support needed for Aboriginal people, not just financial support, but encouragement, patience and understanding for Aboriginal people to develop an economic base. It will need that support. It also requires a change of attitude in many Aboriginal people. In Commissioner Johnston's words, `The desire to put an end to their disadvantaged situation and take control of their own lives'.

Much of my reply today, and much of what has been talked about in recent days, has actually focused on failure; on failure of the system and on failure of successive governments. Not all in Aboriginal affairs today is failure. There are some fabulous successes happening in this country. The royal commission alludes to some of them. It talks about the Tangentyere Council and about the community at Port Lincoln. I have had similar experiences.

Anyone who spends considerable time in Aboriginal Australia has had the same experiences, whether it be from the Aboriginal fruit growing operations at Cardwell in Queensland, the success of the pastoral enterprise at Woorabinda, the Aboriginal coordinating council at Moree, or the communities at Daly River, Robinson River and Wallace Rockhole in the Northern Territory. All these communities are stunning successes and they all have one thing in common. Aboriginal people have become tired of waiting for others to do it and have taken control of their own lives to make things happen. As Commissioner Johnston says, `There can be no other way'.

I look forward to the Minister's response in three months time. I look forward to seeing how Government will help Aboriginal people develop an independent economic base. I believe that after the development of a partnership, development of an economic base is the greatest challenge we face. If we do not face it, then self-management, or self-determination, whatever we call it, is reduced to talking about how Aborigines control the government money given to them.

My third area of concern relates to administration of programs and Aboriginal organisations. This is vital because these are the vehicles by which benefits pass to people in the community. Aboriginal programs in DEET appear to be in a real shambles. In recent years, successive Auditor-General reports on DEET programs have shown insufficient verification checks for applications, insufficient information on clients' application forms, lack of coordination with other departments and no procedures to avoid duplication of payments. The most recent Auditor-General's report stated that auditing was not undertaken in relation to $80m of expenditure under Aboriginal education supplementary assistance because auditing had revealed that departmental records were not adequate to determine whether payments were valid or accurate. DEET accepted this. In its own words, `Sufficient documentary evidence was unable to be located to support the expenditure relating to this program'. We are talking about $80m.

Year after year these issues are raised; year after year DEET states they are being addressed; year after year the Auditor-General expresses these concerns; year after year DEET says something will happen. Year after year nothing happens.

This year the Auditor-General stated that the Department had breached section 34 of the Audit Act relating to authorisation of expenditure for bona fide purposes. The Auditor-General raised this as a major concern in audit reports dating back to 1987. The departmental response has been effectively the same since that time, namely, action to correct the situation will take place. Five years later we are still waiting.

Accountability has to start at home. Unless the Federal Government can be accountable for its own expenditure in those departments that it has control over, we cannot ask for the same sort of accountability in Aboriginal organisations. Aboriginal organisations themselves are pivotal for the future of Aboriginal people. Most of our funding is channelled through Aboriginal organisations, and their effectiveness, or the lack of it, will determine whether the benefits and programs, for which we have so much hope in this place, make one jot of difference.

In the additional programs that the Minister announced on Tuesday, these funds will be channelled via ATSIC to Aboriginal organisations in the main. Yet, the effectiveness of these organisations, or their ability to deliver desired outcomes, is not even questioned. The royal commission does not touch on this, yet there are very real problems here.

In my own State of Victoria, two years ago when I first became shadow Minister I decided to see how many Aboriginal organisations I could identify. I found 174 for 12 1/2 thousand Aboriginal people. That is one organisation for every 72 Aborigines. Today there are almost certainly more. This is not to criticise Aboriginal organisations per se. Many do a fabulous job, but as they are pivotal in the area of service delivery to Aboriginal people, they have to be subject to greater accountability. Let me give some examples.

Not long ago I was travelling in remote Australia. I visited a town where an alcohol rehabilitation organisation asked to see me. I met with it, visited its officers and they told me with great pride about their organisation and what they hoped to achieve. It was fully funded, had a number of staff positions, a car and offices. Things went well until I asked them how many people they had actually helped. They looked at me a bit puzzled and said, `Well, we haven't actually seen anybody yet'. This might be an extreme example, nonetheless it happens.

The biggest initiatives in Tuesday's announcement were in the areas of Aboriginal legal services. The extra funding to meet the main recommendations of the royal commission will be channelled through Aboriginal legal services. Yet, Aboriginal legal services are structures that are not open and transparent. Many produce no annual reports, in spite of their being repeatedly requested to do so. ATSIC itself generally has no idea of whether or not the money it is handing over is being used effectively and wisely. It hands it over, closes its eyes, crosses its fingers and hopes it will work. Not long ago ATSIC had to take the New South Wales Aboriginal legal service to court to recover $94,000 that a couple of its directors had spent on a one-week jaunt around Europe.

This same New South Wales Aboriginal legal service pursued a custody case that legal aid had rejected as hopeless, unwinnable and with no merit. This case involved grandparents attempting to adopt their murdered daughter's children. An eminent child psychiatrist stated strongly that the interests of the children were with their maternal grandparents, yet the Aboriginal legal service put this family through a custody battle of 18 hearings at a cost to the grandparents of $30,000. This prompted the children's psychiatrist to write:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned that the Aboriginal legal service is wasting its scarce resources on such an inappropriate and unwinnable case without any apparent thought for the stress and damage being caused. The ongoing and protracted litigation is causing enormous financial and emotional burden on the grandparents, destabilising the children's security and emotional well being.

The irony of all this is that the child over whom the custody was being fought had no Aboriginal blood whatsoever. The only Aboriginal person was an Aboriginal step-grandfather. The child herself was being raised in the Jewish faith.

PARA.TAB: Not long ago a proposal to establish a new Aboriginal legal service was handed to me. I will not mention its name, as my purpose of this is not to embarrass the service, but I read it for the benefit of honourable members. This is what was being asked for: branch office staff—one office manager, one secretary, six field officers, three welfare workers, four administrative assistants, one bookkeeper and two clerical staff. Then, after asking for 18 people, it must have felt a bit guilty and, as it was a legal service, thought it should have some solicitors, so there were three solicitors. The list continues: non-legal section, office equipment—one computer, one 10-inch printer, one photocopier, three typewriters/word processors, dictaphone, facsimile machine, appropriate complement of filing cabinets, desks, storage cupboards, et cetera; in the legal section—one computer, one 10-inch printer, two typewriters/word processors, one dictaphone, appropriate complement of filing cabinets, desks, chairs, storage cupboards, a telephone switchboard operating one telephone number with eight lines and 15 telephone units, two-way radio with base and five units in the field, video cameras, tape recorders, motor vehicles; non-legal section—three passenger vehicles, one nine-seater bus; legal section—two passenger vehicles. The list goes on. This is a $1.5m small business and, if this is indicative of how Aboriginal legal services operate around the country, I shudder to think how much of the extra assistance is actually going to make it onto the ground.

To come back to the report in general: the Government's response is a monumental work. Collating 339 responses from eight governments is no easy feat. I commend the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) for his work on this. On the Federal level we often disagree; however, we have made an effort to look for common ground. It is disappointing that the responses of many of the States have appeared to be self-serving, publicity seeking and have not taken the same initiative as we have tried to take at a Federal level. This report does offer a great opportunity to take a step forward. We really must take advantage of it.

Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 are a package of measures that need to be read together.

PARA.TAB: When this Government took office in 1983, most people would look to the age pension as their main source of retirement income. Superannuation was the preserve of a few, mainly the wealthy, and a substantial proportion of concessionally taxed superannuation savings was dissipated well before retirement.

The reform of superannuation has been one of the great achievements of the Government. Over its term of office, the Government has greatly expanded access to superannuation savings. In particular, award superannuation has fostered the spread of superannuation to large areas of the work force which previously had no cover. The Government has also restructured the tax concessions for superannuation to make them more consistent with retirement incomes objectives, while still maintaining them at a generous level.

In addition, access to superannuation concessions has been made substantially more equitable.These reforms have moved superannuation from being a concessionally taxed source of windfall gains for high income earners towards being a genuine retirement savings vehicle for most Australians.

When we came to office, 40 per cent of the work force had some superannuation cover; in 1991, the proportion was 72 per cent. On this basis alone, our reforms of superannuation are an achievement which the retirees of the future will value highly. Despite these reforms, there is an ongoing need to ensure that as many Australians as possible have access to superannuation. There is also a need to increase the average level of superannuation savings for each individual, if these savings are to provide an adequate level of retirement income. Consistent with these goals, the superannuation guarantee levy was announced in last year's Budget.

The superannuation guarantee levy represents another major step forward in the development of retirement incomes policy. It will lay the foundation for income security and higher standards of living in retirement for future generations of retirees. The superannuation guarantee levy provides:

SPEECH.PARA: .a major extension of superannuation coverage;
.an efficient method of encouraging employers to comply with their award obligations; and
.an orderly mechanism by which employer superannuation support can be increased over time, consistent with the economy's capacity to pay.

The levy will consolidate the reforms implemented since 1983, and will provide a coherent and equitable framework in which retirement incomes objectives can be progressed. It will ensure that, by the beginning of the next century, virtually all employees will be accumulating substantial superannuation savings to help fund their retirement income.

PARA.TAB: The increased self-provision for retirement will permit a higher standard of living in retirement than if we continued to rely on the age pension alone. The increased self-provision will also enable future Commonwealth governments to improve the retirement conditions for those Australians who were unable to fund adequately their own retirement incomes.

Lastly, self-provision will increase the flexibility in the Commonwealth's Budget in future years, especially as our population ages, and will increase our national savings overall, thus reducing our reliance on the savings of foreigners to fund our development.

In December last year an information paper was released for comment on issues raised by the operation of the superannuation guarantee levy. The Government then undertook wide ranging consultations on the issues raised by the information paper. As a result of the consultation process, this package of measures contains some changes to the proposals outlined in that information paper.

PARA.EMPHASIS: How the Superannuation Guarantee Scheme Will Work

PARA.TAB: The Bill, which applies from 1 July 1992, will encourage employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation support for employees. Where employers provide less than the minimum level of superannuation support, they will be liable for a superannuation guarantee charge. The superannuation guarantee charge—which will not be a deductible expense for employers—will be used to meet the superannuation contribution entitlements of the relevant employee and will be used, as I discuss later, to fund administration costs.

I should stress that this mechanism is not intended to be the principal vehicle for the funding of employee's superannuation contribution entitlements. It is intended, instead, to be an incentive for employers to meet their own obligations, and to be a support mechanism for employees where those obligations are not met.

In introducing the levy, the Government has been particularly conscious of minimising the labour cost impact of the levy on employers. We have designed the levy to be a floor under existing superannuation arrangements. All existing employer superannuation support that meets the provisions of the levy arrangements will count towards the minimum prescribed level of support.

The level of superannuation support an employer is expected to provide will depend on the employer's annual payroll. For the 1992-93 year, employers with an annual payroll in excess of $500,000 will be expected to contribute 5 per cent of an employee's earnings base to a complying superannuation fund. This percentage will increase over the next nine years to 9 per cent. Employers with an annual payroll of $500,000 or less will be required to contribute 3 per cent, increasing on a slower transition schedule to 9 per cent.

An employee's earnings base will depend on whether the employer was providing superannuation support for employees on 20 August 1991. Employers who, on that date, were contributing to a superannuation scheme which has an earnings base can continue to use that earnings base so long as it is not reduced. This will help minimise compliance costs. In any other case, the employer will be assessed against an earnings base that the employer is required to use under an industrial award or a base not less than ordinary time earnings.

Superannuation support must be provided through a complying superannuation fund in order to be counted towards the minimum level of superannuation support. The fund can be either a defined contribution fund or a defined benefit fund. In the case of a defined benefit fund, the employer will be required to obtain an actuarial certificate specifying the level of employer superannuation support implicit in the benefits available to employees in the fund. For all other funds, the employer's level of support will be based on the actual contributions made to the fund.

The level of superannuation support will be measured on a financial year basis for the 1992-93 year. However, where an employer has provided insufficient superannuation support during that year, the employer will be able to make up any shortfall in contributions by 14 August 1993.

The Government has decided that, from the 1993-94 year and in subsequent years, employer support will be measured on a monthly basis. The employer will be expected to provide the minimum level of superannuation support during the month or within 28 days of the end of the month. However, if there is a shortfall in employer superannuation support, the superannuation guarantee charge will not be due until 14 August in the next financial year.
If an employer does not provide the minimum level of superannuation support, a charge will be imposed on the employer. The charge will be equal to the sum of:

SPEECH.PARA: .the total of the employer's individual superannuation guarantee shortfalls;
.an interest component; and
.an administration component.

A superannuation shortfall for an employee is calculated by applying to the employee's salary and wages the percentage difference between the minimum level of superannuation support and the actual employer support. The interest component is a proxy for superannuation fund earnings. The interest will be calculated from the commencement of the financial year until the time the superannuation guarantee charge is due to be paid.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the administration charge is to recover some of the costs incurred in administering the tax. The charge will initially consist of a flat amount of $50 plus an amount of $30 for each employee in respect of whom the employer has a superannuation shortfall.

The Government has decided to support the inclusion in existing superannuation award provisions of the rates of contribution to superannuation funds required by the superannuation guarantee scheme as they become operative. The Government considers that, where there is no agreement between the parties to an existing award superannuation provision nominating a particular fund, the fund to which such additional award contributions are to be made should be determined by the relevant industrial tribunal looking to the best interests of the beneficiaries.

The superannuation guarantee scheme is designed to encourage employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation support. It is intended to improve the position of those employees who have inadequate superannuation coverage. It is not designed to provide a mechanism for a general increase in superannuation support for those employees who are already receiving in excess of the prescribed minimum level.

The Government expects that increases in the prescribed minimum level would not result in additional contributions in cases where employers were already providing superannuation support at or above that level. Of course, parties are free to negotiate levels of superannuation support above the minimum as part of enterprise agreement.

Many employers already provide such higher levels, often through a combination of contributions to industry funds and employer funds. In such cases, the Government expects negotiations between the parties on a case-by-case basis would determine the fund or funds to which superannuation guarantee/award contributions would be made. Any breakdown in negotiations should be referred to the relevant industrial tribunal.

Under the superannuation guarantee scheme, an employer will not be expected to provide superannuation support for employees who are under 18 years of age and who are working part time. Income earned by a person as a member of the Defence Force reserves will also not be taken into account. As a result of comments on the information paper, the Government has also decided to exempt:

SPEECH.PARA: .employees who earn less than $250 a month;
.employees who are aged 65 or over;
.non-resident employees who are paid for work undertaken outside Australia; and
.resident employees who are employed by non-resident employers and are paid for work undertaken outside Australia.

Accordingly, the previously announced weekly and annual threshold exemptions will no longer apply. The revised exemptions are designed to ensure that virtually all employees receive superannuation support. There will be a maximum limit of $80,000 per annum—indexed—on the annual earnings to which the superannuation guarantee requirements will apply in respect of any individual employee. That is, the superannuation guarantee will apply to the first $80,000 of salary.

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation will be responsible for administering the superannuation guarantee scheme. The scheme will be administered on a self-assessment basis with generally only those employers who are liable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge required to furnish a statement to the Australian Taxation Office. The statement and charge will be required to be lodged and paid by 14 August in the following financial year.

Revenue collected under the Bill will be placed in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. An amount equivalent to the charge, less the administration component, will be redistributed to a complying superannuation fund for the benefit of those employees in respect of whom the charge was paid. Employees will have a choice as to which fund these amounts go to.

In the information paper a number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act were proposed. These amendments have not yet been finalised and will be included in a consequential Bill to be introduced later in these sittings. Notwithstanding the fact that these consequential amendments have not been finalised, the Government decided to introduce these two Bills now so that people have as much time as possible to consider the impact of the arrangements and make any changes they consider necessary.

The minimum level of support required by the superannuation guarantee will have to be compulsorily preserved from 1 July 1993. The Government has decided to extend this deadline from 1 July 1992 to provide time for schemes to amend their trust deeds where necessary. Employers will, however, remain liable to provide the minimum required level of vested benefit to all non-exempt employees from 1 July 1992.
It is estimated that employers will remit an insignificant amount of the charge in 1992-93 and $17m in subsequent years, of which amount $15m is expected to be redistributed for employees.

The Government believes these measures represent a major step forward in the development of retirement incomes policy and will lay the foundation for income security and higher standards of living in retirement for virtually all workers.
I present the explanatory memorandums for this Bill and for the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It will implement several measures outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his One Nation statement of 26 February 1992. In this regard the Bill will give effect to the new accelerated plant depreciation rates measures.

PARA.TAB: It will also provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1991-92 income year, as announced by the Prime Minister. Additionally, this Bill will amend the capital gains tax provisions by increasing the exemption available for gains realised on the disposal of the goodwill of small businesses.

The research and development provisions of the taxation law are also to be amended to provide for the exemption of eligible companies from the operation of the clawback provisions when grants or recoupments of relevant expenditure are made under the cooperative research centres program.

The Bill contains amendments to the provisions of the law that deal with the avoidance of Australian taxation through the use of offshore companies and trusts. This Bill will also extend the circumstances in which deductions for contributions to superannuation funds are allowable. The gift provisions of the income tax law will also be amended.

The Bill contains measures to exempt the pay and allowances of Australian Defence Force members serving with the UN in Cambodia. Medicare levy relief for health card holders will be confined to blind pensioners and sickness allowance beneficiaries. Finally, the Bill contains a number of minor technical and procedural amendments of the taxation laws. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

The Bill will provide higher depreciation rates for plant and equipment with an effective life of five or more years. In some instances, this will represent a substantial reduction in the period over which items can be written off. For example, the cost of items with an effective life of 20 years will now be able to be written off over eight years—half the time it took under the former system.

The Bill also simplifies the calculation of depreciation. Once effective life is determined, the rates of depreciation for most items of plant are set out without the need to amend the rate further to take account of broadbanding and loadings. For most taxpayers, the only calculation required will be to reduce the rates if the taxpayer has elected to use the prime cost method of depreciation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deferral of the initial payment of company tax

PARA.TAB: The Bill will provide the legislation necessary to give effect to the announcement in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1991-92 income year.

The companies affected are those with a tax liability of $1,000 or more, but less than $400,000, and which pay their tax in two instalments. The date for the initial payment will be deferred by nine weeks from the twenty-eighth day of the month following the balance date to the twenty-eighth day of the third month following the balance date.
The amendments, which will defer revenue of $10m, will ensure that franking deficit tax and franking credits and debits will be determined as if there had been no deferral of the initial tax payment.

Taxpayers disposing of a business, or an interest in a business, will be subject to the capital gains tax provisions on any gain or loss realised on the disposal if the asset was acquired after 19 September 1985. The goodwill of a business may be one such asset. Under the existing provisions, 20 per cent of any capital gain realised on the disposal of goodwill is exempt from tax, provided that the net business interests of the taxpayer have a value of less than $1m.

In recognition of the unique circumstances facing the owners of small businesses, the Government has decided to increase the capital gains tax exemption for goodwill from 20 per cent to 50 per cent for disposals of goodwill that occur after 26 February 1992. In addition, the new exemption level will apply to taxpayers whose net business interests are worth up to $2m. The effect of inflation will be offset by the annual indexation of this exemption threshold in line with the consumer price index, commencing with the 1993-94 income year.

The Government also proposes a number of technical amendments to the capital gains tax provisions which are intended in some cases to clarify the operation and effect of the existing law and in other cases to alleviate the possible inequitable application of these provisions to taxpayers.

The estimated cost to the revenue of the increased goodwill exemption is $5m in 1992-93 and $10m in subsequent years. The additional amendments to the capital gains tax provisions are not expected to have any significant impact on the revenue.

The Bill will prevent the application of the research and development clawback provisions to certain eligible companies where a grant or recoupment is made by the Commonwealth under the cooperative research centres program.

The exclusion will also apply to a company that is a partner in a partnership designated as a cooperative research centre. However, this exclusion from the clawback provisions will not extend to an eligible company that is a partner in a partnership that is not designated as a cooperative research centre. These amendments will cost the revenue an estimated amount of $2m in 1991-92, $4m in 1992-93 and 1993-94, and $5m in 1994-95.

Amendments in this area reflect the Government's willingness to act on proposals for the smoother implementation of the accruals tax measures introduced with general effect from the 1990-91 income year.

In this vein, the Bill will correct certain anomalies which arise in relation to the tax exemption of branch profits of an Australian company when derived through a partnership or trust; and the incidence of double taxation that could arise in the case of certain transactions that are deemed to be dividends. The Bill will also amend certain exemptions from tax that apply to offshore life insurance businesses of resident companies to ensure that only the correct amount of relief is provided.

Also, in order to relieve taxpayers from an unintended liability to tax, the Bill will reduce the income of a controlled foreign company that is attributed to resident taxpayers by the amount of dividends paid to another company on certain transitional finance shares.

The Bill will provide a further benefit to taxpayers by extending the capital gains tax roll-over relief for asset disposals which is available when determining whether a controlled foreign company passes the active income test.

However, I must also emphasise the Government's determination to ensure that these measures have their intended effect in countering tax avoidance. In this regard, some of the amendments will ensure that:

SPEECH.PARA: .an election for capital gains tax roll-over relief for an asset disposal when determining whether a controlled foreign company passes the active income test is binding when calculating the amount of a capital gain on a subsequent disposal of that asset; and

.income from related party transactions with a controlled foreign company will escape attribution to resident taxpayers only where the company itself is conducting an active trade or business in its country of residence.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deductions for contributions to superannuation funds

PARA.TAB: This Bill will amend the income tax law to extend the circumstances in which deductions are allowable for contributions to superannuation funds to provide superannuation benefits to employees. In particular, the Bill will allow as deductions contributions to three superannuation funds if one of those funds has been established by a law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory. Under the existing law, the deduction is limited to two funds only. This amendment will have effect from 1 July 1990.

The Bill will also amend the law to enable substantially self-employed people with minimal employer superannuation support to receive the same higher maximum level of tax deductions for personal superannuation contributions as self-employed people and employees without superannuation support. Under the existing law, they are limited to a maximum of $3,000.

The change proposed by this Bill will mean that the maximum deduction is the lesser of $3,000 plus 75 per cent of the contributions over $3,000 and the amount required to fund their reasonable benefit level. The proposed amendment will apply to contributions made on or after 1 July 1991. These amendments are not expected to have a substantial impact on the revenue.

The gift provisions of the income tax law are amended to reflect a change in name of the World Wildlife Fund Australia to the World Wide Fund for Nature Australia. This change will have no impact on the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Pay and allowances of Defence Force members serving in Cambodia

PARA.TAB: This amendment will exempt from income tax the pay and allowances of members of the Australian Defence Force allotted for duty with the United Nations Advance Mission in Cambodia and the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia.

Relief from liability for half the Medicare levy, at present available to all health card holders, will be restricted to blind pensioners and sickness allowance beneficiaries. This will ensure that the law operates as the Government originally intended it to do.

In addition to the amendments of a technical nature to which I have already referred, the Bill will make technical change to amend the expression `resident' or `resident of Australia' to include Commonwealth public servants who are members of the new public sector superannuation scheme.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends 28 Acts to update provisions in them relating to superannuation. The amendments are required as a result of the enactment of the Superannuation Act 1990 and amendments made to the Superannuation Act 1976 with effect from 1 July 1990.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Act 1990 provided for the establishment of the public sector superannuation scheme, which was a new superannuation scheme for Commonwealth employees. The Superannuation Act 1976 provides for the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, which is the former main scheme for Commonwealth employees. The Commonwealth superannuation scheme was closed to new employees from 1 July 1990. That scheme remains open for existing members and to some former members who return to Commonwealth employment.

The amendments are of the following kinds. Firstly, where the Acts presently refer to the Superannuation Act 1976 or parts of that Act or to aspects of the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme, the amendments include corresponding references to the Superannuation Act 1990 and to the 1990 public sector superannuation scheme.

Secondly, where the Acts presently provide for the removal or retirement of office holders on grounds such as incapacity, the amendments include references to the invalidity retirement requirements of the Superannuation Acts 1976 and 1990. These requirements include that members of the superannuation schemes are not able to be retired on invalidity grounds unless the board of trustees of the relevant scheme has certified that the person is entitled to receive invalidity retirement benefits.

Thirdly, where the Acts presently provide for action to be done in accordance with superannuation arrangements approved by the Minister administering the Superannuation Act 1976, the amendments reflect the replacement of the provisions of that Act by the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990.

The amendments to the Acts are proposed to take effect from 1 July 1990. This reflects the date of commencement of the public sector superannuation scheme and the changes to the commonwealth superannuation scheme and the Superannuation Act 1976. Transitional or savings provisions are included in the Bill in relation to amendments to four of the Acts so that any action that might inadvertently have been taken that is inconsistent with the amendments will not be invalidated. The savings provisions for the Australian Federal Police Act 1979; the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984; and the Public Service Act 1922 are intended to protect the superannuation scheme membership of anyone who might inadvertently have become a member of one of the superannuation schemes when he or she should have become a member of the other scheme. The savings provision for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act is intended to protect a redeployment and redundancy benefit that might inadvertently have been paid by the Corporation in a form similar to pension benefits under the commonwealth superannuation scheme to any member of the public sector superannuation scheme.

This Bill will have no new financial effects. It makes only consequential amendments that reflect changes that have previously been put in place. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to proposed changes in the areas of telephone concessions, Job Search allowance and Newstart allowance, social security agreements with other countries, debt recovery, the income and assets test, compensation payments and data matching. The Bill also provides for a number of minor and technical amendments.

PARA.TAB: In the 1991 Budget the Government announced that from 1 July 1992 a new payment, known as telephone allowance, would replace the telephone rental concession voucher scheme. The new allowance will be more user friendly in that under the old concession scheme vouchers were sometimes misplaced or lost and pensioners were put to the inconvenience of obtaining replacements. It will also be much simpler to administer. The telephone allowance will be a payment of $51.80 per household each year. A lower rate of $25.90 per year will be paid where the person commenced to receive pension or benefit after 12 March 1992 and the person's partner is not getting a social security payment. It will be paid in quarterly instalments to pensioners who are permanently blind or who satisfy fringe benefit means tests and who are telephone subscribers. It will also be payable to certain social security beneficiaries aged 60 or over who are telephone subscribers and to certain other recipients of Commonwealth fringe benefits. The allowance will be indexed annually in line with CPI increases.

Last year the Government introduced a series of measures directed at young people under 18 years of age. One measure extended qualification for Job Search allowance and sickness allowance to 15-year-olds who meet the requirements for those allowances—apart from age—who are above the minimum school leaving age or have a formal exemption from attending school, who have an employment history, and who are not living with or being supported by a parent. This Bill will provide that 15-year-old Job Search allowance or sickness allowance recipients who are in substitute care, often referred to as foster care, will also be paid the higher independent rate of allowance. This measure will align the rate of Job Search allowance and sickness allowance for 15-year-olds with the rate for 16- to 17-year-olds in substitute care. It will further improve the overall level of income support to families who do not receive a substitute care allowance from a State or Territory authority and will encourage the substitute care of young people who may otherwise be at risk of homelessness.

The Bill will assist sole parents receiving Job Search allowance, Newstart allowance or sickness allowance whose only child is under 16 years and in employment. From the day of royal assent, the allowance will be paid at the higher maximum basic rate that is currently payable to a sole parent pensioner. This will ensure equitable treatment for pensioners and beneficiaries in similar circumstances. The allowee's child, despite being employed, will be taken to be dependent for the purposes of working out the allowee's maximum basic rate.

The Bill will remove an unintended restriction in the Social Security Act which prevents a recipient of Job Search allowance who is 18 or over, or Newstart allowance who is incapacitated for work for a period which is expected to be longer than six weeks in the case of Job Search allowance or 13 weeks in the case of Newstart allowance from being qualified for sickness allowance for six or 13 weeks. The Bill will enable the recipient to transfer to sickness allowance once the person is no longer qualified for Job Search allowance or Newstart allowance, subject to the recipient satisfying the usual qualification conditions for sickness allowance.

The Government will continue to target the provision of social security to those in need of assistance. To this end, the qualification conditions for Job Search allowance and Newstart allowance will be amended so that a person who is the subject of an assurance of support—the assuree—will not be qualified for Job Search allowance or Newstart allowance if the Secretary is satisfied that the assuror is willing to provide the person with an adequate level of support and it is reasonable to expect the person to accept that support. As a consequence of this measure, an assuror who is willing and able to comply with his or her obligations under an assurance of support will not incur a debt to the Commonwealth.

It is inappropriate for assurees who enter Australia on the understanding that they will be supported by an assuror to refuse, without good reason, to accept support which the assuror is willing and able to provide. Conversely, the interests of assurees will be protected by not requiring the assuree to accept such support in all cases; for example, where the assuree is subjected to abuse.

Austria is set to become the latest partner in the network of social security agreements between Australia and other countries. The Bill will provide for implementation of the agreement with Austria once it has been signed.

The Bill contains a measure which will facilitate the Department's capacity and responsibility to recover social security debts. The Act will be amended to provide that if a person owes to the Commonwealth an amount which is recoverable under the Act, the Secretary may recover the amount by making deductions from instalments of pension, benefit or allowance payable to another person. The consent of the latter person would be necessary. It will usually be the debtor's partner or relation who will agree to the deductions being made.

The Director of Public Prosecutions has commented critically on provisions in the Social Security Act which have created difficulties in prosecuting social security fraud. This Bill will remove these obstacles by repealing the provisions that prevent a social security recipient from relying on the privilege against self-incrimination when requested under the Act to provide information. The provisions that limit the use of information obtained from social security recipients, pursuant to the information gathering powers under the Act, will also be repealed. From the day of royal assent, pensioners, beneficiaries and allowees will have the same right as other citizens not to provide information that may tend to incriminate them in an offence.

The Bill will make a number of changes to the rules for the ordinary income test and the assets test. For some time now, people who are `asset rich but income poor' have sought to provide for themselves by accessing the equity in their principal home through a variety of sale/lease-back schemes. At present, under the Act a person who enters into such a scheme is treated as a non-home owner and is allowed the higher non-home owner asset limit under the assets test for pensions, benefits and allowances. In some cases a social security recipient would be better off if he or she was treated as a home owner—even though home owners are subject to a lower asset limit—because any amount outstanding under the contract of sale would be disregarded under the assets test.

The Bill will therefore align the treatment of sale/lease-back schemes with the treatment of retirement village residences and granny flat living arrangements. As a consequence, a person entering into a sale/lease-back agreement will be given the most advantageous result, whether as a home owner or a non-home owner.

The Mark Fitzpatrick Trust was established by the Government in 1989 to provide special financial assistance to people with medically acquired HIV infection and AIDS, their dependants and carers. In keeping with the Government's intention in setting up the trust, the Bill will provide that payments made from the trust will not be counted as ordinary income for the purposes of working out a person's rate of pension, benefit or allowance.

On 2 December 1991 my predecessor as Minister for Social Security announced a special measure to assist the restructure of unlisted property trusts in the wake of the downturn in sectors of the property market. The Bill will give effect to this by providing that, if a social security recipient with an investment in an unlisted property trust realises that investment and is paid out with investments—units—in another trust, any capital growth at the date of realisation will not be counted as ordinary income. However, the units in the other trust will be taken to be a new investment and will be subject to ongoing assessment. Only those investments in unlisted property trusts made or acquired before 9 September 1988 will be affected by this measure. It will apply only to investments in trusts that are realised and paid out with units in other trusts before 23 July 1992.

The Bill will make two changes which will assist a person whose partner has died. It will enable certain wife pensioners and carer pensioners who care for their partners to be transferred automatically to sole parent pension after the deaths of their partners without having to lodge a claim for that pension. This will prevent unnecessary intrusion into the person's grief and ensure that there is no break in continuity in the provision of income support where it is apparent that the person would be qualified for sole parent pension after the 14-week bereavement payment period.

Generally, a claimant for Job Search allowance, Newstart allowance or sickness allowance must serve a waiting period before receiving payment. The Bill will provide that a person whose partner has died and was receiving Job Search allowance, Newstart allowance or sickness allowance at a rate which included an additional amount for a partner will not have to serve the waiting period if he or she lodges a claim for one of the allowances within four weeks after his or her partner's death.

The Bill will make a number of minor changes in the area of compensation recovery, such as stipulating that a payment of arrears of periodic compensation is not a lump sum compensation payment and protecting insurers and compensation payers from legal action where they are prevented from releasing moneys after being served with a notice under the Act.

Finally, a number of amendments will be made to the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990—the data matching Act—and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These amendments relate to the matching of personal information and the use of tax file numbers. Most importantly, the Bill makes explicit that data matching results can be used to increase the assistance a person receives from the Commonwealth. Up to now, the legislative emphasis in that program has been on use of results to reduce assistance. Implementation of the data-matching Act has also demonstrated the need for some minor amendments.

As well, the Bill will give effect to recommendations made in a report tabled in Parliament in December 1990 by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, entitled The Proposed Tax File Number Provisions and Data-Matching Program. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, for Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has three major elements. First, it proposes to alter the salaries of members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It proposes to tie these salaries to those of judges of the Federal Court. Second, it proposes to vary the salaries determined by the Remuneration Tribunal for vice-chancellors and deputy vice-chancellors of the two universities which come within the Commonwealth's responsibility. Third, it proposes to broaden the range of persons eligible to be chairperson of the Remuneration Tribunal. The Bill also proposes to make minor technical corrections and clarifications to existing legislation. The proposed amendments are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members may appreciate a reminder of the genesis of the issues dealt with in this Bill. In May 1990, the Government received a determination from the Remuneration Tribunal on judicial and other remuneration. This had the effect—through the nexus between the salaries of members of the Commission and judges of the Federal Court—of proposing an increase of 14.3 per cent for members of the Commission.
