The Government responded by deciding that the remuneration of judges should be raised by 6 per cent with effect from 1 July 1990 and another 6 per cent with effect from 1 January 1991.

In the prevailing climate of recognition of the need for wage restraint by all in the community, the Government decided further that this should be varied: members of the Commission would receive the first stage of the increase but, since the Commission's structure should undergo the same process of review that it was overseeing in other public institutions, the second stage of the increase should be withheld pending this process.

In November 1990, following the robust discussion which followed these decisions, the Government established a review of the structure and remuneration of members of the Commission. The review was conducted by an eminent group: Mr Gerry Gleeson, AC, former head of the New South Wales Premier's Department; Justice Trevor Olsson of the South Australian Supreme Court; and Professor Alan Fels, Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority. The terms of reference for the review included that regard had to be had, among other things, for the central role of the Commission in industrial relations, its developing relations with State tribunals and the need to maintain its independence and effectiveness.

The report of the review was presented to the Government on 1 March 1991. Its recommendations included introduction of two new levels within the Commission's structure—a vice president and senior deputy president—and a revised structure of salaries. On 20 March 1991, the Government announced that it had accepted the recommendations of the review and that they would form the basis of a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal on the remuneration of members of the Commission. The Government forwarded a submission to the Tribunal on 28 March 1991 and a supplementary submission on 8 May 1991.

The Parliament passed amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to establish the new Commission structure in May 1991. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has accepted all of the Committee's recommendations as they provide a sound basis on which to strengthen the Commission's structure and to put it in a better position to address its increasing range of responsibilities and the wider scope of its jurisdiction.

These reforms will complement the initiatives which the Government took in framing the Industrial Relations Act to enable the Commission to exercise a broader jurisdiction. It will also facilitate the increasing co-operation between the Commission and its State counterparts, including through members of each being commissioned to hold office on both the Federal and State tribunals.
On 30 November 1991, six months having elapsed after the granting of royal assent, the amending legislation came into effect.

PARA.TAB: The Remuneration Tribunal forwarded its determination of remuneration for members of the Commission on 24 December 1991. The determination containing technical defects, the Tribunal indicated that a further determination had to be issued. The Government received this further determination on 9 March 1992. In these determinations, the Tribunal failed to establish salary rates for the new offices and it maintained the previous relativities between the various levels in the Commission structure. The Tribunal indicated that it would not determine remuneration for the new offices until persons were appointed to them and the duties to be performed established. Thus, the Tribunal's determinations prevented establishment of a salary structure for positions which, following the Parliament's decisions on the matter, had come into existence nearly six months earlier.

It is the Government's view that, like those who come before it, the Commission must be able to respond to evolving developments in the industrial relations environment as it adapts to the change taking place in the broad economy. In particular, the Commission must be able to facilitate the increasing cooperation between Federal and State tribunals. The new offices and the consequent revised relativities for the other offices of the Commission are critical for the creation of a more appropriate and effective structure for the Commission. In its amendments to the Industrial Relations Act last year, the Parliament accepted this view. Recruiting persons to fill the new offices, however, cannot be done until the salaries have been set.

Let me sum up for the benefit of honourable members. An eminent committee has conducted a full and objective review of the structure and remuneration of members of the Commission. The Government accepted the proposals of the committee. The Parliament agreed with the Government's decision and acted to create the structure which the committee proposed for the Commission. The Remuneration Tribunal has failed to establish salaries for the new structure which the Parliament has created. Recruiting persons to fill the new offices in this new structure cannot be done until the salaries for these new offices have been set. An impasse has been created, therefore, which the Government must resolve so that the will of the Parliament can be carried out.

This Bill proposes the means by which this can be done. It proposes to establish salaries and relativities with judicial salaries as the basis for future remuneration for the five levels of office holders on the Commission. This is in line with the recommendations of the Gleeson Committee which were accepted by the Government and endorsed by the Parliament.

The Bill proposes that the salary for the office of President of the Commission should continue to be equivalent to that of the Chief Justice of the Federal Court. The salary rate for the office of Senior Deputy President will become the benchmark for the internal salary relativities in the new Commission structure. It will be equated with that for a judge of the Federal Court. It is proposed that the salary for the office of Vice-President of the Commission should be 3 per cent higher than that for a Senior Deputy President; for the office of Deputy President, 95 per cent of that for a Senior Deputy President; and for the office of Commissioner, 70 per cent of that for a Deputy President.

Consistent with the Gleeson Committee report, the Government proposes to seek advice at regular intervals about the appropriateness of the relativities established by the nexus between salaries of members of the Commission and those of judges of the Federal Court.

This Bill also proposes to modify the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal relating to vice-chancellors and deputy vice-chancellors of universities within the responsibility of the Commonwealth. The reason for this is the concern which the Government had at the salary levels which the Tribunal has proposed for this group.

The salary levels proposed would have given this group significantly greater increases than those received by other public sector executives under the structural efficiency principle. Moreover, the Tribunal's determination anticipated a further review of the remuneration of heads of departments and other senior public sector executives in advance of any consideration by the Government.

The Government acknowledges the significant restructuring which institutions of higher education have undergone and the impact this has had on the work of vice-chancellors. This restructuring and its effects, however, have been no greater than that which has occurred elsewhere in the public sector at the Senior Executive Service level.

The Bill introduces new rates for vice-chancellors of Commonwealth institutions and their deputies consistent with those granted to university academic staffs and senior public servants. There will be appropriate adjustments to funding for non-Commonwealth institutions to reflect this decision.

I now turn to the question of the timing of these salary increases. The salaries proposed in this Bill for Commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and for vice-chancellors and their deputies will take effect from the date the Act receives royal assent. This group has already received the salaries proposed by the Remuneration Tribunal from 1 January 1991. The position for presidential members of the Commission is somewhat different because the Tribunal's determination does not take effect until 15 parliamentary sitting days after tabling. To ensure fairness to all concerned, the Government proposes that the new salary levels for presidential members of the Commission should also take effect from 1 January 1991.

I have referred to the proposal to change the qualifications for appointment to chair the Remuneration Tribunal. The details are as follows. Subsection 4(6) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 currently restricts appointment to the position of chairperson of the Tribunal to a person who is a judge or a retired judge of a State court or one who is qualified for appointment as a judge of a State court. This provision is not considered appropriate because of the conflict created as a result of arrangements agreed by the Commonwealth and States to prevent leapfrogging between Federal and State judicial salaries. Because of these arrangements, it could be inferred that the chairperson of the Tribunal, if a judge of a State court, could be in a position to influence his or her own remuneration. This provision also has the effect of restricting the field of candidates for appointment to the position. This Bill therefore proposes to remove this qualification for the position of chairperson of the Tribunal. Persons with legal qualifications will not be precluded from appointment by this action.

The Bill also proposes three minor technical amendments to the Act. They relate to the validity of certain determinations, the inclusion of an additional office within the jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal, and the restoration of an annual leave loading for particular office holders. The details of these proposed minor amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum.

Supplementation for additional expenditure in 1991-92 has already been provided to cover the salary increases determined by the Tribunal. The rates proposed in this Bill will reduce the call on the level of supplementation.

Mr Speaker, I would like to finish my remarks with two observations. They concern, first, the role of the Parliament in relation to determinations by the Remuneration Tribunal and, second, the standing and independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is alleged in some quarters that members of the Remuneration Tribunal have been offended by the fact that its most recent determination has not been accepted. The Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 which established the Tribunal explicitly provides for its determinations to be disallowed if the Parliament so wishes. Indeed, Parliament disallowed the very first determinations the Tribunal made in 1974. Its determinations have been overturned or modified seven times since then, not only in relation to the remuneration of members of parliament but also of other groups within the Tribunal's jurisdiction.

The Government must accept the ultimate responsibility for the effects of Tribunal determinations. It is therefore appropriate that it retain the right to disallow or modify these determinations. Indeed, the Opposition acknowledged this as recently as 1990, when Senator Durack stated in the Senate in debate on the Remuneration and Allowances Bill 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: For many reasons the Opposition has decided that it will not oppose this legislation. It simply wishes to reiterate the firm view that it takes in relation to the proper course of action for governments to take. When all is said and done, the ultimate decision in matters of this sort has to be made by the Government. It has to take the ultimate responsibility and it is not for oppositions to seek by some means or other to change that.

It is also alleged in some quarters that the Government's decision not to accept the Tribunal's most recent determinations somehow threatens the independence not only of the Tribunal but also of the Commission itself.

PARA.TAB: Section 72 (iii) of the Constitution states that the Justices of the High Court and other courts created by the Parliament `shall receive such remuneration as the Parliament may fix: but the remuneration shall not be diminished during their continuance in office'. Is it seriously suggested that this constitutional duty of the Parliament threatens the independence of the judiciary either in fact or in appearance? Before the Tribunal was established, decisions about the remuneration of all Federal judges and members of the Federal industrial tribunal were made by Cabinet on the advice of a very small committee of senior public servants. Is it suggested that this compromised the independence of such eminent Australians as Sir Owen Dixon or Sir Richard Kirby? To ask these questions is to answer them.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission has—and should continue to keep—a central role in the industrial and economic life of the nation. The Government has no time for the argument that it should be sidelined and made irrelevant to our industrial and economic well-being. It is a crucial influence on our economic policy-making and on our capacity to undergo economic reform. It has helped maintain industrial harmony and stability. It has provided access to wage justice for Australian workers, particularly those without power in the marketplace. Its manifest fairness and competence are the reasons why the tribunal system has been so strongly supported so widely and for so long. The Government's support for the standing, credibility and independence of the Commission remains as clear and as strong as it has ever been.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. I also table the Tribunal's recent determinations relating to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises that nuclear science and technology can be used in many ways which are beneficial to Australia. It was specifically to encourage the safe, peaceful and beneficial use of nuclear science and technology that the Government, in 1987, legislated to revise the charter and change the name of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. That legislation established the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, ANSTO.

PARA.TAB: It has become apparent, however, that the Act does not take proper account of a number of national interest requirements, or of the Government's commercialisation objectives for ANSTO. Accordingly, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill 1992 has been prepared to introduce appropriate amendments into the principal Act. I shall now outline the proposed amendments.

ANSTO has conditioned, stored and managed radioactive materials and wastes for many years both on its own account and on behalf of other parties. However, this activity was recently challenged when the Sutherland Shire Council took action in the NSW Land and Environment Court. It sought, inter alia, to restrain ANSTO from transferring to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories 17 cubic metres of radioactive waste from the St Marys site of Australian Defence Industries, and to require ANSTO to remove from Lucas Heights Research Laboratories some 2,000 cubic metres of radioactively contaminated soil from the former CSIRO site at Fishermans Bend, Victoria. These wastes were to be stored at Lucas Heights Research Laboratories pending the construction of a national repository for radioactive wastes.

The issue before the court was whether the storage was in accordance with the provisions of the NSW Environmental Planning and Assessment Act. Safety was conceded as not being an issue. The judge accepted that Lucas Heights Research Laboratories is presently the safest site in Australia for the storage of such material. In his decision on 5 February 1992, Mr Justice Cripps found in favour of the Council. His ruling, inter alia, restrained ANSTO from transferring the ADI wastes to Lucas Heights Research Laboratories and ordered ANSTO to remove the CSIRO wastes within three years.

One effect of these orders is to prevent ANSTO providing certain services essential for public health and safety. These include, for example, bringing to Lucas Heights Research Laboratories for repair packages containing radioactive substances which have been damaged in handling at airports. Such services are obviously in the public interest. In the circumstances, the Government has decided that ANSTO's powers in this area must be placed beyond doubt.

The amendments accord ANSTO the function of conditioning, managing and storing radioactive materials and waste from its own activities or from companies in which it has a controlling interest. The function extends to other radioactive substances from persons who are specified in regulations, thereby allowing parliamentary scrutiny where such cases arise.

The amendments respect the order of the NSW Land and Environment Court that ANSTO must remove the CSIRO waste from Lucas Heights by 5 February 1995. In addition, the ADI waste cannot be moved to Lucas Heights Research Laboratories except by specific regulation.

The judgment of the NSW Land and Environment Court has focused attention more sharply on the need for a permanent repository for Australia's low level radioactive wastes. My colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has been actively seeking the cooperation of the State and Territory governments in locating areas for investigation to identify a suitable site.

The Government has ordered a full investigation of the technical, legal and other issues concerning the conditioning, management and interim storage of the ADI and CSIRO wastes. A report will be prepared by December 1992 identifying all practicable options. These actions clearly demonstrate that the Government has no intention of allowing the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories to become, de facto, a national radioactive waste repository.

The Government decided some time ago that public research institutions such as ANSTO should be encouraged to become more commercial in their orientation and activities. ANSTO has made good progress in this direction. The proportion of non-Budget revenue in its total revenue reached 30 per cent in the 1990-91 financial year—two years ahead of schedule.

However, the ANSTO Act constrains the extent to which ANSTO can make further progress. The Act may not be sufficiently specific, for example, to provide for ANSTO's development and operation of its business and technology park. These amendments will ensure that ANSTO has a statement of functions which permits it to carry out fully the Government's intentions regarding the commercialisation of its activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Territory Laws

PARA.TAB: The degree to which ANSTO, a Commonwealth instrumentality situated in the State of New South Wales, is legally bound by NSW laws is a complex issue. The policy of successive Commonwealth governments is that such instrumentalities are to operate consistently with all State laws where there is no existing parallel Commonwealth law and where those laws do not directly conflict with the existing ANSTO Act.

However, advice has been received from the Attorney-General's Department that the ANSTO Act does not provide that ANSTO is a Commonwealth agent or emanation. ANSTO may, therefore, be fully subject to the laws of the State of New South Wales. The Commonwealth has never intended that ANSTO should be fully subject to State laws. Indeed, this situation is unacceptable, as it may impair ANSTO's ability to carry out its functions properly and may even be prejudicial to safety.

Accordingly, ANSTO is to be provided with immunity from certain classes of State and Territory laws. Similar clauses are included in the legislation which established ADI and the Civil Aviation Authority. On the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, the proposed amendment is to apply retrospectively. Once again, the amendment respects the judgment of the NSW Land and Environment Court in that it contains a clause excluding the CSIRO waste from immunity after 4 February 1995.

The ANSTO Act established a Nuclear Safety Bureau which is responsible to the Minister for monitoring and reviewing the safety of any nuclear plant operated by the organisation. The ANSTO board appoints the staff of the Bureau and may assign it other functions to perform. In practice, the NSB has operated with complete independence of ANSTO's management. However, the structure of the Act means that the independence of the NSB is open to question. The Government has decided, therefore, to amend the Act to ensure that the NSB is independent of ANSTO de jure as well as de facto. The new NSB will have the principal functions of monitoring and reviewing the safety of any nuclear plant owned or operated by ANSTO, and of providing technical advice to the Commonwealth on the safety of nuclear plant and related matters. It will be funded directly by parliamentary appropriation.

These sections of the Bill tidy up a number of administrative matters. They deal with matters such as employment conditions for the Executive Director of ANSTO, and the setting of a realistic maximum monetary level—$1m—for contracts which ANSTO can enter without ministerial approval.

The amendments have only minor financial implications. Additional costs in the order of $150,000 annually will be incurred on an ongoing basis to cover added administration costs associated with separating the NSB from ANSTO. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1992-93[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1992-93SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1992-93]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mr Willis.
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! Before the debate is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a cognate debate be allowed covering the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1992-93, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1992-93 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to be part of this debate which, as I am sure honourable members will be aware, has been very wide-ranging thus far. I am sure my contribution and the contribution of those following me will not be much different. At the outset, I make the observation that today around 25,000 families in the Northern Territory, with more than 42,000 children, will receive an additional special payment of family allowance of between $125 and $250 tax free. That is a welcome boost of around $4m to the Northern Territory economy.

PARA.TAB: When the Government first announced this expenditure, some people within the Northern Territory community bagged it. That is a polite way of putting it. Not only do they not understand the nature of the Northern Territory community; they do not understand the needs of many people within it. The most scandalous observation has been made by two members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and, in my opinion, it was quite racist. The observation which was made during a debate was that this money would be used on grog.

That observation was aimed at a particular group within the community. I believe it is reprehensible. It is something which should not happen. I believe that the people about whom these remarks were made should be given an apology. That has not happened. Unfortunately the people in the Northern Territory are used to these sorts of statements coming from conservative politicians.

This is a matter of great embarrassment to me as a Northern Territorian and to many people in the constituency; in fact, I would argue, without a shadow of a doubt, that it would be an embarrassment to the vast majority of people in the Northern Territory. It is time for the people who made those observations to shut up. The people who have taken the obligatory step of casting aspersions upon a particular group within our community should stop doing so, stop attacking them, stop undermining them and look at a positive way to build up community relations and assist people who are in need. That is what this money does.

Further, the 1,790 families that receive the family allowance supplement—that figure does not include those families who receive this payment as part of their pension or benefit—will gain a further $3.00 per week. More Territory families will be eligible for this allowance after the One Nation increase in the income eligibility limit. This is real help for Territory families.

The One Nation statement goes a lot further in helping Territorians. It addresses areas of concern in a number of industries, including tourism, which is a significant private sector employee in the Territory. The increase in the amortisation rate on tourism income producing buildings; the more generous depreciation rates; the ability to write off tourism infrastructure; and a $15m international tourism advertising campaign will be of genuine, immediate and lasting value to an industry which has suffered in the past as a result of a number of things, not exclusively, including the pilots dispute and the Gulf war.

In addition to tourism, other announcements in the One Nation statement mean that projects such as the Darwin to Alice Springs railway and new mining projects are more likely to become viable in the near future. An amount of $6m has been allocated for the upgrading of the Kakadu Highway. In addition, there is to be a very much needed new bus terminal, roadworks in Tennant Creek, and the Victoria River Highway is to be widened. By the time the project has been finalised, Federal Government expenditure on upgrading the Victoria Highway will be around $100m, a not insignificant amount. An amount of $18m has been allocated to develop the Three Ways to Brisbane link of the national highway network. I know that those people who travel on the Barkly Highway from Three Ways to Mount Isa and onward to Brisbane will appreciate that much needed expenditure.

These measures from the One Nation statement add to the significant Commonwealth expenditure already in the Northern Territory, particularly in the area of defence works and its related housing and other infrastructure. Of course, the vast majority of Territory taxpayers will benefit from the tax cuts also announced in the One Nation statement. There is no doubt of the positive impacts for the Northern Territory of not only the One Nation statement but also of the Government's ongoing commitment and programs in the Northern Territory.

Members of the Opposition who were part of the episode which occurred during Question Time today will need to spend time thinking about their actions. I would like to make just one quick observation: it showed an Opposition which had a glass jaw, which was unable to defend the indefensible, which was unable to carry the arguments on the merit of the policies it was putting forward, and which had to resort to the sorts of tactics of trying to disrupt this Parliament by subjecting the Chair to unfair criticism. The way those opposite have behaved in the last few days is a very poor reflection on their ability to state their case. It is also an indication of the strength and validity of the Government's arguments about the Opposition's `Frightback' package. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know you are about to tell me that we are adjourning for dinner—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—In actual fact, I was about to tell you that you cannot revive an earlier debate. The honourable member still has a few seconds left.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be reviving an earlier debate. During my contribution after the dinner break, I intend to amplify a number of remarks which have been made over the past few days in the public arena about the `Frightback' document. It is very important for my constituents in the Northern Territory for that to take place. It is also very important for this Parliament.
—Now that we have all had the chaff bag on, I am pleased to be able to resume my speech. We all look as if we have had a very comfortable hour.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I think the appropriate wording is that we have been on a good pasture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, on a good pasture.
—He's looking for some more praise. Just tell him he's done a great job.

—You have done a great job, Mr Deputy Speaker, and you have filled many chaff bags. Before it was time to shove the nosebag on, I was about to address the impact of the Opposition's goods and services tax on the constituents of the Northern Territory. I would like to go through the issues that have arisen as a result of the national prices task force March results. Its survey of groceries shows that the average basket price for the Northern Territory was $83.93. If we take 10 per cent off the prices of those goods currently subject to a wholesale tax—and this is being generous to the Opposition, because we are taking only 10 per cent off the retail price, not the wholesale price—and add a 15 per cent goods and services tax to the balance, we find that the average Darwin resident will be paying $93.15 for his or her basket, which is an increase of $12.16. If we carry out the same exercise on an Adelaide basket, the value of goods in the basket comes to $75.60, which is an increase of $9.86. A Darwin family is paying 23 per cent more for that basket of goods after the imposition of the goods and services tax than its counterparts in Adelaide.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask Opposition members whether that is what they mean by helping families. I would like to ask them further what they mean by helping families who really suffer as a result of the tremendously high expenses in terms of buying the essential items of food and clothing. Let me give an example. A breakdown of the typical foods that might be bought in a remote community—that is, essentially, a remote Aboriginal community in northern Australia—is provided by Gracey and Sullivan, who constructed what they call the market basket based on food consumption patterns amongst Aboriginal families in the Kimberley. In a moment I will give the estimate of Gracey and Sullivan of the commonest food purchases of an average family of mother, father, two children and one baby for a fortnight.

A recent examination of the price of these goods in a typical Sydney supermarket—this survey was undertaken in about November of last year—suggests that this basket would be purchased for $237 in a capital city, in this case Sydney. We should bear in mind that the costs in Darwin would be at least 10 to 30 per cent higher than they are in Sydney. Research by the Northern Territory Department of Health and Community Services indicated that foodstuff prices in remote community stores might be between 30 and 60 per cent higher than Darwin supermarket prices, which are themselves approximately between 10 and 30 per cent higher than the average capital city rate.

If we assume that the remote community prices are 40 per cent higher than in Darwin, this makes them approximately 54 per cent—if we use the 10 per cent higher prices for Darwin—higher than those in capital cities. On this basis, the basket of goods could be expected to cost $365 in remote communities—$237 in Sydney and $365 in a remote Aboriginal community. In all probability, in a remote Aboriginal community, 80 to 90 per cent of the population would be on unemployment benefits or some other welfare benefit. Of course, this estimate could be conservative. In many communities, prices can be double those in capital cities.

Of the basket of goods which I have here, sales tax is payable on only soft drink, chips, sweet and cream biscuits, and orange juice. Soft drink is taxed at 20 per cent of the wholesale price; the other four items are taxed at 10 per cent of the wholesale price. If we assume that the wholesale prices for these items are 30 per cent below final community store prices, the wholesale sales tax that would be levied on this basket of goods would be $9.28, or $241 over a year, which is approximately 2.5 per cent of the final retail price of these goods. In the case of the imposition of a 15 per cent consumption tax, a total of $55 might be expected to be paid in addition each fortnight, which over a period of a year would add up to $1,425.

That is not a bad imposition! In fact, it is an onerous burden that would be put upon these people by the imposition of the 15 per cent consumption tax. We should remember that these are people who, by and large, will be dependent upon welfare payments of some description or government transfers and whose discretionary income would be almost nil. To a large extent, one would expect that probably 70 to 80 per cent of what income they had would be spent on basic items such as food and clothing. These are the people who would be suffering the most under the imposition of a 15 per cent goods and services tax. One might ask—and certainly the people of the Northern Territory would ask: what compensatory packages has the Opposition proposed which would go anywhere near alleviating this onerous burden? Is this what Opposition members mean when they say that they have been looking after the bush?

Over the last couple of days, we have noted the sort of suggestions which have been made as a result of the Fightback proposals and the publicity stunts which have been put out by the Opposition, particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). What I have now come to call the Opposition's Harpic milkshake and Pal diet is what it would have us believe would be a responsible analysis of what the average basket of goods would comprise in the supermarket. I say to Opposition members that what they need to do is look clearly, fairly and squarely at the consumption patterns of those people who live in these remote areas, their income levels, their ability to pay the 15 per cent imposts and how they would suffer. In my view, one can come to only one conclusion: that these people would be severely disadvantaged. I might say that this 15 per cent would, of course, flow across the whole of the community.

There are many aspects to this proposal which, I think, deserve special attention. Perhaps one of the most insidious is the proposal to cut, as the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said today, $10.1m out of expenditure in gross terms, or $4.7m in net terms, from government outlays in terms of the public sector. This, of course, would have an horrendous impact on a community such as the Northern Territory, whose Government is, in large part, dependent upon the expenditure which comes out of the Federal capital. Indeed, the Opposition might also look at the proportion of Northern Territory people who work in the public sector.

As at September 1991, 64,000 of the 154,848 people in the Northern Territory were employed; 42,400 are in the private sector and 21,600 are in the public sector. We have heard again today about the Opposition's attitude towards those people who work in the public sector. We have heard that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) believes that they should be kneecapped—or cut off at the knees, I think, was the term that he used. Nothing could be more scandalous or shameful than a person who would purport to be the Deputy Leader of the Government attacking the public sector in this way. I might say that in terms of the threats which—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the Government?
—If he would be, as I said, the Deputy Leader of the Government. He is a would-be—and he never will be. Let there be no doubt.
—He has been condemned by his own mouth, as the Leader of the Opposition has been condemned by his mouth.
—Order! The honourable member for Forrest should not be provoking.

—He is not being provoking. I am enjoying the repartee. He is being condemned by his own mouth. The fact is that he supports the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who would argue that public servants should eat their children and that they should be kneecapped.
—That's a beauty.

—He said it. If those opposite do not support him, they should say so. If they do not support him, they should disown him. It is a scandal that he should even suggest such a thing. In the Northern Territory, a community that is largely dependent on public sector transfers, we are seeing propositions put by the Opposition which would gut the Northern Territory public sector. I might just remind the Opposition that last year we saw an exercise by the Northern Territory Government in cutting back its own expenditure—ERC cuts. That had a very detrimental impact upon the Northern Territory community. In 1991 these ERC cuts amounted to $108m, and $60m or 55.5 per cent of this was in wages. That is the equivalent of 1,233 jobs. In terms of the multiplier effect that that had on the Northern Territory economy, that worked out to about $290m—negative in terms of its impact on the Northern Territory economy.

PARA.TAB: If we take the Fightback package to its logical extreme, it would propose cutting at least between $46m and $50m in revenue to the Northern Territory government. If we extrapolate this and look at the ERC cuts of $60m, we are probably looking at a loss of at least 500 jobs. Those opposite have put out a pamphlet—a fraudulent pamphlet, a pamphlet that lies, a pamphlet that is guesswork—which says that they are going to create two million jobs. Let there be no doubt: the immediate impact of the imposition of the Fightback package, the goods and services tax proposal, on the Northern Territory would be the loss of at least 500 jobs. That is not bad for a document which has been strewn around the Northern Territory in a mailing campaign in the last week and which tells lies. There is no other word for it: lies.

What defence do we have from those opposite? When the heat was put on today, they attacked the Speaker. There is no doubt that they are scared because they can see the damage that the Government's opposition to their package is doing to them in the community. The little stunt today was all about the by-election in Wills and trying to distract media attention away from the Government's attack on the Fightback package.

It has backfired—tremendously backfired, as the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), who is at the table, has said. I point out that my good friend the Minister said, as he well should, that the policies that those opposite are proposing, including the basket of goods, I have termed the `Harpic, milkshake and Pal diet: Move over, Rover'. Well might Rover move over. If I were Rover I would be very scared of getting ticks, because that is about the only thing he would get from the Opposition. He would get no gratitude or good fortune. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity of speaking in this debate tonight on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1992-93, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1992-93 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93. I have noted that the debate last night and tonight has been a very wide ranging debate indeed. I want to start off by talking about the proposed development of the CSIRO site at North Ryde, which is a project that is going to cost in the vicinity of $100m. One of the major propositions associated with that redevelopment is the relocation of the food processing division. Last year there was a CSIRO feasibility study into what could happen, and that study reported in January this year. Now the CSIRO has appointed a review of that particular feasibility study, which did suggest that none of the country aspirants for the relocation would be successful. It is interesting, too, that only yesterday the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works submitted a report relating to the CSIRO redevelopment which suggested that the food processing laboratory should be relocated in the Riverina area.

PARA.TAB: I am a bit concerned that, apart from Wagga Wagga, the areas that also were interested in the proposed development—Coffs Harbour and Port Macquarie, both of which are in my electorate, Werribee in Victoria and Lismore, which is also on the north coast of New South Wales—have not been considered by the Parliamentary Committee. I will come back to that in a moment. I just want to make the point that I will be in here fighting to the last ditch for both communities in my electorate, Port Macquarie and Coffs Harbour, to see that they get every possible consideration.

I am a bit perturbed about the poor people of Lismore, who were also aspirants for this relocation but appear to have been rather left in the lurch. I will come back to the question of relocation, but I want to talk about the situation regarding the 25,201 political orphans in the Lismore area of the electorate of Richmond. It will come as a great shock to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure, to learn that the current honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) has abandoned the people from the Lismore part of his electorate who elected him, and he has skipped off to the north. I am absolutely appalled because he shot through like a Bondi tram. He has left in the lurch 25,201 electors who voted him in as the honourable member for Richmond. He has now closed his office in Lismore and gone back to the northern part of his electorate. In fact, in what I consider to be an irresponsible dereliction of duty, he wrote on 20 February 1992 to the residents that he has abandoned. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Resident,

As you probably know, the boundaries for the Federal electoral divisions in New South Wales have been changed by the Australian Electoral Commission. This means that at the next election you will be in the Federal electorate of Page, which is represented by Harry Woods, MP. I have been pleased to have represented the people of Lismore as your local Member of Parliament for almost two years. My job as your local MP has been both informative and rewarding and I would like to thank you for your support during that time.
This is a ta-ta letter, Mr Deputy Speaker. He continued:

I would like to take this opportunity to introduce you to the member for Page, Mr Harry Woods, MP. His office is situated at 82 Prince St Grafton and he will soon be opening an office in Lismore. I know that Harry and his staff, David, Annette and Linda will be pleased to help you with any Federal issues or concerns you may have.

This is a member of this Parliament saying goodbye to 25,000 of his constituents and walking away and leaving them because the redistribution at the next election is going to change the boundaries. I must say that I believe this is a disgraceful and absolutely outrageous piece of behaviour. His letter went on:

Harry has been an active member of the business and wider community of the north coast for many years and understands the issues that concern us here. I know Harry to be a hard worker for the residents of the Page electorate and will work hard to represent the people of Lismore in the Federal Parliament.
Yours sincerely
Neville Newell MP
Federal Member for Richmond

I am not aware that the honourable member for Richmond has any dispensation from the Parliament to abandon 25,000 of his electors. I do not know that he has any dispensation from the Electoral Commission to treat his constituents with such contempt. But I must say that I am absolutely appalled by it.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation where the honourable member for Richmond is just shooting through, as I said before, like a Bondi tram, in what I believe is an act of desertion. He is just abandoning ship and neglecting 25,000 of his electors. Of course, he has passed the ball to another member of this Parliament who is not the member representing the people of Lismore, namely the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who in this case is a usurper. I believe there is a great deal of impropriety involved, if not, perhaps, even illegality. I do not know, but certainly it is improper for the honourable member for Page to go and be a squatter in the Federal seat of Richmond, which is not in his electorate. As I believe he will be beaten at the next election, he will never represent the people of Lismore in any electorate. But there he is like a cuckoo in the nest. And he has opened an office there. I have had a number of complaints from people in that area who say that they cannot get in touch with their own member. I even had a report today from a woman who rang the Lismore office of the honourable member for Page, shop 14, Star Court Arcade, Molesworth Street, Lismore, and this lady took notes of her conversation. It was not recorded, of course, so they may be slightly inaccurate, but she assures me that she has the thrust of it.

The conversation went like this: `Is that the office of Neville Newell, Federal member for Lismore?'. `No, this is Harry Woods's office'. `Isn't Mr Newell my Federal member? I live just outside of Lismore'. `No, Harry Woods has taken over Lismore now'. What a disgrace. The lady who spoke to me said, `When did that happen? There hasn't been an election'. The answer was, `Quite a while ago. I'm not sure, but months ago'. This is Federal members of this Parliament playing ducks and drakes with their electorates, passing out bits to themselves. The next question was, `Is this Lismore office operating every day?'. `Well, we are supposed to be open every day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. This isn't always so as we are supposed to be manned by volunteers, but they are not very reliable and we are doing the best we can coming up from Grafton'. The final question from the woman who contacted me was, `I'm confused. Who is my Federal member? I've been to Mr Newell in the past to help me'. It was suggested, `Harry Woods has taken over from Mr Newell, but if Mr Newell has your file perhaps you should contact him in Tweed Heads'.

I submit that this is a most reprehensible turn of events, and I believe that the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Page should be heavily censured because of this contempt of the electors—just to parcel out between themselves the existing electorates of Page and Richmond. I come back to the question of the relocation of the CSIRO food laboratory—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I know that the honourable member for Cowper does not want to press that matter of contempt of the electors too much. I would be counselling him against that and I—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have finished with the subject, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Yes. The Chair would be a bit disturbed about that. I know you are moving on to other matters now.

—I am in the process of so doing. As I said earlier, I am concerned about the fact that the Public Works Committee has made a recommendation that the CSIRO should relocate its food research laboratory to Wagga Wagga. I know that the Federal members from that area are very pleased about that, but I am concerned that the Committee in examining the situation interviewed people from Wagga Wagga but did not invite opinions from anywhere else. I know that the very reasonable answer will be that it was advertised in the Sydney Morning Herald. I know it was, as I have a copy of the advertisement, but it is very easy for people in Coffs Harbour, Lismore and Port Macquarie to miss one ad in the Sydney Morning Herald.

PARA.TAB: I would have been much happier if the Committee had invited other aspirants to give evidence as well, because the Committee has brought down a recommendation that it believes that the food research laboratory of the Division of Food Processing can operate effectively in a non-capital city location. I certainly believe that is the case. I take this opportunity to speak on behalf of Port Macquarie and Coffs Harbour, because both communities have been very active in seeking the relocation of this laboratory and the division. Both John McGahn and the Hastings Municipal Council have been very active. They have had a lot of work done on submissions. In the Coffs Harbour area, coordinators of the submission were headed by Mr Graeme McDougall, who did an enormous amount of work.

Because the feasibility study reported in January, a review committee has been set up, and I believe that all the other aspirants should have the opportunity of making additional submissions. If we are talking about a coastal location, it can take longer to drive through all the traffic from the University of Western Sydney to the Sydney University than to fly from a coastal location, and the lifestyle is so much more attractive. I say too that, with the advent of fibre optics, the divisions of distance are being wiped away. It would be appropriate for the Committee to have another look at the situation, but it would certainly be appropriate for the CSIRO review committee to look at all the other aspirants for the relocation.

I now move to something that was raised with me by a great friend of mine, Mr Stan Harris of Wauchope, a regular correspondent who keeps me on the ball in many ways and keeps me informed in many ways, too. I am very grateful to him that he drew to my attention an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 March 1992 with the headline, `Health Insurance Deal Under Fire'. In this Parliament when we hear the word `deal' we know it has something to do with the Government.

The information in this article indicates that Medibank Private and the Public Sector Union have done a deal for the provision of health insurance to union members and their families at substantial discounts. I am very much afraid, Mr Deputy Speaker, that what we are seeing here is the setting up of two Medibank Privates—one for special groups such as the Public Sector Union and one for ordinary citizens such as you and me.

There was an announcement by the 107,000-member Public Sector Union that it had entered into an agreement with Medibank Private to provide union members and their families with tailored health and hospital insurance plans at a discount of about $15 a week on normal family premiums. Of course, this arrangement is not available to other fund members. This means that, if one is not a public servant, in terms of Medibank Private one is a second-class citizen. I think it should be asked: why is there this discrimination? That $15 a week is virtually a gift of $800 a year. Seventy five per cent of the Australian work force are not members of the PSU, and this arrangement is not available to other fund members.

It was suggested that, because of Medibank Private negotiating this deal, there is likely to be—and I think it is a reasonable assumption—an all-out recruiting war between insurers trying to do deals with large employers and employee groups at cheap prices. I do not believe that that will be in the best interests of the citizens of Australia. If Medibank Private or any other provider of health insurance services can provide them at $15 a week less, it should be able to do it for all of its clients. I can see no equity and no justice in the proposition that, because one happens to belong to a certain organisation, be it a trade union—I am not union bashing—or any other group, one will get an $800 gift at the expense of other Australians. I take this opportunity to make a significant protest about that.

My next point concerns second-hand Japanese car engines coming into Australia. I want first to refer to a press release by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, dated Monday, 2 December 1991, in which he said the Government was not willing to let cars forced off the road in Japan by tough registration laws there to undermine the Australian industry. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Importers planning to bring these cars into Australia must realise we will not allow second-hand imports to jeopardise the local industry.
Senator Button said he was also concerned that consumers could buy one of the second-hand imports without realising the potential problems they could face. He said:
I am not convinced that people buying these cars would have access to a full range of spare parts.
And so he went on. My concern goes beyond the second-hand cars to the second-hand engines. I want to quote briefly from a Government publication called Importing Vehicles to Australia. It says:

Australian vehicles are amongst the safest in the world. We have a system of checking vehicles to make sure they have very high safety standards. These are in accordance with the uniform national standards for all vehicles which are the Australian Design Rules (ADRs).
We also insist on strict environmental controls for vehicles in Australia.

Of course they do. And so they should. I certainly believe in competition and I am quite happy for importers to bring in second-hand Japanese motors, provided they are on the level playing field—to use the current phrase—and they are subject to ADRs, the same as anything else. But I do not believe this is the case. The document goes on:
The Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, which came into effect on 1 August 1989, makes it an offence to import a new or secondhand vehicle unless:
.it meets the safety and emissions standards applying to vehicles to be used on Australian roads.
It has been suggested to me that, while that is the legal situation regarding an engine in a second-hand car, it is not being applied to second-hand engines coming in by themselves.
I think that is of some concern. The document concludes:
It is an offence to sell a vehicle which does not meet the ADRs or which is not fitted with a compliance plate and such action may attract a penalty of up to $12 000.
If it is an offence to sell a car that does not meet the compliance regulations, I believe it should also be an offence to sell a second-hand imported engine.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that more than 66,000 second-hand engines entered Australia last year and they are still coming in at the same rate this year. The ABS has recorded that 35,859 units were imported in the financial year to January 1992—that is, in seven months. So that level of importation is continuing.

I certainly know that the consumers who need a second-hand or a reconditioned engine want a cheaper job. But other factors are involved. Something like 300 engine reconditioners are operating around Australia and they provide a lot of employment. According to the figures I have been given, because 66,000 second-hand engines are coming in there is the possibility of something like 1,400 jobs being lost every year, which is not appropriate. The other point is that if 66,000 second-hand engines are imported from Japan and they go into cars here which have crook engines, it means that 66,000 engines are not reconditioned and are dumped in garbage dumps right around Australia. I think that is a great waste. My main point is that the consumers should get a fair go. But that fair go for consumers does not apply only to price; it applies to quality, emissions control and other very important factors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use this debate on the Supply Bills to talk about the most important element of the One Nation statement: investment in national infrastructure. Australia is only just starting to emerge from a severe and prolonged recession. Substantial government action to stimulate renewed economic activity is therefore essential. The only debate during the last few months has been about the extent of the stimulus. It is also generally accepted that part of the stimulus should be increased infrastructure investment.

PARA.TAB: That is a refreshing change from the unrelenting advocacy by some groups, particularly the Opposition, of cuts in public outlays during the 1980s. Of course, the Opposition, astonishingly, wants to continue those cuts at present. Commonwealth and State governments have been under constant pressure to reduce their outlays. Now, however, there is general recognition throughout the community, except on the other side, that the Government must act in counter-cyclical ways to stimulate the economy when it has been so deeply recessed. It is simply not enough to reduce interest rates in the hope that the private sector will renew investment. Fiscal stimulus is also essential.

Infrastructure investment is one of the most cost-effective forms of economic stimulus. It has a significant multiplier effect, for there is relatively low leakage to imports. That is a centrally important factor. Most of the inputs are of labour or materials which are produced in Australia. As well, infrastructure contributes directly to the productivity of the private sector by improving the quality of support services.

The highest priority for government for the next year or two must be to renew economic activity and slow the growth of employment. Unemployment is disastrously destructive for those directly affected and their families and it involves enormous economic waste for the whole community. Despite our openness to the rest of the world, there is much which government and business can do to renew economic activity.

One positive by-product of a severe recession is that we are reminded of the interdependence of the public and private sectors. There is now no part of the business, farming or mining communities which does not support government action to stimulate recovery.

Infrastructure is the solid skeleton of community services. Infrastructure has been neglected by many who have not noticed that they are not charged directly for the roads on which they drive, for the subsidies to public transport on which they or their employees travel to work, for the schools attended by the majority of children, or the hospitals used by the majority of the sick. Public infrastructure is neglected by the Opposition in its so-called Fightback package.

When the public infrastructure suddenly collapses or fails, governments are blamed for lack of foresight and investment. The recent flood in Sydney—and there was another one today—led to publicity about the inadequacy of Sydney's drainage system. The inadequacy of that system has been well recognised by the drainage experts for many years. It was only when the system failed and there was widespread flooding again that the lack of investment was recognised. Drainage experts say that about $2 billion should be spent on Sydney's drainage system over the next 10 years.

The inadequacy of the Pacific Highway was recognised only when there were major accidents. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), has been a strong advocate of upgrading the Pacific Highway. I wish he were here to hear what I have to say about it. The damage caused by the failure to invest at all in railways during the last decade—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am reluctant to interrupt my colleague the honourable member for Fraser, but I draw your attention to the state of the House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! A quorum not being present, the sitting will be resumed at 8.50 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A quorum being present, I call the honourable member for Fraser.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. How wonderful to have such a large audience for a centrally important speech on public infrastructure! I think the Opposition's failure to show any interest in this subject is a clear example of the cuts it would make through its so-called Fightback package. But the Government has clearly accepted the view that public infrastructure is important, as is shown in the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: I was in the middle of a clear explanation of this when I was so rudely interrupted. There is evidence from many countries that a slowdown in public investment can help explain a significant portion of the slump in productivity growth during recent years. That is clearly shown from evidence in the United States and many other OECD countries. The outlays in the One Nation statement are particularly well targeted too, for they show clearly that they would increase public investment, they would increase expenditure on TAFE and they would stimulate private investment.

One of the interesting things happening at present with our major trading partners, the Asian tigers, is that they accept the same insight. In 1991 both South Korea and Taiwan announced huge new infrastructure programs, and such programs have been under way in Hong Kong and Singapore for some years. The Financial Times reported, for example, that the South Korean Government aims at increasing the total length of roads from 57,000 to 400,000 kilometres and that of its underground railways from 150 to 500 kilometres over the next couple of decades. It plans 60 new power stations, two new airports, a high speed railway system, several new ports and expanded waterworks. In Taiwan, similar programs are under way.

It is, of course, true that those east Asian countries are less developed than Australia. Yet if we are looking for lessons from those countries which are growing successfully at present, we could well take note of the priority they are giving to upgrading their infrastructure at a time when there are still great gaps in our own.

Lack of maintenance of Australia's infrastructure is also of concern. Declining public investment is linked with declining spending on maintenance. The worst fears of major infrastructure networks falling apart in Australia are probably unfounded, even though there have been some catastrophes in the United States and elsewhere. But Australia's infrastructure networks were begun at about the same time as those in Europe and the United States.

To avoid the problem of the gradual inevitable deterioration of infrastructure we need careful planning. Without adequate maintenance infrastructure will deteriorate rapidly. Maintenance and replacement needs will substantially increase during the rest of this decade owing to the age pattern of Australian infrastructure. Unless funding requirements due to ageing can be offset by savings elsewhere, public investment must rise, simply to ensure that existing infrastructure is maintained.

It says something for the managers of public assets that they have been able to maintain public infrastructure reasonably well with a declining share of national resources. This situation is now changing with increased requirements for rehabilitation and maintenance, and that again is one of the important outcomes of the One Nation statement. Fortunately there is a renewed commitment by the Commonwealth Government to national infrastructure.

A major policy statement was adopted as Party policy at the ALP national conference in June last year. The first step towards implementing that policy was included in the November employment statement. The One Nation statement gives further expression to that policy, to filling gaps, to improving the quality of existing infrastructure and to meeting the need for maintenance and renewal.

It is not only the quantity of spending which is important. There are many ways in which the efficiency of delivery can be improved. The establishment of the National Rail Authority can be expected to substantially improve the efficiency of rail freight handling. Corporatisation of some statutory authorities has contributed to improving efficiency through increasing the responsibility of boards and of management for the efficiency of their enterprises. Price systems have been changed in some areas to more closely reflect market conditions, but certainly insufficient account has been taken of externalities, both positive and negative.

There may well be a case for private sector involvement in infrastructure provision in some areas. Privatisation is generally not appropriate, because it would simply involve translating a public monopoly into a private monopoly with the inevitable opportunities that that creates for exploitation of market power. Private provision of infrastructure is inevitably more costly than through the public sector in one regard; the interest rate paid by private infrastructure companies is inevitably higher than that paid by the Government itself.

Even when private monopolies are extensively regulated, the difficulty of preventing exploitative prices or reductions in the quality of service delivery is greater than when the enterprises were in the public sector. Private sector competition may well be an option in some areas. It will be interesting to see the impact on Telecom of a second telecommunications network. However, cosy duopolies are scarcely involved in intense competition. In certain areas, user charges and franchising may provide means of mobilising private capital.

The risk occurs because the private provision of infrastructure is difficult to scrutinise. Niches can be created which allow unconstrained overpricing. As well, circumstances often set limits to private sector involvement. While it may be possible to charge tolls on bridges, tunnels or on certain roads, that is often not feasible if the service is to be generally available.

Normally, infrastructure will be provided more accountably, accessibly and equitably by the public sector. The pressure for efficiency can be maintained through complaints mechanisms, by scrutiny by the public auditor, by Parliament and by consumer groups. This does not rule out business involvement; it just means that such involvement must be evaluated comprehensively, taking account of all costs, benefits and externalities, including accessibility and equity.

There would be little difficulty in funding substantially increased public infrastructure. That is what the One Nation statement shows. It is entirely appropriate that such public investment should be funded by borrowing, as is most business and domestic investment. The benefits of investment are received for many years. Those who receive the benefits can contribute to the cost of the investment through contributing to interest and loan repayment. There is no risk of public borrowing crowding out private borrowing when there is a recession. In any case, the evidence for crowding out in Australia is weak at the best of times.
Even the Economist editorialised recently that borrowing for investment by governments is appropriate because:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . future generations who enjoy the benefits of that investment will pay for it through higher interest payments.
This `seems to give reflation a ring of prudence', the Economist concluded.

PARA.TAB: Australia has a lower level of government debt than all but one other Western country. To use the flexibility that gives us to increase economic activity when the economy is only just starting to emerge from recession is simply responsible.
To conclude, there has been a simple theme for what I have been saying. It was expressed recently by Professor Russell Mathews, who wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: When there are so many Australians who desperately need jobs and so many jobs desperately need doing, it does not require great ingenuity to use each problem as a means of solving the other. What is necessary is an end to. . . policies that frustrate all attempts to achieve that result.

That is what we have been given in the One Nation statement. That statement is a breakthrough in economic policy because it is directed at improving economic productivity and efficiency in the economy in the areas where government expenditure was needed most.

PARA.TAB: That expenditure was concentrated principally on infrastructure, but also on technical and further education and on stimulating business investment. Those are the three areas which will bring us out of recession. There was a whole series of other minor expenditure outlays which were very well targeted also, but those were the three crucial areas. That statement was ideally targeted; therefore it should be strongly endorsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Supply Bills tonight, I would like to pick up on a few points the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) raised in regard to the coalition's Fightback package. Either the honourable member for the Northern Territory cannot read or he fails to understand the huge benefits of the Fightback package not only for people throughout Australia but certainly for those in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: To the small business sector, Fightback means a cut of $20 billion in taxes that flow through to the community through more competitive and cheaper prices. I would have thought that, if the honourable member for the Northern Territory knew anything about Fightback, he would have realised the enormous benefits to the Northern Territory that the package would bring.

Cuts to the fuel excise of $6.6 billion will mean that every form of transport by motor vehicle, truck or bus will be substantially cheaper in the Northern Territory. The number of aircraft that fly around the Northern Territory, small aircraft that use avgas, will also substantially benefit through lower costs in operating in those areas.

Fightback cuts and scraps wholesale sales tax at a saving of some $9.4 billion. The honourable member should also be aware that, during this Government's term in office, it has been successful in increasing sales tax from $3.4 billion in 1983 to $9.4 billion today. One thing it has been very successful in doing is screwing more tax out of the Australian consumer—a well hidden tax but, nonetheless, a tax on everything we touch and, in part, what we eat.

The payroll tax cuts proposed in Fightback amount to $5.8 billion. While some small businesses do not pay payroll tax, many of the businesses they deal with do pay it, and those charges are passed on in the costs that they give to those small businesses.

Fightback also rewards those people who want to put in hard work and effort. It is a package designed to reward hard work and effort—a package that gives tax cuts of up to 30 per cent. I know that many of the tradesmen around this country do not work overtime because they are taxed so heavily for it that they are worse off as a result. Take the case of a tradesman on $450 per week. After tax, he is on about $9.88 per hour. If he works a Saturday, the first two hours at time and a half and thereafter at double time, his gross goes up to about $627, his tax doubles—and what happens to his hourly rate? It drops to about $8.87 an hour. So what does he do? He says, `I'm not interested in working overtime because it's not worth my while'—because this Government taxes away the incentive for him to work.

If we want to get this country back to work, if we want to trade our way out of the problems we are in today, we have to be able to give people the incentive to do it. Under our tax proposals, the average tradesman will be able to double his income and not move up into the next tax scale. Today, just on half of all taxpayers pay a tax rate of 38c in the dollar or more—up to 47c in the dollar. Under our tax proposals, 95 per cent of all taxpayers will pay a tax rate of 30c in the dollar or less. As a result of our lifting the tax-free threshold from $5,400—something, I might add, that this Government has never done—to $7,000, an additional 320,000 Australians will drop out of the tax net altogether.

The incentives in this package to business are enormous. Let us take the capital gains tax. We do not just muck around and tinker about the edges like One Nation; we do something positive about the capital gains tax. Hard work and effort builds up businesses across this country. When people choose to sell their business and roll the proceeds into another business, we allow them a full capital gains tax roll-over; we do not just muck around the edges. We want people in this country to build up assets, to build up their business, to give them the reward of being able to put that into a greater productive capacity in their business and employ more Australians.

Our policy is about jobs, jobs, jobs: the Government's policy is about driving this country further into debt with $2.3 billion worth of unfunded promises. When this Government came to power, gross foreign debt was $23 billion. Today, it is just on a staggering $200 billion. In fact, our net foreign debt today is $145 billion. I say to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): thanks very much; you have added to that, and added to it very substantially.

In addition to the capital gains tax roll-overs, we are proposing both short and long term savings accounts. But, of course, most importantly, we do not tinker with industrial relations agreements; we put meaningful reforms into the labour market through our enterprise agreements. Our enterprise agreements will allow flexibility in the work market so that we can get better productivity, true productivity, into the workplace. True productivity will mean a better utilisation of plant and equipment in this country.

We have the ability in this country to take on competitors from overseas. What we have been good at in this country for the last decade is exporting jobs. Clearly, the equipment I come across in factories that I visit in this country is the same equipment I come across in factories in the US, Britain, Germany and Asia. Our work force is well educated and well trained. But where do we fall down? In two areas: firstly, government taxes, because governments choose to put so much tax on our businesses and our products that they make us uncompetitive; and, secondly, labour on-costs. If we are able to rationalise some of those costs, this country, our factories and our workers can become truly productive, truly competitive.

We have to strive in this country to become both internationally and domestically competitive—and we can do it. But we will not do it with mickey mouse schemes such as One Nation; we will not do it by trying to spend money on new railway lines without getting the productivity right on the rail service; we will not do it by trying to spend our way out of the problems. The small business sector in this country has an enormous capacity to employ more people, an enormous capacity to be competitive, and an enormous capacity to produce goods that we currently import: we have only to try to do it.

The misrepresentations that I have heard today and in the last couple of days in regard to the impact of the goods and services tax is nothing short of scandalous. The extra spending capacity of workers in this country through our proposal, our policy of reforms, will give all Australians far greater spending capacity.

Home affordability will be far more achievable under our policies. This is something that has been a real struggle in the last 10 years and particularly in the last few years of very high interest rates—engineered, I might add, by this Government. We intend to give first home owners a $2,000 start—something, I might add, that this Government dropped, as it did not consider it was necessary any longer. The misrepresentation in regard to the amount of tax going onto products does not take account of the amount of tax paid on products already.

I might just take up for a moment the very famous time during the last New South Wales State election when the Leader of the State Opposition, one Bob Carr, picked a packet of Weeties off the shelf and said, `Do you know that the Liberals are supposedly going to put 15 per cent on this packet of Weeties?'. What he did not have the honesty to say was, `This packet of Weeties has 20 per cent sales tax on the package—20 per cent on the printing, 20 per cent on the liner inside, 20 per cent on the wrapping; the conveyor rollers on which it is produced have a 20 per cent sales tax on them; the pallet trolley conveying the packet to the pallet bay has a 20 per cent sales tax on it; the wrapping machine has a 20 per cent sales tax on it; the fork-lift has a 20 per cent sales tax on it; the truck on which the product is loaded has a 20 per cent sales tax on it; the tarpaulin that is put over the product on the truck has a 20 per cent sales tax on it; and the binding straps securing the tarpaulin have a 20 per cent sales tax on them'.

There is a 20 per cent sales tax on everything on that truck, from the tyres to the radiator hoses. When the truck moves out of the warehouse, what happens to the fuel? There is a tax on the fuel of 26c a litre. When the truck gets to the shopping centre and is unpacked, the pallet trolleys also have a 20 per cent sales tax on them. The supermarket shelves on which the product is stacked have a 20 per cent sales tax on them; the vinyl floor tiles in the supermarket have a 20 per cent sales tax on them; the light fittings in the shopping centre have a 20 per cent sales tax on them.

The shopping trolley into which the lady puts the product has a 20 per cent sales tax on it. She takes it out to a car which had a 20 per cent sales tax on it, which has only just dropped to 15 per cent. She takes it home and puts it on the kitchen table, which has a 10 per cent sales tax on it. The fridge has a 10 per cent sales tax on it, and the TV has a 30 per cent sales tax on it. People do not realise the amount of tax—$9.4 billion worth—that this Government has put on the consumers in this country.

To make business and industry in this country internationally competitive, we are proposing to lift all the tax that this Government puts onto business. About $7 billion of that $9.4 billion is a direct tax on business under the Government's tax proposals. This mickey mouse scheme that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) proposed today will still put tax on business inputs. Let us take for example a rig, a semitrailer, worth $200,000. Under the Government's tax system, it has $40,000 worth of sales tax on it and, of course, tax on all of the parts, the components and the fuel. Under our proposal that rig would cost $200,000 net. The capital investment return under our proposal will be far better.

Those cost savings will be passed on to consumers through lower and more competitive prices. More importantly, jobs will be created in this country. We will stop exporting jobs overseas—that is the Government's policy. For small business it means that there will be no tax on the truck, the fax machine, the photocopier, the computer, the floor jacks or the spray guns; whatever small businesses buy as a business input will not have any tax effect on it. Under the Government's proposals there is a tax on all those items. We have an enormous tax burden to bear in this country.

We have to propose to take those taxes off, to give people in this country the incentive for their hard work and effort and to give the small business sector the incentive for its hard work and effort as well. Let those in small business keep some of the money and roll it over when they sell their business.
