Let them put aside some of the money as a tax free component on the sale of the goodwill component of their business. Let us stop taxing the life out of the average Australian. Let us stop taxing the life out of the Australian business sector.

If we give the Australian business sector the opportunity, it can truly turn around the fortunes of this country. This country, like any business, must start trading at a profit. The sooner this Government realises that and stops doing deals with its union mates to keep pushing up wages, irrespective of what the market is like, the sooner we will be able to get this country competitive and the sooner we will stop exporting jobs from this country.

The rubbish that those on the Government side of the Parliament propose in regard to the cost impact of the GST is just a load of absolute codswallop and, in fact, what they do not say is that the costs, in their own Treasury analysis, were well below 4 per cent. In our proposal the average—one-off, I might add—cost increase is 4.4 per cent. The benefits are enormous. The additional take home pay is substantial. Pensioners will get an 8 per cent increase and there are substantial other benefits.

The Australian people will not be hoodwinked by this blatant load of misrepresentation that the Government is proposing and pedalling. The people in this country want a better deal. They want a fair deal. The people in this country want to be able to get on with the job. They are confident that they can turn the economy of this country around, just given the opportunity. With Fightback, we intend to give them that opportunity. With Fightback, we intend to reward hard work and effort. That is something that the Government's One Nation proposal does not do.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PRICE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have witnessed a somewhat emotional contribution from the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), my good friend.
—Spirited.
—Flamboyant.

—`Spirited', `flamboyant'—I am happy to acknowledge those words. He raises some very serious issues. He says that a Labor Government—for us, it is a very serious charge—is not interested in true productivity and we are exporting jobs.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that, when we look back at the 1960s and 1970s, one of the things that could be said about our going into partnership with the Japanese was that we were very much prepared to export our raw materials. If the Japanese said to us, `We will buy your wool', we said `Thank you'. If they said, `Look, we will transport it for you', we said, `We are freed from another management problem'. If they said, `We will enter it into the distribution chain', we said, `That's another problem removed; please go ahead'.

That is the tragedy of Australia—and no more significant than on a day that is marking the importance of wool to Australia and the Australian economy—that we were never able to take advantage of value added opportunities in Australia, transportation elsewhere and distribution chains in third countries. That is the tragedy of Australia. In the 1990s it is just so hard to claw our way back.

In terms of productivity, let me say that we on the Government side are very proud that, in relation to the organisations representing the working men and women of Australia and young Australians—the ACTU—we have been able to establish an understanding. We call it an accord. There have been many benefits to the nation through that accord. If we wanted to take a very businesslike approach to the relationship and consider what it has done for businesses in Australia, we would point to the decline in real labour costs. But, if we wanted to address it from an equity point of view, what it has done for the ordinary men and women of Australia, we would point to a whole raft of things that we have done—the so-called social wage. This reforming Labor Government has introduced things such as the family allowance supplement, the family allowance and a comprehensive educational scheme, Austudy. We have done a whole variety of things along those lines. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that your electorate, like mine, has benefited significantly from these sorts of reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Heaps of unemployed people, though, Roger.

—In my electorate, of course, unemployment is a real problem. I am pleased that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gilmore, who is at the table, raises that issue. Let me say that, as a member proud to represent my electorate of Chifley, I have always been concerned about things such as education, jobs, education and jobs. One of the things that we have done in terms of education is to increase tremendously—we have doubled—the retention rate in years 11 and 12.
—Doubled the unemployment rate.

—Just bear with me. I wanted to say this, and very sincerely: perhaps the most important report in terms of opportunities, whether it be educational opportunities or job opportunities, is now being considered by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) and, therefore, before the Parliament—the report produced by the Employment and Skills Formation Council, led by Laurie Carmichael, known as the Carmichael report. The Carmichael report follows on from the Deveson report, and the Finn report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education. It proposes a revolution for young people in Australia, in my view.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Gilmore said, `What about unemployment?'. Well, in Chifley, in good times we have been used to unemployment; in bad times, it is even worse. This report hopes to break the nexus. I passionately believe in its recommendations. Essentially, what does it address? It addresses the issue that, yes, Australia needs more young Australians going on to university. In my electorate I am pleased to say that that is the case. In particular, the brightest of young students look after themselves and do very well. I can give a number of case studies, but I will not take up the time of the House in that regard.

My passion has always been a concern for the majority of young Australians. The reality is that, whether they are in the electorate of Gilmore or in the electorate of Chifley or even the electorate of Oxley, Mr Deputy Speaker, the majority of Australians do not see their immediate vocation as being in tertiary education. They legitimately aspire to a job, to traineeships, to apprenticeships, to vocational training. This is the most significant report to address the majority of young Australians and to provide them with real opportunities. I sincerely hope that the Minister, as he has indicated, will allow a parliamentary debate on its recommendations.

Let me tell honourable members a number of things the report tackles. It tackles the issue of whether years 11 and 12 provide a real challenge, a real rigour, for those who are tertiary bound. It suggests that vocational training has a real place in years 11 and 12. Notwithstanding the changes we have seen over recent years, that has not been the case. Those who are not tertiary bound, I regret to say, at present do not have a real place in years 11 and 12.

The report talks about the issue of traineeships and apprenticeships and whether they should be amalgamated, whether they should be competency-based and, I say for the edification of the shadow Minister opposite, it tackles for the Labor Party and the trade union movement the most difficult issue of youth wages.

If we are going to be a clever country we should not always equate the clever country with research; we should not always equate the clever country with universities or tertiary education. They in themselves are very important and we want a concentration of them, we want more of them; but, equally, the clever country can be equated with the ordinary men and women of Australia who aspire to jobs in retailing, in banking, on the factory floor and on outback stations. It is a challenge to provide them initially with the recognised skills to enter their trades and to re-skill them throughout their careers.

In my view, and in the view of the Carmichael report, there ought to be two paths to university: one is the traditional way we know through the various certificates at year-12; the other is through a vocational trade, through articulation in the TAFE system. If we adopt the Carmichael report, we adopt a revolution, but we adopt a commitment to young Australians. We will not allow them to be the flotsam and jetsam of economic upturns and downturns.

I want to say a few things about defence—a recent love of mine, if I may say so, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence. I am very disappointed that the Opposition in its Fightback proposal, which my Opposition colleague the honourable member for Forrest was talking about, proposes that there should be a $500m cutback. Many Australians would be looking at the world scenes and seeing the collapse of European communism and the development of all sorts of nation states, and perhaps even tracking what is happening in America with its severe cutbacks in the defence budget and saying, `Why can't we have that in Australia, too?'.

The reality is that in Defence we are already accustomed to zero real budget increases. Unfortunately—or fortunately—there was not the explosion in the defence budget in Australia that we witnessed in the United States. Therefore, there is not really the capacity in the defence budget for those sorts of cutbacks. As the honourable member for Gilmore is in the chamber, I am reminded of what a colleague of his, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), was saying when he was talking about the Opposition's approach to defence in Fightback. As the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, has pointed out, if we institute a $500m cut across the board in the defence budget, we are talking about 15,000 jobs in the Defence Department. The Opposition may say, `Hear, hear! Well done! More, give us more!', but in reality, at the very least, that would involve a cutback of 5,000 in the armed services, in the ADF. Frankly, I do not think we can afford it.

After all, this Government has adopted some very brave approaches in the defence area. We have adopted the force structure review, which is predicating that we should move more and more of our defence forces north, and we are implementing that. Secondly, we have adopted the commercial support program, which gives effect to two elements: first, that we should be self-reliant; and, secondly, that we should be based in the community. We are allowing private enterprise to provide more and more of the support functions that are currently provided by the ADF. I welcome that; it is a real challenge.

I can say to Opposition members that there are some 4,000 jobs that potentially will go to the commercial area, and we see something like $300m in potential savings in the defence budget. The Opposition may say that they are considerable benefits, but in reality the greatest benefit will be the change in culture of the ADF and the Defence Department—and that is incalculable.

We have to contrast what the Government and the Opposition are proposing. The Opposition is saying, `Blanket cuts—cut out $500m—a loss of 5,000 uniformed positions'. This is when the ADF and the Defence Department are undergoing considerable change, when the Government has acted on report after report and taken considered positions. Not content with that, in addition the Opposition is saying, `$500m in cuts; 15,000 jobs; 5,000 uniformed jobs'—and it is saying, `We adopt a bipartisan position on defence'. I know some people in the Defence Department who would be disappointed in that position.

During a recent debate in this House about defence, the honourable member for Mayo, whom I mentioned earlier, said that there was an economic brief circulating within the Defence Department that was incorrect. Mr Downer was keen to point out that the Defence Department was exempt, or zero rated, under the coalition's proposal regarding the GST.

In relation to the GST, we have talked about the community; we have seen Question Time after Question Time the dodgy shopping trolleys that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has wheeled out, and I think they have been well and truly demolished. As my ministerial colleague at the table, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Ms Fatin), has pointed out, families will be in a woeful position, women especially, as a result of the GST. What about the defence forces and those people who are asked to make potentially the supreme sacrifice? Not only is the Opposition proposing a $500m cutback, not only is it suggesting that a further 5,000 uniforms disappear, but also it is saying that the Defence Department is zero rated. I point out to the honourable member for Mayo that the section from which he was quoting referred to instances where the public sector is the supplier of goods and services. This is not what concerns Defence. There are few instances where Defence or the ADF is a supplier of services. When it is—that is, in the defence of Australia—it does not make a charge; that is what it is funded to do. It is not a private enterprise organisation that knocks on the doors of Darwin city and says, `Hey, we are going to charge you $1m to defend you'. It makes purchases. In my own area of interest, acquisitions and logistics, the Department spends $4 billion a year. (Quorum formed)

I am disappointed that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) would interrupt a contribution about the defence of Australia, the ADF and the Department of Defence. I really thought that we could look for bipartisan support from the honourable member for Wakefield.

As I was saying to the House, the Opposition is insistent on cuts to the Defence Force—a 5,000 cutback in the uniformed forces; 15,000 overall—not zero rated because we do not offer services but the defence forces will pay full dollar. The Opposition does not care about the impact of the $4 billion we spend on supplying services or the $2 billion on replacement of capital equipment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to get the call after a few false starts. These Bills—the Supply Bill (No. 1), the Supply Bill (No. 2) and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93—are inextricably mixed up with the recent `One Job' statement of the Keating Government. The recent effort of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is the sixteenth economic statement presented to this House since the Labor Government was elected in 1983. The disastrous mismanagement of Australia's economy by Labor has made it necessary for major changes to general economic policy to be made at almost twice the rate that a normal parliamentary appropriations program would indicate.

PARA.TAB: The Australian economy, and particularly the Victorian economy, is in a parlous state. Not much notice was taken recently of a small newspaper article, hidden away in the middle pages of the Australian Financial Review, which showed that Australia's net foreign liabilities now exceed half of the annual gross domestic product for the first time. Net foreign debt of $145,000m has risen from $36 billion in 1983 when Labor came to power.

Reasonable foreign debt is not a bad thing, especially when a nation such as Australia needs capital inflows which help to counter a pathetically low households savings ratio of between 4 and 6 per cent, which is half that of Germany and other Western nations. However, that is not to say the massive debt we now have is in any way to be tolerated. What is worrying is that interest payments by Australia take about $14 billion each year—that is just to service our overseas debt—a figure that continues to grow every year that the Labor Party is in power.

There has been 10 consecutive falls in private capital expenditure. The private sector accounts for around 75 per cent of Australia's total employment. It is little wonder that a reluctance to invest has flowed through to the labour market. There is little sign of improvement in investment capacity, although the Prime Minister continues to clutch at any straw he can.

In my search for the best advice to the Government from a non-economist, I came across some statements from the managing director of Air Radiators in Lara, which is just outside my electorate of Corangamite. Mr Neville Trevena describes government regulation of industry as being too restrictive, a point that the Business Regulation Review Unit has made many times. Mr Trevena said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the Government elected to eliminate the administrative load off a lot of us (exporters) . . . there's at least 1,000 companies in this country that would start doing $1 million or $2 million a year of export business.

The multiplier effect of the $1m or $2m from each of these small businesses would probably mean at least an extra $100m revenue for the Government, not to mention thousands of sustainable jobs that would be created. Against this advice, how do these Supply Bills and the `One Job' statement—that is, Keating's job—compare? The One Nation statement was well summarised by Terry McCrann of the Melbourne Herald-Sun on 11 March. He had the real comment about the One Nation statement. He stated:
. . . `One Nation' has sheer irresponsibility in seducing the electorate with promised tax `cuts' that depend on a highly implausible economic `scenario' . . .

Mr McCrann's contention covers one of the two central issues in these Supply Bills and the One Nation statement. As he implies, all these measures are based on the belief that somehow there is going to be a magical growth in the gross domestic product of 4 3/4 per cent in 1992-93. This period starts in three months time. I cannot believe that we could have this sort of growth rate projection in three or four months time which would start the whole economy going in the right direction.

PARA.TAB: The so-called analysis on pages 144 and 145 of this economic statement gives the game away. The Department of the Treasury is not willing to use the term `analysis'; instead, it uses the word `scenario' just to protect itself from any future reassessments of these projections, with its negative connotations. Why is Treasury so unwilling to positively endorse the `One Job' statement?

Treasury has been very careful in the way in which it has drawn up those particular statements, which are the foundation of the One Nation document. It has access to the latest economic models but, after having put all the figures through, it found that they did not support the Government's position. Treasury had this to say about the terms of trade, an important barometer for Australia because of the prominence of our marvellously productive agricultural and mining sectors:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the scenario implies a modest improvement . . .
Four lines later, it stated:
The terms of trade can be volatile, however, and could well be noticeably higher or lower . . .
On the level of wages, it stated:
. . . the scenario—
it is not game to make a clear statement, as it usually does in the Budget Papers—

has a half a per cent per annum increase in real wages . . . This is broadly in line with the experience of the 1970s and 1980s . . . If real wages increased more rapidly without any compensating increase in productivity, there would be a significant reduction in the demand for labour.
That means less jobs. This is the same document that on page 47, in respect of work practices, says:

PARA.TAB: The focus of reform has now shifted from the industry and award level to individual workplace to generate the productivity gains necessary for Australia to reap the full benefits from . . . structural adjustment . . .

SPEECH.PARA: How about that compared with our position on Fightback and industrial relations reform?

PARA.TAB: No doubt some Government members will regard Mr McCrann as a tainted observer. No such criticism could be levelled at the National Australia Bank Ltd, whose latest quarterly magazine suggested that this forecast by the Keating Government of 4.7 per cent growth rate in 1992-93 is unlikely to be achieved. So we have two very respected commentators challenging the whole basis of the One Nation statement and saying that it will not be achieved in a month of Sundays.

With the evidence that backs up the claim of the Bank, I would like to look at the forecasting record of the Government. It would be an understatement to say that the Hawke and Keating administrations have not had a good track record in making predictions about government expenditure, revenue and the overall budgetary balance. In 1990-91, asset sales were predicted to be $840m, and they came in at $520m. So that estimate was way off track. Industry development and assistance was budgeted at just under $2,700m, and the actual figure was $4,000m, which is a difference of close to 50 per cent of the latter figure. But the real corker was the anticipated Budget surplus of $8.1 billion, which has whittled down to an estimate of $1.9 billion, and we have yet to see the final figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only surpluses in history have been on this side.

—Government members should have a look at how many deficits the Government had in the early years of the present Prime Minister's arrangements, especially when the Government had the upturn of the economy in 1983 and 1984. In the early times of the current Prime Minister, the Government had a cumulative of $22 billion worth of deficit. Let us not forget that.

PARA.TAB: The second issue that I was relating to the document is that now, in this One Nation statement, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister are prepared to spend more money—$2.3 billion—at a time when we are in recession and the Government has taken the Budget into a further deficit. Last August, the Budget deficit for the 1991-92 year was predicted to be $4.7 billion. After the latest revision, the Government now estimates it to be $6.8 billion, which is a rise of $2.1 billion since the Budget was brought down last August. I add that we still await the final outcome, which could be anything. Access Economics has put it in the range of $7 billion to $9 billion, and we wait with interest to see what the final figure is.

Because the cuts in personal income tax that the Government is to bring in are not funded from any careful reductions in government expenditure, there will be little overall benefit to individual Australians. In contrast, the Fightback package incorporates appropriate reductions in government spending. For instance, why do we have the CES and Social Security staff located in different buildings when the counter services that they offer could be combined? Part of our proposition under Fightback is to make such savings in some of those government instrumentalities.

As sad as it is, while Australia overall is going through a severe recession, the Kirner Government in Victoria is ensuring that whatever little glimmers of hope may appear in other States, such as New South Wales, from time to time are obliterated by negative indicators emanating from Victoria.

On the one hand, the Federal Government claims that the One Nation statement will merely involve a small addition to national spending; on the other hand, it suggests that the One Nation statement will deliver a great stimulus to the Australian economy. It really cannot have it both ways. It is just saying that it is going to spend a little bit; but all the rhetoric of Prime Minister Keating is that this will restore confidence and bring the whole economy back to a more buoyant state. We know what happened in Victoria when Premier Kirner and Premier Cain adopted these tactics of spending more and more money—so much so that I think it will take 15 years for Victoria to recover from its absolutely horrendous debt levels. It is beyond belief that anyone will ever overcome that situation.

The raw figures show that nearly one million Australians are unemployed. The suggestion that the Government is putting forward is that Australia is sharing the pain of world recession. Of course, this does not compare very well with the eight leading OECD nations from the March quarter 1990 to the December quarter 1991. It does not put Australia in too good a light. Over that period, Australia's unemployment rate increased from 6 to 10.4 per cent. Let us get it clear; it rose from 6 to 10.4 per cent. That sharp increase was exceeded, amongst the industrialised nations, only by Sweden, where the rate tripled from a very low level of 1.3 per cent to 3.2 per cent. Britain, New Zealand and Canada all recorded increases, but none as sharp as Australia's in the deliberately engineered recession that we `had to have'.

One of the worst features of Labor's mismanagement of the economy has caused many Australians to have less optimism for themselves and their children. The number of discouraged job seekers has risen over the last three years from 84,000 to 138,000, which is a rise of 60 per cent over a normal term of office for a Federal government. What we are seeing here is that people who were hoping to seek jobs now do not have the confidence to go to the job agencies and put in an application. They lack the confidence and the ability even to seek out a job. They know they are in a hopeless situation and that to go down to the CES or to respond to any job vacancies that are in the newspapers is just not a proposition.

In such an environment, many commentators offer advice as to what action the Government should take in order that the economy can begin to recover. I remind Government members that the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Don Sanders, said on 26 March that forecasters have overestimated the strength of the predicted upturn, and on a number of occasions we on this side of the House have endorsed those remarks. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and others have been saying for months that the economy is on the verge of an upturn, yet we do not see any upturn. In fact, we see the economy bubbling at a very low level.
At the Institute of Chartered Accountants conference at Lorne, in my electorate, the Commonwealth Bank's chief credit controller, Mr Paul Rizzo, had this to say—and it is a very interesting comment:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . growth in the `90s can only come from supply side changes such as privatisation, labour market reform and faster micro-economic reform . . . maybe we can get away with (demand-driven growth) for a short time in the `90s but reasonable and sustainable growth can only come from supply-side reform.
This is very much along the lines of the Fightback package proposals, which advocate fundamental and radical reforms. It is only by implementing those reforms that Australia will turn around.

PARA.TAB: A total of 84 per cent of manufacturers surveyed by the Confederation of Australian Industry have responded negatively to the One Nation statement because they can see through the fundamental deficiencies of the One Nation statement, in spite of the rhetoric in this House by the Prime Minister and other Government members about the virtues of the statement.

The Government had a golden opportunity with its statement to take the bull by the horns and abolish the plans for the superannuation guarantee levy—the superannuation legislation was introduced into the Parliament only this afternoon—which will mean that an extra impost will be enforced on those businesses with payrolls under $500,000 from 1 July. Of course, the smaller businesses do not really save very much from the deferral of their employer funded rate increase, because under a Labor Government they would be paying up to 12 per cent in a compulsory superannuation levy by the year 2000. It is quite a remarkable suggestion that that extra burden will be imposed on employers by this Labor Government. This one single measure and impost could result in the loss of up to 70,000 jobs. That figure has been well accepted by the commentators and by those people who have made some judgments on the effect on business of paying these quite massive amounts of superannuation.

Where is the Government's so-called commitment to social justice, which is really a threat? It will be the same situation as that which arose in 1981 and 1982 when the metalworkers pursued the fantastic rise in wages. Of course, the consequences were that great numbers of people were put out of work at that time. We have a similar situation because this impost of superannuation will put large numbers of people out of work around the nation in a subtle way. The extra people will not be put on and those jobs will be lost.

The alternative is the coalition's emphasis on voluntary agreements helping to make a true understanding between the employees' contribution from their own efforts and what the employer contributes to business operations. This is a big change under which the workers and management can get a proper understanding of their own contributions to profitability. Employees of Australia are sensible enough to understand that the employers no longer have a pot of gold. They understand in the superannuation issue that they just cannot continue to pay superannuation, Workcare and holiday loading at 17 1/2 per cent, which adds up to 45c to 50c in the dollar for every wage paid.

It is a pity that the One Nation statement does not come to the realisation that employers can no longer stand these imposts on their ability to create jobs. The One Nation statement makes the claim in its summary documents that our reforms to industrial relations have been the most constructive steps our country has taken since the war. What a remarkable statement by the Labor Government. It suggests that it has brought about changes to industrial relations. The facts are that Australia's productivity growth through the middle 1980s has been less than 2 per cent per year. The Government's new found enthusiasm, what is called enterprise bargaining, has not come to fruition, because only 47 workplace agreements have been put in place, as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Cook) has admitted.

Our policy is to have enterprise agreements administered and organised by the workers and management. It is easy to see why there has been so little change. The Government has insisted that it allows only the unions to represent employees, and is directed by the head office bureaucrats of the unions so that it can control the outcomes of these agreements.

The newspapers today have been full of plans about the suggestion to bring subcontractors within the ambit term of `employee'. Despite the Minister's claim, this measure has the potential to increase housing prices and reduce the efficiency of Australia's domestic housing industry. It really is a pathetic attempt to pander to union muscle and, more importantly, it is an attempt to hold the declining number of union members. Union members are very clear in their view that they do not wish to join unions. If we look at the figures, we see that union numbers are declining and workers are leaving the unions in droves. During the reign of Prime Minister Hawke, a former President of the ACTU, union numbers declined in Australia. What a remarkable epitaph for that particular Prime Minister. History will write it up that the union movement was a declining force in those years of a reigning Labor Government under Prime Minister Hawke.

The One Nation statement is falsely based on growth rates. It is optimistic of the way in which Australia will turn around. It is a big spending, bankcard document which depends on spending more money to raise a sense of confidence here in Australia to bolster a failing government. In this way the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is hoping that the Australian people might start to support him, because they know that the recession we had to have was caused by the Prime Minister himself in his eight years as Treasurer. This is his last throw to turn around the situation he created himself. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little surprising, I suppose, that the debate on the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1992-93, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1992-93 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93 has turned into a debate to a large extent, at least tonight, over the One Nation statement and the Fightback package. I was interested to hear the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price) say in his contribution to the debate tonight that he hoped there would be parliamentary debate on recommendations contained in the Carmichael report. What we can see happening over the life of this particular Parliament is almost a total absence of debates on ministerial statements and debates about other matters of considerable public and parliamentary interest.

PARA.TAB: Therefore it is little wonder that the debate on the Supply Bills tonight has largely turned into a debate on One Nation and the Fightback package, as we have seen evidenced by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) in the last three contributions to the debate. The One Nation package was introduced by the Prime Minister on 26 February this year. There have only been two other occasions on which this statement of so-called importance and national significance to the people of Australia has been debated.

I am reliably informed that it will be at least June before this matter is brought on for debate again. I think that says something about two aspects of what we have seen in this Parliament this year. The first is the absence of ministerial statements. If one goes back to the Whitlam or Fraser governments, one can see that ministerial statements were used much more, and there were wide-ranging debates on matters of public importance within the Parliament. But now we see that ministerial statements are not made; in fact half of Question Time is taken up by Ministers virtually announcing policy and making statements, rather than doing it on a more appropriate occasion. I turn now to the One Nation statement. I am amused by the title `One Nation' used by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —His speech writer.

—Apart from what my honourable colleague points out about the Prime Minister, `One Nation' was first used by that great conservative politician, Benjamin Disraeli. It was Disraeli who coined the expression `One Nation', and it was his `One Nation' that he spoke about when he talked about the great democratic and conservative principles that he put into play whilst Prime Minister of Britain in the last century. Until tonight, leaving aside the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), only 15 members of 147 members of this House have had the opportunity to speak on the One Nation statement. If one goes into the Opposition Whip's office—I presume it is the same in the Government Whip's office—there are long lists of members of this House who wish to speak on the statement. They are being denied the opportunity. Instead of a debate on the Supply Bills, honourable members are making comments about the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation statement has been an almost total flop. If one considers the surveys of opinion that have been taken, and takes that as a guide to the way in which the public has regarded this statement, it has done very little to restore confidence within the community. Of the numerous polls I have seen, only one poll has suggested that confidence in the Government may have increased as a consequence of the One Nation statement. Of 188 responses to the Australian Chamber of Manufactures survey of members, 84 per cent of the respondents viewed One Nation unfavourably; 92 per cent said it would not encourage investment, and 93 per cent said it would not increase employment. This is the statement held up to increase employment and turn around the disastrous recession we have at the moment.

If we look at a survey of opinion taken by the Australian Business Monthly, we see that 79 per cent of the respondents said that the One Nation statement would not stimulate investment in this country. This is a statement intended to boost confidence within the business community and the general populace—and confidence is something we greatly need at the present—yet on all the polls that have been taken of this statement it would seem that little has been achieved. Probably little has been achieved because there is little in this statement when one leaves aside some of the rhetoric in which the Prime Minister has engaged ever since he delivered it.

In fact, the One Nation statement could be more aptly entitled `One Broke Nation'. Australia's foreign debt now stands at a net level of $145 billion. For many Australians an amount of $145 billion may simply sound like a large figure. Let me put that in understandable terms for Australians. It amounts to approximately $8,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. In 1983 this debt was just $23 billion, or less than $1,500 for every Australian. Over the period of the Hawke and Keating governments we have seen a growth in the net foreign debt of approximately $1,500 for every man, woman and child to approximately $8,000 for every man, woman and child.

For the household of husband, wife and two children, that means that the net foreign debt equivalent is $32,000. For the retired pensioner couple or for the single mother and child, there is a net foreign debt equivalent to $16,000. For the young person who has just left school and is increasingly unable to find a job, the foreign debt burden is some $8,000. Of the total net debt of $145 billion, nearly one third, or some $50 billion, is owed by the public sector. The reality is that this figure disguises the true level of public sector borrowings in Australia, as the gross foreign borrowings by Australian governments and instrumentalities are a staggering $81 billion of a total gross debt of $183 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is their policy that created the other debt, too.

—Precisely, as my honourable colleague points out.Leaving aside private borrowings—that is, borrowings by individuals and companies in Australia—the total indebtedness of Australian governments and instrumentalities to foreign lenders amounts to some $4,500 for every Australian. Ordinary Australians have been partly sheltered from the full impact of this debt burden. Consider the impact of it on our economy. It now costs approximately 20 per cent of our export earnings to service the debt, that is, to pay the interest on the debt that we have as a nation. Just to maintain the debt at its current level would require the equivalent of the exports of another entire mining industry, five wool industries or seven wheat industries. On a day such as today when we promoted the wool industry, if one says, `Just to maintain the foreign debt at its current level, we would need the equivalent of the exports of another five full wool industries', one can understand the significance of this for the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Back in 1901 Australia was the envy of the world. On a per capita basis it was the richest country in the world. Now it does not even make the first 11. Amongst OECD countries Australia now ranks fifteenth in terms of gross national product. In our own economic region, the Asia-Pacific region, we might rate as what was described in Gone With the Wind as poor white trash. In economic terms Australia is the laughing-stock of its own region. Between 1980 and 1990, while other regional countries' share of world output rose from 16.3 to 22.5 per cent, how much did Australia's rise? From 1.4 to just 1.5 per cent.

During the Hawke-Keating years, the greatest growth industry in the top 10 industrialised nations in the world was the computer industry. In Australia the growth industry was property speculation, which is, in terms of national savings, a colossal waste of money. Instead of investing in the industrial future which puts bread and butter on our tables and pays for the cars, the compact disc players and the other items that we want to import, we increased our indebtedness to foreign lenders by buying second and third houses and building office blocks that are now empty because there is not enough business to fill them.
Just recently the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank said that Australia could become the best housed country in the Third World if we continued to borrow beyond our means. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We borrowed so hard we couldn't provide the savings ourselves for the borrowers, so we had record levels of foreign debt.

In fact, household savings in Australia dropped to a record low of around 4 per cent of average disposable income.In the early 1970s household savings in Australia were some 15 per cent of the average disposable income. Even in 1984 they were around a level of 9 to 10 per cent. Since 1990 we have seen a disastrous drop to 4 per cent. We have also seen falls over the same time in the business investment to GDP ratio. In fact, our falls have been more sharp than those in other OECD countries.

PARA.TAB: Our foreign debt represented 14 per cent of our gross domestic product in 1983. By 1987, under then Treasurer Keating, it had blown out to 33 per cent. It is now over 38 per cent of our gross domestic product. Australia in fact has the third largest net foreign debt in the world after the United States and Canada. It is much larger than the net debt position of the banana republics of Argentina and Brazil. It is larger than that of India and even Mexico. It is even larger than Russia's. Measured on a per head of population basis, Canada, Denmark, Australia and New Zealand have comparable levels of foreign debt. The Danes and the New Zealanders have adopted measures to address the problem, but we continue to borrow and spend as if we have an unlimited credit card facility.

It is arguable that a prime responsibility of government in these circumstances is at the very least to stabilise the alarming increase in our indebtedness to foreign nations and, preferably, to reduce that burden. Yet there was not one mention of foreign debt in the One Nation speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Parliament. This is perhaps understandable. After all, it was the Prime Minister who, as Treasurer, in his 1984 Budget speech, when the foreign debt was just $27.9 billion, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I am proud to be able to tell the Australian people that we now have strong economic growth, many more jobs, a substantial fall in inflation and declining interest rates. The Government's policies are on track.

The following year he said that his strategy `builds upon our very significant successes'. Of course, foreign debt rose to $51.2 billion. By 1987 he assured us that `our economic strategy is now bearing fruit', and foreign debt rose to $82.9 billion. In his 1988 Budget speech he said:

The nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation. . . this is the one that brings home the bacon. . . Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.

But he had sold us a pig in a poke, and foreign debt climbed to $92.8 billion. Just two years ago he asserted that his Budget would deliver higher employment without the misery and despair of a savage recession. Despite similar extravagant predictions by the Prime Minister since, our indebtedness to foreigners is now a net $145 billion. Some fall! While the Prime Minister may have been embarrassed to mention to the Australian people this outcome of his policies, hidden away in the background statement is an acknowledgment at least of the problem, and I quote:

High levels of external debt leave us more exposed to external developments, such as slowing world growth and falls in commodity prices, that could set in train processes leading to sharp reductions in national wealth and living standards.

Yet based on the statement, the ratio of foreign debt to gross domestic product will increase by 4 per cent, adding another $30 billion to our national indebtedness. At the current rate, Australia's foreign debt will exceed 50 per cent of GDP before the year 2000.In fact, the best the One Nation statement can promise is the following:
As the ratio of debt to equity financing returns to levels which existed prior to the excessive leveraging in the late 1980s, the net external debt to GDP ratio could—
and I emphasise the word `could'—
stabilise or decline slowly.

In the Fightback package we acknowledge that foreign debt must be stabilised and foreign borrowings cannot be used to create jobs, as occurred in the 1980s. As we acknowledge, the rest of the world will not allow us the massive increases in foreign debt which have been occurring over the past decade. Australia would almost certainly be plunged into another recession to curb our demands for credit as our foreign creditors became less willing to lend and as our debt climbed higher and higher.

PARA.TAB: In recent days the Prime Minister has called for an Australian republic. The irony of this diversionary tactic and our alleged subservience to Great Britain is that our economic subservience to foreign nations is, in fact, a looming reality. The fall of Singapore to the Japanese in 1942 will be insignificant compared with the economic fall of Australia by the end of the decade if our foreign indebtedness is not addressed. Already one quarter of our foreign debt is owed to the Japanese.

Given the fact that the Japanese economy, with its unrealistically inflated stocks and land prices, is only kept buoyant by stock market manipulation and government intervention—as we have seen in the past week—and there are signs of recession in the world's leading economies, Australia is increasingly at risk. As I have said, we have seen a major fall below the 20,000 mark—and now it is below 19,000—in the Nikkei index, which indicates that is a problem we have in this country.

In the last day, figures that were released under the balance of payments revealed that the monthly current account deficit fell to $667m after seasonal adjustment. This suggests a lower current account deficit for the year than we may have expected. This is partly due, of course, to the increase in exports. I suppose it is significant to acknowledge today the 44 per cent increase over last year in wool exports from this country, and coal has increased by 14 per cent over last year as well.

But those figures also partly reflect a reduction in our current account income deficit. This is comprised largely of our foreign debt interest payments and profit repatriations from foreign-owned companies. This figure has fallen for two reasons. First of all, international interest rates have fallen; and, secondly, because of the recession we are in, Australia's repatriation to foreign-owned companies has also fallen. Because both of these factors should be expected to increase again as the nation comes out of recession—no matter how slowly—we will need to continue to maintain a trade surplus in this country if we are to reduce our foreign debt. Yet there is little in the One Nation statement to provide the confidence that this outcome will eventuate. If one reads the background papers, at best it seems to be put as an outside chance. There is the ongoing problem that, even in a recession, Australians consume imports at an increasingly worrying level.

Therefore, instead of increasingly vitriolic personal attacks on the Leader of the Opposition and tilts at diversionary issues like some Don Quixote suffering from mid-life crisis, the Prime Minister has a responsibility to address our real economic situation. As I said at the outset, the fact that the Government has hardly debated One Nation and is preoccupied with the Fightback package underlines the Prime Minister's inability to deliver much more than jibes written by highly paid speech writers. Is this what we have come to expect of the Prime Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the wide ranging debate that is allowed under the Supply Bills, I would like to bring to the attention of the House tonight what I believe is a good example of the reason why Medicare and private health insurance cannot exist together. I have said before that they are a disaster and I have a case here which I think proves my point. I have a letter which one of my constituents has written to me. I will not read out all of the letter, but I will read out some of the more relevant points. My constituent says:

SPEECH.PARA: As I am in the top table with H.B.F. and also covered by the medicare scheme I did not expect to get only half the cost of the anaesthetist.
I have had medicare and H.B.F. look at it twice and have managed to get a further two small amounts off the account, however there is still $1283.00 left to pay and this is a real problem.
I am a pensioner in a rental home and have no savings at all.
I can't see how a person could get such a large account when the fact is that if I had had no private cover I would have got the operation cost free.

I think a number of things can be said about that letter. My constituent is right: if she did not have private health insurance she would not have received a bill. She took out extra health insurance and she received a bill from the anaesthetist which she says is $1,283 over the schedule fee

PARA.TAB: I would like to bring to the attention of the House some of the charging practices of these people. I have the bill which was sent to my constituent. Item No. 533, which has a schedule fee of $271, attracted a charge of $1,155.70. Another example is item No. 97, which has a schedule fee of $42.50 but which attracted a charge of $180.75—more than 400 per cent higher than the schedule fee.

My constituent knows that by taking out private health insurance she will not be covered for bills. She does not get extra financial coverage, but she is able to buy access. That is very important, especially for older people who do not like to wait. This is a pressure that sections of the medical profession can exert upon Australians. They can say, `If you have private health insurance you can have the operation straight away, but if you don't have private health insurance then you could wait three or four years'.

The anaesthetist I am talking about—I have never mentioned doctors' names before, but I think this one deserves a mention—is Dr Sodhy. In contrast with the anaesthetist—who was not picked by my constituent and who never discussed his fees with my constituent—the surgeon, whose name is Michael Anderson, charged her the schedule fee and she got the lot back. There is the contrast: the surgeon who actually knows the patient, talks with the patient and knows the financial position of this full-rate pensioner renting privately, charges the schedule fee; the anaesthetist, who never talks with the patient, charges—on my reckoning at least—about $1,400 above the schedule fee.

My constituent came to see me and she was very distressed about this situation. I wrote to Dr Sodhy pointing out her financial position and asking him to drop his charges on top of the schedule fee so that she would be fully covered by Medicare and her private health insurance. His response was not to write me a letter, but to get his secretary to ring my constituent, accusing her of being ungrateful and saying how upset Dr Sodhy was that she had come to see me about this massive overcharge that he had inflicted upon her. He offered to cut that overcharge in half. He said, `If you send me a cheque today for $740, I'll accept that as full payment and I won't sue you. But if you don't send it to me I will take you to court'.

If one knows elderly people, one would know how upset they would be at such a threat. She rang up one of her friends, who is 82 years old, and borrowed the money. Her 82-year-old friend drove over and gave her $740. My constituent, on two walking sticks, walked down to the Commonwealth Bank in Armadale, got the cheque for $740 and sent it in.

When I heard about this, I phoned my constituent and I said, `What sort of an impact will this have on your lifestyle?'. She said, `Well, I've cut back as far as I can. I just can't afford to buy petrol for my car'. So now she has to get her daughter to do the shopping for her. Of course, if she cannot afford petrol for the car, she cannot afford to use the car, so there are no more outings for the pensioner and her husband.

It really shows that these charges are having a significant impact on low income earners, to the extent that they are actually lowering the standard of living significantly for people who are charged excessively by medical specialists only because they have private health insurance. I say to the anaesthetist that I know the standard of his living will not rise by as much as my constituent's will fall because of this incident.

Just to take out that private health insurance with HBF costs her $114 a month—so there is a double sting in this. With the meagre income they have, they had to pay the hospital, the HBF insurance and then they had to pay the $740, which my constituent had to borrow, using savings from her pension.

I have always said that the answer is one national health insurer. We have to get rid of private health insurance; it is an absolute disaster. The Opposition, faced with the fact that more and more people are choosing to get out of private health insurance, wants to drive them back in again. But we should get rid of it. There is no equality of access under private health insurance and it is not based on the ability to pay—the two characteristics of Medicare.

I finish on this note: I think the case I have presented to the House tonight illustrates the impact that the present health insurance arrangements are having on people in Australia, particularly people on low incomes such as my constituent. If I were Dr Sodhy, when I got this cheque for $740 I would put it in an envelope and send it back to the pensioner. He will know who I am talking about. If he did that, he would have a modicum of decency and I for one would applaud him.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to honourable members that I welcome the One Nation package of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with open arms. For the past two Budgets I have been urging the Government to end its fatal attraction to the rationalistic economic theories and get back to those good old traditional Labor Keynesian economic objectives of full employment, price stability and balance of payments stability. In particular, I was urging that something meaningful be done about our unconscionably high unemployment levels, and arguing that that meant the Government had to increase public expenditure to create jobs through economic growth. That is why the four-year plan to boost spending by $2.3 billion and thereby create 800,000 jobs was music to my ears.

PARA.TAB: It is pretty clear that the economy was going to stay in recession for a long time if we left it to the private sector. The economy had to be kick-started by government if things were to get moving. It follows that my most enthusiastic response to the One Nation package was generated by the fact that the Government is moving to accelerate recovery and build a stronger Australia, in that it is clearly stating that it has moved away from the conservative economic theories of Senator Peter Walsh and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and is back in the business of active economic intervention to achieve our economic goals.
Opposition members—Walsh is one of your mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is no mate of mine. Having said that, I wish to look now to the future to see how the One Nation strategy might be progressed as we approach this year's Budget and the 1993 election. My belief is that, in following the blinkered, inflexible rationalist approach that is taken to its absurd extremes in the Opposition's Fightback! document, the Hawke Labor Government began to blot its previously remarkably successful copybook.

PARA.TAB: The accord, which put the brakes on inflation and produced substantial reductions in industrial disputation, has two serious limitations. Firstly, it applies only to wage and salary earners. The incomes of professionals and company executives were allowed to explode and were paid for by increases in the prices of goods and services. Wage-earners' real incomes dropped from 62 per cent of the gross domestic product to 58 per cent over eight years. The second limitation was that the captains of industry were not party to the accord and had no commitment to ensuring that their massive profits arising out of wage restraint were ploughed back into productive investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did they go?

—I will tell the honourable member for Bruce where they went. Instead, company executives led by the likes of the honourable member's heroes, Holmes a Court, Bond and Skase, indulged in an orgy of asset inflation, takeovers and many other money games. Taking advantage of the deregulated financial system, they, with the indulgence of the banks, engaged in a corporate borrowing spree that saw our external debt ratio rise by a factor of three. Predictably, the boom busted and we headed down the well-worn cyclical path to recession that so characterises free market economies.

PARA.TAB: The stark truth is that our corporate sector failed to support productive development, particularly in our export industries, and that caused external debt to rise to impossible proportions, which in turn forced the Government to impose high interest rates. However, it was the Government's own rationalist commitment to an inflation first policy that proved to be so electorally damaging by reducing business investment and blowing out employment.

Long-lagged interest rates are a brutal economic instrument; once set in motion, their impacts are as difficult to stop as a supertanker. By the time the economic indicators tell us that the policy is working, the intervening period of high rates has laid waste to demand, causing growing unemployment, business bankruptcies and low levels of business investment. That is why I am very pleased to see the turn in Government economic policy with the One Nation statement, which takes the Labor Party back to where it has been for many years, and where it has always been successful, with good old traditional Keynesian economics. We have seen a tremendous resurgence in our support from the community, and I think we will continue to see it.

I understand that this Bill will be passed this evening. I will not continue my contribution to the debate, although I intend to speak at some length on the next item when it comes on again in June. I finalise my contribution tonight by saying that the Prime Minister in producing his One Nation package has produced a very credible alternative to the Liberals' neoclassical conservatism. It is an alternative that has already seen great success in the electorate, but that is only the tip of the iceberg. I predict that it will see continuing sweeping success as Australians reject the new GST and support the One Nation package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some fascination to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker), because I was not sure whether he was talking about the Supply Bills or the economic statement. It seems that he has confused the two, truncated the debate and moved on to the next Bill. One thing that the honourable member from the Left of the Labor Party seemed to have great difficulty in understanding was that there is still a massive unemployment problem. We have 10 1/2 per cent unemployment. If we add to that those who have stopped looking for a job and those who cannot get the work they want, we see that, according to today's figures, unemployment is probably closer to 17 per cent. That is the legacy of the economic policies of this Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: It is all very well for the honourable member for Robertson to talk about Keynesian or neoclassical economics, but the fact remains that the Government of which he is a member is responsible for the current mess that we have in this country. Government members cannot walk away from it just by talking about the February economic statement. I think it is worth also pointing out to honourable members that the economic statement that came out at the end of February was the fourth attempt by the Government to bring out a statement that was meant to turn around the recession we had to have—the worst recession in 60 years; the recession that the Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer, seemed rather proud to say he had inflicted on this nation.

We had a statement in March last year that was supposed to set this country going; we had the August Budget that was supposed to set the country going; and we had a job statement in November that was supposed to save the former Prime Minister's skin, but that seemed to disappear as quickly as all the others did.

TALK.START.PARA: —And as he did.

PARA.TAB: Mr HAWKER—Almost as quickly as he did—in fact, more quickly than he did. Now we have had the February statement. Contrary to the wishes and the hopes of the Government, the fact remains that to most Australians, particularly to those who are finding it very difficult to get a job, that February statement has disappeared without trace like the other three. One almost wonders whether the Government is trying to look for a statement-led recovery.

I also noted that the honourable member seemed to have great difficulty in supporting some of his own colleagues. It is fascinating to watch the way the Labor Party is so quick to disown a former very senior economic Minister, the former Minister for Finance. It seems that, as soon as it becomes convenient, he is dispensable. I look at this in some amazement, because this is quite contrary to former Labor Party practice.

It is very difficult to get a member of the Labor Party to bag former Prime Minister Whitlam, yet by any measure until now most Australians would rate him as the worst Prime Minister we have seen, certainly since World War II. He was the engineer and architect of many of the problems that we have had over the last few years. It was under Whitlam that we had the incredible 25 per cent blow-out of wages in 1974. It was Whitlam who ignited the fire of inflation that took years to bring under control. It was Whitlam who showed the incredible economic irresponsibility of running up debts and increasing the level of taxation in this country at a rate that hitherto had never been seen in peacetime.

Yet it seems that up until now the Government and members of the Labor Party have always found it difficult to bag one of their own. It is an interesting development in this Government that the former Minister for Finance, at one time a very respected member of this Government and still a person noted for making some very astute observations about some of the developments of the Government, particularly some of the economic developments—
