TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, in speaking on the subject of urban consolidation, I pointed out that urban consolidation as a policy had failed. It failed because of the false ideas that housing density was related to urban sprawl, that there is an economic advantage in the concept of greater utilisation of spare infrastructure, that higher densities produce cheaper housing and that urban consolidation can be imposed on the community without public support.

PARA.TAB: Not only have governments chased these rainbows; they have ignored the fundamental causes of city sprawl. Firstly, the main determinant of urban form is transport. While private car usage is encouraged and subsidised with no relation of cost to usage, as has been the case since the Second World War, then cities must sprawl and densities must reduce. With a plethora of subsidies to encourage private transport at local, State and Federal levels of government, there is no way to stop Australian cities developing on the Los Angeles model.

Not only are subsidies provided for parking, fuel, registration, company cars, licences and registration, but the high capital costs of cars in relation to low fuel costs break any relation of cost to usage. Personal and land use decisions are thereby massively distorted. The overdependence on the use of cars then causes an acceleration of demand for land required for roads and parking.

The reduction of sales tax on cars recently introduced from 20 per cent to 15 per cent was worth while in terms of its effects on reducing the age of Australia's car fleet. This means an increase in jobs, improved road safety and less pollution and as such it is welcome. It is a pity, however, that the opportunity was not taken to make the reduction in revenue neutral by putting 1c on the price of fuel to improve the imbalance of the cost to usage relationship. Better still, all taxes on the capital costs should be removed in a phased program and transferred to fuel taxes. While ever there is little relation of cost to usage and the general subsidies remain, all land uses and transport decisions will remain distorted and sprawl will continue apace.

Secondly, non-residential urban land use, both private and public, is virtually in a state of anarchy. Government departments, State and Federal, and the commercial world have operated in isolation pursuing their own interests. There is no overall land use plan related to transport and no mechanism to implement and control such a plan even if it existed. As a result, there is little relation of where people live or work or the location of public facilities. For example, if one wants to keep an ever expanding international airport in the centre of a city occupying an area where 200,000 people could live, then it is foolish not to expect urban sprawl.

Thirdly, while tax systems distort land use and transport, encourage the leaving of idle land, subsidise fringe infrastructure and governments reduce infrastructure spending while running the fastest rate of population growth in the OECD countries, then urban sprawl and deterioration must continue. Minimising of urban sprawl and all associated problems can only be achieved by a coordination of policy at the three levels of government arrived at with public support.

Substantial improvements can be made by such mechanisms as traffic limitation policies, investment in public transport, decentralised employment locations, conservation of residential land, flexible planning controls, tax reform, subsidy removal, a coordinated land use and transport policy, high density centres and sub-centres. All of this requires a reversal of the continuing reduction of urban infrastructure spending of the last few decades.

If, however, there is a continuation of the present trend to privatising of roads, creating a group of interests with the incentive to increase private car usage, then urban sprawl will accelerate. It has to be recognised that, given people's basic desire for more, not less, space, the equally strong desire for personal mobility and high population growth rates, added to conceivable rates of infrastructure spending, there is little alternative to continuing relatively low density cities.

Nevertheless a great deal can be done if governments are prepared to address the real problems. The better cities program is at least a start, but if it avoids the issues and is frittered away on a handful of relatively insignificant individual projects spread over a dozen cities and five years, together with a shoal of consultants, overseas trips and reports, then it will be meaningless.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the saddest aspects of Australian history was the formal adoption of the White Australia policy, a policy which was officially renounced as late as the 1960s. Unfortunately, there are some in the community who would welcome the return of such a policy. These people believe that Australia should return to the dark ages and adopt an immigration policy in favour of predominantly white Anglo-Saxons. It is an argument based purely on racist beliefs and should be exposed for the fraud that it is.

PARA.TAB: In recent years Australia's immigration policy has generated much debate. Often this debate has been quite heated and passionate. I fully support rational and informed debate, yet I reject most strongly those who espouse racist doctrines. In recent times these people have refined their argument in order to conceal their true motives. We now have these people using both the environment and unemployment as issues to legitimise their racist arguments. They argue that Australia should reduce its migrant intake because it is ecologically unsustainable. When pressed, these people are basically concerned only with excluding non-English speaking, non-white migrants. They are not at all concerned with protecting the environment but rather with exploiting the issue to further their own ends.

A fact that we must never lose sight of when discussing Australia's immigration policy is that we are dealing with people, not facts or figures or statistics—people who look to Australia with hope and optimism; people who leave behind their family and friends because they believe Australia offers them more hope for the future.

As the product of a migrant family, I am well aware of the difficulties that face migrants. My father migrated to Australia in 1926. Like so many of Australia's early migrants, he could not speak the language and had few possessions. My parents raised 10 children here: five have obtained university degrees, three have trade qualifications, one is a secretary, and the youngest is currently studying at university. My family is not unique. It is but one of the many millions of migrant families that highlight the benefits that flow from immigration.

My parents and migrants of their generation can consider themselves fortunate because it is unlikely that they would have been able to migrate to Australia under the present guidelines. Having no skill, no formal education and no knowledge of the language, my parents and many others like them would have been denied entry.

History records the valuable contribution of these people to Australian society. The massive levels of immigration post-World War II helped Australia achieve a rapid rate of growth and expansion. Our society has been enriched enormously by our migrant community and the interchange of different cultures. Regrettably, these migrants were not always welcomed by a society still clinging to the facade of the White Australia policy. Racial abuse of the Greeks, Italians, Maltese and Lebanese was prevalent. What is significant, though, is that the first and second generations of these migrant families have made an enormous contribution to Australia.

An immigration policy must above all be based on people and compassion. We must never lose sight of the fact that our immigration policy must find the balance between the contribution that both skilled and family migrants can make. We should be doing all that is possible to assist those people who look to Australia for a better future. We should not let lack of skills or formal qualifications act as an impediment to re-uniting families.

Australia can be rightly proud of the success and benefits which have flowed from immigration. We must not allow the narrow-minded racist attitudes of a few to influence policy. Indeed, we must ensure that, above all else, our immigration policy does not discriminate on grounds of race or wealth, and does not reinforce the discrimination already suffered by some groups in their country of origin but benefits those who most need assistance.

Ignorance breeds fear and conservatism. Regrettably, much of the debate concerning immigration is driven by fear and ignorance, which the opponents of our present policy have deliberately sought to exploit and manipulate. History will ultimately pass judgment on our deeds and actions. It will expose those who espouse populist politics and stand for the latest fashion and condemn those who lack principle and conviction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two of my constituents, ex-service couple Jack and Hester Mews of Two Rocks, have experienced problems with their defence service home loans, or DSHL, portfolio for quite some time now. It was in June last year when I first brought to the attention of the House the fact that the Government had reneged on its commitment to DSHL recipients that they would be no worse off as a result of the transfer of the defence service home loan portfolio from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to Westpac Bank in 1988.

PARA.TAB: In June Mr and Mrs Mews were in the middle of legal proceedings with the bank. An amazing thing happened as a result of those proceedings. Mrs Hester Mews's account with Westpac was debited with Westpac's legal fees. Westpac also charged an $80 discharge fee in addition to the fee levied by the Titles Office for the discharge of a mortgage. Under the Department of Veterans' Affairs, this discharge mortgage fee was not levied. Granted, these fees have now been removed by Westpac for Mr and Mrs Mews, but the matters of principle that affect the ex-service community around Australia which Mr and Mrs Mews have fought for remain.

Mr Mews pays around $73 a month on a two-tier DSHL mortgage that stood at $10,925 in September of last year. His loan is levied at two levels of interest: 3.75 per cent on $8,476 and 7.25 per cent on $2,449. Mr Mews says that, when the DSHL portfolio was with the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the threshold over which the higher interest rate was charged was $12,000. He finds himself with less than $11,000 to pay off his mortgage, but he is still paying the higher interest rate on a portion of his loan.

Mr Mews says that there is nothing in the terms of the mortgage to say that he cannot pay off the higher interest bearing account in one payment. However, the bank has other ideas. If Mr Mews wanted to pay some of his mortgage off in addition to his monthly repayments, four-fifths of his payment would go to pay off the amount that the lower interest rate is levied against, and only one-fifth would go towards paying off the amount at which the higher interest rate is levied.

Mr Mews argues that the recession has brought the market interest rate down substantially. A bank account with Westpac could therefore be earning less interest than is being levied on some portion of a DSHL account which was originally set up to reward and assist members of the veteran ex-service community in return for their valuable service to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to take the opportunity to give a vote of thanks to a very distinguished senior citizen in my electorate of Parramatta. The lady, Mrs Gwen Logan, this year celebrates 50 years of community service in a variety of voluntary organisations and, as part of the recognition of her efforts, she was nominated and awarded the title of Parramatta Senior Citizen of the Year on Australia Day this year.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Logan is a lady who has lived in Parramatta throughout her life. She is now 76 years of age and, having raised six daughters, she has 13 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren to whom she is very devoted and with whom she spends a lot of time assisting. Nevertheless, she has found time over the last 50 years to be very active in a variety of community organisations in the Parramatta area. Her efforts and deeds on behalf of many deserving citizens in the community are legendary.

The range of activities that Mrs Logan has been involved in throughout those 50 years includes active periods in parents and citizens organisations at various schools in the Parramatta electorate. She was an active contributor to those organisations at all levels, particularly in craft and handicraft fields and on the fund-raising side.

Over approximately the past 30 years, she has been very active in the Parramatta Community Services and Information Centre. Indeed, she established the centre in 1967 and has been secretary and directly involved in its development throughout the intervening period. During that time she has helped establish activities such as the home and community care service, the occasional child-care service, the inter-agency service, and Gwennie's market—which raises significant amounts of money in the Parramatta Festival period. As well as that, she is active in ladies auxiliary activities relating to the child-care service, and even today is still treasurer of the community centre and an active member of the Red Cross Calling appeal.

As part of the celebration of Australia Day in Parramatta this year, the senior citizen's award was again organised by Mr and Mrs Topp in an outstanding way and with the support of many in the community, including the Parramatta Advertiser. It was the strongly held opinion of all those involved in that exercise that Mrs Logan, as a result of her 50 years of achievement of voluntary service to the people of Parramatta, should be recognised in such a fashion.

Last Monday Mrs Logan was able to come to Canberra with Mr and Mrs Topp. She had an excellent day here. It is many years since she has been to Canberra. She certainly had not seen the new Parliament House before. She was very impressed with this project. As part of the day she also had the opportunity to meet the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who expressed both his interest in and appreciation for Mrs Logan's efforts towards the people of Parramatta.

Mrs Logan is one of many people in our communities who throughout their working and adult life contribute actively, not seeking recognition. It is fitting on an occasion such as this, after someone has achieved 50 years of voluntary service, to have at least a small recognition paid for that effort. On behalf of all the people of Parramatta, I certainly want to say congratulations to Gwen Logan on her great achievement of 50 years of voluntary service to our area and on being the Senior Citizen of the Year.

I pay tribute to her efforts and deeds over that period for many needy citizens in the community. I also congratulate Mrs Topp, who helped to organise the granting of the awards and the active and successful way in which it was conducted. Each of them, as citizens, contributed enormously to the well-being of many needy folk in our area. I congratulate them on their efforts and wish them all the very best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only is the township of Gatton in the Lockyer Valley in Queensland a centre of 8,000 people and the centre of the fruit and vegetable industries within my electorate, but it is also the home of a very nice lady, Mrs Win Davson, who has been a leading light in the arts and drama in the past four decades. I take the opportunity for the second time in this House to salute Win for her irreplaceable contribution to local youth activities and, in particular, for her contribution to the Mercury Children's and Youth Theatre, which she started in 1951.

PARA.TAB: This Davson family community spirit is not restricted to Win herself. Galleries worldwide are now supporting an art initiative by her daughter, Sharon, who is involved in the Artists for Life project. For the first time the world's artists are collaborating on a common theme to focus attention on the plight of the earth's endangered flora and fauna. It carries the slogan: Together we can help.

As a central focus, a major art exhibition will tour the world commencing next year, 1993, and will feature paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures and ceramics by distinguished artists from many countries. This is the first time that artists of this calibre will have cooperated to create a collection on a single theme on a global basis.

The impact of such an art experience progressively touring the world will also help to consolidate a common purpose in countries of differing political and philosophical doctrines. If the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has not already done so, I hope that she will take more than a casual interest in this very large initiative. Scores of international art galleries have assisted and have expressed an interest in holding supporting art exhibitions. Similar support has been expressed by over 100 galleries and art societies in Australia. The wife of the Premier of New South Wales, Mrs Greiner, launched the project in Sydney in June of last year. Like her mother's, Sharon's personal efforts, her dedication and her creative inspiration are an example to us all. I urge anyone who can contribute in financial or artistic terms to write to Sharon at Post Office Box 306, West Ryde, New South Wales 2114.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is National Wool Day. This morning I had the pleasure to present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Efficiency of the Interface between Seaports and Land Transport: Warehouse to Wharf. That report and its recommendations have major implications for people in the wool industry, people with whom it is associated. The thrust of the report is to generate a greater understanding of the needs of all who are involved in the whole interface, including users of those services, and a better understanding about how we can make the system work more efficiently and to the benefit of this nation.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), whom I advised earlier that I would be speaking, attacked sections of that report. It seems to me that the honourable member continues to be obsessed with union bashing on the waterfront. Late this afternoon I received from Sydney a copy of a statement that he issued—I assume it was issued in Canberra; I did not know it had been issued—in which he makes some complimentary remarks about the Committee's report but then proceeds to attack sections of it and, in effect, reflect upon members of the Committee. I will come to that.

It is clear that he does not understand what is in the report. I suspect he has not read it. He may have listened to the tabling statement. He does not understand the operations of the interface between the waterfront—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you tell Mr Sharp you were going to talk about this?
—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.

—I have told the honourable member. I paid him that courtesy. I repeat: it is clear that he does not understand the operations of the interface between the warehouse and the waterfront. It is clear that he does not understand industrial relations on the waterfront. He did not make a submission to the inquiry. He could have; he would have been most welcome. He did not appear before the Committee. He could have; he would have been most welcome. He did not attend any Committee hearing as the Opposition spokesman on shipping. He could have; he would have been welcome. He has reflected on members of the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Before turning to some of the statements in his media release, I want to say that it is obvious to me that the honourable member is a captive of the past. He is obsessed with union bashing. He is hooked on the adversarial theme—us versus them—the very thing that the Committee, in its work over the past 18 months, tried to dispel and tried to develop in its place a spirit of cooperation, of getting people to understand the complexities of each other's tasks and responsibilities and needs, and of making that whole interface work better to the benefit of this nation.

I would say that he will certainly fight to the last drop of blood of the last exporter. He will fight to the last cent of the last dollar of the last exporter. He will have all the rhetoric, but the exporters will bear all of the pain and, accordingly, this country will suffer. Let me turn to the second paragraph of the statement where the honourable member for Gilmore says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, however, a soft-option report, in which much of the good work and intentions of the Chairman and some of the members of the Committee have been sacrificed to the Labor Party's political constraints.

What the devil is he saying? He compliments the Chairman, a member of the Government. He refers to some members of the Committee who have been sacrificed to the Labor Party's political constraints. His own colleagues were on the Committee. The Committee's report was a unanimous report. The conduct of the inquiry was based on the best spirit of goodwill. Sure, there were differences of views; but they were resolved and there was give and take, and we presented a unanimous report to this Parliament

PARA.TAB: Is he suggesting that his colleagues had been suborned in some way by the Labor Party? Who has got at them? I do not know about it, and I am the Chairman of the Committee. I want to know about it. If there are members of the Opposition who in some mysterious way have been suborned by the Australian Labor Party and are willing to make a statement, let them own up to it. The honourable member for Gilmore says:

SPEECH.PARA: The report does not deal . . . with the issue of loosening the stranglehold of the Waterside Workers' Federation on the waterfront labour market . . .

Workers do not have coverage in the interface. They have coverage on the wharf, but once they leave the wharf, they do not have coverage. Obviously he does not understand what it is all about. He says that we left out unions. We did not leave out unions; unions got a mention. We covered everybody involved. Among other things, paragraph 4.5 of the report states:
The central issues to emerge during the inquiry were:

the need for attitudinal change within the total transport chain, including the stevedores, land transport operators, freight forwarders, customs brokers, shipping companies, trade unions and importers and exporters;

In this report we have tried to present a document that will, in a positive way, generate improvements in the interface between the warehouse and the wharf. It depends upon a positive change in outlook to produce a positive result. In this report—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—we have done the best to improve the efficiency of the interface.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Bairnsdale Aerodrome, Vic., been determined by the Department of Transport and Communications to be non-viable in respect of assistance under the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan (ALOP); if so, what is the precise meaning of the term non-viable in this case.
(2) What explicit criteria would the aerodrome need to meet to be classified as viable under ALOP arrangements.
(3) Is there scope for the aerodrome to meet the criteria referred to in part (2) and to have the determination altered.

(4) When the aerodrome's application for a social benefit subsidy under ALOP was assessed, were any features of the aerodrome's service identified as negating the allocation of a subsidy; if so, which features.
(5) Was the wider regional significance to East Gippsland of the continued operation of the aerodrome considered in relation to the allocation of a social benefit subsidy.
(6) What assessment of the regional role of the aerodrome was used and from what sources of information was that assessment developed.
(7) What is the extent of maintenance support currently allocated to the aerodrome.
(8) What assessment has been made of the asset values associated with the aerodrome.
(9) What total sum has been received by the aerodrome from the Commonwealth for capital, maintenance or other programs.
(10) What options are available for the aerodrome to maintain its existing level of operations in the absence of support under the ALOP.
(11) What evaluation has been made of the aerodrome's future outside the ALOP.

(12) Was the travel time and distance travelled between Bairnsdale and West Sale aerodromes relevant to the determination referred to in part (1); if so, on what calculations were the distance and time based.
(13) Was the aerodrome considered to play any significant role in providing important community services such as dealing with medical emergencies.

(14) Do any aerodromes which have been designated as being viable under the ALOP and which receive withdrawal or social benefit subsidies have similar travel times or distances between them and other viable aerodromes as those between the Bairnsdale and West Sale aerodromes; if so, in each case why has that aerodrome been treated differently from Bairnsdale.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Non-viable ALOP aerodromes are those where the ongoing and cyclical maintenance costs met by the Commonwealth cannot be covered by reasonable user charges. For regular public transport services the maximum reasonable charge was determined as $10 per passenger.
(2) See (1) above.

(3) As Bairnsdale aerodrome does not receive any regular passenger services and there is limited other traffic it is unlikely that the aerodrome could become viable through the application of reasonable user charges.

(4) No. The services provided at the aerodrome do not have a bearing on the eligibility of the aerodrome for a social benefit subsidy. Eligibility for a social benefit subsidy is assessed on the basis of the size of the population served by the aerodrome; the proximity of the community to another population centre which can provide social services such as schools, medical services, etc; the quality of road access to the community and the proximity of the community to an equivalent or higher standard of aerodrome.
(5) Only in the context of the social benefit criteria outlined in (4).

(6) No assessment outside of the announced criteria was made of any of the aerodromes in the ALOP scheme. This approach ensured a fair and equitable evaluation of the claims for funding for all aerodromes participating in the Scheme.
(7) In the 1990/91 financial year the Commonwealth provided $47,056 in maintenance assistance to Bairnsdale Aerodrome.
(8) None. The aerodrome is owned and operated by the Shire of Bairnsdale and as such the Commonwealth has not made an assessment of the asset value of the facility.
(9) Total Commonwealth expenditure at Bairnsdale Aerodrome from 1978 to February 1992 is as follows:
capital works—$128,017
maintenance——$483,545

These are matters for the Shire to consider. The new arrangements are intended to provide the local community with the opportunity to exploit the commercial potential of its aerodrome to the benefit of the local region. Importantly it gives greater decision making powers to local authorities who are in a far better position to manage their aerodromes to meet the needs of the local community and the aviation industry.
(12) No. The issue of distance from West Sale and time taken to complete the journey was not a matter taken into account when assessing the financial viability of Bairnsdale Aerodrome.
(13) Access for medical emergencies is one aspect of the social access and equity needs of local communities which have been taken into account in the provision of social benefit subsidies.

The fact that Bairnsdale does not qualify for a social benefit subsidy would indicate that the community is not solely dependent on the aerodrome for such community services and that alternative means of access to those services is available.

(14) The reason for establishing standard criteria for assessment of viability and eligibility for a social benefit subsidy is to ensure that aerodromes serving local communities throughout Australia are treated equitably. Therefore, communities with similar characteristics to Bairnsdale have been treated in the same manner under the social benefit criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure made recommendations on Adelaide-Broken Hill-Sydney rail services which conflict with those made by Booz Allen and Hamilton Pty Ltd in July 1991; if so, how will that conflict be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in November 1989 published a report, Rail: Five Systems—One Solution, which made a number of recommendations relevant to investment and operations on the Adelaide-Broken Hill-Sydney line by Australian National and the State Rail Authority of NSW of both freight and passenger services.

In 1991 the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force (the predecessor of the National Rail Corporation (NRC)) commissioned Booz Allen and Hamilton Pty Ltd (BAH) to report on the NRC's network needs. They have made several interim reports to the Task Force and, subsequently, to the NRC.

The BAH reports relate only to infrastructure needed for interstate rail freight and have no bearing on the infrastructure needs of intrastate rail freight within NSW. They do not cover the same ground as Rail: Five Systems— One Solution and BAH's recommendations do not conflict with the recommendations of the Standing Committee's Report.

The standardisation of the Melbourne-Adelaide line will create a second transcontinental route for standard gauge traffic. The NRC will make a decision on its use of this and the Sydney-Broken Hill-Crystal Brook line on the basis of its commercial requirements.

If the NRC determines that it does not need to take over operation of the Sydney-Broken Hill-Crystal Brook line from Australia National and the State Rail Authority, the line will remain with the current systems, and they will be responsible for reassessing any investment or changes in operational procedures needed on the line.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: When Australia's supply ships were serving in the Persian Gulf, were they used to transfer munitions between shore facilities and ships of the US Fleet; if so, (a) what types of munitions were transferred (b) were any nuclear munitions transferred, and (c) did the Australian authorities have any control over the types of munitions carried on Australian ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Two Australian supply ships, HMA Ships SUCCESS and WESTRALIA, deployed to the Persian Gulf for operations with the Multi-National Naval Force. Of these ships only SUCCESS had the capability to embark ammunition for transfer to other units (consigned ordnance) in addition to the ammunition carried for use in the ship's fitted weapons (outfit ordnance).

SUCCESS embarked all outfit and consigned ordnance in Australia prior to her deployment. All ordnance was of conventional nature—no nuclear weapons were carried. Once deployed, the ship did not receive any munitions from shore facilities or US ships. SUCCESS transferred all consigned ordnance to the supply ship USS SACREMENTO prior to being replaced in the Persian Gulf by WESTRALIA because WESTRALIA could only carry her outfit ordnance. All ordnance transferred to SACREMENTO was conventional. This ammunition remained in the US ship until completion of hostilities, when it was transported to the US Naval Base at Subic Bay for onward despatch to Australia. The Maritime Commander Australia authorised the movement of this ordnance, maintaining close liaison with the relevant US authorities and the Flag Officer Naval Support Command throughout.
Agreements were in place with the USN during hostilities to reammunition RAN ships with conventional ordnance to replace ammunition expended. No such transfers were required.

Details of RAN ordnance and amounts to be carried by each class of ship are listed at the Fleet Warrant of Naval Armament Stores. All ordnance listed in this publication is of a conventional nature. The publication is promulgated by the Flag Officer Naval Support Command in consultation with the Maritime Commander Australia. Ordnance carried by RAN ships deployed to the Persian Gulf accurately reflected the requirements of the Warrant, although inert practice ammunition was embarked in addition for training purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 3 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are residents of the electoral Division of Aston who are retrenched to be offered the same special assistance measures which are to be given to retrenched Nissan workers; if not, why not.
(2) Are residents of the electoral Division of Hotham being singled out for special benefits.
(3) Do unemployed persons receive equal treatment wherever they live; if not, why not.
(4) What will the Government do for unemployed persons who have received less favourable severance terms than the retrenched Nissan workers.
(5) Is priority for unemployment benefits given to the long-term unemployed or the young; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Passenger Motor Vehicle (PMV) Labour Adjustment Package (LAP) assistance provided to Nissan workers is available to all PMV workers retrenched on or after 1 February 1991 and who meet certain criteria relating to length of service in the PMV industry.

The PMV LAP is one of a range of Industry Labour Adjustment Packages (LAPs) which provide assistance to retrenchees from designated industries affected by tariff reductions or other Government policies. Designated industries include the Passenger Motor Vehicle (PMV) and Textile, Clothing and Footwear (TCF). Industry LAPs are designed to minimise the economic and social costs of individual and regional unemployment resulting from industry restructuring, and increase the supply of skilled workers in demand through retraining and upgrading skills.

(3) The CES provides job brokerage services to all unemployed people and access to labour market programs, according to eligibility criteria which relate to a person's individual circumstances. Under the Government's NEWSTART Strategy, priority for labour market program assistance is given to those most in need, especially long term unemployed (those jobseekers who have been unemployed for more than 12 months).

Immediate access to mainstream labour market program assistance is also given to jobseekers classified as especially disadvantaged given their likelihood of experiencing an extended period of unemployment. Especially disadvantaged groups include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, job seekers with disabilities, job seekers over 50 years of age, homeless people, ex-offenders and "at risk" youth.

The Government has also made special provision, through Labour Adjustment Packages such as the PMV LAP, for workers displaced from employment as a result of Government policies on industry restructuring.

The forms of assistance available under LAPs which include wage subsidies, preparatory and formal training, English language training and relocation assistance are similar to those available under mainstream labour market programs.
(4) Parties to an Award negotiate termination provisions for redundancy. Therefore any negotiations for conditions above those stipulated in the Award would have to be negotiated by the parties.
For all unemployed people the Government provides a job brokerage service and access to labour market assistance as summarised in answer to question (3) above.

(5) Unemployment benefits were replaced by Job Search Allowance and Newstart Allowance on 1 July 1991. All unemployed persons within certain age ranges may receive these allowances, subject to meeting certain eligibility criteria. Male clients must be aged 16 to 64 and female clients 16 to 59 to be eligible for these Allowances.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have there been any (a) informal or (b) formal approaches from the USA to the Minister or his Department concerning the possible establishment on Australian territory of US military facilities or logistic support capabilities; if so, what are the details.

(2) Is the Minister able to say whether an arrangement was recently announced between the USA and the Republic of Singapore for the relocation from The Philippines to Singapore of certain naval logistic units; if so, is he also able to say what these arrangements will be worth to the Singapore economy in a full year when they are established.

(3) Has any part of the Minister's Department made any (a) informal or (b) formal approaches to the USA concerning the possible establishment on Australian territory of US military facilities or logistic support capabilities; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Informal discussions between officials to enhance the already close cooperative defence relationship with our US ally are a routine activity. In accordance with longstanding practice I do not comment on informal discussions.
The US already has extensive access to facilities in Australia, including our ports and airfields, and both countries benefit from well-established intelligence and logistics support arrangements.

The Government has indicated clearly to the United States that it will consider positively proposals that will assist the US in sustaining an effective presence in the region, as demonstrated in the new arrangements at the Naval Communication Station at North West Cape announced by the Minister for Defence on 28 November 1991. Another example is the continuing discussion between officials concerning US access to a new air combat training range being planned for the RAAF at the Delamere Range in the Northern Territory.

However, the US has made it clear that it is reducing its permanent presence overseas and is not looking to establish major new facilities in our region. Rather, it is seeking to obtain access arrangements where these might support US objectives. Australia is, in any case, remote from the principal areas of strategic concern to the United States.

(2) Yes. In January 1992 President Bush and Mr Goh Chok Tong, Prime Minister of Singapore, announced agreement in principle for the transfer of a US Navy logistics unit from Subic Bay in the Philippines to Singapore. I will not speculate on the value of any arrangements made between the United States and the Republic of Singapore. It is for the Government of Singapore to determine the financial value of such arrangements to the Singapore economy.
(3) See (1) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) ln each year of the period for which data can reasonably be provided, what proportion of applicants for entry to the permanent (a) RAN, (b) Army and (c) RAAF were rejected as failing to meet the required medical standards.
(2) Is the Minister able to say how the figures referred to in part (1) compare with those during the 1964-73 national service scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The information is available for the current financial year only. Information for the preceding year was kept in a manual format and is not readily retrievable. Records beyond two years are not available.

The available information is: Navy 1.41 percent, Army 1.13 percent and RAAF 0.87 percent. The figures represent the percentages of applicants in each instance found to be permanently medically unfit by a doctor. The medical testing is conducted after all other testing and does not therefore include those who would be eliminated due to possible medical conditions at an earlier phase but for other reasons—or those who self eliminate on possible medical grounds or for other reasons.

Additionally the figures are averages for each Service and could be quite misleading if used in specific instances. The medical standard required varies markedly between categories with the medical "failures" varying accordingly (ie between airman and pilot, or sailor and submariner).
(2) A comparison with the National Service period of 1964-73 is not possible. However, it should be noted that only the Army had National Servicemen in any significant numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement by Malaysia's Minister for Defence, Dato Sri Mohamed Najib bin Tun Haji Abdul Razak, in issue 7/91 of the Asian Defence Journal, that exclusive of Vietnam most south-east Asian states are under-armed.
(2) Has the Australian Government made a similar assessment; if so, why; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) As Dato' Najib explained in his statement, many Southeast Asian states, such as Malaysia, have previously concentrated on internal rather than external security. With consistent economic growth and growing national resilience, such states are now able to focus more on their external defence and security requirements.

All national governments have a responsibility to provide for the external security of their people. The appropriate level of defence spending and the size of armed forces are matters for individual countries to decide in the light of their overall national priorities. It is not for Australia to comment in this context on the appropriateness of the level of resources allocated to defence by regional states.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have two major RAN surface combatants been withdrawn from active duty for financial reasons.
(2) Did the RAN have (a) personnel for the vessels but insufficient funds, (b) funds but insufficient personnel or (c) neither sufficient funds nor personnel.
(3) Does the Force Structure Review (FSR), presented to the House on 31 May 1991, allow for a RAN with 16 destroyers or frigates.
(4) Can the RAN currently operate the number of vessels referred to in part (3).
(5) If the RAN is to operate 16 destroyers or frigates how will the funds and personnel be made available.
(6) Will the defence allocation be supplemented to cover Australia's presence in the Persian Gulf; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Navy have proposed several measures to conserve funds over the Five Year Defence Plan (FYDP). The most significant measure proposed is to reduce fleet activity levels by sequentially retaining two ships of the destroyer force (one Frigate in Sydney and one Destroyer Escort in Fremantle) alongside at any one time commencing in Financial Year 92/93. The ships would rotate with other ships of the destroyer force on, say, a four month basis such that fleet readiness would be retained within that prescribed in the Chief of the Defence Force Operational Readiness Directive (CORD). Crew Training would still be done by the ships alongside and the opportunity would be taken for their crews to attend courses and take leave. This practice is similar to that used by some NATO nations (notably Germany and Holland).

(2) The RAN presently has sufficient personnel to man all destroyers in the current force structure and adequate funds to maintain all these ships at the level of readiness required by the Chief of Defence Force Operational Readiness Directive (CORD).

(3) Yes. The Force Structure Review, paragraph 2.29, states that a force of 16 destroyers/frigates is required based upon an analysis of the principal tasks required to be performed by the surface combatant force in credible contingencies. The total number of these ships will rise to 14 in 2005 with the progressive introduction of the ANZAC ships. Planning is proceeding to replace the DDGs with an ANZAC derivative, the first of which will be delivered in about 2006. This will allow the destroyer/frigate force to reach and maintain a strength of 16 in the second half of that decade.
(4) No. The present Destroyer Force consists of eleven ships with a twelfth (HMAS NEWCASTLE) to be delivered next year from Amecon.

(5) Navy has firm plans in place to man and operate the first four Anzac Ships (within the Ten Year Defence Plan) and will have similar arrangements in place well ahead of the planned acquisition of the remaining ships of the class (2001-2005). The Anzac ship is designed to minimise crew size and operating costs through advanced technology and low maintenance requirements at sea.
(6) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he or his predecessor take any steps to have the prefix "Royal" granted to Randwick Racecourse.

(2) Is he able to say what steps were taken by the (a) Premier of New South Wales, (b) Governor of New South Wales or (c) Governor-General of Australia to have the prefix "Royal" granted to Randwick Racecourse.
(3) Is he also able to say which other sporting bodies have been granted the prefix since 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (2) I am advised that the Governor-General had no involvement in seeking the grant of the prefix "Royal" to Randwick Racecourse, although he was informed of the proposal as a matter of courtesy. The honourable member may wish to direct questions as to the actions of the Premier and Governor of New South Wales to the Government of that State.

(3) I am advised that, in so far as relevant Commonwealth agencies are aware, the only other Australian sporting body to be granted the prefix "Royal" since 1982 is the Royal Queensland Tennis Association which was granted the title in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: How many employees of his Department are located in premises at 6 Ewing Road, Woodridge, Qld.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: At 25 March 1992, 97 employees of the Department of Social Security were located in the Regional Office at 6 Ewing Road, Woodridge, Queensland.
